Title: Bigg Boss is like a new beginning for me, says Harish Raj
Content: Sushant Singh Rajput’s death case is currently being investigated by the Central Bureau Of Investigation (CBI) and they have been questioning a lot of people connected to the late actor. According to the latest report on India Today, three officers who are a part of the probe, have stated that their team has so far not found any evidence that suggests Sushant was murdered on June 14.

Title: More women are studying science, but how many are pursuing it as a career?
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Pop culture has its fair share of depictions of women scientists pioneering breakthrough findings either in the forefront or in the shadows of more illustrious male colleagues. And given that cinema and TV is often a reflection of society, one would be inclined to believe that there are quite a few women toiling away in laboratories across the world.

The truth, though, say those in the know is a far cry from this. According to women scientists and college professors, there are only a handful of women pursuing sciences. In fact, there is a huge disparity in the number of women and men in science, with the latter far outnumbering the former. This, they add, is strange, because quite a few women take up science and science-related courses for graduate and even post-graduate studies, but the numbers taper by the time they reach the post-doctorate level. BT explores why...

‘Women make compromises for family; only the strongest can survive in a science stream’

Shobhana Narasimhan, professor, Theoretical Sciences Unit at Jawaharlal Nehru Centre For Advanced Scientific Research (JNCASR), who is a member of the Standing Committee on Women in Science of the Government of India and has presented several papers on women in science, says that multiple factors contribute to fewer women in science. “Often, when I attend conferences, either I’m the only woman speaker or there would be no women speakers at all. Women scientists have raised objection and even boycotted many conferences because of the lack of representation,” says Shobhana.

Why, though? “It is the women who have to make compromises to accommodate family responsibilities. Looking after the kids, managing the household and being a working mom can be hard. And when choices have to be made, family comes first. Also, those pursuing science often end up marrying within the community. The trouble with that is that scientific institutions have unwritten rules to not hire couples. As a result, one of the partner has to either find other employment for which he/she is overqualified, or move cities to find the right job, which in turn affects family life. Most importantly, though, the general perception is that it is best to not hire a woman to a position of importance because she will not be able to manage,” she adds.

Science is not a stop-gap arrangement before taking up professional courses

One of the most common reasons for students to drop out of science graduate studies earlier, explains Vimala CM, Dean of Sciences undergraduate studies at Mount Carmel College, was that they looked at the course as a stop gap measure while continuing to attempt entrance exams for professional courses in engineering and medicine. “Pure science study was not at the top of the list for many students. If they didn’t get through to a professional college straight after Class XII, they’d join an undergraduate science stream, but drop out in the middle of the academic year once they got into the course of their choice,” she says, adding, “Today, things have changed. We’ve students leaving engineering and medical courses midway to pursue degrees in sciences. Courses like chemistry, botany, zoology, environmental science, microbiology and biotechnology have more takers.”

Girls now understand the importance of pure science study

Lekha George, professor, Department of Botany at Mount Carmel College, says, “Earlier, we had fewer students taking up pure sciences, today the classes are at full strength. Students are turning down engineering and medical seats, because they understand the importance of pure sciences.” Vimala adds, “There are a few girls in the field of research now. Their numbers are far less compared to their male counterparts, but there’s a steady rise. For example, a student of mine, Radha Krishnakumar, was a part of the team at the J Craig Venter Institute in Rockville, Maryland, which created the world’s first synthetic bacterial cell.”

‘Need to help women in science minimise career breaks’

Rohini Godbole, Honorary Professor, Centre for Higher Energy Physics, at the Indian Institute of Science (IISc) says the need of the hour is for institutions to frame rules and guidelines that make it easier for women to follow a career in science. “There are existing programmes under the Department of Science and Technology and Department of Biotechnology that urge women to return to their fold even after the break. These programmes have been there for almost 15 years. But, I feel that such programmes address issues superficially, because science does not wait for anyone. By the time people return after a break, newer methods, technology and processes come into the picture, so, for an individual it’s like being at the starting line again,” she says.

To minimise the breaks, Rohini advocates setting up creche facilities for the children of post-doctoral fellows/students (both men and women) as well, and not just for faculty, because students cannot afford to pay for childcare.

‘I Want to be like Jane Goodall’

I wanted to pursue a bachelors degree in chemistry, botany and zoology (CBZ), because I have always been attracted to wildlife sciences. In fact, I have been a fan of Cristina Mittermeier, who is a conservation photographer, Jane Goodall, primatologist and conservationist, and Asha de Vos, marine biologist from Sri Lanka. I follow their work online and I see myself doing what they do.

— Ranjana Gauri M, a final year student at Mount Carmel College

‘Parents support my career choice’

Though my father is an engineer and my mother is a doctor, they supported her decision to pursue microbiology. They know the importance of science and how our foundation needs to be solid. In fact, my mother, who is now venturing into research, says that for any cure or any medicine, the foundation of pure science is needed and that is why they supported my decision to study microbiology.

— Ashwini Prasad, a final year microbiology student

Women in science On screen

Hidden Figures: The film shows the struggle, and later success, of three African-American mathematicians who work at NASA.

Ghostbusters (2016): Scientists and paranormal enthusiasts Erin Gilbert and Abby Yates get together with nuclear engineer Jillian Holtzmann and a subway worker Patty Tolan to stop ghosts invading Manhattan.

Gravity: The film shows two astronauts, played by Geroge Clooney and Sandra Bullock, who work together to survive an accident in space.

Big Bang Theory: Mayim Bialik and Melissa Rauch play scientists in this popular sitcom.

Hasee Toh Phasee: Parineeti Chopra plays a geeky scientist with quirky habits.

Title: Havyaka: Diganth plays a farmer in film set in his hometown
Content: For Diganth , his upcoming film is special for two reasons. For starters, it reunites him and Aindrita Ray onscreen after eight years, their last outing being Parijatha . More importantly, it is film based on his hometown, Sagara , which sees him play a farmer. Directed by debutant Vinayaka Kodsare, the untitled film will be wholly based in Nittur and Sigandur, two hamlets in Sagara. “I play Shankara, a Havyaka maani — the community I belong to in real life, too — who is a farmer and owns an agro shop in the village. Aindrita plays a lawyer who I meet and fall in love with. We are happy to be back onscreen together,” says the actor. Director Vinayaka adds, “My film is about showcasing the grameena sogadu of this Havyaka community belt and the beauty and intricacies of life in Sagara. There’s suspense and comedy involved, too.” Meanwhile, Ranjani Raghavan will also play a pivotal role in the film. “I play Soumya, a village belle who works at a manure shop. Shankara has a crush on her and she reciprocates his affection. This is my fourth onscreen outing and my most realistic character yet. My role is a detour from the regular song-and-dance routine,” she signs off.

Title: Sharad Malhotra: There is no scarcity of work, but good-quality content is not easy to find
Content: Actor Sharad Malhotra , who was last seen on 'Musakaan', is clear about the kind of work that he wants to do. He says, “My audience is the most important part of my journey. Every time I pick a project, I ask myself...Will the audience connect with this? He adds, “I would never want to do a show which offers nothing interesting to my viewers. It takes lot of time to choose the right project. The struggles of an established actor like me, who has worked for many years, is very different now. No one wants to sit at home because every actor is hungry for good content .” Elaborating further on content across different platforms, Sharad tells us how it is hard to find good content on television. He says, “In today’s times, there is no scarcity of work, but good-quality content is still not easy to find. Television is my first love, but if we don’t think of more finite shows, the audience will continue lapping up the content available on other platforms that are experimenting with interesting stories.”

Title: mysuru: Music director Arjun Janya stable after minor heart health scare
Content: On Thursday morning, news broke of music composer Arjun Janya having suffered a minor heart attack. Arjun, who was in Mysuru , was undergoing treatment for suspected viral gastroenteritis, when an ECG irregularity was noticed and dealt with. According to his doctors, Arjun was recovering, but continued complaining of pain in the head, abdomen and back. “Tests were repeated and although his first ECG was fine, the second one showed an anomaly and we suspected a cardiac issue. He was referred to specialist cardiac care, and underwent angiography and angioplasty in the nick of time. He is now out of danger and has been shifted to a ward from Critical Care Unit (CCU),” said an attending doctor. Sources from the hospital add that the music man is expected to be discharged from the hospital in the few days.

Title: Mohit Malik goes on a detox vacation
Content: Actor Mohit Malik , who was recently seen as Sikander in ' Kullfi Kumarr Bajewala ', took off for a detox sojourn right after his show ended. Mohit says that he takes a gap after each show, to unwind and bounce back. “Shooting for a daily soap can drain you out. Sikander has given me a lot, but at the same time, I don’t think I realised how much I had delved into the character. In fact, I couldn’t even sleep well because I was living the character 24x7,” he shares.Speaking about his detox holiday, he shares, “I went to Kerala without my wife, Addite , for 10 days and completely detoxified myself. I was away from my phone and I feel that I have come back with my soul, heart and body aligned. My body feels much better and I truly feel like I am living each moment.”

Title: My First Shot: I was in Class 4 when I faced the camera for the first time, Shanthnu
Content: My first experience in front of the camera was quite an amusing one. My appa (K Bhagyaraj) was making Vaettiya Madichu Kattu then and he was discussing the script with my mother (Poornima Bhagyaraj) at our home. He was telling her about how he was searching for a boy in a particular age group to play an important role in the film. I was in Class Four then and had just come home from school. I walked into their room and was just hopping around, holding my school bag. Appa saw me then, and he was like, ‘Sonu, un age la oru character irukku. Pannariya?’.I said ‘okay’ and just walked out. He was surprised when I agreed immediately, but was also worried that I might feel let down or conscious if I didn’t get to act in the film. My mom told him that they could shoot with me after school and on weekends. But my dad wanted to first do a screen test to see how comfortable I was in front of the camera. So, on that big day, he gave me a dialogue sheet and told me that I should walk inside the room, mouth the dialogues and simultaneously do some actions.So I confidently walked inside the room, took off my school bag, played around with the phone, all the while delivering my lines. And then suddenly, I stopped and told them that I had to urgently use the restroom, much to their amusement. They all burst out laughing, but I guess my dad was convinced by then that I was at ease in front of the camera. He was like, ‘Dialogues-um, action-um simultaneous-a pannaradhu chinna pasangalukku kashtam. Ivan manage panniduvan’. That screen test was the first-ever time I faced the camera and was quite a memorable experience. When Sakkarakatti happened years later, I was already prepared to face the camera.So, there was no nervousness. The first scene they shot for the film was the one in which Deepali (played by Ishita Sharma) and I break up, but the makers wanted to do a happy shot before that. So, I filmed for a small montage shot — for which I had to smile — on the terrace for the Marudaani number.

Title: Sayyeshaa graced the launch of YOLO salon at Anna Nagar
Content: When the women dress up to party, they’re sure to make some noise! As they did at this do — they chatted with each other, laughed out loud and compared notes on what to wear and where to shop from!The evening also saw they talk about haute makeup trends world over and where to get them in Chennai. Title: Israeli orchestra to enthrall with a mix of classical and electronic music
Content: Bringing together tunes of western classical and electronic music this weekend is Castle in Time — an Israeli youth orchestra, which is set to perform in Bengaluru for the first time. The orchestra will perform along with 15 members of The Bangalore School of Music Chamber Orchestra. The 24-member orchestra, boasting instruments like woodwinds, brass, electric guitar, bass guitar, drum set, percussion, synthesizers, harp and other instruments, is known for its original compositions and performances that combine music, movement and video. “Unlike other orchestras, we write and perform original music. We write the music specifically for our musicians and the setup we have, which helps each artiste to contribute on an individual level,” says Shalev Ne’eman, percussionist.Tal Donner Rozenrot, CEO for the orchestra, says, “Another factor that sets us apart is the fact that we combine western classical and electronic music. There aren’t that many orchestras that combine these two genres of music. In addition to this, the conductor, Matan Daskal, is a professional dancer and he introduces movement into the performance. We also have visual elements in our performances sometimes.”One of the most interesting parts of the performance is when the band follows Matan’s movements and signs for the music and do not have any music sheets to follow. “During that particular segment, the musicians do not follow any musical notation charts. Instead, they follow Matan, who communicates with them through signs — this form of communication is called sound painting and is used in many countries. It’s more of an interaction and a visual treat for audiences and the musicians as well. It’s a perception of space and the people around the conductor,” explains Shalev.Speaking about the performance of the two orchestras, Jagadeesh MR, Director of operations at the Bangalore School of Music (BSM), says, “We have always looked forward to performing with different artistes and orchestras, especially from Israel. It’s great exposure to western classical music for our students, because in Bengaluru it is still considered niche. A collaboration like this also helps in exchange of views, music and culture and this is exactly what we need today. The performance will be very different from what we usually do, because of the concept of sound painting as it brings out the creativity in the musicians, who are on stage.”

Title: Seaweed is a lot more than just exotic food
Content: Whether or not you have tried scuba diving, that the ocean bed is a treasure trove of a variety of unique flora is no secret. One of the marine species, the seaweeds are no longer a source of food for ocean life alone, as many people in East and Southeast Asia are indulging in this slimy green vegetable as a dietary option. You’ll find seaweeds in their soups, rolls, sushi and other traditional cuisine. Thanks to their health benefits, these underwater plants are now gaining the reputation of ‘wonder food’ in India as well. “Seaweeds are invaluable marine herbs. These are considered a prolific source of bioactive compounds that have extraordinary medicinal properties,” says Dr Kajal Chakraborty, Senior Scientist at Central Marine Fisheries Research Institute (CMFRI), which recently released a research paper on the benefits of seaweeds. Studies also claim that farming seaweed could help counter the threats of global warming. Here’s why switching to seaweed is a good idea…This newbie superfood, which is now added to several health drinks, is said to be a great source of fibre that promotes gut health. “The sulphated polysaccharides found in seaweed have been proven to increase the growth of good gut bacteria. “One such seaweed, called Nori, which is used in Japanese cuisine, is now available in India,” says Nicky Dabas, National President at Nutrition and Natural Health Sciences Association. Dr Kajal adds,“Marine macroalgae is an antioxidant, while it also anti-obesity, anti-inflammatory, anti-allergic, and helps to tackle hypoglycaemia.”Loaded with fatty acids and antioxidants, seaweed masks can do wonders for your skin. “It also moisturises and calms the skin, as well as helps in fighting acne,” says Neetha Bhoopalam, natural cosmetologist and aromatherapy expert. To prepare this mask, mix seaweed powder with water and add a few drops of lavender essential oil to it. Then apply the paste on the face and neck; wash it off after 20 minutes.“Commercial farming of seaweeds in coastal habitats could lead to C-sequestration (removal and sequestration of carbon dioxide from theatmosphere),” says Dr A Gopalakrishnan, Director at Indian Council of Agricultural Research-CMFRI. This means that apart from being asustainable source of food, seaweed could play a role in tackling climate change too. Globally, seaweed is currently grown on a small scale for use in food, medicines, and beauty products. Scientists have proposed establishing industrial-size farms to grow seaweed and sink it in the deep ocean. The carbon stored in its tissues would then remain buried.The extraction of bioactive components from seaweed for potential health benefit is an emerging area of research, according to Dr Gopalakrishnan. The Indian Council for Agricultural Research has already developed a few products as green alternatives for synthetic drugs to combat rheumatoid arthritis and Type-2 diabetes.

Title: Left to fend for himself, Yash proves a point again
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

PANAJI: The moment Yash Fadte won the French Junior Open crown, a thought struck his mind.

He had seen pictures of sporting stars celebrating their triumphs in front of iconic places, and for someone who had picked up his medal in Lille, Eiffel Tower , a magnificent iron structure that illuminates Paris, was not too far behind. He made a trip to see the wonder of the world, and posed gleefully with his shiny medal in front of the 324 meters high monument.

French Junior Open is among the three more prestigious squash tournaments in the world and pales only in comparison to the British Open and US Open. Yash, 18, has won the US Open in the past and made it to the quarterfinals of the British Open this year. But he’s really chasing just one title since breaking into Asia’s top-10 a few years ago: Worlds.

“All that I have really wanted is to become a world champion. That’s what I am fighting for all these years. I want to be known as the world’s best (junior) squash player,” Yash told TOI on Thursday.

Yash has the credentials. He is Asia’s top-ranked player, never mind his loss against compatriot Veer Chotrani – training in the United States – in the Asian Junior Squash Championship. He finds himself in the top-five players in the world, with the top three from heavyweight Egypt. He’s defeated Louis Anderson, ranked World No. 4, at the US Open and believes he can make the best of his final year in the junior circuit when the WSF World Junior Championships is held in Australia from July 19.

“This is a crucial year for me. I’ve focused all my energy into training to be the best, but sometimes I am left to wonder, why I do not get as much support as everyone else. Why am I being punished for no fault of mine?” said Yash.

That support, or the lack of it, is clearly from the state government. While the Sports Authority of Goa (SAG) has been known to be the most generous and distributes funds to sportspersons almost on a whim, Yash has never ever benefitted. Despite being the best in Asia, despite his achievements around the world and despite showing he can conquer the best in business.

“We are releasing him the prize money immediately. His funds were stuck because the association did not complete the registration formalities but now, we are making an exception for him,” said SAG executive director VM Prabhu Desai.

Claims that Yash is paying for the faults of the association hasn’t found many takers. Last month when Yash went to the SAG headquarters, he was told that one crucial document was missing from his file. When he opened the file and looked himself, the document was right there, while officials sat on the file for nothing.

“Yash has won so many medals and brought so many honours to Goa. He should have been our pride and neighbours envy. Yet, the state has rarely recognised his achievements by giving him cash awards or financial incentives. Most of his grants documents are lying in SAG due to procedural hassles. Reminds me of the famous Munnabhai MBBS movie dialogue, "yeh form bharna zaroori hai kya?,” asks sports enthusiast and Goa Badminton Association secretary Sandeep Heble.

The SAG knows better.

Title: National coach to have a look at Seriton, Liston
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020



Panaji: When India coach Igor Stimac landed in Goa to watch a crucial I-League game last week, he dialled a few numbers and sought to meet players who had impressed him.

The first on his list was Jackichand Singh and soon another message was sent. He wanted to have a word with Seriton Fernandes too. Both Jackichand and Seriton promptly showed up at the hotel in South Goa and after half an hour’s discussion, left with a smile on their face.

Jackichand’s form this season, particularly in the last few games, has been terrific for FC Goa, while Seriton has been the most consistent performer. For two seasons now, he has been an automatic choice at right-back for the Goan club. The last game that he sat out due to suspension was his first after playing in a record 46 consecutive matches.

When Stimac announced his teams previously, Seriton was a surprise omission. Fans felt he at least deserved a call to attend the national camp Now, Seriton has the chance to impress after being summoned to attend the camp ahead of the World Cup qualifier against Qatar on March 26.

Another Goan, Liston Colaco , has also been summoned to the senior team for the first time. The sharpshooter hardly got a chance when with FC Goa, but his move to Hyderabad FC saw him play more regularly and he even scored a brace against NorthEast United FC.

Stimac has called up 23 players for the national camp from March 9 from the Indian Super League (ISL) teams who have failed to qualify for the playoffs this season. Another 20 players will join after the ISL final on March 14, or if their teams get knocked out earlier.

Several interesting names have made it to the list. There is a return for veteran goalkeeper Subhashish Roy Chowdhury, while young goalkeeper Rafique Ali Sardar also gets his maiden call-up after impressing for Jamshedpur FC.

Pratik Chowdhary (Mumbai City FC), Shubham Sarangi, Jerry Mawihmingthanga, Nandhakumar Sekar (Odisha FC), Lalengmawia (NorthEast United) and Jeakson Singh (Kerala Blasters) are among the other players who have caught the eye.

Meanwhile, injured players like Sandesh Jhingan and Jeje Lalpekhlua have also been asked to report to the national camp where they will undergo fitness tests. Having been out of action for a long time, neither of them are expected to make it to the final team.

When he opened the file and looked himself, the document was right there, while officials sat on the file for nothing.

“Yash has won so many medals and brought so many honours to Goa. He should have been our pride and neighbours envy. Yet, the state has rarely recognised his achievements by giving him cash awards or financial incentives. Most of his grants documents are lying in SAG due to procedural hassles. Reminds me of the famous Munnabhai MBBS movie dialogue, "yeh form bharna zaroori hai kya?,” asks sports enthusiast and Goa Badminton Association secretary Sandeep Heble.

The SAG knows better.

Title: Gabriella Demetriades: I don’t think you necessarily have to get married. There is no ‘one way’ to always do something
Content:
Gabriella Demetriades came to Mumbai from South Africa to fulfil her dreams of starting a fashion line. Little did she know that this city would become her home, and she would comfortably settle down here with a partner and child. While she made a splash in the modelling world, she even did brief roles in a few Indian movies. In the midst of this, she happened to meet Arjun Rampal and their relationship blossomed over time. Around April 2019, they surprised everyone when Arjun posted a lovely picture him with Gabriella showing her baby bump, with the message, “Blessed to have you and start all over again…thank you baby for this baby.” Now, while Gabriella is busy expanding her clothing line, she is also a hands-on mommy to 7-month-old baby boy, Arik. In a candid chat with Bombay Times, she talks about how she met Arjun, her thoughts on marriage and way she’s made India her home. Excerpts:

What drew you to pack your bags and move to India?

I’ve always had this ambition to be a successful fashion designer, like my mother. I began as an assistant stylist in South Africa. Later, a photographer spotted me and told me that I should try modeling. I looked at it as an opportunity to make money which I could use to fund my business. It was also a gateway to making contacts with people associated with the business, like models, photographers and other designers. During the process, I happened to meet someone from an Indian modeling agency in South Africa. He told me that I should come down to India as I would get great modeling opportunities here.

So, your prime motivation was to set up your fashion line, and not you’re your way into Bollywood as an actress? In the past, women from other countries have come to India to pursue a career in the movies.

Acting and Bollywood were never my aspiration, but fashion was. When I came to Mumbai, I didn’t even know what Bollywood was. While I was doing modelling here, my agent suggested that I try acting in a Bollywood movie. I had heard about the creepy side of Bollywood with women facing bad experiences here. I was aware of it and was careful. When I was offered Sonali Cable (2014), I took the plunge. I liked the treatment that I received from the Sippy family (Ramesh and Rohan Sippy, the makers of the film). I had a great time with my co-stars on the set, too. I loved being in front of the camera, but the glitch was the language. I am very bad at learning new languages. Getting the lines of a foreign language right, with hundreds of people staring at you, is very scary. I thought that maybe this is not where I was supposed to be. But before deciding to quit movies, I wanted to be sure. So, I went did a film down South with Nagarjuna and Tamannaah (Oopiri, 2016). It was an amazing experience, but language continued to be a big barrier. Finally, I bid adieu to movies. I am a creative person and like to be busy. To sit on the set and wait for the shot is not my cup of tea. While all this was happening, I started my clothing line, which grew over a period of time.



While you were focusing on chasing your dreams here, when did you meet Arjun Rampal?

We have a few mutual friends, so, I would end up meeting him at social occasions along the way. The first time I met him was in 2018. We kind of hit it off from there. And with time, the relationship blossomed into something meaningful. Arjun is a gentleman. Our love for work, creativity, ambition and fitness are the things that we have in common. We both are also very family oriented.

Arjun is an actor and a producer, has there been any discussion on you getting back to movies?

He tells me that I am a bad actor (laughs!). I doubt he has seen any of my movies. In fact, he has been very supportive towards my fashion endeavour. He has been a supermodel himself for many years and is incredibly stylish. He has a great taste in fashion. He is always on the lookout for what I am making and wearing. I value his opinion. Having said that, we don't mix our workspace or interfere in each other’s profession.

You hail from South Africa. How is Arjun helping you to adapt to the culture and life in Mumbai?

Since I am from another country, I would feel lost and left out during the festive season, as I couldn't understand what was going on. Arj is a proud Indian and he celebrates all festivals. It is only after I started spending time with him that I celebrated Holi, Diwali and other festivals. Before that, I was clueless about these celebrations. What I like about India is that it embraces and accommodates people from all over the world.

You fondly call him Arj, what does he call you?

(Laughs!) This is a South African thing. We kind of abbreviate everything. Back home, my family and friends call me Gab. Arjun doesn't call me Gab, as he loves my name, so he calls me Gabriella.

Arjun and you decided to have a child without tying the knot. This is still a rare in our country. Weren’t you worried about societal pressures?

We wanted to keep things private. Also, I am very different in that sense. I don’t think you necessarily have to get married. I think there is no ‘one way’ to always do something; to each their own. Yes, there is societal pressure, but personal choices are important. When it comes to deciding what gender you want to be, who you want to date or marry, it should be left to the individual or individuals concerned. Just like in other parts of the world, people here, too, are opening up and accepting others’ choices. I have always been accepting of others and their choices, so hopefully, the world will accept mine.

What do you think about the institution of marriage?

I don’t have a strong opinion about it. It is just my choice. I don’t think we need to be so serious about everything. I don’t think love is something that needs a definition or a rulebook. Times are changing and people are more accepting today. I don’t think that people are categorising any one particular way of living as the right way anymore.

What are Arjun’s thoughts on this? Have you discussed tying the knot, if not right away, but probably someday?

It is a topic that doesn't really come up between us.

You named your son Arik, who came up with the name Arik?

Arik is a Hindu name, which in Sanskrit means ruler of rulers. We were looking for a name that’s easy to pronounce. I think it is a very strong name that is short and easy to pronounce for my family and friends, who are not from India. I wanted to name him Ari, which is a Hebrew name. Then, Arjun came up with the name Arik.

Are both of your very hands-on with him?

Motherhood, it is a full-time job, and I am happy about how Arjun and I divide the work when it comes to the baby and help each other out.

Title: Even before Parasite, Korean films were a hit in Delhi
Content:
Along With The Gods (2018), and Love Me Not (2006)









India hasn’t been immune to the Parasite wave that swept the awards season this year. Though Parasite is the first South Korean film that got a theatre release in India, South Korean films are already quite popular among Indians, thanks to OTT platforms. When Parasite won the Golden Globe Award for Best Foreign Language Film, in his acceptance speech, director Bong Joon Ho, told the crowd through his translator Sharon Choi, “Once you overcome the one-inch-tall barrier of subtitles, you will be introduced to so many more amazing films.” It seems that movie buffs in India overcame this one-inch-tall-barrier long ago.From OTT platforms to Delhi’s pirated film markets and now to the cinemas, it seems Korean films have a huge following in India. The Korean Cultural Centre in Delhi vouches for this and says they get a huge turnout when the screen Korean film. Kim Kum-Pyoung, Director, Korean Cultural Center India, says, “Korean films and dramas are getting popular in India through OTT platforms. Many youngsters watch Korean dramas and films on these platforms. Keeping the popularity in mind, the Korean Cultural Centre is now running weekly movie screenings. Apart from that, we are supporting Korean films’ screening at various film festivals.” An I&B official says, “In general, Korean films get a very good response. But when we screened Parasite at IFFI last year, moviegoers stood in line for three hours to watch it. And many were left disappointed because they couldn’t get an entry as the auditorium was packed. Hence, we had to organise a second screening of the film.”If you are looking for a Korean film which you couldn’t find on OTT platforms, there are high chances you’ll get it at the stores at Majnu Ka Tila. Namit Konsam, a seller at the market, says, “The highest demand for Korean films come from teens and DU students. The demand has gone up in the last two-three years. And these days, most of the customers are asking for Bong Joon Ho’s films, which are not available online.” A seller at Kamla Nagar says, “College students come to us with titles of these films, and we get those for them.” The most popular Korean films include Bong Joon Ho’s Mother and White Man.Debashish Saha, a DU student who came to Majnu Ka Tilla with a list of Korean films, tells us, “I feel that Korean films are more mature compared to what we have in Bollywood. I first saw a Korean film when one of my friends from the northeast showed it to me. And since that day I couldn’t stop watching them – be it teenage love stories or thrillers.” The Korean Cultural Centre also says that many youngsters are learning Korean language to understand the films, shows and music better. Sellers at Delhi’s movie piracy hubs – Kamla Nagar, Nehru Place and Kotla Mubarakpur – say that they are flooded with requests for South Korean movies. A seller in Kotla Mubarakpur says, “We charge the same price (Rs100) for Korean films and Hollywood films. Right now, Korean films are in huge demand. In fact, we sold more Korean films last year than we did in the previous years.” He adds, “In the last two months, customers have been asking for Parasite. But piracy laws have become so strict that we couldn’t get the film from anywhere.”

Title: Theatre review: Dearest Bapu, Love Kasturba
Content: A fictional narrative of Mahatma Gandhi and his wife Kasturba Gandhi ’s marital journey, ‘ Dearest Bapu Love Kasturba ’, features letters from the great-beyond.A dark, minimalistic set features Gandhi (Arif Zakaria) and Kasturba (Zeenat Aman) seated on two elevated platforms, deeply engrossed in writing and reading elaborate letters to each other. A soothing rendition of ‘Vaishnava Jana To’ reverberates in the auditorium with iconic pictures of the real Bapu flashing on screen. From the very beginning, director Saif Hyder Hasan’s narrative abruptly jumps from one phase of Gandhi’s life to another, and a mishmash of information ensues. With limited room for movement, Zeenat Aman maneuvers through the verbose script. Arif Zakaria, on the the other hand, effortlessly replicates Gandhi’s body language and conveys a plethora of emotions without saying much.Marking Zeenat Aman’s comeback after 15 years on stage, ‘Dearest Bapu, Love Kasturba’, attempts to trace the historic events that transformed Gandhi into the Father of the Nation, and subtly recounts the marital woes that defined his relationship with Kasturba. “Marriage choked me… I learnt the concept of Satyagraha from you, my feisty better half,” confessed Gandhi. “I did not know how to deal with you… your ever-growing idealism clashed with my conservative upbringing,” complained the wife. Statements like these uncovered the lesser-known side of Bapu. Their intimate conversational letters, filled with poetic anecdotes, spoke of his experiments with physical pleasures of life. They highlighted the political unrest, his father’s death, Kasturba’s deteriorating health and a lot more through Arif’s portrayal of the endearing and humourous Gandhi.The constant banter that humanised these powerful figures was refreshing. Overall, this play’s plot had the potential to explore so much, but it turned out to be monotonous with not much to hold on to.

Title: Akshay Anand: I rue the fact that I didn’t market myself properly
Content: With new faces entering showbiz every day, it is no mean task to remain relevant in the industry for almost three decades. Actor Akshay Anand attributes his long inning to his ability to adapt to the changing times. Currently seen in ‘ Ek Duje Ke Vaaste 2 ’, he says, “Earlier, we never thought too much about the popularity of a show or promoting it. While people recognised my talent and kept offering me work, I rue the fact that I didn’t market myself properly. Or else, I would have been in a better position as an actor.”Though he has been associated with several projects, the latest show is particularly close to his heart, as his character lives in a cantonment area. “My real name is John Gardner and I come from the family of William Linnæus Gardner, who had served with the 74th Highlanders. He established 2nd Lancers (Gardner’s Horse), which is one of the oldest and highly decorated armoured regiments of the Indian Army. Though I don’t play a military officer (in the show, he plays a man, whose company makes combat gears for the Indian Army), I feel proud to be associated with a show that has Indian Army as its backdrop. It’s quite nostalgic,” he explains.So, why did he change his name? “When I joined the industry, I felt that no one would give a chance to someone with that name. So, I changed my name to Akshay Anand, after being inspired by Dev Anand sahab, who gave me a break. I am glad that things have changed now and given a chance, I would like to go back to my original name. But alas, all the important documents have my name as Akshay Anand,” he signs off.

Title: #CoronavirusOutbreak: Import of electronic items hit, Delhi markets see price increase
Content: Electronic items in the popular markets of Delhi, which people visit to buy goods at inexpensive rates – including Gaffar Market, Palika Bazaar, Karol Bagh and Nehru Place – are seeing a distinct rise in prices. From replicas of the latest AirPods, Fitbit bands and watches to cheaper non-branded items, these markets are known for their Chinese goods. While the rising cost has left Delhiites disappointed, sellers say that they have no choice. The coronavirus outbreak means that there is a shortage of supply of goods from China, which, in turn, is leading to increased cost.The dealers and sellers are anticipating huge losses due to blockages in their supply chain. They tell us that if this continues, in a couple of weeks, it will be a crisis situation. Mikko, a seller in Karol Bagh, says, “All the major electronic markets of Delhi get over 80% of their items from China. From mobile phones and laptops to earphones and power banks, all the items are imported from China. We are refusing wholesale orders and are only catering to individual customers because we have stock left for 15-20 days.” Awadesh Sathpathy, who works for an event management company, says, “I go to Gaffar twice a week to order bulk items like headphones, bluetooth speakers and power banks for our events. But the sellers are not agreeing to sell over 40-50 items at one go as they say there is a scarcity in the market. Additionally, they have revised the rates.”Shoppers at Gaffar tell us that they’ve started feeling the impact when it comes to the price of items in the replica market. Gunjan Mallik, a shopper who was in Gaffar recently to buy a screen for iPhone, as she had to replace the old one, tells us, “I have checked almost 10 shops in Gaffar market and nobody is ready to sell it for below Rs3,000. My friends have bought the same screen for Rs900-1,500.” PP Prasad, a seller in Gaffar market, says, “Due to no supply from China, we have increased prices of these items. Some rates have been doubled, and items like replicas of iPhone screens, fitness watches – the main draw for buyers here – are being sold at Rs500-Rs1,000 more than their usual prices. The scale of impact on the sale of items in Gaffar market, in the long run, would depend on how long we’re unable to get items from China.” Rajat Kashyap, a corporate employee and a regular shopper at Gaffar, says, “The same earphones that I bought for Rs100 three-four months back are now being sold for Rs300. While it is still cheaper than what we get at branded outlets and online, but this is not Gaffar’s price.”Gaurav Bhagat, a managing director of a company selling electronic items for corporate gifting (in a retail shop and online), tells us, “We get a bulk of supplies from China of components used in the electronic items and these are our bestselling items. For example, the batteries we use in power banks come from China. So do the LED lighting accessories and bluetooth pods. As factories are shut in China, I am not sure when I will get my required stock. During the recently-concluded auto expo in Greater Noida, we were getting orders from auto companies for items like bluetooth pods and power banks for gifting purposes, but we are almost out of stock. If the situation doesn’t resolve in the next few days, there would be a shortage of affordable range of power banks, etc that sell the most in Delhi.” Several corporate offices are also feeling the heat. Mamta Desai, who works in a corporate firm in Gurgaon, says, “We have hosted three events in Gurgaon and Delhi recently, and when we contacted our vendors for the electronic gifts, they told us that the items are out of stock. So we had to go ahead with plants for gifts.” Sourav, a store owner in Nehru Place, adds, “We have stopped selling our items to the sellers who come from neighbouring states like UP, Punjab and Haryana.”— With inputs from Divya Kaushik

Title: Taapsee: Any kind of violence is not acceptable in a relationship
Content: "Sirf ek thappad– par nahi maar sakta!"- This dialogue by Taapsee Pannu ’s character captures the essence of the film Thappad . At the first public screening of the film, when director Anubhav Sinha and Taapsee were asked why they decided to keep it to 'just' one slap in the film, their reply was "even 'just one' was enough.""How much is too much, where should you draw the line? Who decides that ek thappad chalta hai par paanch ke baad tum kuch kar sakte ho? When you raise your hand on someone in a relationship, you are disrespecting that person. Woh dhakka ho sakta hai, thappad ho sakta hai, any kind of violence is not acceptable in a relationship," asserts Taapsee."The idea of the story was that a good husband hits his wife for the first time and she can't deal with it. I used to tell everyone that this movie is a very difficult one because it is about "nothing." Wife ko thappad marna toh 'nothing' mana jaata hai na humari society mein. But one slap is not 'just'. Women are expected to not make a big deal out of it – but I don’t endorse it," shares Anubhav.Anubhav SinhaMany critically-acclaimed filmmakers have endorsed Thappad. They organised screenings in multiple cities and the film has got laudatory reviews. Vishal Bhardwaj, who organised the Delhi screening, said, " Ek chota sa thappad jo kisi ko bada nahi lag raha hai and what it does to Taapsee's character is the beauty of the film. I found the movie subtle, nuanced and impactful." Hansal Mehta organised the screening in Jaipur and tweeted, "This exceptional film is a very engaging drama, with absolute knockout performances, especially by the supremely gifted Taapsee." At the Bhopal screening, Sudhir Mishra called it "Anubhav's best work." "It is beautifully done, simple at one end and complex and deep in another way,” he said. Anurag Kashyap also organised a screening of the film in Mumbai. The film also stars Pavail Gulati, Dia Mirza, Ratna Pathak Shah, Tanvi Azmi and Kumud Mishra.Thappad, produced by Bhushan Sudesh Kumar and Anubhav Sushila Sinha, releases on March 28, 2020.

Title: A display of vibrant flowers and quirky planters in Noida
Content: It was a kaleidoscope of colours as the Noida Stadium in Sector 21 hosted the 34th Noida Flower Show . Dianthus was the theme flower of this year and beautiful arrangements of the same greeted visitors right at the entrance. Over 3,500 species of flowers were showcased at the event and nearly 40 nurseries and 35 stalls were a part of the show, catering to gardening requirements of visitors. Quirky planters and pots in various shapes and sizes were a big hit at the show. “I have bought a planter in the shape of a cute frog for my office desk and another watermelon one to keep by my bed at home. The variety available here is not found anywhere else or even on online stores,” said Vasudha, a visitor from Sector 76. Saplings of herbal plants like parsley , thyme, celery, rosemary and basil were also in high demand. “We sold around 500 saplings of these plants at the show, daily. There is an increasing trend among customers looking to grow their own food and many like to start with herbal plants since they are small,” said Vikram, a vendor from Sahibabad. Various competitions were also organised at the show such as cut flower decoration and vegetable carving competitions apart from bonsai exhibition and nature photography.

Title: Adaa Khan: True and unconditional love does not exist anymore
Content: For years, Adaa Khan ’s only focus was work. And then, a severe bout of illness opened her eyes to the fact that there is more to life than just work. ‘Tomorrow’, she realised, might never come; it’s all about capturing the beauty of each moment. It was after ‘ Naagin 2 ’ wrapped up, that Adaa fell sick and was bedridden following severe dehydration. However, despite being unwell, she was back in action with ‘ Vish Ya Amrit: Sitara ’. The actress shares, “Since I was shooting for ‘Sitara’ and ‘Kanpur Wale Khuranas’ at the same time while I was unwell, I did not get a chance to rejuvenate. That was when I realised that I haven’t done anything beyond work. I didn’t want to die thinking that maine kuchh nahi dekha life mein. I can either keep working and saving money for the future or live in the moment; I could either be wise about money or life. I chose the latter.”Now, Adaa takes time out in between projects to pursue her passion for travel. In fact, in the last three months, she has travelled extensively. She says, “When I fell ill, it was like a moment of truth for me, I realised the need to pursue my other interests. So, after ‘Sitara’ wrapped up, I took off to see Europe. When I went to Bulgaria for the shoot of ‘ Khatron Ke Khiladi ’ (‘KKK’), I extended my trip by 10 days and also travelled to Italy and Switzerland, as I didn’t want to return home so early (smiles). I have also been to Malaysia, Dubai and most recently, Maldives. Life has taught me that self-love is more important than anything else. I love and pamper myself and do what I want to do. I have evolved as an individual and learnt my lessons, and I think that it’s been for the better. I don’t regret anything that has happened in my life, because I know that God has better plans for me. If those things hadn’t happened, I wouldn’t have experienced what I am experiencing now.”Of course, enjoying life is important, but isn’t she worried that such absences will affect her career? She replies, “Of course, as an artiste, it’s important to be seen on screen. Actors have a short shelf-life and people tend to forget you if you are away for long. Besides, the competition is also fierce. But in my case, with ‘KKK’ going on air, I could afford to not take up another show.”On the personal front, Adaa was in the news for her relationship with Ankit Gera going kaput a few years ago. Talking about what she thinks of love and marriage today, she says, “Everyone is taking love for granted. For that matter, even friendships are taken for granted. Today, it’s all about gaining something, and I don’t like that selfish aspect of friendships and relationships. For me, love is about being loyal to your partner. However, now that everything is so easily available, true and unconditional love doesn’t exist anymore.”She adds, “Marriage is a huge risk and I don’t believe in it. At this point, I don’t wish to settle down, but I can’t predict the future. If I find the right person, I will think about it. As of now, I am happy being single and doing what I am doing and enjoying my life. One doesn’t need to look outside for happiness, it comes from within.”

Title: nirmala gokhale: ‘Get down or drive over me!’
Content: video of a retired teacher scolding bikers to get off the pavement went viral recently, with over 377k views. Fed up with bikers riding on the pavement of Canal Road, off Law College Road,Nirmala Gokhale, in her 70s, took things into her own hands, instead of waiting for the authorities to intervene. “We are all well aware of our rights, but we aren’t aware of our responsibilities,” she says, adding with a smile, “I wasn’t even aware that somebody was taking a video. It was only the next day that I got a call from my relatives saying you are in the news and that’s when I found out.”Recalling the day when the incident happened, she says, “That day, the traffic was really bad and I was trying to cross the road. Amidst that, there were two-wheeler riders getting on the pavement just to get ahead in the traffic. They were honking behind me and in front of me and I was completely stuck. I immediately turned around and started asking each of them to get off the footpath and ride on the road.” She adds that though some riders asked her to get out of their way, she stood strong and kept repeating, “If you want to ride on the pavement, then you will have to ride over me.”Riding on footpaths is an issue not just in Pune, but across the country. And very often, senior citizens and children find themselves at risk because of this. “One of my friends was once hit by a two wheeler rider who was riding on the footpath. She was majorly injured and had to undergo surgery. And that rider was so inhuman that he didn’t event stop to check on her. The pavement is for people to walk – not just senior citizens but for everyone – so why would do people ride there and take away that space from us?” she asks.Nirmala also emphasises that it’s not only youngsters who behave like this. “That day, I saw people of every age group doing the same thing. From youngsters to older citizens – they were all trying to get on the footpath. When children see their parents breaking rules, they will automatically learn that. Blaming youngsters alone is not fair,” Nirmala explains.Her husband Prabhakar Gokhale, who is proud of his wife for standing up against those who break the rules, feels that she should continue to do this when she comes across people breaking traffic rules. “People are scared of women in charge. That’s why they got off the foothpath when they saw how angry she was. Instead of Nirmala, if I had done the same thing, people would not have listened. They would probably have pushed me away. But you cannot do that to a woman. Nothing can be more powerful than a woman and such women can bring a change in the country,” he says.

Title: Arindam Sil to start shooting his next with Mimi and Parambrata from April
Content: Sushant Singh Rajput’s untimely demise on June 14 has brought his relationship with girlfriend Rhea Chakraborty in the limelight. The actress is being interrogated by the Central Bureau of Investigation as well as the Enforcement Directorate. Even a drugs angle is being probed by the Narcotics Control Bureau. Amidst this controversy, Rhea Chakraborty has found some support in Bollywood, while there are a few who have raised questions against the actress. Here’s taking a look at Bollywood celebrities who are in support of Rhea and those standing against her.

At the Bhopal screening, Sudhir Mishra called it "Anubhav's best work." "It is beautifully done, simple at one end and complex and deep in another way,” he said. Anurag Kashyap also organised a screening of the film in Mumbai. The film also stars Pavail Gulati, Dia Mirza, Ratna Pathak Shah, Tanvi Azmi and Kumud Mishra.

Title: Taapsee: Any kind of violence is not acceptable in a relationship
Content: "Sirf ek thappad– par nahi maar sakta!"- This dialogue by Taapsee Pannu ’s character captures the essence of the film Thappad . At the first public screening of the film, when director Anubhav Sinha and Taapsee were asked why they decided to keep it to 'just' one slap in the film, their reply was "even 'just one' was enough.""How much is too much, where should you draw the line? Who decides that ek thappad chalta hai par paanch ke baad tum kuch kar sakte ho? When you raise your hand on someone in a relationship, you are disrespecting that person. Woh dhakka ho sakta hai, thappad ho sakta hai, any kind of violence is not acceptable in a relationship," asserts Taapsee."The idea of the story was that a good husband hits his wife for the first time and she can't deal with it. I used to tell everyone that this movie is a very difficult one because it is about "nothing." Wife ko thappad marna toh 'nothing' mana jaata hai na humari society mein. But one slap is not 'just'. Women are expected to not make a big deal out of it – but I don’t endorse it," shares Anubhav.Anubhav SinhaMany critically-acclaimed filmmakers have endorsed Thappad. They organised screenings in multiple cities and the film has got laudatory reviews. Vishal Bhardwaj, who organised the Delhi screening, said, " Ek chota sa thappad jo kisi ko bada nahi lag raha hai and what it does to Taapsee's character is the beauty of the film. I found the movie subtle, nuanced and impactful." Hansal Mehta organised the screening in Jaipur and tweeted, "This exceptional film is a very engaging drama, with absolute knockout performances, especially by the supremely gifted Taapsee." At the Bhopal screening, Sudhir Mishra called it "Anubhav's best work." "It is beautifully done, simple at one end and complex and deep in another way,” he said. Title: Supreme Court to consider revisiting ‘Hindutva’ definition case
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court on Thursday said it would expedite hearing on a pending petition seeking revisiting the court’s earlier definition of ‘ Hindutva ’ as a way of life and hear arguments for and against the plea from certain quarters to disqualify candidates if they made use of ‘Hindutva’ to seek votes.

A bench headed by Chief Justice S A Bobde said it would hear the petition after completion of arguments in the faith versus fundamental rights case arising from pleas seeking review of the SC’s judgment striking down the religious custom banning entry of women in the 10-50 year age group into Sabarimala Ayyappa temple in Kerala.

CJI Bobde said the nine-judge bench led by him, and comprising Justices R Banumathi, Ashok Bhushan, L Nageswara Rao, Mohan M Shantanagoudar, S Abdul Nazeer, R Subhash Reddy, B R Gavai and Surya Kant, would resume hearing the Sabarimala case on a day-to-day basis from March 16. The hearing was derailed because one of the judges was down with swine flu .

In the case relating to Abhiram Singh, pending since 1992, senior advocate Arvind Datar said several candidates had been acquitted in the electoral malpractices case relating to the 1990 Maharashtra assembly polls. “But my client Abhiram Singh is stuck with the case as the petition was referred to a three-judge bench, then to a five-judge bench and finally to a seven-judge bench which decided to expand the scope and ambit of disqualification of a candidate for seeking votes by appealing to religion, race, caste, community or language of his own, his rival candidates or electors,” he said.

When Datar sought early hearing on Abhiram Singh’s petition, CJI Bobde said the opposite side wanted the court to revisit the definition of ‘Hindutva’. “Their prayer is to offset the ‘Hindutva’ judgment. It will take time as long arguments are expected on the issue. We will try to hear this petition after completing hearing in the Sabarimala case,” he said.

On December 11, 1995, in the Ramesh Yeshwant Prabhoo case, SC had ruled that mere use of the words ‘Hindutva’ or ‘Hinduism’ in an election speech would not attract the rigour of disqualification under Section 123(3) of the Representation of the People Act. “Mere use of the word ‘Hindutva’ or ‘Hinduism' or mention of any other religion in an election speech does not bring it within the net of sub-section (3) and/or sub-section (3A) of Section 123, unless the further elements indicated are also present in that speech,” the SC had said.

“No precise meaning can be ascribed to the terms ‘Hindu', ‘Hindutva' and ‘Hinduism', and no meaning in the abstract can confine it to the narrow limits of religion alone, excluding the content of Indian culture and heritage. It is also indicated that the term ‘Hindutva' is related more to the way of life of the people in the subcontinent,” the court held.

The court had said, “It is difficult to appreciate how in the face of these decisions, the term ‘Hindutva' or ‘Hinduism' per se, in the abstract, can be assumed to mean and be equated with narrow fundamentalist Hindu religious bigotry, or be construed to fall within the prohibition in sub-sections (3) and/or (3A) of Section 123,” it had said.

Title: Skoda Octavia RS 245 priced at Rs 35.99 lakh, booking commences on March 1
Content: NEW DELHI: Škoda Auto India on Thursday announced the booking and prices of Octavia RS 245. A limited two hundred units of the Octavia RS 245 will be sold exclusively through the website, which is priced at Rs 35.99 lakh (ex-showroom).The booking will commence for Octavia RS 245 on 01 March, through company’s website at Rs 1 lakh.Equipped with the turbocharged 2.0 TSI paired with seven speed DSG transmission, the premium sedan delivers 245 PS of power and a peak torque output of 370 Nm.The Skoda Octavia RS 245 accelerates from 0 to 100 kmph in 6.6 seconds and has a top speed ‘electronically limited’ to 250 km/h - making it the fastest Škoda Auto offering, in India.Major highlights inside the car include Carbon Décor, flat-bottom SuperSport steering wheel with paddle-shift, Virtual Cockpit, and black Alcantara Sports Seats with integrated headrests.The sedan sits on 18-inch dual-tone Vega alloy wheels, distinctive RS badge, and glossy black design elements underline the Skoda Octavia RS 245’s dynamic, sporty, and urbane appeal.

Title: AGR Dues: DoT working on 3 options for telco bailout
Content:
DoT is working on at least three options to defer the Rs 1.47 lakh crore adjusted gross revenue (AGR) liabilit... Read More

NEW DELHI: The telecom department is working on at least three options to defer the Rs 1.47 lakh crore adjusted gross revenue (AGR) liability of telecom companies, including proposals to let the operators pay around 20% of the outstanding amount upfront.The proposals are among several measures to be discussed on Friday by the Digital Communications Commission (DCC), the inter-ministerial panel comprising top officials, that could provide much-needed relief to beleaguered telcos such as Vodafone Idea and Airtel .A decision on the extent and modalities of a bailout would depend on the view taken by officials from other ministries, especially finance and DoT can only come up with recommendations.“A variety of options are being worked upon. We are walking a tightrope as while adherence to the SC order is a top priority, there is also a need to see that the industry doesn’t end up as a monopoly, or even a duopoly,” a source told TOI.The first option being considered by DoT hinges on payment of 20% of the principal licence fee and the spectrum usage charges that are part of the AGR liability. If the proposal is accepted, the remaining amount will have to be paid over 16 years and will come annual interest rate that is 0.5% higher than what a comparable government security costs. Besides, there will be a five year moratorium on principal and interest payment.The second option is an improvement over the first option and includes issue bonds and warrants, after the initial payment of 20%. Once this is done, a part of the liability will be converted into bonds based on the self-assessed value by telecom companies. The other component – the difference between the self-assessed value and DoT’s claims – will come in the form of convertible warrants that companies will have to issue, sources explained.Once the amount is reconciled after audit, the warrants will be converted into bonds, in case there is additional liability.Another option on the table is to have an arrangement between the government, the telecom companies and banks, which provide funds against the bonds issued by the telecom companies. The money will then be used to settle the AGR dues and the funds will be set aside in a separate account so that banks have a charge on it.In case of a default, the government’s rights over the claims can be protected through subrogation rights over the bonds, suggested a source.As the bonds are redeemed, the government will be able to collect an equivalent amount from the security account. And, if telecom companies default, banks can recover the amount from the security account.

Title: Hero Super Splendor BS-VI launched at Rs 67,300
Content: NEW DELHI: Hero Motocorp on Thursday launched the Super Splendor in its BS-VI version at Rs 67,300 for self-drum alloy wheel and Rs 70,800 for self-disc alloy wheel (ex-showroom Delhi).The new Super Splendor comes with an all-new 125cc BS-VI Compliant Programmed Fuel Injection engine with XSens Technology , providing a superior ride experience to the customer. It delivers 19% more power - 10.73 BHP @ 7500 RPM and an impressive torque of 10.6 Nm @ 6000 RPM. The engine is mated to an all-new 5-Speed Gearbox along with i3S technology.Underpinning the Super Splendor BS-VI is an all-new chassis which promises greater maneuverability and a plush ride. The rigid diamond frame combined with an increased suspension travel (Front: +15mm; 14% increase, Rear: +7.5mm/10% increase), class-leading 180mm ground clearance (+30mm; 20% higher) and a longer seat (+45mm) guarantee a comfortable ride over any road condition, for the rider as well as the pillion.The Super Splendor BS-VI is offered in dual-tone paint scheme, bold flowing lines, and distinct chrome elements. An all-new Metallic Nexus Blue colour variant adds vibrancy to the daily ride. The motorcycle is available in three more colour options: Glaze Black, Heavy Grey, and Candy Blazing Red.The company has already stopped production of all BS-IV products and is now manufacturing only BS-VI products. The launch of Super Splendor BS-VI follows the company’s recent BS-VI launches at the Hero World 2020 – the new Xtreme 160R, Passion Pro BS-VI and Glamour BS-VI alon with prior introduction of Splendor iSmart, Splendor+, HF Deluxe, Pleasure+ 110, Destini 125 and Maestro Edge 125.

Title: Honda Unicorn BS-VI launched at Rs 93,593
Content: NEW DELHI: Honda Motorcycle and Scooter India on Thursday introduced Unicorn BS-VI starting at Rs 93,593 (ex-showroom, Delhi).At the heart of Unicorn BSVI ticks Bharat Stage VI-compliant Honda’s mid-size advanced 160cc PGM-FI HET ( Honda Eco Technology engine that provides greater performance and superior efficiency. The engine is specially designed to deliver good low end torque and higher fuel efficiency with a 10:1 compression ratio, the company claims.Smooth power delivery is ensured with a needle bearing rocker arm which helps in reduction of friction losses. The new engine also comes equipped with counter weight balancer which reduces vibrations and helps in delivering smooth acceleration from low to high rpm.New Honda Unicorn BSVI comes equipped with ABS (Anti-brake system), HET tubeless tyre (Low Rolling Resistance tyreat the rear, which reduces energy loss while maintaining optimum grip.The rear mono shock suspension is housed below the seat and mounted on the advanced tough and flexible diamond frame. It offers superior riding comfort and excellent stability.Increased ground clearance (+8mm) and long wheelbase inspire rider confidence and comfort. A longer seat (+24mm) provides ample space for comfortable long distance travel. It comes with seal chain which needs less frequent adjustments and low maintenance. Unicorn BSVI now comes with new engine stop switch for the convenience of turning-off the engine on brief stops with the flick of a button.Broad front cowl with smoked screen and big tank create a bold character. Chrome stroke on side cover, chrome garnish on front cowl, signature tail lamp and 3D Honda Wing Mark on the fuel tank add an appeal of premiumness to the motorcycle. Unicorn BSVI is available in three color options – Pearl Igneous Black, Imperial Red Metallic & Mat Axis Gray Metallic.As another industry first, Honda is also offering a special 6-year warranty package new (3 years standard + 3 years optional extended warranty) on Unicorn BSVI.

NEW DELHI: Honda Motorcycle and Scooter India on Thursday introduced Unicorn BS-VI starting at Rs 93,593 (ex-showroom, Delhi).

At the heart of Unicorn BSVI ticks Bharat Stage VI-compliant Honda’s mid-size advanced 160cc PGM-FI HET ( Honda Eco Technology ) engine that provides greater performance and superior efficiency. The engine is specially designed to deliver good low end torque and higher fuel efficiency with a 10:1 compression ratio, the company claims.

Smooth power delivery is ensured with a needle bearing rocker arm which helps in reduction of friction losses. The new engine also comes equipped with counter weight balancer which reduces vibrations and helps in delivering smooth acceleration from low to high rpm.

New Honda Unicorn BSVI comes equipped with ABS (Anti-brake system), HET tubeless tyre (Low Rolling Resistance tyreat the rear, which reduces energy loss while maintaining optimum grip.

Increased ground clearance (+8mm) and long wheelbase inspire rider confidence and comfort. A longer seat (+24mm) provides ample space for comfortable long distance travel. It comes with seal chain which needs less frequent adjustments and low maintenance. Unicorn BSVI now comes with new engine stop switch for the convenience of turning-off the engine on brief stops with the flick of a button.

Broad front cowl with smoked screen and big tank create a bold character. Chrome stroke on side cover, chrome garnish on front cowl, signature tail lamp and 3D Honda Wing Mark on the fuel tank add an appeal of premiumness to the motorcycle. Unicorn BSVI is available in three color options – Pearl Igneous Black, Imperial Red Metallic & Mat Axis Gray Metallic.

As another industry first, Honda is also offering a special 6-year warranty package new (3 years standard + 3 years optional extended warranty) on Unicorn BSVI.

Title: Delhi violence: Bernie Sanders slams Donald Trump for being non-committal on riots
Content:
Democratic 2020 US presidential candidate Senator Bernie Sanders (Reuters photo)

Over 200 million Muslims call India home. Widespread anti-Muslim mob violence has killed at least 27 and injured ma… https://t.co/xukArMLDBX — Bernie Sanders (@BernieSanders) 1582748654000

Our hearts go out to the families of the deceased and injured in New Delhi. We echo PM @NarendraModi’s call for cal… https://t.co/9C2CKhplx7 — State_SCA (@State_SCA) 1582802595000

Leading Democratic presidential hopeful Bernie Sanders attacked US President Donald Trump for failure on human rights leadership, saying Trump’s comment that handling the unrest over the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) was up to India was inadequate.Sanders tweeted on Wednesday, “Over 200 million Muslims call India home. Widespread anti-Muslim mob violence has killed at least 27 and injured many more. Trump responds by saying, ‘That’s up to India’. This is a failure of leadership on human rights.” Sanders took on Trump for his reaction at the press meet here on questions about the clashes.In a milder reaction, supportive of the Indian government, a senior US state department official also tweeted on the violence in Delhi, urging calm and respect for the right of peaceful assembly. “Our hearts go out to the families of the deceased and injured in New Delhi,” Alice G Wells, principal deputy assistant secretary for south and central Asian affairs at the state department, tweeted on Thursday.“We echo PM Narendra Modi’s call for calm and normalcy and urge all parties to maintain peace, refrain from violence and respect the right of peaceful assembly,” she wrote.BJP general secretary (organisation) B L Santhosh responded to Sanders’s tweet on Thursday and said his party may be “compelled” to play a role in the US presidential elections coming up later this year. He, however, soon deleted his tweet.Santhosh posted a sharp reaction at 7.45am on Thursday, saying, “How much ever neutral we wish to be, you compel us to play a role in the presidential elections. Sorry to say so… but you are compelling us.”While BJP did not react to Santhosh’s tweet and deletion, clearly a political faux pas, the party general secretary evidently realised that he might have crossed the line and acted hastily by making the statement on social media.Sanders took on Trump for his reaction at the press conference here on questions about the clashes during his visit, saying, “As far as the individual attacks, I heard about it, but I didn't discuss that with him (PM Modi). That’s up to India.”Apart from the Democratic presidential candidate, other influential Senators too expressed concern over the developments on Wednesday. "We are alarmed by the recent violence in New Delhi. We continue to support an open dialogue on issues of significant concern in order to advance our vital long-term relationship," Senator Mark Warner from the Democratic Party and John Cornyn from the GOP said in a joint statement. they are co-chairs of the Senate India Caucus, the largest country-specific caucus in the US Senate.Richard N Hass, who heads the powerful Council on Foreign Relations, said the reason for India's relative success has been that its large Muslim minority saw itself as Indian. "But this is at risk owing to govt attempts to exploit identity politics for political advantage," he said.Earlier in the day, the US Commission on International Religious Freedom (USCIRF) urged the Indian government to take swift action for the safety of its citizens. Expressing "grave concern" over the violence, the US body said the Indian government should provide protection to people regardless of their faith amid reports of an attack on Muslims.And yesterday, the US House Foreign Affairs Committee said its chairman Eliot Engel was “deeply troubled by the deaths from communal violence in India” (reported in Thursday’s final edition).

Title: Delhi violence: Delhi riots toll rises to 38 as bodies are found in drains; over 400 detained
Content:
A view of a riot-hit area in Delhi (AFP photo)

NEW DELHI: With more bodies being recovered from drains and people in hospitals dying of injuries, the death toll in the north-east Delhi communal riots rose to 38 on Thursday. However, no incident of violence has been reported since Tuesday night and life is slowly returning to normal. Prohibitory orders imposed under Section 144 will be relaxed for 10 hours on Friday in view of the improvement in the ground situation.Delhi Police has arrested over 130 people, detained over 400 and registered 48 FIRs. It has also booked Aam Aadmi Party councillor Tahir Hussain and his associates in the case of murder of Intelligence Bureau official Ankit Sharma. He is yet to be arrested. Sharma’s case, along with other cases of riots, have been transferred to the crime branch and a special investigation team (SIT) — as reported by TOI on Thursday — has been set up to probe the case.Delhi violence: Live updatesThe SIT will also probe a “larger conspiracy”, which cops suspect was hatched over a period. Their suspicion has been strengthened by the recoveries made from the area which include improvised hand grenades tied with rope and “bottle bomb launchers” which resemble a big-size slingshot tied to trees or fences to make it look like swings. These arrangements could not have been made overnight, said a source.Meanwhile, chief minister Arvind Kejriwal announced on Thursday that Delhi government will bear all medical expenses of the riot victims even if they are admitted to private hospitals and give up to Rs 10 lakh as compensation to the kin of the dead and up to Rs 5 lakh each to those who have lost their houses and shops in the riots. Eighteen subdivisional magistrates (SDMs) have been deployed to monitor the relief and rehabilitation operations.The Delhi LG on Thursday reviewed the situation and directed the police to ensure continued and adequate deployment of force apart from carrying out enhanced patrolling and area domination exercises.Four teams of Delhi FSL — physics, biology, chemistry and photo — visited several spots in the area to lift samples. The authorities will now make efforts for quick disposal of burnt vehicles, lifting of malba, clearing of animal carcasses and repair of roads, signages, government assets and religious structures, in coordination with the police.“The LG has also asked for setting up of sufficient number of shelter homes with basic amenities, including beddings, blankets, medicines, food, sanitation and clean drinking water, ensuring timely medico-legal certificates and post-mortem reports etc. to the victims and their families,” said a government official. The principal secretary (law) was asked to coordinate with the district legal services authorities to provide immediate legal aid to the victims.Arrangements are being made in coordination with IHBAS for counselling of riot victims to treat those with post-traumatic stress disorder and any other issues. The LG has also asked the revenue department to adopt confidence-building measures and make a quick survey of the quantum of loss to individuals, families, business establishments, shops and institutions and ensure speedy compensation.Special CP Sundari Nanda, assisted by East Delhi Municipal Corporation officials, health department and district administration, will meet the injured and families of the deceased personally and ensure that all steps are taken to provide them help.Delhi Police has appealed to people residing in north-east Delhi that if they had witnessed violent incidents, they should come forward and share their ordeal and videos with the police. The locals can also send videos and pictures through WhatsApp on two mobile numbers —8750871221 and 8750871227.In Video: Delhi riots: Bodies found in drains, death toll rises to 38
