PANAJI: The high court of Bombay at Goa has dismissed the anticipatory bail application of transport minister Mauvin Godinho ’s brother Wilson in the case of alleged abetement to suicide of Merces panch member Prakash Naik in January.Godinho had knocked the doors of the high court after the sessions court last month rejected his anticipatory bail application.The judge Nutan Sardessai heard long drawn out arguments by the senior counsel representing Godinho, counsel representing the sister of the deceased who was permitted to assist the prosecution and the government.During the last hearing, the prosecution told the high court that the “original scene of offence” was not available to the police.Additional public prosecutor Pravin Faldessai told the court that the scene of offence was lost and later reconstructed, and that the police came into the picture only after Naik was declared brought dead at the Goa Medical College and Hospital, Bambolim .There was also no conclusive gunpowder residue, he said, adding that a team has been constituted to travel to Delhi to obtain an immediate report to ascertain whether the gun was used by Naik himself, instead of relying on the laboratory at Hyderabad which could take some time.Faldessai told the court that no angle of investigation was closed and that all angles were being probed. He said the possibility of murder is also being considered and presented the names of three additional suspects identified on February 11, 12 and 13. He, however, did not disclose the names in the open court.Senior counsel Nitin Sardessai , representing Wilson, told the court that the authenticity of the WhatsApp message sent by Naik minutes before his death must be verified and added the police were under pressure to file an FIR after Naik’s family threatened not to cremate the body. His contention was that Godinho ’s custody was not requried by the police.

Title: Trichy CWC rescued 1,210 children last year
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

TRICHY: The district child welfare committee (CWC) has rescued 1,210 children below 18-years, who were victim to various circumstances, in 2019 and has sought the cooperation of all stake holders to ensure the welfare of children. The committee was set up on November 17, 2018.

“Achieving the goal of child welfare, rehabilitation and restoration would not be possible but for the cooperation from all stake holders. In order to ensure their support, CWC is now organising meeting with all of them and discussing the issues coming in the way of rescue and rehabilitation of the children,” said CWC member N Krishnamoorthy on Thursday.

The meeting held on Thursday was attended by officials from the deputy director of health services (DDHS), district social welfare office (DSWO), district child protection unit (DCPU), railway children India, anti-child trafficking unit, integrated child development scheme (ICDS), district differently-abled welfare office, child labour elimination and effective rehabilitation society, labour department, Samagra Shiksha and ChildLine.

CWC highlighted the recent illegal sale of two babies by their parents to adoptive parents in Trichy and advised DDHS officials to keep track of ante-natal mothers enrolling in primary health centres.

“The two cases of illegal adoption highlights a disturbing trend. In one of the cases, the birth record at the PHC was doctored to replace the name of the biological parents with the adoptive parents. It can be prevented if the personal information of the pregnant women is collected clearly,” said CWC member Dr M Gnanavelu.

The rehabilitated children include child marriage victims, run-away children, child labourers, sexual abuse victims, abandoned children etc.

The committee also raised concern about post-child marriage follow up in Trichy. The members asked DSWO officials to keep track of rescued child marriage victim for certain period to avoid the victims being forced into child marriage again.

CWC said it would coordinate with stake holders to conduct the meeting once in three months.

Title: Bijnor court nixes bail pleas of 3 men involved in violence during anti-CAA protests
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Bijnor: The bail applications of three men accused of being involved in violence during anti-Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) protests in Bijnor, have been rejected by a court here. The three men were involved in violence which took place in Bijnor’s Nahtaur area. Bijnor police had filed three FIRs in Nahtaur against 1,000 unnamed and 18 named protesters after the December 20 violence.

The bail pleas of Gulzar Ahmad, Harun Ahmad and Jafar were rejected by additional district and sessions judge Sanjeev Pandey on Wednesday.

During the hearing, government counsel Sanjeev Verma objected to several facts produced by defendants’ lawyer and claimed, “The three protesters were arrested from the violence spot. Country-made pistols and cartridges were also recovered from their possession. There were over 1,000 people protesting against CAA on December 20 at Nahtaur. Police tried to pacify them but they did not heed to them and turned aggressive. They opened fire at policemen and pelted stones. Several police personnel and common men were injured.”

After hearing the pleas of both the sides, judge Pandey rejected the bail pleas of the three protesters. “Keeping all the facts in mind, the court found that crime’s nature is serious and protesters do not have enough ground to be granted bail,” the judge observed. Last week, the court had rejected the bail pleas of 30 protesters in Bijnor.

Title: Slain IB official cremated with state honours in Muzaffarnagar village
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Muzaffarnagar: Slain Intelligence Bureau (IB) official Ankit Sharma was on Thursday evening cremated with full state honours in his native village in Muzaffarnagar. Sharma’s relatives, his friends from Delhi, Union minister Sanjeev Balyan, DM and SSP of Muzaffarnagar were among thousands of people who bid him a final adieu as the pyre was lit in Muzaffarnagar’s Itawah village.

The mortal remains of Sharma reached the village at 5PM amid sloganeering.

Subodh Kumar, a relative of the deceased, said, “We want justice and the government should help the family. His killers should be punished.”

Union minister Balyan said, “I have spoken to chief minister Yogi Adityanath. He has assured all possible help to the family.” When asked about the alleged link of the accused to a political party, Balyan said, “No matter he belongs to which party. He will soon be arrested and sent to jail.”

Sharma’s body was recovered from a drain in Chand Bagh on Wednesday. He was killed by a mob during communal clashes in Khajuri Khas.

Title: Dug-up road adds to commuters’ woes
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Secunderabad: Lack of coordination between the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) and Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HMWS&SB) prior to undertaking development works at Pipeline Road in Jeedimetla is causing frequent traffic jams on the stretch.

Commuters are having a tough time as GHMC workers had dug up the road a month ago for laying a CC road. However, the water board again dug up the newly-laid road for laying drainage pipelines. “The road is used by several people daily, and yet, the debris is right in the middle of the road. Many take this road to reach Suchitra Junction. I request the authorities to restore it immediately,” said Chakra Teja, a resident of Jeedimetla.

GHMC deputy commissioner of Qutbullapur, Manga Tayaru, said the GHMC will restore the road immediately. “To ensure better coordination between line departments, we are holding a convergence meeting every month,” said a senior GHMC official.

While the onus of laying roads is on the GHMC, as per the rules, the water board must ensure building utilities are not damaged and any work relating to drains and manholes is supposed to be undertaken before a road is laid.

Title: This guru teaches English through maths!
Content:
Gordhan Dihora

AHMEDABAD: Words and numbers don’t match, one might say. But not for this teacher from Bhavnagar . Gordhan Dihora, a primary school teacher from Trambak Primary School near Ghogha , has found a unique method to teach English while he teaches Mathematics to the students of Class VI-VIII.His is one of the 135 teacher-led innovations displayed at DIET Ahmedabad organized by Gujarat Council of Educational Research & Training (GCERT), Gandhinagar as part of three-day Education Innovation Festival.It was participation of his students in finals of Talent Test 2019 organized by All India Ramanujan Maths Club that led him to the innovation. “They were among the top five teams but could not be winners — the deciding factor was their inability to understand English even when they knew the mathematics involved,” said Dihora. “After the event, I started working on a plan to include English in Mathematics — the challenge was not to let the students know that they were learning it!”“There are 22 such exercises designed — some of which have taken me days — which are for different mathematical concepts of class VI to VIII,” said Dihora. Currently, 145 students are learning with this concept, leading them to discover 4,000 English words annually.T S Joshi, director of GCERT, said that the idea of the festival is to promote innovations like Dihora’s. “They are the teachers who have faced problems and have come up with indigenous solutions which are easy to replicate. We are also documenting these innovations and bringing in teachers from across the state so that they can get inspired by the grassroots ideas,” he said.

Title: Shoddy medians prompt HMRL to rebuild them
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

The HMRL is rebuilding the medians with bigger pipelines to ensure water drains out

SECUNDERABAD: The shoddy repair work by the Hyderabad Metro Rail Limited (HMRL) while constructing central medians at Punjagutta has prompted the Metro officials to rebuild the medians to avoid the stretch from getting waterlogged during rains. The HMRL is rebuilding the medians with bigger pipelines to ensure water drains out.

Experts said that before executing a project, a digital survey has to be conducted to understand the contours. “While constructing a median , the problems that can be faced during a natural disaster have to be taken into account,” said Structural Engineers World Congress-India vice-president and infrastructure expert Dr SP Anchuri.

Addressing concerns, the HMRL said that the taxpayers’ money is not being utilised to rebuild the medians. “The advertisers who had put up ads at the medians have outsourced the job to contractors. The HMRL has come up with a good solution to the problem,” NVS Reddy, managing director, HMRL told TOI.

According to Reddy, in the earlier medians, the outlets which allow the water to flow towards the corner of the road during rains were smaller in diameter and this may cause waterlogging. The HMRL officials added that a ground verification found that the slope is uneven, which restricts water from flowing into manholes located towards the corner of the road. “I will speak to the GHMC commissioner and ask him to ensure that the water seamlessly flows into the manholes,” he said.

Meanwhile, the GHMC engineers admitted that several roads in the city were being damaged due to waterlogging.

“Even the best quality bitumen can be destroyed due to stagnant water,” said a GHMC engineer.

Title: Bithoor fest begins on Friday, buses to run for visitors
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Several sports events were held under the Bithoor Khel Mahotsav at Green Park stadium of the city on the secon... Read More

KANPUR: For those wishing to visit the three-day Bithoor Mahotsav starting from Friday, the administration has decided to operate buses between Rawatpur to Bithoor.

Addressing the media persons here on Thursday, divisional commissioner and president of the festival committee Sudhir M Bobde said that the festival will commence with a traditional prayer of Lord Ganesha followed by patriotic songs by Suhasini Joshi on Friday.

He added that the festival would present vibrant colours of folk culture along with Bollywood attractions and development exhibitions.

The committee had approached chief minister Yogi Adityanath and invited him for the inauguration of the festival, however, no confirmation has been received regarding his visit to the fest so far.

Giving details of the cultural programmes to be held during the fest he said that Ganga Aarti would performed every day at Patthar Ghat in Bithoor. On the inuagural day, performance by Suhasini Joshi and her group will be followed by national level Kavi Sammelan which will witness participation of Dr Vishnu Saxena, Dr Ankita Singh, Dr Sarvesh Asthana, Hemant Pandey, Gaurav Chauhan and others.

On February 29, a boat race will be held from Siddheshwar Ghat to Brahmavart ghat. Bollywood night with Sudesh Bhosle and his group would be another attraction of the day.

On March 1, Vintage car rally will be the main attraction. Besides other cultural programmes like Braj Ki Holi, Charkula dance, solo musical drama based on Vivekanand by Shekher Sen Mumbai and songs on Ganga by Sarthi organization of Yatharth would be held.

Besides, an exhibition based on revolution of 1857 will also be held during the fest. Shilp haat displaying handicrafts and local art and skills will be open for public in from 1pm to 8pm.

Bobde added that the administration is planning to start Kanpur Festival from next year keeping in view the historical significance of the city.

Meanwhile, several sports events were held under the Bithoor Khel Mahotsav at Green Park stadium of the city on the second day on Thursday. The sports fest was formally inaugurated on Wednesday at Green Park stadium.

Title: 3 dead & counting, a wedding which didn’t happen: UP’s Bulandshahr bears brunt of Delhi riots
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Meerut: They had left the dusty tracks of UP’s Bulandshahr in hope of a better life in Delhi. They were doing well, till the communal violence cut their lives short. Now their bodies are arriving, one after another. So far, three persons from the district have been confirmed killed in the national capital.

Ashfaq Hussain (22), an electrician who got married just 10 days ago, was killed when he went out for work. Shahid Khan (25), an auto-rickshaw driver, was returning home after dropping a passenger when he was shot dead. Shaban Aziz, 22, a labourer, was the third causality from Bulandshahr. He lived with his family in Delhi’s Gokulpuri area.

So far, 38 people have been declared dead in Delhi’s communal clash.

The violence not only sent bodies back home, it also crushed some dreams. A wedding was postponed at the last moment in Bulandshahr’s Sikandarabad area on Tuesday. The ‘baarat’ was to come from Mustafabad-- one of the epicentres of riots that broke out in the national capital.

Nagina, 22, was set to marry a man from Mustafabad area of Delhi. She is distraught now. Due to the tense situation in riot-hit area, the baarat didn’t turn up.

“Nagina and her younger sister Rani were getting married on the same day. While Rani got married to a man from Okhla in Delhi, her elder sister’s wedding was temporarily postponed after ‘baarat’ didn’t arrive,” says Jameel Malik, uncle of the sisters.

“The preparation for the feast and other arrangements were made, but the ‘baarat’ didn’t arrive due to tension in Mustafabad. I hope the normalcy is restored soon,” said Yameen Malik, father of the bride.

Title: Minister praises Maharashtra, lands in a soup
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

MANDYA: Minister KC Narayanagowda stirred a row after allegedly praising Maharashtra and Marathi in a programme held in KR Pete a week. A video of the alleged incident surfaced on Thursday and was widely shared on social media.

In the video, Narayanagowda allegedly boasts of his growth as an hotelier and realtor in Maharashtra and attributes all his good fortune to the neighbouring state.

“Maharashtra is my strength,” Narayanagowda purportedly says. “Whatever I’ve achieved in my life as hotelier, realtor and now as a minister, Maharashtra is the reason for that. If I have strength and power, then it belongs to Maharashtra only. I have no qualms in praising Maharashtra and Shivaji.”

Narayanagowda’s purported comments have, obviously, not gone down well with pro-Kannada activists, who held a protest in Mandya on Thursday. Various organisations also demanded an apology from Narayanagowda and sought his resignation.

Karnataka Raskhana Vedike (KRV) activists, who held a protest at Sri Nalvadi Circle on the Mysuru-Bengaluru highway, raised slogans against Narayanagowda and dubbed him a Marathi.

“How can he continue as a minister in Karnataka when he has openly declared allegiance to Maharashtra? Whose side is he on with regard to the border dispute with Maharashtra?” asked protesters.

Protesters warned of a fierce agitation if chief minister BS Yediyurappa did not remove Narayanagowda immediately from his cabinet.

Title: Karnataka: Yatnal refuses to apologise for mocking Doreswamy
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

SHIVAMOGGA/MYSURU/MANGALURU: Former Union minister and BJP MLA Basanagouda Patil Yatnal, who is facing flak from the opposition for calling freedom fighter HS Doreswamy a “fake” and a man who acts like a “Pakistani agent”, refused to apologise for his controversial remarks.

“I will apologise only if opposition leaders tender an open apology for their derogatory remarks made against Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Hindutva icon Vinayak Damodar Savarkar in the past,” Yatnal, who represents Vijayapura in the assembly, said on Thursday.

In a touch of defiance, Yatnal went on to say: “Who is Doreswamy? What kind of freedom fighter is he? Was he lodged in Andaman jail during the freedom movement? I don’t think so. He is just a Congressman who is opposing the Citizenship Amendment Act.”

The opposition Congress has decided to continue its protest till Yatnal tenders a public apology. Former minister and Congress legislator UT Khader accused the BJP of revealing its “true colours” and “hidden agenda” by criticising freedom fighters and branding anyone it dislikes as traitors.

“The saffron party is apparently afflicted with the Pakistan virus for which there is no cure available in India,” Khader said. “They should get medicine from Pakistan itself to cure the disease.”

Functionaries who pass derogatory comments against the Independence movement are real traitors, Khader said insisting chief minister BS Yediyurappa and BJP leadership should clarify their stand on Yatnal’s comments.

Former minister and senior Congress functionary HC Mahadevappa said Congress will continue to stage protests both inside and outside the assembly in the upcoming budget session and the protests will continue till Yatnal apologises.

“If BJP really believes in [Mahatma] Gandhi’s ideologies, then the saffron party must initiate action against Yatnal,” Mahadevappa said. “Or else they will be deemed anti-Gandhi. The BJP did not contribute anything to the freedom struggle. Now, its leaders are humiliating freedom fighters.”

Title: 2 Maha students back from Wuhan; 195 from China, Japan
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Mumbai/New Delhi: Two PhD students from the state, who chose to stay back in Wuhan when the first batch of Indians was evacuated in January after the coronavirus outbreak, landed in Delhi on Thursday.

In a major rescue exercise, India on Thursday evacuated 195 nationals from Japan and China. While 119 people were evacuated from cruise ship Diamond Princess in Japan, 76 more were brought back from Wuhan by a relief military aircraft. India also evacuated 36 foreign nationals from Wuhan and five from Japan.

Students Girish Patil (29) and Chandradip Jadhav (29), studying at College of Materials and Metallurgy, Wuhan University of Science and Technology, had opted to stay back in Wuhan—the epicentre of the outbreak—due to financial constraints. From Delhi airport, the students, along with other Indians from Wuhan, were sent to the quarantine centre at Chawla camp for 14 days.

Patil and Jadhav, both residents of Dhule, were among the bunch of six Indian students who stayed back in the university’s dormitory. One of the six said now the university has officially extended the holidays for a few months. They also gave them a no objection certificate for evacuation, he added.

Meanwhile, the special Air India flight that brought back 119 Indian and five foreign nationals from Diamond Princess cruise liner early on Thursday includes two Mira Road residents. Mira Road’s Dinesh Thakkar was at the forefront of the effort to get back his daughter Sonali who worked as a security personnel on Diamond Princess. “My daughter spoke to us briefly on landing and after reaching the army quarantine spot in Haryana,” said Dinesh.

“The evacuation has underscored the priority India attaches to the welfare of its citizens wherever they are,” said foreign secretary Harsh Shringla. He added that India was “happy to have been able to assist our friends from Bangladesh, Myanmar, Maldives and other friendly countries from our neighbourhood and beyond in the evacuations from both China and Japan”. Of the 36 foreign nationals evacuated from Wuhan, 23 were from Bangladesh, six from China, two each from Myanmar and Maldives and one each from South Africa, US and Madagascar. Of the five from Japan, there were two from Sri Lanka and one each from Nepal, South Africa and Peru.

The Indian relief flight to Wuhan carried 15,000kg of medical assistance comprising masks, gloves and other emergency medical equipment. These supplies were delivered by an IAF C-17 special flight, which landed in Wuhan late on Wednesday evening. The medical supplies followed Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s letter to President Xi Jinping offering assistance to deal with the crisis. “The medical supplies will help augment the China’s efforts to control the outbreak of this infection which has been declared as a public health emergency by the World Health Organisation,’’ the MEA said in a statement.

Some of India’s neighbours such as Bangladesh and Sri Lanka had sought help from India to evacuate their citizens. The government said assistance to them was in keeping with India’s neighbourhood first policy. India has until now operated three relief flights from Wuhan, evacuating 723 Indian nationals and 43 foreign nationals. In the case of Japan, a special Air India flight landed in New Delhi from Tokyo on Thursday, bringing back 119 Indian nationals—113 crew members and six passengers—who were on board the Diamond Princess which docked off Yokohama in Japan. “In line with India’s neighbourhood first policy and Indo-Pacific vision, the special flight also evacuated five foreign nationals—two Sri Lankans, one Nepalese, one South African and one Peruvian. All the evacuees will undergo a 14-day quarantine at the facility set up by the Indian Army in Manesar, Haryana,” the MEA said.

Three Indian crew members did not board the special flight and conveyed their wish, according to the government, to continue their stay on board the cruise ship to complete the period of extended quarantine put in place by the Japan government.

“Out of the total 138 Indian nationals originally on board the Diamond Princess, 16 Indian crew members have tested positive for coronavirus 2019 and are receiving necessary medical care and treatment at onshore medical facilities in Japan. Embassy of India in Tokyo has established contact with these individuals and is continuously following-up on their recovery,’’ the foreign ministry said.

Title: Mumbai toddler loses three fingers after they get stuck in mall escalator handrail
Content:
22-month-old Chinmay Rajiwade lost three fingers in the mishap

MUMBAI: A 22-month-old toddler lost three of his right hand fingers in a freak escalator mishap at R-Mall in Mulund (West) on Tuesday. Chinmay Rajiwade’s fingers got stuck in a gap in a down escalator’s handrail when he tried to climb on to it on the ground floor. His father Ravindra, an autorickshsaw driver, rushed him to KEM Hospital in Parel as he was unable to afford the fees quoted by a private hospital. But the toddler’s middle, ring and little fingers could not be reattached. On Thursday, Mulund police registered an FIR against persons responsible for operating the escalator.Mall authorities, though, have denied the allegation that a technical issue could have led to the mishap.The accident occurred when Chinmay was on a shopping trip with his parents and family friends for his second birthday on April 16.He was admitted to a Mulund nursing home on Thursday after he developed a high fever. His parents suspect it to could be a side-effect of the surgery he underwent at KEM Hospital.“Initially we rushed to a private hospital but the fees quoted for surgery were very high. Thereafter, I got in touch with a friend who works in KEM and rushed there with my son, carrying the amputated fingers. They did a test and said there was barely 5% possibility of saving the fingers. So, they performed a plastic surgery. My son is now left with just two fingers on his right hand,” Ravindra (26) told TOI.The Bhandup resident said he was holding his son’s hand when the toddler freed himself and walked towards the escalator. “I ran after him but by then he had started to climb the escalator, which was moving down. He lost his balance and three of his fingers got stuck in the handrail. The mall had no security measures to operate the escalator,” said Ravindra who went to a private hospital but found the fees steep. “I make less than Rs 1,000 a day, so how can I afford huge fees for surgery? For the last three days, I have stayed home with my son. I am worried about his health. He even tries to remove the bandage from his hand,” he said.An R-Mall spokesperson said the mall team kept his fingers in the cold storage till his parents asked for them. “We take utmost care of all our customers and are committed to the highest level of safety and security of our patrons. The investigation revealed there was no technical issue in the escalator. We are cooperating with the authorities in their investigation. We pray and hope for speedy recovery of the boy,” said the spokesperson, adding mall authorities are working on a compensation plan for the toddler but refused to disclose the details.A case was registered under IPC Section 338 for causing grievous hurt by an act endangering the life or safety of others. “We will take a technical expert’s opinion. We have called mall authorities for details before deciding the course of action,” said Mulund police senior inspector Ravi Sardesai. (With Chittaranjan Tembhekar)

Title: Gandhi market street vendors relocated to Diamond Jubilee bazaar
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Encroachments being removed in Gandhi market

TRICHY: Trichy city police in a joint operation with Trichy City Corporation have evicted a section of street vendors who have encroached on a portion of arterial roads near the Gandhi market in the city. At least 50 street vendors have been relocated to an alternative site near the war memorial in the market.

According to police, public complaints and grievances came up at road safety council meetings have forced them to evict makeshift shops on Big Bazaar Street and Vellamandi Road. The officials have warned the street vendors not to return to the roads near Gandhi market and urged them to use the 4,000-square metre alternative space behind the war memorial. "The evicted vendors were given space at Diamond Jubilee Bazaar near the corporation’s cycle stand. They have to operate only from the space allotted to them and should not occupy the roads," a corporation official said.

Though the traffic police had earmarked space with ropes for street vendors to do business, they often cross the line choking public mobility. "The street vendors were asked to leave the space permanently," the corporation official said. The corporation will install warning boards along with the retrieved space. The relieved local people urged the authorities to maintain the order in Gandhi market.

Since city buses are halting away from bus stops, street vendors utilise the gap between the halting point and pedestrian platforms to set up their stalls, local people said. "We will ensure that city buses pick up and drop passengers only at bus stops. But public cooperation is essential, it is the passengers who signal the buses to halt haphazardly," a senior police official told TOI.

Title: BDU launches exclusive website for entrepreneurs
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: Bharathidasan University (BDU) has launched an exclusive website (www.bechrusa.in) for its entrepreneurship, innovation and career hub, which was started last year, with an objective to develop innovative ideas by students into business models. Students from BDU and its affiliated colleges can apply for theme-based projects, post-doctoral fellowships and seed money for start-up ideas through the portal.

BDU is among seven universities in the state which was allotted Rs 15 crore under the Rashtrya Uchchatar Shiksha Abhiyan (RUSA 2.0) to establish entrepreneurship and innovation career hub.

The hub, registered as Bharathidasan University Entrepreneurship , Innovation and Career Hub (Bech), under Section 8 of Companies Act, 2013, will inculcate entrepreneurial skills in the academic curriculum and research at the higher education level.

“Bech will promote students to become innovative entrepreneurs on completion of graduate studies. It is ready with a roadmap in preparing students right from the basics of entrepreneurship, project proposal, research and training and seed money till they come out with a prototype to become a full-fledged entrepreneur,” said BDU vice-chancellor P Manisankar

Bech has been organizing a series of awareness programmes towards sensitizing students on entrepreneurship, innovation in a systematic and scientific manner.

“Bech has plans to collaborate with a global partner to give shape to entrepreneurship and innovation career hub and plan further development,” said N Prasanna, Bech co-coordinator. “We are looking forward to nurture ideas from students that can be developed into a successful business model,” he said.

Title: Chandrababu Naidu: Former Chief Minister N Chandrababu Naidu detained at Visakhapatnam airport as YSRC cadre lay siege, TDP protests
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

TDP president N Chandrababu Naidu returns to the airport following protests by YSRC activists

VISAKHAPATNAM: The TDP president and former chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu was detained at the Visakhapatnam airport on Thursday under Section 151 of Criminal Procedure Code and was thwarted in his attempt to go on his Praja Chaitanya Yatra.

He was finally sent back to Hyderabad on a flight at 7: 20 pm.

Earlier, Naidu had landed at the Visakhapatnam airport at 11.20 am. When Naidu stepped out of the airport, YSRC cadres stopped his convoy.

But the police did not allow him to go out as supporters of YSRC and TDP were camped outside the airport. They tried to shout down each other and created a tense atmosphere.

Naidu and his supporters then sat on the road outside the airport to protest. YSRC supporters were seen holding placards that read ‘go back Naidu, traitor of north Andhra.’ Throughout the day, tension continued to mount with TDP and YSRC supporters trying to shout down each other.

Naidu was served the preventive notice by assistant commissioner of police, west, Visakhapatnam.

TDP supporters blamed the police for behaving in an undemocratic manner. Naidu said the government was behaving in a dictatorial manner and blamed the authorities for being high-handed.

In 2017, TDP cadres had blocked YS Jaganmohan Reddy in a similar manner.

YSRC cadre blocked the Naidu’s convoy from moving out of the airport. The police formed a wall between both factions. While the stalemate at the airport continued, there was traffic snarl along the highway till the NAD Junction stretch, resulting in chaos on the highway and connecting roads.

Title: 300 students booked for anti-CAA protest in Trichy
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: Over 300 students, including women, took part in the protest against CAA (citizenship amendment act) in front of Jamal Mohammed College on Thursday, for the sixth day, which also witnessed tense moments as students only dispersed after four hours while police registered a case against them.

The students blocked Khajamalai road outside the college around 12pm while the police regulated traffic to one side of the road. Unlike the previous protests in five occasion, the students refused to disperse and tried to hold indefinite protest.

The police team comprising Cantonment range ACP P Manikandan, Srirangam range ACP K Ramachandran, KK Nagar police inspector R Sahaya Anbarasu and others rushed to spot.

The protest raised remarks against CAA, national register of citizens (NRC) and national population register (NPR) besides condemning the violence in Delhi. The students blamed the Narendra Modi led BJP government at the centre for CAA and for not handling the riots properly.

Since the vociferous protests lasted for nearly two hours, the police advised the students to disperse citing nuisance to the public and inconvenience to motorists, which they ignored. The police identified some of the outsiders in the crowd and pushed them away and even sought the interference of the college administration to ask students to leave the protest.

Despite assurances from the police that they will give permission to hold similar protests few days later, the students stood firm. The police managed to get the students give up and disperse at 4pm.

The KK Nagar police registered cases against 300 students, of which 50 were named, for unlawful assembly and causing nuisance. It may be pointed out that the police has already registered cases against the students for their protests against the same issue for five days.

Makkal Adhikaram outfit also staged a demonstration near the central bus stand against the violence in Delhi on Thursday.

Title: Goa: Organic agriculture hub to be self-sustaining
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Chandrakant Kavalekar

PANAJI: Agriculture minister Chandrakant Kavalekar said that 5 lakh sqm of land in Quepem and another plot of 15 lakh sqm has been identified in Ponda to set up the organic agriculture hub. The land is already in possession of the agriculture department and state funds won’t have to be spent on acquiring land, said Kavalekar. His comments come in the backdrop of a section of academicians criticising the decision to strain state finances to set up an agriculture university from scratch in Goa.

Kavalekar said the organic agriculture university is only one aspect of a larger plan to establish an organic agriculture hub in Goa. The hub will carry out research into organic farming, will do certification of organic agricultural produce, and will help in marketing and branding organic products.

“Already in 500 clusters covering 10,000 hectares of agricultural land, farmers are being helped to switch to organic agriculture. Within a three-year period, these farmers will be producing fully organic yield. We will help them in certification of organic produce, which will help them fetch a much bigger price. Organic fields also yield much better quantities of produce. So this will help boost production within the existing agricultural land in Goa, with the research carried out at the hub further helping in achieving this objective,” said Kavalekar.

While Kavalekar’s project is being criticised for its initial requirement of Rs 410 crore to set up the organic agriculture hub, the minister said the money is not to be invested within one financial year but in phases to develop the project.

“We have already written to authorities at the Centre for funds for the institute. We want the hub to help Goa become a fully organic agriculture state on the lines of Sikkim. As our hub will provide certification and marketing and branding services, it will generate its own revenue, besides the help we will receive from the Centre. So it will be a self-sustaining project and won’t be a burden on state finances,” Kavalekar told TOI.

“Those criticising the project have not understood that all 65 agriculture universities have been set up under ICAR, which comes under the agriculture ministry and not the HRD ministry,” he said.

Title: PWD environment library to come up in Trichy by March
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

PWD is all set to start first of its kind environment library in a portion of existing staff training institut... Read More

TRICHY: The public works department (PWD) is all set to launch a first-of-its-kind environment library in Trichy by the end of next month. While the state government had allocated Rs 5 lakh in the first phase for the library, a seminar and exhibition hall will also be raised in the coming weeks.

Government funds for the project came along with ecological restoration of eight water bodies in the state apart from conducting descriptive study, assessment of pollution and preparation of detailed project report in August last year. The library is being raised on a portion of the existing staff training institute building of PWD in Trichy. Saying that the seminar will be conducted once a week by inviting experts in environment studies, a senior PWD official said the library will be helpful for officials to know various aspects of a project and environmental implications.

While PWD has started asking for environmental clearance for most projects it sanctions of late, the official said there has been very less awareness among people about this in the area. Further, there are also very few avenues to refer to the legal aspects related to environmental clearance. College students too can make use of the facility, said the official.

Title: No response to NMC’s auction of 89 properties
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik Municipal Corporation’s (NMC) auction of properties, which belong to property tax defaulters, received poor response on Thursday.

A total of 89 properties were to go under the hammer, but the civic body did not receive a single bid. It was the NMC’s second attempt at auctioning properties of the defaulters.

Last month, the NMC had put up another 44 properties for auction, but then too, it did not receive any response. Now, the civic body has decided to change ownership of these 133 properties on the 7/12 extract.

A civic official said they will soon start the process to change the ownership and will approach tehsildar to complete the process.

“As per norms, the civic body may change the ownership if it does not receive response to auction of properties of tax defaulters for two times. We may take the decision following approval from the standing committee,” he said.

Earlier, the NMC had set a property tax collection target of Rs 218 crore for the current financial year 2019-20, but has so far managed to collect only Rs 133 crore. Hence, the civic administration has revised the property tax collection target to Rs 140 crore.

Municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game recently presented the civic draft budget for the financial year 2020-21 to the standing committee for its approval. In the budget, the NMC has set a property tax collection target of Rs 170 crore.

In the last financial year, 2018-19, the NMC had collected property tax amounting to Rs 117.12 crore. It was for the first time that the NMC’s property tax collection target had touched Rs 100 crore.

“There are total 1.92 lakh tax defaulters having dues from Rs 4,000 to Rs 1 lakh. The civic administration has served notices to 1.85 lakh property tax defaulters, giving them a deadline of 21 days to pay their taxes,” a civic official said.

Title: No new schemes for Telangana in budget
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Telangana CM K Chandrasekhar Rao

HYDERABAD: No new schemes will be announced in the upcoming state, chief minister K Chandrashekhar Rao decided in areview meeting on Thursday. He has also asked the officials to be rational with the allocation of the budget as the economy is not showing a progressive trend.

During the last budget session, the CM had said that he had many schemes in mind for the state. But according to sources, the plans have been snubbed due to the condition of the economy.

The CM has asked the officials to not announce any infrastructural projects like building roads and continue to complete the old work. Schemes like Rythu Bandhu and loan waiver for farmers will see adequate budget allocation for the farewell of the residents of state.

Title: Future imperfect? JNTUH faces staff crunch for BTech courses
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

File photo of Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University

HYDERABAD: Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University , Hyderabad (JNTUH) is facing a dearth of faculty members who can teach students new courses in emerging technologies that are set to be introduced from the academic year 2020-21.

Ahead of the affiliation process, the JNTUH approved four new BTech courses in artificial intelligence (AI), computer science & information technology, computer science & business systems and information technology & engineering. While the state government has plans to train about 30,000 students in AI-based skills, shortage of faculty members to teach these emerging technologies has emerged as a major challenge for JNTUH.

“We may start 10 new courses but where are the people to teach those courses? The state government needs to support a large-scale faculty development programme so that the gap can be filled,” said Jayesh Ranjan, in-charge vice-chancellor, JNTUH.

Last year, apart from Indian Institute of Technology, Hyderabad (IIT-H) that had 20 seats in a full-fledged BTech course in AI, there were only 84 seats in two colleges affiliated to JNTUH that offer a BTech course in AI. This year, although the number of seats is set to increase, the number of faculty members teaching these courses is in double digits.

“An MTech degree or PhD degree does not qualify someone to be an assistant professor or an associate professor. Right now, with an MTech, they become assistant professors. Teachers have to be qualified. They should receive a six months certification before becoming assistant professors in the next two years,” said BVR Mohan Reddy, executive chairman of Cyient Ltd., who also headed a panel that drafted the short-term and long-term perspective for the All India Council of Technical Education (AICTE).

The Telangana State Council of Higher Education (TSCHE) is planning to introduce a large faculty development programme to meet the demand for teachers who can teach these emerging technologies to students. In order to do that, the TSCHE has decided to seek help from coveted institutions such as IITH, International Institute of Information Technology, National Institute of Technology-Warangal and Birla Institute of Technology.

“There is a need to shift from mere classroom teaching to developing creative talent. We can strengthen faculty through capacity building activities and close interaction with industrial organisations by sending them to companies for a few days for on-ground experience,” said Chitra Ramachandran, chief special secretary (education).

Title: Ahmedabad: Loan shark booked for threats, extortion
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Sardarnagar police on Wednesday booked one Jay Tekwani for illegal money-lending and criminal intimidation, based on a complaint filed by Krunal Lasiyani, 30, of Sardarnagar alleging that Tekwani had been threatening him for recovery of money. “We have booked the accused under sections 294 (b),506 (2), 507, 114 IPC and under Gujarat Money-Lenders Act. We will soon arrest him,” said a senior police official.

According to the FIR, Lasiyani had returned to Gujarat after working in Dubai about three years ago, and began working as a broker at Choka Bazar. To expand his business, he first first borrowed Rs 10 lakh and then Rs 30 lakh from Tekwani at a monthly interest of 7%. He claimed that he had already paid back Rs 40,00,000 but Tekwani maintains that Lasiyani owes him another Rs 45,00,000.

Lasiyani has stated that he used to pay his daily instalments of Rs 10,000 at the office of one Umesh Goplani at A ward in Sardarnagar. After running into losses he failed to pay the daily instalments, but by that time he had already paid back Rs 40,00,000. However, Tekwani told him that he will have to pay another Rs 45,00,000 within 15 days.

“On February 25, Lasiyani’s friend Jaggi Chelani called up Lasiyani and said that if he didn’t pay the money, Tekwani will act within two days,” said a police official. Before this, allegedly, Tekwani had threatened to break Lasiyani’s legs.

Title: Gujarat: Sparks fly over inordinate delay in Narmada canal work
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Narmada canal network in Gujarat

AHMEDABAD: Deputy chief minister Nitin Patel on Thursday blamed Congress leaders Sonia Gandhi and Ahmed Patel for the delay in completion of the Narmada canal network in the state. He was participating in a discussion on Narmada canal network and sub-canals.

Congress MLA from Morbi , Brijesh Merja said that the BJP government has been neglecting farmers from Saurashtra. “Due to the delay in canal works, farmers have been suffering,” he said.

Reacting to this, the deputy CM said the the Congress government at the Centre had not permitted installation of the gates, leading to delay in the work.

The leader of opposition in the assembly, Paresh Dhanani, claimed that the delay was caused by the then BJP government in Madhya Pradesh. Dhanani said the MP government had objected to giving permission to installation of the gates. Taking it further, Nitin Patel said that it was former Union minister Saifuddin Soz who had denied permission, after which the then chief minister Narendra Modi sat on a fast.

Later, Patel said that one person is not giving his land for the construction of the canal, leading to the delay. He said the government will take action against this person.

Title: 2 Maha students back from Wuhan; 195 from China, Japan
Content: Mumbai/New Delhi: Two PhD students from Maharashtra, who chose to stay back in Wuhan when the first batch of Indians was evacuated in January after the coronavirus outbreak, landed in Delhi on Thursday.In a major rescue exercise, India on Thursday evacuated 195 nationals from Japan and China. While 119 people were evacuated from cruise ship Diamond Princess in Japan, 76 more were brought back from Wuhan by a relief military aircraft. India also evacuated 36 foreign nationals from Wuhan and five from Japan.Students Girish Patil (29) and Chandradip Jadhav (29), studying at College of Materials and Metallurgy, Wuhan University of Science and Technology, had opted to stay back in Wuhan—the epicentre of the outbreak—due to financial constraints. From Delhi airport, the students, along with other Indians from Wuhan, were sent to the quarantine centre at Chawla camp for 14 days.Patil and Jadhav, both residents of Dhule, were among the bunch of six Indian students who stayed back in the university’s dormitory. One of the six said now the university has officially extended the holidays for a few months. They also gave them a no objection certificate for evacuation, he added.Meanwhile, the special Air India flight that brought back 119 Indian and five foreign nationals from Diamond Princess cruise liner early on Thursday includes two Mira Road residents. Mira Road’s Dinesh Thakkar was at the forefront of the effort to get back his daughter Sonali who worked as a security personnel on Diamond Princess. “My daughter spoke to us briefly on landing and after reaching the army quarantine spot in Haryana,” said Dinesh.“The evacuation has underscored the priority India attaches to the welfare of its citizens wherever they are,” said foreign secretary Harsh Shringla. He added that India was “happy to have been able to assist our friends from Bangladesh, Myanmar, Maldives and other friendly countries from our neighbourhood and beyond in the evacuations from both China and Japan”. Of the 36 foreign nationals evacuated from Wuhan, 23 were from Bangladesh, six from China, two each from Myanmar and Maldives and one each from South Africa, US and Madagascar. Of the five from Japan, there were two from Sri Lanka and one each from Nepal, South Africa and Peru.The Indian relief flight to Wuhan carried 15,000kg of medical assistance comprising masks, gloves and other emergency medical equipment. These supplies were delivered by an IAF C-17 special flight, which landed in Wuhan late on Wednesday evening. The medical supplies followed Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s letter to President Xi Jinping offering assistance to deal with the crisis. “The medical supplies will help augment the China’s efforts to control the outbreak of this infection which has been declared as a public health emergency by the World Health Organisation,’’ the MEA said in a statement.Some of India’s neighbours such as Bangladesh and Sri Lanka had sought help from India to evacuate their citizens. The government said assistance to them was in keeping with India’s neighbourhood first policy. India has until now operated three relief flights from Wuhan, evacuating 723 Indian nationals and 43 foreign nationals. In the case of Japan, a special Air India flight landed in New Delhi from Tokyo on Thursday, bringing back 119 Indian nationals—113 crew members and six passengers—who were on board the Diamond Princess which docked off Yokohama in Japan. “In line with India’s neighbourhood first policy and Indo-Pacific vision, the special flight also evacuated five foreign nationals—two Sri Lankans, one Nepalese, one South African and one Peruvian. All the evacuees will undergo a 14-day quarantine at the facility set up by the Indian Army in Manesar, Haryana,” the MEA said.Three Indian crew members did not board the special flight and conveyed their wish, according to the government, to continue their stay on board the cruise ship to complete the period of extended quarantine put in place by the Japan government.“Out of the total 138 Indian nationals originally on board the Diamond Princess, 16 Indian crew members have tested positive for coronavirus 2019 and are receiving necessary medical care and treatment at onshore medical facilities in Japan. Embassy of India in Tokyo has established contact with these individuals and is continuously following-up on their recovery,’’ the foreign ministry said.

Title: Madhya Pradesh high court asks govt to ban single-use plastic
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: In a landmark judgment, the Madhya Pradesh high court on Thursday asked the state government to order schools and colleges to stop use of plastic, and directed industries to take immediate steps to stop production and use of single-use plastic.The order, issued by a division bench at Gwalior , states, “The state and its instrumentalities shall issue directives ensuring manufacturing and marketing of carrybags and packets made of non-plastic biodegradable material on highly subsidized rates to be affordable to the common man. For this purpose, the state should encourage small-scale industry to manufacture and market such bags/packets by setting up necessary plants in all districts of MP.” It was in response to a PIL filed by social activist and lawyer Gaurav Pandey .The court suggests adding lessons on adverse effects of use of plastic/polythene in school curriculum to increase awareness among children. It urges people to stop using non-biodegradable plastic.The court also asked the state government to set up water dispensers in Gwalior for people. “The state should set up single-use plastic bottles crushing machines in adequate numbers,” the court ordered, besides asking the government to install recycling plants. The court directed each stakeholder to submit their independent progress reports through collectors every three months before the principal registrar of the court to ensure compliance with the order.“As the order is passed in the interest of public at large, it is expected that the directions shall be complied with in letter and spirit with utmost promptitude,” it adds.The court asked print and electronic media to propagate awareness among citizens that use of plastic has become a national problem. “The media should create an atmosphere in society against the use of plastic,” it said .

Title: Gujarat: Lakhpat throws up more pre-Harappan proof
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

The bangles that have been uncovered were made of shells, indicating they were procured from the nearby seasho... Read More

RAJKOT: Archaeologists have got more clinching evidence of a thriving human settlement dating to pre-Harappan times in Khatia village close to Lakhpat in Kutch district.

Exactly a year after excavating 25 burial sites out of the total around 250, the archaeologists found skeletal remains of a woman’s hands, which had bangles, from one of three additional graves dug out since February 17.

One hand had 16 bangles and the other three. All bangles were made of shells, which indicates that they were procured from the nearby seashore.

Moreover, the previously excavated sites had cemeteries made of small-size stones while a few excavated recently are made of big slabs of stones. The burial sites are estimated to be around 4,600 to 5,000 years old.

Last year, they had found a human skeleton from one of the burial sites.

Some pottery items were also found from the graves. “This shows that there may have been a tradition to bury all the belongings of the dead with their bodies,” said Subhash Bhanderi, head of archaeological department of Kutch University .

“We are also trying to study the reason for use of different stones to build graves. Was it some cultural change?” he added.

What is important, according to archaeologists, is the direction of the graves found last year and the ones excavated in the last 10 days as it would help understand the change of culture and their eras.

“The 25-odd burial sites found last year were made in east-west direction with the head pointing eastwards. Of the three dug out recently, two are south direction while one is in an unusual north east-south-west direction,” said Bhanderi.

The present excavation is being jointly done by Kutch university and Kerala University and state archaeologists.

Dr Rajesh SV, a faculty from Kerala University said, “Detailed studies including that of DNA, geochemistry and proper dating of the sediments, bones, pottery and shells will be done to know the age, climate as well as ecology of the people residing in the vicinity.”

Scientists from Jawaharlal Nehru University, Dharvad University and experts coming from Texas, US, are expected to visit this site soon. These are experts in the field of anthropology, archaeology and DNA testing etc.

Title: Experts to decide on GEP indicators at WII on March 5
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Dehradun: Environmentalists, scientists and academicians will gather at Wildlife Institute of India to decide the indicators of ‘ Gross Environment Product ’ (GEP) on March 5. Doon-based environmentalist Anil Joshi while announcing the event on Thursday said, “GEP can help us analyse how developmental projects are causing environmental degradation.”

Notably, Joshi will spearhead the entire initiative at Wildlife Institute of India. The high-level conference will be attended by Krishnaswamy Vijay Raghavan, Principal Scientific Advisor (PSA) to the Prime Minister and directors of leading institutions like FRI, Wadia Institute, and others.

Uttarakhand has been the torchbearer in attracting country’s focus towards measuring ecological development of a state along with its economic development, an order was also passed in year 2010 to have GEP concept by the High Court.

As per TOI sources, GEP was initially accepted by the former governments of Uttarakhand and simultaneously, a petition has approved by High Court also supporting the concept of GEP. The State has also been directed by High Court to follow such appeal of Dr. Anil P. Joshi though nothing has been done in this regards in past ten years.

After almost a decade, once again GEP has come to fore with experts mulling to bring ecosystem at the core of development of country.

“We have to develop in tandem to the eco-system because eco-system cannot develop in tandem to us. Our economy should be seen growing with its ecology not alone otherwise we all are heading to devastation.” he added.

At the conference, indicators to decide GEP will be zeroed in upon and also stratergy will be formulated to pass on the GEP concept across the country and in each state of nation.

Current growth measure is totally lopsided as per scientists and environmentalists as it focuses upon economic growths only. “It does not account status of various resources depleted or added annually. The later is equally important for survival and sustainable growth.” added Joshi.

To strike a balance between economy and ecology development, Anil Joshi under the aegis of his organisation HESCO would ask the experts to include the quality and quantify of – forest, soil, water and air – as the prime indicators of GEP of any state as per TOI sources.

Title: Residents seek more such eviction drives to decongest city
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Trichy: Residents in Trichy have urged the city police and Trichy City Corporation to extend the eviction drive carried out in the Gandhi Market on Thursday to other congested parts of the city as well, since the authorities have failed in constituting the street vending committee and encroachments are ever increasing in most of the commercial streets and on arterial roads.

“Now the roads in Gandhi Market look spacious. Not sure how long the city police will keep the street like this,” K Ramachandran, a trader in Gandhi Market, said. The corporation said that a section of street vendors are intentionally derailing the plan to constitute the street vending committee. The committee to be formed as per the Tamil Nadu Street Vendors 2015 Act will regulate street vendors by earmarking no vending zones, which mean that hawkers will not be allowed to operate from such zones. Members of the hawkers will be elected to the committee to provide amenities and financial support to the street vendors at the vending zones where they will be permitted to function.

However, the local body’s attempts since 2018 are being legally challenged and stopped by a section of street vendors who claim that the civic body has not completed the enumeration of hawkers across the city. The corporation’s call that the enumeration process can be completed after forming the vending committee is not accepted by the street vendors. “Eviction drive from the corporation and city police near Gandhi market is a welcome move. We urge the authorities to make sure that the roads are meant only for vehicular and pedestrian movements,” S Pushpavanam, secretary, Consumer Protection Council, Tamil Nadu, said.

Title: Need strict laws on e-waste disposal: Experts
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

HYDERABAD: Hazardous metals found in e-waste are polluting the soil and water, said experts on Thursday at a seminar on ‘E-Waste Management- Sustainable Development’ organised by The Federation of Telangana Chambers of Commerce and Industry ( FTCCI ).

Kumar Pathak, an environmental engineer with the TPCB , said, “The greatest danger today is the unscientific disposal of e-waste. Hazardous substances, especially heavy metals such as cadmium, mercury and lead, can pollute the environment and have detrimental impact on health if not disposed responsibly.”

Pathak said that pressure must be put on manufacturers to reduce the use of hazardous material to lesser than 0.1%. He said, “While there are collection centres for e-waste many do not meet the standards prescribed by the Central Pollution Control Board.”

J Koteswara Rao, associate faculty member at National Institute for Micro, Small & Medium Enterprises said that the leeching of heavy metals into the soil and groundwater is concerning as even minimal cadmium could pollute 600 cubic metres of water.

Speaking about the amount of waste heading to the unorganised sector, K Srinivas, V-P of Ramky Enviro Engineers Limited, said, “At most 40% of e-waste is recovered by untrained players. Many workers burn e-waste, resulting in toxic fumes.”

Title: AUDA focuses on roads, flyovers and drainage
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: By keeping traffic management its top priority, Ahmedabad Urban Development Authority ( AUDA ) aims to finish construction of four flyovers by 2021. With a project cost of Rs 105 cr the flyovers on SP Ring Road, at Dehgam, Sanathal, Shantipura and Zundal will be ready for public use by next year.

AUDA has also proposed two additional flyovers — at Bhat canal and Bhat-Apollo — and an overbridge at Ghuma railway line.

An initial grant of Rs 5 crore will be provided this year said AUDA chairman Vijay Nehra. On Wednesday, the AUDA chairman presented a budget of Rs 929 crore, which was 101% higher than last year. An additional Rs 289.76 crore was budgeted for footpaths, RCC roads and storm water lines.

Title: Three shops gutted in Naubasta
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

KANPUR: Three make-shift shops were gutted in a major fire that broke out at Naubasta area of the city on late Wednesday night. Property worth several lakhs was destroyed, however, fortunately no casualty was reported.

According to the police, the fire broke in a make-shift garment shop and soon spread to other adjacent garment shop and a vegetable shop near Doosri Puliya in Naubasta. The locals alerted the Police control room following which several fire-tenders were pressed into service. It took more than an hour for the fire personnel to douse the flame completely, said inspector Naubasta Ashish Shukla.

The exact cause of fire has not been found yet, he added.

According to the police, prima facie it appeared that a bidi or cigarette thrown in garbage dump in the area caused the fire. The two garments shop belonged to Shalu and Anil Gupta, while the vegetable shop belonged to one Santosh Gupta .

Title: City-based professor visits European Space Agency
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Nashik: An assistant professor of a city-based engineering college recently visited the European Space Agency (ESA) in Germany

Jaydeep Shah (36) was one of the 37 space enthusiasts who were selected to join the ESA’s Mission Control programme to watch the launch of Solar Orbiter. It is an annual outreach programme of the ESA.

The two-day event was scheduled on February 5 and 6. Shah could only attend the lectures and the technical tour on the first day as the second day’s event was postponed to February 10.

“A social space event gives an unique opportunity to interact with mission specialists, flight directors and the engineering team. It was the best experience of my life. Unfortunately, I missed the launch of the Solar Orbiter and media briefing due to my pre-booked tickets but the whole experience was thrilling,” said Shah. He was the only participant from the Asia Pacific to join the programme. The agency had reviewed his social media pages of the past seven years, on the basis of which he was selected for the event.

“I showed them my 36,000 tweets, 5,000 posts on Facebook and 1,990 posts on LinkedIn, all related to astronomy,” added Shah.

“The ESA had provided a link in January on their Twitter platform for a day where hundreds of people applied for their candidature. The agency had selected only 13 candidates from countries like the United Kingdom, the USA, Spain, the Netherlands, Austria, Serbia etc. The others were from Germany,” Shah said.

Originally from Gujarat, Shah teaches electric vehicles and smart grid at K K Wagh College of Engineering. Shah had designed the subject of smart grid for the SPPU.

Title: Mastermind of forest guard recruitment exam fraud held
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Dehradun: A review officer of the state public service commission was held on Wednesday for alleged involvement in the cheating scam in forest guard recruitment exam . The accused, identified as Kuldeep Rathi, allegedly took money from the candidates for helping them with solutions during the examination. "After Sudhir Kumar and Mukesh Saini, we have arrested Kuldeep Rathi in this case. More people are under our scanner and further arrests would be made soon," said Dilip Singh Kunwar, Pauri SSP. Notably, several unemployed youths have been protesting over cheating in forest guard recruitment exams.

Title: Community rivalry may mar Kalsotsav
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Bicholim: Uncertanity prevails over the annual Kalsotsav festival of the Maya Kelbai Devasthan in Mayem, Bicholim, which is scheduled to begin on Friday, with the two opposing communities vying to host the celebrations unable to reach a compromise.

The groups met the Bicholim deputy collector Jyoti Kumari on Thursday, and the final call on whether the festival will commence will be taken on Friday. It is scheduled to take place from February 28 to March 7. Bicholim mamlatdar Pravinjay Pandit had passed an order last week that the Kalsotsav festivities will be hosted by the Parab Gaonkar community. The other group, comprising Naik Gaonkar, Gosavi Gaonkar, Gawas Gaonkar and Karbotkar Gaonkar communities, had said that the mamlatdar’s order was one-sided.

“The celebration of Kalsotsav is the right of every community and not just the Parab Gaonkar community,” they said. Last year, the authorities had cancelled the festival, fearing a law and order problem.

Title: Mumbai: Now, drive at 60kmph on JJ flyover, but just 35 on curves
Content:
On JJ flyover, low speed limit of 30kmph ensured zero fatalities in 2019

MUMBAI: Speed limit on JJ flyover in south Mumbai has been increased to 60kmph, with a maximum of 35kmph on its curves, following repeated complaints of congestion. Speed limits on 10 other arterial roads have also been revised by traffic police in accordance with a notification issued by the Ministry of Road Transport and Highways (MoRTH).The MoRTH guidelines give an absolute limit of 70kmph in urban areas. So, traffic police have brought down the speed limit from 80kmph to 70kmph on the highways within Mumbai limits. Lalbaug flyover , Aurora bridge at Matunga and Jagannath Shankar Sheth flyover at Dadar have also been assigned a speed limit of 70kmph.“But on Marine Drive, we decided to assign a speed limit a little lower than 70kmph. This stretch is extensively used by pedestrians,” said joint commissioner, traffic, Madhukar Pandey. The maximum speed on Marine Drive has been fixed at 65 kmph.Data-backed research has shown pedestrian deaths declining at lower vehicle speeds, transport experts say. In Mumbai, pedestrians have been the biggest casualty of road crashes in 2017 and 2018. On JJ flyover, low speed limit of 30kmph ensured zero fatalities in 2019. “JJ flyover has dangerous curves that have claimed lives, particularly at Mandovi Post Office,” said an officer.However, Ranjit Gadgil of the non-profit, Parisar, said, “The upward revision of speed limits is completely unjustified. Speed not only increases the chance of a crash but also increases the severity.”Experts suggest doing a speed assessment on Mumbai roads before fixing speed limits. “In Bogota, Colombia, all historical crashes were mapped on arterial roads and this was followed by speed assessment at different times of the day under the Bloomberg Initiative for Global Road Safety... All the arterial streets had maximum speeds of 60kmph and these were reduced to 50kmph. Six months later, there was a huge difference. Twenty five percent road fatalities had fallen and travel during peak hours had increased by a mere 14 seconds," said Dhawal Ashar, transport planner with WRI India. In urban areas where potential conflicts arise between vehicles and pedestrians, fixing speed limits of 30 kmph can result in 90 percent chances of survival, he added.

Title: Osmania University launches patent search facility
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Osmania University

SECUNDERABAD: Osmania University ( OU ) launched a patent search facility ‘TotalPatentOne’ that will act as a database for students to get hands-on training in intellectual property rights (IPR).

OU registrar, Prof Gopal Reddy, said that OU is the only state university in Telangana to provide such a facility to researchers and teachers.

Prof GB Reddy, coordinator, UPE Centre of Intellectual Property Rights and Patent Facilitation Services, OU informed that many more programmes would be conducted to spread awareness on IPR and for coordinating with other research institutions and regulatory bodies. tnn

Title: Jumbo farewell to Padmanabhan
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Elephants of Guruvayur Devaswom bid adieu to Guruvayur Padmanabhan

THRISUR: Vivek Ramachandran along with his wife Vrinda Vijayan flew down from Abu Dhabi to Kochi on Thursday morning to attend a family function in Palakkad. But Ramachandran tweaked his travel plan as he wanted to catch a last glimpse of his ‘best friend’ — Guruvayur Padmanabhan .

Such was the popularity of the 84-year-old tusker, which died on Wednesday, that thousands of people from all walks of life poured into Punnathur Kotta , the elephant camp of Guruvayur temple, to pay their last respects to the most-revered elephant in state. People, with folded hands, were seen chanting ‘Narayana, Narayana’ as they paid rich tributes to Lord Krishna’s ‘favourite son’. With tears welling up, many realized that it was the last time they were seeing their beloved tusker. Education minister C Raveendranath, temple committees, organizations, establishments and individuals paid their last respects to the elephant.

Ramachandran said he was in a conference in Abu Dhabi when the news of Padmanabhan’s death reached him. “I have known Padmanabhan for 42 years. So, I was determined to see him one last time. As I caught up with the truck carrying Padmanabhan’s carcass, I felt like my best friend was being taken away,” said an emotional Ramachandran, who works in Swiss Bank, Abu Dhabi.

Thrissur wore a mournful look on Thursday with posters and flex boards bearing the photos of Padmanabhan appearing across the city and outskirts. Guruvayur Devaswom chairman K B Mohandas said other elephants belonging to Guruvayur Devaswom and the security guards of Punnathur Kotta gave a ‘guard of honour’ to Padmanabhan.

“Punnathur Kotta witnessed huge flow of crowd after the news of Padmanabhan’s demise spread. When Padmanabhan’s carcass was taken to the elephant crematorium at Perumthode under Malayattoor forest division, hundreds lined up along the route and offered floral tributes,” Mohandas said. He said the devaswom will honour Padmanabhan by installing his statue on its premises. “The administrative committee will soon take a decision in this regard,” he said.

At Perumthode, a group of veterinarians led by Dr Divakaran Nair, prof (retd), Veterinary College, Mannuthy, conducted the postmortem.

Assistant conservator of forests, Thrissur, P M Prabhu, said, “Presently, forest department has taken the tusks of the elephant. After completing official formalities and on getting the order of chief wildlife warden, they would be handed over to Guruvayur Devaswom.”

Title: State to explore brackish water aquaculture parks
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Chennai: With marine exports touching 1.16 lakh tonnes and shrimp being a major contributor, Tamil Nadu aims to expand brackish water aquaculture sector with a feasibility study in six months at the potential sites across coastal districts.

Realising that there is plenty of unused fallow land unsuitable for other purposes, the government is now planning to develop shrimp farming in these areas. The state has a potential area of 56,000 hectares of brackish water resources in the form of estuaries, backwaters and creeks. At present, 1,892 brackish water farms are registered.

There is a considerable growth of shrimp farming in the state since early 1980s with Penaeus monodon and Penaeus indicus as the major culturable prawn species.

After coastal aquaculture authority was set up and the rules covering the shrimp farming sector in addition to introduction of Specific Pathogen Free Penaeus Vannamei (white legged shrimp), has turned shrimp farming into a major commercial enterprise as it is a major seafood export earner.

The feasibility study will identify the revenue details of the unused fallow lands suitable for aquaculture, create a land bank, identify high potential zones with requisite hydro biological and chemical parameters and create a roadmap. "The aquaculture parks will be more like a SIPCOT model (for industries), where we will be providing basic infrastructure and people can invest. It will have brood stock management and a hatchery," said fisheries director G S Sameeran.

The Central Institute of Brackishwater Aquaculture (CIBA) has begun a study on coastline mapping for aquaculture and submitted reports for the districts of Tiruvarur, Thanjavur, Cuddalore, Villupuram, Pudukkottai and Tuticorin. The CIBA study found that hardly 10% of the potential area has been developed for brackish water aquaculture. The resource mapping used tools like remote sensing, GIS, and physical parameters like salinity and nutrient value. There are vast unused resources which are yet to be tapped for development of sustainable aquaculture.

Once established, the parks will see shrimp and other diversified culture varieties of commercial importance such as sea bass, cobia, silver pampano, milkfish and bivalve culture in accordance what’s suitable for the site.

Essential infrastructure facilities required to develop the parks, such as common water intake and drainage reservoir, effluent treatment plant, power, pre-processing facility and laboratories will be identified by the authorities. "Identification of land is of utmost importance given the pollution caused by aquaculture wastewater," Poovulagin Nanbargal’s G Sundarrajan said. With its 1,076km long coastline, the state is also planning to frame a policy for land leasing to see a holistic growth in brackish water aquaculture.

Title: Hyderabad schools conduct teacher training programmes in AI
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Schools affiliated to the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) are much ahead in terms of upgrading teacher skills in artificial intelligence (AI) from the ensuing academic year.

According to sources, many city schools such as Delhi Public School , Nacharam, Pallavi Model School, Jubilee Hills Public School , Sanskriti School are contemplating introducing AI as a skill-subject for class 8 and class 9 students.

The Birla Open Minds International Schools, Hyderabad conducted a session on ‘demystifying teaching on artificial intelligence’ for its teachers earlier this month. Similarly, Pallavi Model School became the first school in the city to establish an AI lab at its Gandipet campus.

The CBSE conducted training programmes for teachers in a phased manner. In Hyderabad, AI-enabled SEWA programme was conducted by IBM-trained experts in select schools with Atal Tinkering Labs. The IBM conducted two-and-a-half day training programmes for teachers to acquaint them with the AI curriculum.

The CBSE board, in collaboration with IBM, also held five programmes for students selected from each school and their mentors which included AI-thon, UnBoxAI – a workshop on select areas on AI deployment, rapid prototyping and capstone project with mentoring and showcase.
