Title: ‘Smart city scheme will spur industrial growth’
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Salem: A three-day international symposium on realizing smart cities got underway at the Periyar University here on Thursday. Organized jointly by the Periyar University, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN (Association of Southeast Asian Nations) and East Asian nations, the event was attended by experts from Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia, Japan and Laos.

Vice-chancellor P Kolandaivel said, “Salem is both a connecting hub of the state and an access point to northern India. The smart city scheme will spur the industrial growth by meeting the public’s ever-growing requirements.”

Salem municipal corporation commissioner R Sadheesh said efforts were on to harness green energy by installing rooftop solar, solar trees and LED streetlights. “The smart city scheme would ensure two-tier bus stands, smart parking, intelligent traffic management, smart roads, multi-level car parking facilities and revamping of public space in the city.”

Title: How soak pits recharged Chirawa groundwater
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Jaipur: Even a few years ago, people in Chirawa block in Jhunjhunu district were facing health problems due to the presence of excessive fluoride in groundwater. Today, with smart usage of water and its conservation, lives of people have drastically changed making them healthy and self-sufficient.

With the help of NGO Ramkrishna Jaidayal Dalmia Sewa Sansthan, people living in 88 villages of Chirawa block have built 20-feet deep soak pits in their houses to collect waste water from kitchen and bathrooms that flow into the ground and help in recharging groundwater.

Head of Shivpura Gram Vikas Samiti Sanjay Sharma said in addition to making soak pits, they have also started rainwater harvesting. “We dug a ‘kund’ or pit in every house to store around 20,000 litres of rainwater from the roofs. When the kund overflows, water is collected in a pond dug far away from the house through a connection. The water from the pond is used for farming,” said Sanjay.

In all, around 3,400 kunds have been constructed in the Chirawa village till now.

The villagers have now moved towards low water crop farming. Bhupendra Paliwal, the project manager of Ramkrishna Jaidayal Dalmia Sewa Sansthan, said they had made people to understand about the usage of low water farming.

“Earlier, farmers used to grow onions, cotton or wheat and needed a lot of water. We asked them to switch to mustard, barley and gram. We have installed piezometers in villages to calculate the level of groundwater in the region and for how many years it will be sufficient. Many signboards were installed in villages to generate awareness about water usage,” said Bhupendra.

Convincing villagers about rainwater harvesting and need to conserve water wasn’t easy. Vikram Katewa, a member of Raghuveer Gram Vikas Samiti from Raghuveer village, said initially people were apprehensive about it.

Vikram explained, “When NGOs approached us, we called a village meeting to discuss the plans. No one agreed, but after some persistence, they agreed to build three kunds in the village. Looking at the fruitful results after monsoon, people were ready to spend to construct kunds.” He said before water harvesting, villagers were suffering from dental fluorosis and joint pain after 40 years of age. “A 40 year-old used to look like a 60-year-old. The older generation of the village still have yellow teeth but the younger generation is healthier. This gives us relief,” said Vikram.

Title: Govt defends land allotment in HC, hearing posted to March 4
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Vijayawada: The state government on Thursday told the Andhra Pradesh high court that petitions seeking cancelation of the government decision to allot 1251.5 acre land in capital villages for affordable houses scheme was unconstitutional.

Advocate general Sriram argued that the petitioners were merely obstructing to government schemes. He said the petitioners’ argument that the government schemes will change demography in the capital city area was unconstitutional.

The AG said that the petitioners were objecting to the government’ decision of allocating house pattas to the weaker sections. He said the petitioners had maintained silence when the earlier government undertook a housing programme for the weaker sections in 2017.

The AG argued that the state government has been vested with the power as per the constitutional obligation under Part IV cases. “The petitioners cannot decide who has to be their neighbours and we are only following the scheme that was followed in 2017,” he said.

The AG informed the court that the distribution of house pattas will be held on Ugadi.

The HC bench headed by chief justice J K Maheswari questioned the AG on what grounds the government had alloted land to the weaker sections in Amaravati when it is not implementing APCRDA Act and developing Amaravati. He also asked the AG to file a counter.

Further hearing will take place on March 4.

Title: Man trying to sell tusks arrested in Vadodara
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: The forest department has arrested a man who was trying to sell two elephant tusks in the city. Vinayak Purohit, a resident of Subhanpura, was nabbed after forest officials received information about his plans to sell the tusks. The forest officials set up a trap and sent a decoy customer to meet Purohit on Wednesday.

The meeting was arranged at the house of Vinoo Darbar who is a friend of Purohit. As soon as Purohit showed the tusks, forest officials raided the spot and nabbed him. They also seized the tusks that weigh about 2.5 kilograms each and are three-and-half-feet long. Purohit wanted to sell them off for Rs 1.5 crore.

Forest officials questioned Purohit about the source of the tusks. “He claimed that the tusks were part of his family’s ancestral property. He said that his grandfather had brought the tusks from Africa in 1964. But we are verifying his claims,” said Nidhi Dave, range forest officer, Vadodara. Forest officials suspect that Purohit, who works as a driver, may be part of some gang that deals in elephant tusks or he may be connected with poachers too.

When asked why he wanted to sell off the tusks suddenly, Purohit couldn’t give satisfactory reply to the forest officials. The tusks will now be examined to ascertain if they are authentic. While Darbar is absconding, a local court has sent Purohit to judicial custody.

Title: Priest, two sons arrested for killing chief priest in Pilibhit
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

PILIBHIT: A priest and his two sons were arrested for killing the chief priest of Balaji temple in Bisalpur town of Pilibhit district, police said on Thursday.

Ramesh Chandra Mishra and his sons Devesh Kumar and Bhuvnesh Kumar, hailing from Charkhaula under Bilsanda police station, were arrested for hacking chief priest Vishnu Saran, whose body was found in a room on the temple premises on Tuesday morning.

Divulging details, superintendent of police Abhishek Dixit said the accused, along with his family, who had been living on the temple premises for over past 10 years, was envy of Saran for the prominence he was given by the temple management committee in the affairs of the temple.

“According to Chandra, the committee, Balaji trust, had given him ultimatum to leave the temple by March. This filled him with vengeance as he was set to lose his service due to Saran. Meanwhile, on Tuesday morning, when Saran allegedly refused to give the key of toilet to Chandra an argument ensued between them, following which Chandra and his two sons hacked Saran to death and the trio, along with other family members fled the temple on motorcycles,” said the SP.

“They used to wander from one place to the other in a bid to evade arrest. However, they were arrested from Bhandaria Crossing in Bilsanda on Thursday morning, and sent to jail,” the SP added.

Title: Quack held in Krishnagiri
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

KRISHNAGIRI: Police on Thursday arrested a 48-year-old quack, who is also a panchayat ward member, at Anandhur village near Pochampalli in the district.

According to the Kallavi police, A Sardhar had completed only Class XII but he has been practicing as an allopath doctor for more than a decade. “He was running a clinic at Anandhur and treated patients,” a police officer said.

Sardhar had prescribed medicines and administered injections to patients who came to his clinic. Following several complaints, police arrested Sardhar, who confessed to the crime.

A case under Section 420 (cheating) of Indian Penal Code and Section 15 of Indian Medical Council Act, 1956 has been registered against Sardhar, who was remanded in judicial custody at Salem prison for 15 days.

Title: Pakistan team to reach Ajmer today, security tightened
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Tight security arrangements have been made for 808 Urs in Ajmer

AJMER: Around 260 members from Pakistan are expected to reach Ajmer on Friday to participate in the 808th Urs of Khwaja Moinuddin Chisty .

The district administration on Thursday deputed public relations and liaising officials for the delegation. Special security measures have also been made at railway station and at Central Girls’ Government School at Naya Bazaar where the delegation will stay.

The Pakistan delegation, as per officials, will reach New Delhi by a special train on Friday morning and from there another train will take them to Ajmer and will reach late in the evening. Platform number one will be vacated when the train arrives in Ajmer and no one will be allowed to enter the premises. There will be high security on the railway station and the Pakistani delegation will be taken to the Naya bazaar school in a bus.

The main gate of the school will be shielded with high security and no one will be allowed to enter the premises. A schedule will be made for the Pakistani delegation to visit dargah. IB and police officials will remain with them during their visit. Sources said a special team has been formed to keep an eye on social media platforms.

Last year, there was no Pakistani delegation and then Pakistan high commissioner had come to the dargah to offer chadar on behalf of his government.

Title: TADA prisoners killing in Pilibhit jail: HC summons principal secretary
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

PILIBHIT: The Allahabad high court has issued an order to the Uttar Pradesh principal secretary (home) to appear before it in person on March 5 for not filing a counter affidavit in compliance with the court's previous order dated January 20, 2020, in the matter related to the 1994 custodial death of seven Sikh TADA prisoners in Pilibhit jail .

A division bench of Justice Sudhir Agarwal and Justice Rajiv Mishra issued the order on Wednesday while hearing an impleadment application filed under Section 482 of CrPC by 12 petitioners, including families of seven TADA prisoners killed in Pilibhit district jail on the intervening night of November 8 and 9, 1994.

According to one of the petitioners, Asad Hayat, a senior high court lawyer, the impleadment application was filed with the objective of challenging the notification of the UP government dated January 17, 2007, by virtue of which Section 321 of CrPC was invoked to withdraw all criminal cases against the accused personnel of Pilibhit jail, including the then jail superintendent Vindhyachal Yadav.

The government notification of January 17, 2007, came despite the CBCID (crime-branch crime investigation department) filing a chargesheet against 41 jail officials and police personnel on January 24, 1995. Following the CBCID chargesheet, only one jail constable, Anokh Singh, was arrested and sent to prison but he later managed to get bail, Hayat said.

After the UP government’s notification, the chief judicial magistrate at Pilibhit passed an order on March 30, 2007, for withdrawal of all cases against the jail staff. In fact, the government’s notification was antithetical to the order of the then principal secretary of jails issued in January 1995 granting sanction to prosecute the then jail superintendent, said Hayat.

As many as 28 TADA prisoners lodged in barrack number 7 in Pilibhit prison were brutally beaten up by the jail staff on the intervening night of November 8 and 9, 1994, on the charge that they had attempted to escape. On the morning of November 9, six of the prisoners were brought dead to the district government hospital while one seriously injured prisoner, Vichitra Singh, was referred to King George’s Medical College (KGMC) in Lucknow, but he succumbed to his injuries on November 21.

An FIR against the jail staff, including officials, was lodged at Pilibhit Kotwali police station by then Samajwadi Party district president Gyani Trilochan Singh, in which one of the petitioners, Haroon Ahmad, was made a witness in the case.

Title: Call for Tamil Semmal Award nominations
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Coimbatore: Officials of the district Tamil development department have been awaiting applications from Tamil scholars and writers from the district for the ‘Tamil Semmal Award’.

The award is given to people who have been working to develop and promote Tamil language. It consists of Rs 25,000 and a citation.

Officials of the department said people who have published books of poetry, fiction and have promoted Tamil language in other means can apply for the award. “The applicants have to submit their biodata and the details of their works along with copies of their books. We would collect them, prepare summaries of them and send them to Chennai. Officials in Chennai would shortlist them and select the awardees,” said the official.

The deadline for submitting the applications to the department at the collectorate is March 10. Last year, there were 10 applications from Tamil scholars and writers from the district. “This year, we have not yet started receiving applications for the upcoming award,” the official said.

Title: Heritage walk speaks volumes for disabled
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

A lady explains to the visitors about its history in sign language

VADODARA: On Thursday afternoon, the hallowed halls of Baroda Museum and Picture Gallery in Sayajibaug were reverberating with silent noise when a lady was explaining the history of human civilization to en-rapt group of special visitors — all in sign language!

It was for the first time that nearly 30 deaf and speech impaired heritage lovers were invited for a heritage walk at the museum.

Their expressions showed their immense happiness at the novel venture by Sahapedia and Mookh Badhir Mandal.

“The Indian Heritage Walk Festival is being organized for the past three years and Sahapedia invited me to organize it in Ahmedabad. This year I decided to keep such walk in Vadodara that also has rich heritage,” said Avni Varia who organized the walk.

“I always like to reach out to people with physical disabilities, mentally challenged as well those with special needs. They also love our heritage and want to learn more about. So I decided to design a walk for the hearing and speech impaired people here,” Varia added.

The heritage walk began at 3 pm from the Egyptian gallery of the museum. While museum curator, Vijay Patel explained the importance and history of every artefact, Trushna Shah, who works at Mookh Badhir Mandal, translated it in sign language for these special Barodians. The group was keen to know more about Harappa civilization and the ceramic vessels kept in the Chinese gallery.

“It was a fantastic move to organize heritage walk for the hearing and speech impaired. The group learnt a lot about our history and insisted that such walks should be organized regularly,” said Deepika Gajjar, trustee, Mookh Badhir Mandal . A similar walk has also been organized at Dr Manekrao Jummadada Vyayam Mandir on Saturday.

Title: BJP worker held for misbehaving with woman, 37
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: District president of the BJP’s SC/ST wing was arrested on Thursday evening for harassing a woman sanitary worker while she was cleaning toilet at the ESI hospital at Varadharajapuram in Singanallur.

The Singanallur police identified the accused as Jothi, 40, of CMC Colony at Ukkadam. He was working as a contract plumber at the ESI hospital.

According to a policer officer, the incident took place a few days ago when the 37-year-old woman from Anjugam Nagar was cleaning the toilet at the hospital. “Jothi had gone to the toilet for plumbing work. He pulled her hand and attempted to misbehave with her. She raised an alarm. He, however, managed to flee.”

The woman lodged a complaint with the Singanallur police, who registered a case under Section 75(i)(c) of the Tamil Nadu City Police Act, Sections 323 and 506(i) of the Indian Penal Code and Section 4 of Tamil Nadu Prohibition of Harassment of Women Act and arrested Jothi on Thursday evening.

He was produced before a judicial magistrate, who remanded him in judicial custody. Subsequently, he was lodged in jail.

Title: Ajmer: Youth held for planning stir against delegation
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative Image

AJMER: Police on Thursday arrested a youth for hate speech and planning to protest against the Pakistan delegation coming to attend the annual Urs of Khwaja Moinuddin Chisty. Police came to know that the accused was planning to gather other youths for the protest.

According to police, Rishab Tak, 22, a resident of Ramganj, was arrested for spreading religious hate on social media . Police came to know that Tak made an appeal to youths of Ajmer and asked them to gather at Bad Balaji Temple on Beawar road for the stir.

Acting on the information posted by Tak on social media, police reached the spot at the time stated in the social post. Police found that no one came to the spot and Rishab was alone and he was arrested. Ramganj police said they are investigating if others were involved in his plan.

District magistrate Vishwa Mohan Sharma on Thursday took the meeting of district peace committee considering the communal riots in Delhi. Thousands of devotees visit Ajmer during the annual Urs and an appeal was made to maintain peace. Security has been beefed up to avoid any attempt to disturb communal peace as the Pakistani delegation is also reaching Ajmer. “The major task for the administration is that Holi is also fast approaching and therefore this is the time when anti-social elements can disturb peace,” an official said.

Title: Canal boon for parched Jaisalmer & Barmer dists
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Work underway for drinking water project in Jaisalmer district

JAISALMER: Indira Gandhi canal project in the desert districts of Jaisalmer and Barmer districts is proving to be a boon, with drinking water being available in these parched areas.

Currently, different projects are going on to provide water to many villages in Jaisalmer and Barmer districts through Pokaran-Phalsoond-Balotra-Siwana lift canal.

Amid the tough sand dunes and rocky areas, PHED in western Rajasthan has laid big diameter pipeline of one of the two much awaited drinking water schemes (368 villages) in October 2019 and the second scheme (195 villages) is expected to be completed by 2021. With these schemes, 12.68 lakh people of 563 villages in Jaisalmer and Barmer districts will get drinking water.

So far, Rs 1569.33 crore has been spent on this scheme. The scheme of the water works department will ensure a permanent solution to the drinking water problem for these villages.

Additional chief engineer of the project Rakesh Jain said, “The work of two drinking water projects worth Rs 1,500 crore is at the final stage. The projects proposal were conceived in 2007 while the first sanction for financial sanction came in 2011. The work started on these two projects in 2012-13.’’

Water is being drawn from Indira Gandhi main canal RD 1253 Nachna. Till now, Rs 1,559.33 crore has been spent. The beneficiaries include armed forces posted in the area and will also fulfill the water demand for refinery being set up at Pachpadra.

Jain said it was a big challenge for the PHED to complete the works of both projects. The 300-km long project is now on the stage of completion.

Title: Firms warm up to green ways on Kovai-Tirupur belt
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Coimbatore: Many companies in the Manchester of South India are beginning to go green. At least 20 companies in the Coimbatore-Tirupur belt have got GreenCo ratings in the past two and half years, and another 20 companies have applied for ratings and are in the process of being evaluated, according to data with the CII’s GreenCo mission.

They attribute this trend to many multinational clients based from the United States and Europe looking only to employ environment-friendly companies.

The GreenCo mission was launched by the Confederation of Indian Industries in 2012 to make industries improve their efforts to save natural resources. While Greenco rating system was launched in the country in 2012, and Brakes India’s Sholingur unit became the first company from Tamil Nadu managed to get Greenco rated in 2013, the western region seemed slow to wake up to the trend. While Kirloskar Brothers got its manufacturing unit in Karumathampatti certified in 2014 along with the rest of their units, the rest of the region seemed to jump on to the bandwagon in 2017. “It was around 2017-’18 that Coimbatore-based industries like LMW, KG Fabrics and many garment exporters in Tirupur began applying for GreenCo ratings and achieving them,” counsellor for the climate change and environment sustainability division of CII, Chennai, Hirin Prashanth said.

Of the 20 companies that have got Greenco ratings in Coimbatore-Tirupur belt, five of them are from Coimbatore. “In and around Tirupur, there is a surge in garment manufacturers applying for the ratings, because many of their buyers and clients from Europe and the US have begun asking for environment sustainability certificates from their suppliers,” Prashanth said. At least another 20 companies are in the process of being certified in the belt, he said.

Applying for GreenCo ratings involves showing your company’s efforts to become more environment friendly in the last three years and efforts taken after applying for the rating. “We have teams to first train the company on ways to become more environment-friendly and then six to eight months later, an assessment team to assess their improvement efforts. It includes changes like fitting pumps with more energy efficient motors, fitting water efficient taps, setting up a sewage treatment plant, reducing overall energy consumption, among others,” Prashanth said.

Speaking at the one-day conference on Green Manufacturing conducted by CII on Thursday, chairman of the CII GreenCo forum Unni Nayar said currently 285 companies across the country are rated and certified. “We target increasing the number to 1,000 by 2022,” he said. He also said it was encouraging to see many public-sector units like the railways, getting their units like the Integral Coach Factory in Perambur, green certified.

Title: Burglars leave credit society in Anamalai empty-handed
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Coimbatore: Burglars who broke into a cooperative credit society in Anamalai here on Tuesday night had to leave empty-handed after they failed to open the locker using a blowtorch.

The miscreants had gained entry into the Primary Agricultural Cooperative Credit Society at Marappagoundenpudur after removing a window grill, a police officer said. “The locker contained 180 sovereigns of gold ornaments and Rs 8 lakh in cash.”

As many as 300 customers, mostly farmers, are members of the society, which provides gold loans and agriculture loans. After failing to open the locker, the burglars sprinkled sulphas, a pesticide, inside and outside the building so that sniffer dogs won’t be able to follow their trail.

Employees, who opened the building on Wednesday around 9.30am, were alerted by the pungent odor of the pesticide. “They found the mangled grill and the damaged locker, and alerted the Anaimalai police. Society secretary Sharmila Banu lodged a complaint,” the officer said.

A police team consisting of fingerprint experts, scientific officer and cybercrime cell members inspected the crime scene. “The burglar alarm did not trigger when the burglars attempted to break open the locker. Also, the images of the burglars were not recorded in the CCTV system. The security guard was sleeping in his room when the incident happened,” the officer added.

Title: Vadodara: Two more booked for hate messages
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Team of RAF personnel march through the affected area on Thursday

VADODARA: Two offences were registered on Wednesday afternoon against a man named Matin Vohra and an unidentified person for making statements conducing public mischief and indulging in deliberate and malicious act to outrage religious feelings of a community. Police have also invoked section of Information Technology Act against the accused.

The special operations group of Anand police have registered the case wherein it has been stated that provocative messages and audio clips were making rounds on WhatsApp. Police said that Vohra and one more person had allegedly spread this messages and audio clips to spread hatred between Hindus and Muslims in the society. “Such messages would breach peace in Khambhat and spread misunderstanding so we have registered the case,” said a police official. However, no arrests have been made in the case yet.

In connection with the rioting that took place on February 23 and 25, six more persons were arrested on Thursday. Police officials said that total arrests are now more than 100.

While cops claim that situation has normalized in the affected areas, local sources said that people are still scared to return to Akbarpura and Bhavsarwad areas. Small shops and establishments have opened but they are hardly making any business as the area is deserted.

Intense police patrolling by senior police officials were conducted besides march by a team of rapid action force on Wednesday.

Title: Artists to bring splash of colours to Ukkadam
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

A year after decorating the walls of the Coimbatore Medical College Hospital and the library building of the p... Read More

COIMBATORE: After decorating some of the city’s iconic buildings like the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital and the library building of the police commissioner’s office, New Delhi-based St+art Art India Foundation is in the city to decorate the walls of the Tamil Nadu slum clearance board’s tenements at Ukkadam.

The foundation has sent Amitabh Kumar from Bengaluru, Avinash Kumar from Jharkhand , Jeeva from Coimbatore and Chifumi from France to beautify the walls.

The theme is ‘The People and Environment of Ukkadam and Coimbatore’, said director of special projects Vikas Nagrare. “The artists began work on Thursday. Unlike our 2018 project, which mainly depicted people of Coimbatore and was painted on walls, which were tall and most visible in the heart of the city, this project called Ukkadam Art District Coimbatore aims to depict the essence of a location, which includes its environment, festivals, lifestyle, people and their professions,” he said.

The artists spent a lot of time researching the Ukkadam area by observing the lifestyle, meeting people and watching their activities. “Our paintings will depict the Ukkadam Periyakulam and maybe some more lakes and the life around them. We plan to depict the migratory birds visiting the district, which is a popular nesting spot for pelicans,” said Nagrare. “Our interactions with people showed that Ukkadam has a large migratory population, as many displaced people settle there. They will also be depicted. Our research is an ongoing process, with our artists continuing to roam the city and conceptualize their art.”

The artists of the foundation, when they were in the city in 2018, had spotted Ukkadam as a probable location to create an art district. “But the idea materialized after they were invited for a beautification project recently by the city corporation. An art district is basically a campus, where people walking or driving through can get to see a lot of life-size art,” Nagrare said.

The artists will be painting the four walls using wall paints sponsored by Asian Paints. “ The corporation had invited the artists over to beautify the slum tenements. Wall arts will create a sense of pride among the residents and motivate them to keep the area clean. Maybe, one day, it could become a tourist attraction,” president of the Residents Awareness Association of Coimbatore (Raac) R Raveendran said. “Wall art is one measure but we plan to increase greenery and cleanliness also.”

The artists will finish their work by March 15.

Title: 3 held for student’s murder 2 yrs ago
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Pune: The arrest of a suspected thief, Wasim Khan (30), on Tuesday led the Kondhwa police to the chance detection of a civil engineering student’s murder in 2017.

The student, Nikhil Londhe (24), had left home on the night of August 27, 2017, following a fight with his parents. They had scolded him for spending too much time on his cellphone.

During interrogation, Wasim revealed that he and his three aides — Imran Shaikh (20), Ahmed Khan (25) and Shahrukh Khan (19) — had robbed and murdered Londhe the same night. They had spotted Londhe near Central building and forced him into a stolen autorickshaw, police said. They drove him to a secluded spot at Shivnerinagar in Kondhwa where they robbed him of his cellphone and documents before bludgeoning him to death with a stone.

Londhe’s body was found the next day in a badly mutilated condition. He could not be identified because parts of his face had been eaten by stray dogs, the police said. The police had seized a blood-stained stone from the spot.

On September 19 the same year, Londhe’s father, Anil, who was then posted as a havildar at the Yerawada central jail, lodged a complaint with the Vishrantwadi police regarding his son having gone missing. However, the police did not link this complaint to the unidentified, mutilated body found at Kondhwa. The murder case remained unresolved till Wasim’s arrest and interrogation.

Senior inspector Vinayak Gaikwad of the Kondhwa police told TOI, “We have also arrested Imran and Ahmed following Wasim’s confession. The fourth accomplice, Shahrukh, was murdered in a separate incident last year.”

The police have now established that the mutilated body was Londhe’s after recovering a photocopy of his father’s identity card from one of Wasim’s friends living in Yeolewadi. “Wasim said he had told his friend to destroy the documents that they had robbed from Londhe. The friend told the police that while he had destroyed most of the documents, he had retained the identity card. We then contacted the Yerawada jail authorities who said Londhe’s father had been transferred to the Visapur jail,” Gaikwad said.

The Visapur jail officials told the police that Anil Londhe had retired from service and gave his contact number. “When we contacted him, he told us of the ‘missing person’ complaint he had lodged in September 2017. He and his wife visited our police station on Wednesday and broke down on hearing that their son had been murdered. They identified him from his photographs, clothes and a friendship band tied on his hand,” Gaikwad said.

Inspector Mahadeo Kumbhar of the Kondhwa police said, “The Sassoon general hospital had kept the victim’s viscera and DNA sample after the autopsy. We will match the DNA sample with that of the victim’s parents at a forensic lab.”

Anil Londhe told TOI over the phone, “I have nothing to offer as comments for now. You may speak to my lawyer, Mahesh Kakade.” Kakade, when contacted, said, “We are yet to receive complete details about the incident. We won’t comment anything for now.”

Gaikwad said police had received information about Wasim during a check on criminals involved in vehicle thefts. “Wasim and his aides had stolen several vehicles. We recovered five stolen vehicles from him. The four decided to kill Londhe fearing that he might register a robbery complaint and provide their description and the registration number of their vehicle,” he said.

Police have registered an offence of kidnapping, robbery, murder and destruction of evidence, among others.

Title: Catholic priests back anti-CAA protesters
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Coimbatore: Roman catholic priests in the city visited the ‘Kovai Shaheen Bagh’ protest site at Aathupalam Junction here on Thursday and extended support to the protesters.

A total of 15 priests, led by vicar general father John Joseph Stanis, visited the protest site. They said they wished for peace in the country and a society without religious discrimination. They expressed solidarity with the people who were protesting against the Citizenship Amendment Act.

The Shaheen Bagh protest entered the ninth day on Thursday. The protesters said they wouldn’t call off the protest until the CAA, National Register of Citizens and the National Population Register were repealed. tnn

Title: Meet soldiers who got gallantry awards
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Bareilly: As many as 15 soldiers who have recently been conferred with Sena Medal (gallantry award) will be felicitated by General Officer Commanding-in-Chief Central Command Lieutenant General IS Ghuman at the Kargil Hall of the Uttar Bharat area here during an investiture ceremony on Friday.

The soldiers — five officers and 10 other ranks — were awarded Sena Medal for their act of gallantry in the face of adversaries as well as for exceptional devotion to their duty and service to the nation.

Besides, during the ceremony, 12 units will be awarded Central Command’s citation in recognition to their exceptional performance and services.

The five officers who were conferred with Sena Medal are Major Ritesh Sangwan of Garhwal Rifles, Major Yogesh Pandey and Major Soham Bhattacharjee of Corps of Engineer, Major Shakti Singh of 23 Parachute Regiment and Major Ravi Kumar of Bihar Regiment.

Soldiers of 23 Parachute Regiment who were awarded Sena Medal are Havildar Bhupendra Singh, Lance Havildar Sandeep Kumar, Lance Havildar Vijay Kumar, Lance Naik Sombir and Paratrooper Gurwinder Singh.

Besides, three soldiers of Garhwal Rifles who were awarded Sena Medal are Havildar Nagendra Singh Rawat, Rifleman Preetam Singh and Paratrooper Ashutosh Singh. Naik Daljeet Singh of J&K Light Infantry and Sepoy Sushil Singh Kalakoti of Kumaun Regiment were also conferred with Sena Medal.

Prominent among the award winners is Lance Havildar Vijay Kumar of 23 Parachute Regiment, who displayed exceptional courage and made the supreme sacrifice while fighting terrorists in Jammu and Kashmir. Kumar was awarded Sena Medal posthumously. His wife Suman Devi received the award.

Title: Shivajinagar among 3 areas with bad air in cool weather
Content:
A view from Shivajinagar area in Pune.

PUNE: You may want to steer clear of Shivajinagar, Bhosari and Bhumkar Chowk while travelling in Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad.Air quality in these three locations has become 'poor' for the first time this year, as per pollution data from the city-based Institute of Tropical Meteorology's (IITM) System of Air Quality Forecasting and Research (SAFAR).Track the pollution level in your cityA health advisory issued by IITM for these locations on Thursday said, “Increasing likelihood of respiratory symptoms in sensitive individuals. Children and elderly are at risk. Everyone may begin to experience some level of discomfort. People with heart or lung disease, older adults and children should reduce prolonged or heavy exertion.”Lead pollutant—particulate matter (PM) 2.5— levels in these three places have touched a high recently, especially with the sudden drop in minimum temperatures, experts said.On Thursday, the minimum temperature in Pune was 12.1 degrees celsius, among the lowest this month. The sudden dip in night temperature as well as increase in pollution is already starting to trouble those having a sensitive immune system, and those prone to respiratory infections, doctors said.A source from IITM told TOI that the last few days have witnessed a sudden dip in night-time mercury to around 12 degrees celsius, which has been one of the causes of a spike in the level of the main pollutant PM 2.5.“When this pollutant’s concentration is high and reaches ‘poor’ levels, it automatically leads to a worsening of the air quality, making it poor. A fall in temperature causes the planetary boundary layer height to come down. A low height indicates strong temperature inversion and downward air motion which favours the near-surface accumulation of pollutants like PM2.5 and PM10 emitted from local sources,” the IITM source said.Shashikant Nehul, a research scholar in the department of environment of Savitribai Phule Pune University, told TOI that many chowks in the city like Swargate, Nal Stop, and areas in Pimpri Chinchwad and Bhosari, and several others are currently also witnessing high PM 10 levels, around 1.5 times higher than the maximum permissible limit of 100 micrograms per cubic metre (µg/m³).“Areas like Shivajinagar, Bhosari and Bhumkar Chowk are relatively more congested, with high vehicular traffic and construction activities which are major sources of pollution. This coupled with a fall in night temperature prevents the dispersion of pollutants, causing the air to be more polluted,” Nehul added.IITM-SAFAR data also showed that pollutant PM 2.5 concentration in these areas was the highest on Thursday in comparison to the last few days.

Title: Advocates deny their presence during mob gathering, hate speech
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Vadodara: Two advocates accused of delivery hateful speech and inciting mob at Gawara Tower at Khambhat have challenged Anand police for proving the allegations made against them. Vadodara-based Neeraj Jain, president of Hindu Jagran Manch, and Ketan Patel from Nadiad addressed media persons in Anand on Thursday where they said that they were not present when a mob had voluntarily gathered at the spot on February 25. The duo has asked the cops to furnish videos or photographs in which they can be seen. “An offence has been registered against us deliberately so that the image of Hindu Jagran Manch gets tarnished in the society,” Jain claimed. TNN

Title: Age-old water wisdom still rocks in rural Rajasthan
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

A view of Badli talab in Jodhpur

JODHPUR: Technology definitely makes life easy, but people in rural Rajasthan still swear by traditional ways of water conservation in the form of ‘nadis or johads,’ ‘beri’, ‘tankas’ and ‘talaabs’ which date back to a few hundred years.

‘Nadis or johad’ as they are called in different parts of the desert state are waterbodies, which have large catchment areas or ‘aghors’ where water is accumulated during monsoons and is used by locals for their daily needs.

The ‘naadi’ in Bhagtasni village near Jodhpur, which is around 200 years old as claimed by locals, is one such example of water conservation. It is not only existing, but is a crucial part of villagers’ life.

Hukum Singh, a 70-year-old who has been taking water from this nadi since childhood told TOI, “My father used to speak about this nadi and how they would take water from here when he was a child. We still use the water from the nadi, which fills up during monsoon and lasts till the next season. Till 15-20 years ago, the water was used by us for drinking, but now we now use it mainly for livestock. When the nadi was created, the science behind it was simple — to have a large area where rainwater flows from the mountains and is collected.”

Similarly, tankas and beri, which have water throughout the year, are still the main sources of water for locals in an age when almost every household also a has a water pipe connection.

Tanka is a small rainwater collection structure in rural houses. A circle shape structure with slope towards its centre, water runs off to the centre and fall into the tanks below. When needed, the water is taken out from a narrow lid, usually enough to drop a bucket into the tank. This water, depending upon the capacity of the tank, is enough for 6-7 months.

It may differ in design, but the objective is to gather rainwater from around the tank and route it to fall into the tank.

Beris are small well-like structures built in the bed of a pond or ‘nadi’ and fulfill the water needs after the pond or ‘nadi’ dried up. They contain water for longer period than the pond as water charged into the ground, keep filing the beris by way of seepage.

Bhawar Lal, who is the priest at a temple near the ‘talaab’ in Guda Bishoniyan village said, “The talaab in our village is around 500 years old and even today is used by the villagers for fulfilling their water requirements. The basic aim was to have an area large enough to collect the rain water. Even if the pond would dry up, water would get stored in the numerous beris which were dug up in the catchment areas. Even today, we maintain it and clean it regularly. They never dry up and since the water is hard in these parts, the water stored in the beris is still used for drinking. Every household also has tankas where water gets stored and is used for daily consumption.”

Not only are these waterbodies a source for survival, but are also tied to the religious mindset of the entire village community. Vikram Singh from Barli village claimed that the all these bodies not only fulfilled their need for water, but also were also considered pious. “Most talaabs and nadis have temples on their banks. They are just not a source of water but sacrosanct for everyone. Water and worship go hand in hand.”

Title: 2-year-old girl, her 14-year-old uncle killed in wall collapse
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

AGRA: A two-year-old girl and her maternal uncle were killed and the former’s mother was injured when a dilapidated wall in their compound collapsed on them in Mainpuri’s Timar village on Thursday morning.

The deceased were identified as Lado (2) and Nitin Kumar (14). The two-year-old’s mother Sunita Devi sustained injuries and was rushed to a hospital.

According to sources, Sunita had come to her parents’ house a few days back and was sitting with her brother and daughter when the wall collapsed. While Lado died on the spot, Nitin died during treatment. Doctors said that Sunita’s condition is stable and has been kept under observation.

Kurawali station house officer Shiv Kumar Chauhan said that the bodies have been sent for postmortem.

Title: Azam Khan’s jail journey began during Emergency days
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Azam and his kin surrendered before a court in a forgery case related to his son’s fake certificates

RAMPUR: Azam Khan ’s tryst with prison goes way back to the days of Indira Gandhi’s Emergency – 45 years ago. Though, in those days he was a young student activist locked unceremoniously in a prison cell initially for 20 days which, in his own words was “like a grave”. He continued to remain in other prisons for 17 months.

Fast forward to 2020, the student activist is now a senior Samajwadi Party (SP) leader and Rampur MP – with a distinction of being a nine-time MLA to his credit. On Wednesday, Azam and his kin surrendered before a court in a forgery case related to his son’s fake certificates and sent to jail with much fanfare and media attention.

During the Emergency (1975-77), Azam was general secretary of Aligarh Muslim University (AMU). Slapped with the draconian Maintenance of Internal Security Act (MISA), he was jailed for 18 months in Aligarh and Varanasi.

Narrating those Emergency days, Azam had said, “I was sent to jail during the Emergency because I was against the Congress ideology. A resolution was passed by students’ union that no Congress leader will be allowed to enter the campus as Mrs [Indira] Gandhi was scheduled to visit the university.”

He continued, “I was locked inside the cell for 20 days which was like a grave. It was a dark room without sunlight. Later, I was transferred from Aligarh to Varanasi Central Jail where I remained for more than 17 months.”

Azam, who had completed his LLB in 1974 and elected as general secretary of AMU students’ union in 1975, was thrown into prison in July 1975. Like thousands of other political leaders and activists, he languished in prison until January 1977. In March, he contested the elections from Rampur city Vidhan Sabha seat on a Janata Party ticket, and lost.

During his second innings in prison, 45 years later, the former Uttar Pradesh minister has been sent to jail on allegations of forgery. The SP leader has also been booked under several cases which include ‘book theft’, ‘goat and buffalo theft’ and land grab. On Wednesday, Azam said, “I am not a foot soldier, I am a warrior.”

Title: Leopard scare grips Mettur village; cage set up to trap animal
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

ERODE: While forest officials have been trying to trap the leopard that has been on the prowl in Mettur village for the past three days, the animal was spotted on state highway in the early hours of Thursday.

A forest official said, “Motorists sighted the leopard on Gobichettipalayam-Sathyamangalam state highway.”

The big cat was first spotted on Monday morning when it strayed into the farmlands of P Thangavel and S Ranjith Kumar in Mettur village from the Sathyamangalam Tiger Reserve (STR). The two had subsequently requested the forest officials to trap the animal at the earliest.

The official said they have been combing the area for the past three days, but in vain. “We have installed four CCTV cameras to monitor the big cat’s movement. We have also set up cages with bait on farmlands to trap the animal.”

He said five teams - three forest department teams and two Sathyamangalam police teams - have been working round the clock to catch the leopard.

Title: HC grants parole to Arun Gawli to attend to ailing wife
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Nagpur: Underworld don Arun Gawli has been granted parole for the eighth time after being convicted on August 3, 2012, for the murder of a Shiv Sena MLA. The Nagpur bench of Bombay high court allowed his application on Thursday to attend to his ailing wife Asha.

A division bench comprising justices Sunil Shukre and Madhav Jamdar, while quashing the divisional commissioner’s decision to reject the gangster-turned-politician’s application for parole, directed respondents to release him within a week of receiving the HC order copy. The divisional commissioner and Nagpur Central Jail superintendent were respondents in the case.

Gawli, also referred to as ‘Daddy’, had first applied for parole to divisional commissioner to attend to his wife, who would be undergoing surgery. However, it was rejected on the grounds that his presence many lead to law and order situation in Mumbai. He then approached the judiciary through counsel Mir Nagman Ali for 45 days leave under same provision.

Ali contended that on all seven times the noted don was released on either parole or furlough, he returned before the deadline and there was no breach of any condition.

Opposing his contention, the government pointed out that being a gangster, there is every possibility that his return may lead to law and order situation in Mumbai and peace in his Dagdi Chawl area would get disturbed. A long list of crimes allegedly involving him that included some serious ones were also submitted to the court.

The judges, however, observed that there is no basis to the government’s arguments as there is no record that petitioner had jumped sanctioned leaves or committed any breach of conditions in all these years.

Gawli, who was convicted for the murder of MLA Kamalakar Jamsandekar along with 11 others, was awarded rigorous life imprisonment in 2012 and is undergoing the sentence in Central jail here since then. Last year too, the HC had granted furlough to Gawli in March.

Title: Ooty translator wins Sahitya Akademi prize
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Udhagamandalam: Susan Daniel, a resident of Ooty, has been conferred with the Sahitya Akademi’s translation prize, 2019, for translating Padma Shri Devenoora Mahadeva’s critically acclaimed Kannada novel ‘Kusumabale’ into English. The prize comprises Rs50,000 and a copper plaque.

Published in 1988, Kusumabale is a classic work in Kannada literature. The translated version of the novel was released by the Oxford University Publication in 2015 and it was received well. Susan said, “I am happy. With this recognition, I hope the novel would reach more people.”

In 2015, the Karnataka government had bestowed on her award for the best translator of a full novel from Kannada to English. tnn

Title: BJP MP surrenders in court in 27-year-old case, gets bail an hour later
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: BJP MP from Fatehpur Sikri Rajkumar Chahar surrendered in Agra court on Thursday after the district court issued him non-bailable warrant in a 27-year-old Shatabdi Express train vandalism case. However, the court granted him bail an hour later.

Chahar’s advocate Vijay Ahuja told TOI, “At least 90 men, including the MP and his associates Triloki Nath Agrawal and Mukesh Gupta, were booked in summer of 1993 by government railway police of Agra Cantt for allegedly damaging railway property. A non-bailable warrant was issued by the MP/MLA court of additional district and sessions judge Umakant Jindal after which the MP surrendered in the court. He was later granted bail by the same court.”

According to the lawyer, Chahar was booked under IPC sections 147 (riot), 148 (riot with deadly weapon), 149 (every member of unlawful assembly guilty of offence committed in prosecution of common object), 307 (attempt to murder), 427 (mischief causing damage to the amount of fifty rupees), 379 (punishment for theft), 356 (assault or criminal force in attempt to commit theft of property carried by a person) and 145/151 of the Railways Act.

Chahar had defeated Congress candidate Raj Babbar by around 4.95 lakh votes in last year’s Lok Sabha polls from Fatehpur Sikri constituency.

Title: Pune: Court upholds PCB’s property tax levy on multiplex in Fatimanagar
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A district court has upheld the Pune Cantonment Board ’s (PCB) right to fix the Annual Rateable Value (ARV) of commercial properties operating from leave-and-licence rental premises, on the basis of their annual gross rent instead of the estimated cost of building and land value.Sunita Kinkar, the PCB’s lawyer, told TOI on Thursday, “The judgment holds significance vis-à-vis issues of property tax assessment involving commercial properties operating from rented premises in the Pune cantonment area.”District judge Deepak D Almale on February 24 dismissed an appeal by Fame India Limited, which runs a multiplex from a 28,250sqft rented premises that is part of a commercial complex in Fatimanagar, against the PCB’s order of March 29, 2011, that fixed the ARV of this premises at Rs1.18 crore by considering annual gross rent for the period 2008-2011.Based on it, the PCB later issued a property tax bill of over Rs32 lakh to Fame India for the period between April 1, 2010, and March 31, 2011.The ARV forms a critical benchmark for the assessment of property tax against the rent, at which a land or building is reasonably expected to be let-out from year to year. The PCB revises the ARV after every three years. The value, so fixed, applies to each of the three years for the purpose of assessment of property tax bill.In its appeal filed in October 2011, Fame India contended, among other things, that the PCB ought to have assessed the ARV of its premises as per the provisions under Section 73 (a) of the Cantonment Act, 2006, by taking into account the estimated cost of building. As against this, it argued that the PCB “illegally assessed” the ARV under Section 73 (b) of the Act by considering the annual gross rent and did not extend apt opportunity for hearing objections and filing of submissions.The PCB denied all these arguments and said the leave-and-licence amount was of Rs9.88 lakh per month and by multiplying this amount with 12, it was correct in fixing the ARV at Rs1.18 crore for a year.Judge Almale referred to the March 29, 2011, order wherein the PCB had assessed the ARV of the appeal premises under Section 73 (a) of the Act at Rs16.95 lakh, taking into account one-twentieth of estimated present cost of the building and land value appertaining thereto and further assessing the ARV under Section 73 (b), according to gross annual rent, at Rs1.18 crore. “There are recitals in the order that assessment arrived in view of Section 73 (b) is more beneficial to the interest of the board, therefore, the same is recommended,” the court observed.The judge cited the ARV definition and observed that Section 73 (a) was applicable only to hotels, colleges, schools, hospitals, factories and any other building that the CEO decides to assess under this clause. “The appeal premises being a multiplex theatre does not come within the ambit of Section 73 (a) of the Act. The respondents (PCB) ...... have opted for Section 73 (b), to my mind, the said action is neither illegal nor contrary to the provisions of the Cantonment Act,” the judge held.Kinkar told TOI, “We brought to the court’s notice that the legislature’s intent was quite clear from the fact that the term multiplex was not included in Section 73 (a) of the Cantonment Act, 2006 and, hence, the other option was under Section 73 (b). The court upheld our contention.”

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Former village head held for illegal opium cultivation
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: Police have arrested the former head of Kamalner village in Mainpuri on Thursday for allegedly cultivating opium illegally on his farm under Kishni police jurisdiction.

According to police, the market value of the crop sown by the accused, Surendra Singh, is estimated to be around Rs 80 lakh. Police found 815 plants that have reached full growth on the farm. The accused was later booked under section 8/18 of the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, 1985.

Mainpuri SP Ajay Kumar said that police raided the farm based on a tip-off and found opium cultivation on the land since 2019. He added that the accused was earlier the village head and a member of the block development council.

Preliminary inquiry has revealed that Singh was cultivating the crop both for personal use and sale.

Police said that the plantation was destroyed after taking a sample as evidence. They added that they are now trying to ascertain whether the accused had any links with drug rackets.

According to police, it is essential to obtain a licence to grow opium and cannot be sold in the open market.

Title: Rainwater storage is ‘dam’ good in Udaipur
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Water harvesting at a village in Chirawa block in Jhunjhunu district

UDAIPUR: The esteemed model of rainwater management at Udaipur lakes is over four centuries old. It was the ancestral vision of wise rulers that led to a creation of a unique inter-connected micro-system of river diversion and linkage. Prominent lakes such as Pichhola, Fatehsagar, Udaisagar and Badi were built in such a way that overflow from one was not wasted as it flowed into another, thus providing a year-long water storage system to quench the thirst of residents.

It was the visionary rulers of Mewar who created a system of lakes to meet the water requirement of the citizens, claims Pushpendra Ranawat , a retired professor of geology.

In his book ‘Wah Udaipur Wah,’ Ranawat elaborated, “Pichola is a lake behind an earthen dam constructed by a Banjara in the 14th century. Height of the dam was raised to increase the capacity of the lake. Additional water resource for the new capital was created through the construction of Udaisagar Lake, east of Udaipur. Its work started in 1559 and was commissioned on April 4, 1565. The needs of the growing city during the next two centuries were met by converting the pre-existing Pichola from a small pond (talai) to a large lake behind a masonry gravity dam-Badi Paal. Its capacity further increased through the addition of Amar-Kund, Rang Sagar, Kumbhariya Talab, and finally the northern most extension-Swaroop Sagar.” Lakes at Dewali and Badi constructed by Maharana Jai Singh helped Udaipur.

Fatehsagar has a very small catchment area of its own and is fed by Lake Badi, Chota and Bada Madaar. The overflow from Lake Bada and Chota Madaar merge with Ayar river. Ayar river feeds Udaisagar several kilometers downstream. The overflow from Lake Badi directly merges with Fatehsagar. The overflow from Pichol flows into Fatehsagar and the overflow from Fatehsagar flows into the Ayar through a canal before it enters Udaisagar. Below Pichola and Fatehsagar are numerous wells and bawdi (stepwells), which were the only source of drinking water back then. With this web of lakes and wells, most of the rain falling within the Udaipur basin was kept within the basin itself, with very little losses making it a remarkable rainwater harvesting system.

Maharana Fateh Singh enlarged Dewali pond to Fatehsagar Lake (1889) which is now a major source of water and recreation for Udaipur. He also constructed Madar I & II lakes north of Udaipur to provide water to Fatehsagar.

In 1931, water supply through gravity pipelines from Swaroop Sagar launched for Udaipur. In 1944, SAV Consulting Engineers was commissioned to prepare pipewater distribution system for Udaipur-a totally new concept for Udaipurites. In 1945, the water of dug-wells downstream of Pichola were chemically analyzed and found potable.

To the delight of the public, 20 public taps were installed for the convenient supply of water near their homes - the birth of Public Works Department .

However, with the hike in population, about 70 ghats, over hundred hotels and some six thousand houses located on lake slopes, these waterbodies are under constant threat of degradation.

Title: Transgenders to man Aavin parlour
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Udhagamandalam: The hill retreat on Thursday got its first-ever Aavin parlour run by transgenders. Inaugurated by M Vallalar, managing director, Aavin, in the presence of district collector J Innocent Divya, the dairy centre at the Poomalai commercial complex in Charing Cross in Ooty will be manned by a self-help group comprising five transgenders.

P Babu, project director, Tamil Nadu State Rural Livelihoods Mission (TNSRLM), said the self-help group was floated with an objective to help transgenders find more acceptance in the society. “We wanted to encourage them socially and morally.”

Pointing out that at least 10-12 members were required to form a self-help group, he said, “This is a special group with just five members.”

While the centre has been set up at a reduced cost by the Aavin management, TNSRLM has rented out the space at the Poomalai commercial complex to them at a minimal rent.

“We have also arranged them a loan of Rs 5 lakh from the district cooperative bank towards working capital,” Babu said.

Sowmya, one of the group members, said, “We are happy that the Aavin management, district administration and TNSRLM project director have come forward to encourage us and help us enhance our lifestyle.”

Title: CCTV cameras prove crucial in arrest of ATM thieves, frequent flyer kingpin
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Pune: The CCTV cameras helped the Wakad police identify the registration numbers of the bikes used by the Pune aides of the interstate ATM thieves’ gang, leading to the arrest of six men, including the kingpin who would fly in from Delhi to execute the crimes.

“After two consecutive cases of ATM thefts in Wakad, we began checking the CCTV cameras and lodges in the area. One of the CCTV footages helped us identify the registration number of bikes used by the suspects,” the Wakad police said.

During probe, Sandip Salve (43) of Mulshi, Dattatreya Kokate (42) of Thergaon were taken into custody following a tip-off received by assistant inspector Harish Mane. “During questioning, they admitted to their involvement in ATM thefts in the Pimpri Chinchwad areas. They also revealed the names of other gang members, including the kingpin, Azaruddin Tahir Hussain, from Haryana,” senior inspector Vivek Mugalikar said.

He said a police team comprising Mane, sub-inspector Siddhanath Babar, constables Bapusaheb Dhumal and Nitin Dhoraje, among others, then went to Haryana and nabbed one of the gang members, Sarfuddin Hasim. “The team also created network of informants in Haryana to gather information about the remaining suspects,” Mugalikar said.

Assistant inspector Mane said around this time, the gang kingpin, Hussain, came to know about the arrest of his accomplice from Haryana and told his Pune accomplices to go underground. “The duo were already in our custody and talked to Hussain as per our instructions. They told him that they would be coming to Haryana and requested Hussain to pick them up from the New Delhi airport,” Mane said, adding, “After reaching Delhi, we took Hussain into custody.”

The officer said after the news of his arrest spread, the remaining gang members went underground. “We spread the news that the police team had returned to Pimpri Chinchwad. This is when third suspect, Mohammed Shakir, came out from his hideout and was arrested,” Mane said, adding, “The third Pune accomplice, Gautam Jadhav (38) from Thergaon, was arrested later.”

He said Hussain and his accomplice Hasim used to swap the debit cards at the ATM kiosks to dupe people of their monies.

“When people became more alert, they shifted their focus on cutting ATMs. About two years ago, Hussain came into contact with Kokate at an ATM kiosk in Thergaon and took him in the gang for cutting ATMs,” Mane said.

Title: Inter-faith couple seeks protection in Bareilly
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: An inter-faith couple from a village under Aonla police jurisdiction, who had married against the wish of their families around a year ago, took to social media on Thursday seeking police protection claiming that the woman’s relatives have threatened to kill all of them, including their eight-day-old son.

The couple, in their early twenties, alleged that even though they had approached the local police seeking protection, no action was taken against the woman’s family due to which they have been living in fear ever since. As a last resort, the couple shot the video at an undisclosed location and circulated it on social media on Thursday.

The woman said, “I married a man from a different community on my own last year. I am quite happy with my marriage. However, my relatives are unhappy and are threatening to kill me, my husband and our newborn. Even though we had approached the police, they did not provide any protection.” Meanwhile, her husband said that his family members were beaten up by her relatives, adding that they were now threatening to kill the entire family. “I respect all religions and we decided to lead a life together as we love each other. However, we have been facing great threat since the day of our wedding. We request the government as well as the local administration to provide us security. If anything happens to any of us, the government and police will be responsible for it,” he added.

Refuting allegations of police inaction, Aonla station house officer Sunil Kumar said that action was taken under section 107/116 of CrPC (pre-emptive action to prevent breach of peace) against the family of the woman. “Ever since they got married, the couple had been living outside the village. Only the man’s mother and brother live here. If the couple comes to the village and seeks protection, we will be provide the same to them,” he added.

Title: Coonoor: Leopard strays into cantonment area
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

The movement of the leopard was captured in one of the CCTV cameras installed in the defence area in Wellingto... Read More

UDHAGAMANDALAM: A leopard on the prowl has instilled fear among the residents of Wellington cantonment area near Coonoor . The animal has been wandering around the area for the past two days.

The movement of the leopard was captured in one of the CCTV cameras installed in the defence area in Wellington.

However, residents claimed that two leopards were moving around the Wellington area on Wednesday morning.

They said, “With the movement of leopards, it is very scary to send our wards to schools. We must restrict ourselves in homes by not venturing out in late evenings. The forest department should take action to capture the animals.”

District forest officer Guru Swami Baddal said, “It has come to our notice that a leopard has strayed into the cantonment area. Forest guards are monitoring the movement of the animal”.

He added, “We have written to our higher authorities seeking permission to capture the leopard and relocate it. We will soon capture the animal as it seems an adult.”

He said the increase in stray dogs and domestic dogs in Wellington area attracts the carnivores. Wellington cantonment is surrounded by reserve forest area.

Title: How evacuees bypass Wuhan authorities
Content:
Wearing T-shirts at 8-11 degrees Celsius, drinking 2.5 litres were some of the measures that people resorted t... Read More

AGRA: Wearing T-shirts at 8-11 degrees Celsius and drinking 2.5 litres were some of the measures that people resorted to in order to keep their body temperature normal so that they get clearance from Chinese authorities to board the IAF plane that has brought them back from Wuhan to Delhi on Thursday morning.Ashish Yadav (35), associate professor of photonic and plasmonic at Wuhan Textile University , and his 30-year-old wife, pursuing her PhD in computer science, were among the 112 people brought to Delhi from Wuhan by C-17 Globemaster of IAF.Narrating how they managed to get clearance to board the plane, Ashish said, “We had been warned by Chinese authorities that anyone with body temperature of over 37 degrees Celsius will not be allowed to board the plane. Therefore, at multiple locations, our body temperature was checked. Due to anxiety at one point, my body temperature rose to 37 degrees Celsius, and I was flagged by Chinese officials after which I drank several litres of water and wore only one T-shirt even when the temperature in Wuhan was between 8 and 11 degrees Celsius to bring my body temperature below 37 degrees Celsius.”“On Wednesday mid-noon, the Indian embassy contacted us and informed about the evacuation operation. At least 10 Indians and three Bangladeshi nationals were also flagged by Chinese authorities, after which the Indian embassy officials intervened and started negotiating with them. All the flagged passengers were given two hours’ time to bring down their body temperature to normal. We were asked to remain calm by Indian embassy authorities. Every passenger drank at least 2.5 litres of water. Finally, all were given clearance to board the plane,” said Ashish Yadav, who originally hails from Jalesar in Etah district, but lives in Agra city.Around 6:45 am on Thursday, the military cargo plane brought the couple, along with others Indians and 36 foreign nationals, to India. All are currently lodged at the ITBP quarantine facility in Chhawla.Married in November 2018, the couple started living together in an apartment allotted by Wuhan University a year later, though Ashish had been living in Wuhan for much longer time. After arriving in India, the couple was overwhelmed with joy and spoke to TOI over phone after physical fitness check was done at the quarantine facility.The couple, along with other evacuees, will be under round the clock observation for the next 14 days before being declared fit and discharged from the ITBP quarantine facility.

Title: Pizzeria gutted as gas leak sparks fire in Nizampura
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

The fire occurred on Thursday afternoon

VADODARA: Kitchen of a pizzeria in Nizampura was gutted after fire broke out due to leakage from an LPG cylinder on Thursday afternoon.

Leakage in one of the three operational gas cylinders led to fire when one of the employees ignited a stove. No staff member or customer at the restaurant was injured. Most of them rushed out as soon as the fire broke out. As flames started engulfing the kitchen, occupants of neighbouring buildings started sprinkling water to contain the fire until the firemen reached.

Fire department sources said that initial sprinkling of water really helped, as the fire did not spread further in the dining area of the restaurant. “When our staff reached there was thick smoke in the restaurant but we used self-contained breathing apparatus and sprayed water,” said fire officer Om Jadeja. He added that as fire was brought under control, efforts were made to remove the smoke using cross ventilation technique.

“There could have been a major disaster as there were 10 more LPG cylinders in the premises. Had these cylinders caught fire, the disaster would have gone out of control,” he added.

Title: VMC workers threaten to block assembly on Mar 18
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Vijayawada: Municipal workers threatened to block Andhra Pradesh legislative assembly on March 18 if the state government ignored their long-pending demands.

Sanitation workers and contract employees were on warpath on Thursday, demanding the Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) focus on the safety and healthcare of sanitation workers and ground-level staff. Hundreds of municipal workers staged a protest at Lenin Center in the city demanding VMC resolve their demands.

“Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy promised to increase the salaries of sanitation workers. The promise has remained unfulfilled for months. Around 1,500 contract and DWACRA sanitation workers have been eagerly waiting for the payment of arrears. But VMC authorities are trying to escape and saying that the issue is pending with the state government,” said M David, secretary of the Municipal Workers Union (MWU).

Sanitation workers have been facing problem with the door-to-door segregated garbage collection. “Segregating garbage without gloves and other safety material is causing severe health problems. The VMC should give gloves, masks and other safety gear to every sanitation worker,” David demanded.

Municipal workers alleged that the door-to-door scanning machines are adding a huge burden on them. “Sanitary inspectors are insisting we scan each and every home after collecting garbage. It is taking much time. One sanitary worker is doing the work of four persons. We demanded that the VMC increase staff and our demand was unheard,” the secretary added.

CITU state leader and CPM state secretariat member Ch Babu Rao extended support to the municipal workers. “ The state government is confined to making promises. Contract workers in the engineering wing are receiving poor salaries. A driver with a heavy vehicle license is getting only Rs 15,000 per month. We are demanding the government implement a minimum salary of Rs 21,000 for every worker,” Babu Rao said.

“Municipal workers across the state are facing similar issues and we have decided to block assembly if the government turns a blind eye,” he added.

Title: Corona: Saudi suspends Umrah pilgrim visas
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Saudi Arabia on Thursday indefinitely suspended visas for visits to Islam’s holiest sites for the Umrah pilgri... Read More

Saudi Arabia on Thursday indefinitely suspended visas for visits to Islam’s holiest sites for the Umrah pilgrimage, an unprecedented move triggered by coronavirus fears that raises questions over the annual Haj. The kingdom also suspended visas for tourists from countries affected by the virus as fears of a pandemic deepen.

Afzal Patel of Mumbai’s Atlas Tours and Travels said at any given point in time, there must be around 50,000 Indians among 5 lakh Umrah pilgrims in Saudi Arabia from across the world. Pilgrims are disheartened. “We are deeply saddened that pilgrimage had to be called off at the last moment,” said a pilgrim who arrived at Kozhikode airport to be told his flight had been cancelled.

Over 230 Umrah pilgrims from Kozhikode who were to travel to Saudi Arabia were sent back from the airport on Thursday.

While Haj, one of the five pillars of Islam, is an annual ritual, Umrah can be performed through the year. Lakhs do so every year, particularly during the Islamic months of Rajab, Shaban and Ramzan. Rajab, which set in a few days ago, marks the beginning of the peak season for Umrah.

Saudi Arabia, which so far has reported no cases of the virus but has expressed alarm over its spread in neighbouring countries, said the suspensions were temporary but it provided no timeframe for when they will be lifted.

“The kingdom’s government has decided to take the following precautions: suspending entry to the kingdom for the purpose of Umrah and visit to the Prophet’s mosque temporarily,” the Saudi foreign ministry said in a statement. “Suspending entry into the kingdom with tourist visas for those coming from countries where the spread of the new coronavirus (Covid-19) is a danger,” it added without naming them.

Haj and Umrah tour operators in India said they will incur huge losses. “Umrah pilgrims through my company leave for Saudi every day in a week and I have 500 pilgrims already in Saudi performing Umrah. We will face a huge crisis if the suspension order lasts long,” said Patel. “We have around 150 pilgrims in Saudi Arabia currently and another batch of 150 pilgrims was expected to fly out on Saturday,” said Yusuf Ahmed Khereda of Al Khalid Tours and Travels in Mumbai.

A disappointed P V Vijesh, manager at Al Hind Tours and Travels in Kozhikode, said they had been looking forward to a good Umrah season with around 400 pilgrims bookings every month. Baba Bhai Kolsawala, a tour operator from Mumbai, hoped the suspension of Umrah and visit visas would be revoked soon. Telangana Waqf board chairman Mohammad Saleem said he had put off his plans for Umrah in view of the virus threat. Salahuddin Ansari, officer on special duty on the board, said he and his family were to leave for Jeddah from Hyderabad on Friday. “Now, I have cancelled my leave and am joining duty,” he said.

Saudi Arabian Airlines officials, though, informed trade partners in the afternoon that passengers holding employment, work visit visas, business visit visas and family visit visas can be accepted for travel.

Though Saudi authorities have not specified the period of ban on Indian pilgrims for Umrah, in a separate circular the Saudi ministry of health has imposed restriction on travel and cancelled leave of employees in the Mecca healthcare cluster from March 15 to May 30. Imposing a ban on travel for those in Mecca cluster, the health ministry said except in urgent cases, travel outside the station should not be allowed.

Title: Man held for extortion of Rs 75 lakh
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Pune: The crime branch on Thursday arrested Manoj Adsul from Mumbai for extorting a sum of Rs75 lakh from a doctor after issuing threats to him.

Adsul was produced before a court on Thursday, which remanded him in the police custody till March 5.

A woman had filed a complaint of molestation against the doctor’s son a earlier but the case was withdrawn.

However, Adsul threatened the doctor that the woman would file a case against him again and extorted the sum. Deputy commissioner of police (crime), Bachchan Singh, said Adsul transferred the money to 12 accounts.

Title: Taj Mahotsav extended for three days
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Agra: The UP tourism department has decided to extend the ongoing Taj Mahotsav for the next three days till March 1 owing to its suspension for a day during US president Donald Trump’s visit to Agra on February 24.

The extension was announced by the district officials on Thursday, the day of the closing ceremony. The price of entry tickets to the event has been reduced from Rs 50 to Rs 20. The cultural programmes which were scheduled on February 24 have also been rescheduled for February 28.

According to information, 44 lakh tickets have been sold in the past 10 days and after the extension, officials are expecting to cross sale of 50 lakh tickets.

Taj Mahotsav is organised every year by the UP tourism department which provides a vibrant platform to artisans from all parts of the country to showcase their talent.

This year, the carnival has almost 375 stalls and 258 artisans from different parts of the India participating in it and showcasing their talent to promote local handicrafts. Visitors are showing keen interest for handicrafts in brass and other metal ware from Moradabad, pashmina shawls from Kashmir, silk sarees from Varansai, silk from Bihar, kantha sarees from West Bengal, chikan from Lucknow, handmade carpets from Bhadohi, pottery of Khurja and much more. The annual extravaganza is the best time to witness the rich cultural heritage of the country under one roof.

Theme for this year’s Taj Mahotsav is ‘Sanskriti ke rang Taj Ke sang’ (shades of culture with Taj). Various cultural programmes were held in the past 10 days.

Title: Five-day week in PMC to commence from Saturday
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Civic activists said that the PMC’s move is not public friendly

PUNE: The corporation will introduce the five-day week system for the municipal staffers from this Saturday.

The Pune Municipal Corporation ( PMC ) employees will have to work 45 minutes extra every day once the new schedule starts to compensate for the extra holidays. Staffers in emergency services of the civic body would be excluded from the system.

The PMC commissioner’s office issued a circular making the announcement on Thursday. “The civic employees will have to come 15 minutes before their scheduled arrival time and leave 30 minutes later than their prescribed departure time,” said the commissioner, Shekhar Gaikwad, in the circular.

The civic activists said that the PMC’s move is not public friendly and that it was taken only for the benefit of the civic staff.

“The PMC could have taken a different stand in this matter. They could have continued with the same system,” said Vivek Velankar of Sajag Nagrik Manch, a citizens’ group.

He said the salaried people, including the large workforce engaged in the information technology industry, residing in the city would be adversely affected by PMC’s move.
