Earlier, they could go and do the civic body-related works on Saturdays. But now, they would have to take leave to get the works done, he said.

He claimed that the online services of the PMC were very poor. So, it would be double whammy for common people,” he added.

The state government approved the five-day week system for all the state government employees, starting February 29. It will benefit around 22 lakh employees. Till now, the state government employees were getting offs on second and fourth Saturdays.

Once the five-day week starts, the working days will reduce to 264 from 288. The per day work hours will be increased from seven hours and 15 minutes to eight hours to compensate for the extra holidays.

Title: 21 booked in Moradabad for objectionable remarks
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: Police in Moradabad have registered a case against at least 21 people, including Vishwa Hindu Mahasangh (VHM) district president Satish Dhal, for making objectionable remarks and trying to vitiate the atmosphere.

According to police, the accused were protesting in reaction to AIMIM member Waris Pathan for his recent objectionable remarks at Kalaburagi in Karnataka. The agitators also set Pathan’s effigy on fire at Civil Lines.

On Thursday, station house officer, inspector Nawal Marwah, said that scores of people had gathered outside the collectorate to submit a memorandum to district magistrate in protest against Pathan’s comments.

“The outpost in-charge was there when the agitators reached collectorate and raised objectionable slogans. They threatened to slit Waris Pathan’s throat and the video of the speech went viral. Taking suo moto cognisance of the matter an FIR under section 295A (deliberate and malicious acts, intended to outrage religious feelings of any class by insulting its religion or religious beliefs) of IPC has been registered against as many as 21 accused,” he said.

Notably, Pathan, who had recently contested the Maharashtra assembly polls, had said that 15 crore Muslims were more than a match for the country’s 100 crore Hindus. On February 20, while addressing an anti-Citizenship Amendment Act rally at Kalaburagi in Karnataka, Pathan had said, “Time has now come for us to unite and achieve freedom. Remember we are 15 crore but can dominate over 100 crore.”

Title: Six held for beating up duo & ruckus
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Pune: Six people were arrested, and their four accomplices were booked for beating up and injuring two men after one of them objected to the group’s liquor consumption on an open plot along Ganeshkhind Road in the early hours of Wednesday.

The Chatushrungi police said the suspects attacked the duo — Rashid Shaikh (51) of Gokhalenagar and Ramesh Marani (38) of Ganeshkhind Road — with sticks and beer bottles. Shaikh filed an FIR with the police.

Badshah Babu Jadhav (37), Dinesh Laxman Jadhav (34), Ashish Narayan Devkar (22), Datta Vishnu Jadhav (26), Manoj Maruti Devkar (44) and Akshay Kaluram Devkar (26), of Wadarwadi in Shivajinagar, were arrested between Wednesday and Thursday for rioting and causing voluntary hurt to the duo.

Assistant inspector D S Shinde of the Chatushrungi police said, “Shaikh saw the men consuming liquor along Ganeshkhind Road. He called the elder brother of one of them.”

The elder brother of the man visited the site and scolded him. “The enraged group decided to take revenge and they beat up the duo with sticks and beer bottles,” Shinde said.

Title: Sweet shops to display ‘best before’, manufacturing date from June 1
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Pune: Starting June 1, mithai shops will have to display the “date of manufacturing” and “best before date” for loose sweets kept in trays/containers or jars for sale.

Currently, it is mandatory to mention these details on pre-packaged sweets. The Food Safety and Standards Association of India (FSSAI) in its latest notification issued on February 24, said that this will be effective across the country from June 1.

"This is a significant step in safeguarding consumers' health and ensuring that they get value for money. In Maharashtra, we will initially focus on public education followed by strict action against violators," state FDA commissioner Arun Unhale told TOI.

Food business operators can decide and display the ‘best before date’ depending on the nature of the product, and local condition. "An indicative list of shelf life of various types of sweets is given in the guidance note on safety and quality of traditional milk products. The list is available on the FSSAI website," said Dilip Sangat, assistant commissioner (food), FDA. " This step will help consumers make an informed decision. However, there are chances of these dates being manipulated. Hence, some mechanism should be in place to ensure that there is no malpractice," said medical practitioner Abhijit More.

Senior paediatrician Sharad Agarkhedkar, former state president, the Indian Medical Association, said, "Eating sweets long after they have been made may cause food poisoning or other complaints, including vomiting, nausea etc."

Title: Bengal workers escape Delhi violence, take train home
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

The labourers were rescued on Wednesday evening and subsequently, put on train

KOLKATA/BEHRAMPORE: As violence, arson and lynching ruled the streets of Maujpur in Delhi on Monday night, 11 labourers from Murshidabad, who had gone to the capital for work, managed to escape the mob and return to their one-room accommodation in a “Hindu neighbourhood” at Ghonda Chowk, barely a kilometre from the riot-torn zone. The next 48 hours were living hell for them, as they remained hidden inside a dingy storeroom without food or sleep, waiting for help to arrive. They, along with two others, were finally rescued on Wednesday night and sent back home in Naoda, Murshidabad.

Kamal Shekh landed in Delhi a few weeks ago after he got a job at a fan manufacturing unit in northeast Delhi. His friends, who were already there, offered him to stay with them. “Things were alright till Monday afternoon. We heard about trouble breaking out in some pockets and decided to go home early,” Shekh said. As they walked towards Ghonda Chowk, tension had started building up.

“By the time we reached home, managing to dodge attacks or confrontations, it was late. The factory owner told us to leave the place immediately. The violence on the street intensified as the night progressed. We stayed up, fearing an attack any moment,” Shekh said.

As day broke, they crept out of their accommodation. “No one spotted us. We took shelter in a small room that the factory owner arranged for us. It was a storage space and there was nothing to eat. Once, we climbed on to the roof to see hundreds of people roaming the lanes, armed with bamboo poles and stones. We climbed back to the room and remained locked for the next two days. Each minute seemed longer than hours,” he said.

As they started calling up people, the first to respond was Bangla Sanskriti Mancha, a Kolkata-based organization. The Mancha members stayed in touch with them but could not enter the area as curfew had been imposed.

Tanmay Ghosh, secretary of the organization, said, “A few members took help from AAP leaders and JNU students for the rescue operation.” The news also reached Behrampore MP Adhir Chowdhury, who contacted MoS for home G Kishan Reddy. “Cops rescued us on Wednesday evening. We could breathe again only after we reached Delhi station,” Shekh said. Chowdhury tweeted: “We have made arrangements for their return and they will reach Kolkata safely...”

Title: New phishing tactic: Fake online transaction message
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: Move over phishing calls and messages where fraudsters ask for your bank details posing as bank manager or as KYC update executives. The fraudsters have now started replicating messages sent by banks after every valid online transaction or every purchase using debit or credit cards, where they claim a large sum of money has been debited from your account and ask you to call at a number or click on a suspicious link if it wasn’t done by you. The moment you do so, you end up exposing yourself to a potential financial fraud where the fraudster may end up robbing your money with details you only share with them.Alerting citizens about the new method of phishing, Kolkata Police posted a detailed message on their Facebook page with three such examples. Within hours, the post was viewed by thousands of people and shared over 5,000 times. Hundreds of users commented on how they too received similar messages over the past few days.“The scamsters have changed the language and construction of sentence in the messages they send now. The messages look and read exactly like the valid SMS alerts from banks after every card or online transaction. They can cheat you with these fraudulent messages. Read the message carefully and avoid calling any number or clicking on the link if they seem even a bit suspicious,” said a senior officer of Kolkata Police.The post explains that these fake SMS alerts look very genuine. But when a bank sends an SMS, the last four digits of your account number remains visible while the rest are marked “X”. But in case of these fake text messages, all the numbers of the bank account are marked “X” as the fraudsters in most cases don’t know the exact account number.“The messages will ask the receiver to call up at some numbers to lodge a complaint if the transactions were not done by him/her. Please don’t be duped by such messages. If you receive such texts, immediately dial Lalbazar’s anti-bank fraud helpline number 8585063104,” said another officer.Schoolteacher Arijit Roy Chowdhury received a similar message last Tuesday. “The message looked genuine with a proper transaction ID. It said an amount of Rs 32,000 had been debited from my account from an ATM. I dialled the number mentioned and the person on the other end said he would note down my bank details for verification and ensure the money is back in my account within a week. He sought my card’s CVV number and other confidential details that alerted me and while still on the call I checked my account balance and it was intact. I realised it was a fraud and disconnected the call,” said Roy Chowdhury, a resident of Cossipore. Alerted by the cop post, a number of users also began posting screengrabs of the messages they received recently.

Title: Phase 1 of farmers’ Aadhaar database to be ready by June
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Pune: The first phase of authenticating the Aadhaar number of farmers in the state with their landholdings, as part of a pilot project launched by the central government in November last year, is expected to be ready by June, agriculture department officials said.

From Pune, two talukas — Pune Khed and Shirur — were selected for the project covering ten villages. With the pilot completed, the process is now ready to be rolled out across the entire state, stated officials.

Nearly 11,000 beneficiaries of soil health card, PM-Kisan and crop insurance scheme from Pune district had their Aadhaar number authenticated with their landholdings.

The novel initiative entails setting up of a master database for implementing farmer-related government schemes and consolidating a genuine list of farmers. While the move is to ensure that the schemes are disbursed to authentic beneficiaries, states have the task to verify the landholdings of the farmers and submit the data. The creation of an authentic database of farmers with their landholdings and crop varieties produced by them will be one of its kind in the country, added the official.

Maharashtra is among the six states selected for the pilot, the others being Andhra Pradesh, Odissha, Uttar Pradesh, Tamil Nadu and Tripura. The remaining phase of the project is expected to complete by 2021.

“We expect the farmer database of nearly 6 crore farmers by June this year and the remaining farmers pan India by next year,’’ stated Union ministry of agriculture secretary Sanjay Agarwal. This will be used as a master database for implementing farmer-related government schemes.

With a database of beneficiaries of soil health cards, crop insurance scheme, PM-KISAN and other government schemes already in place, efforts will be made to link and integrate all databases and create one Aadhaar-authenticated data.

Title: 1.4 lakh beneficiaries to receive loan waiver amount by May
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Pune: Around Rs1200 crore will be disbursed to nearly 1.40 lakh beneficiaries of the Mahatma Jyotirao Phule farm loan waiver scheme in Pune district by May, collector Naval Kishore Ram said on Thursday.

As per the scheme, loan of up to Rs 2 lakh availed between April 1,2015, and March 31, 2019, and which has not been repaid till September 30, 2019, will be deemed eligible for the loan waiver, according to the GR issued in December last year by the Maha Vikas Aghadi government.

On Monday, the state government released the first list of crop loan waiver for 15,358 farmers. The beneficiaries will be given waiver after Aadhaar authentication. TNN

Title: Telangana: Man crashes bike into electric pole, dies
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A 25-year-old died after he rammed his bike into an electric pole on the median near Icrisat on Thursday. The deceased was identified as Goutham Kumar, a resident of Lingampally .

Goutham was on his way to Icrisat but crashed his bike just after reaching Reliance petrol pump on NH-65. The victim was not wearing a helmet. A case was registered.

Title: Telangana: School bus mows down two siblings
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: An unregistered, new school bus turned into a killer bus on Thursday when it snuffed out lives of two young students — siblings — at Yacharam when they were on their way to attend a function. The accused bus driver was taken into custody.

Their father B Ramesh, who was riding a motorbike, and brother suffered injuries when the school bus knocked down the bike. Police said Ramesh lost control of his bike when the bus swerved to the left all of a sudden. “He was blindsighted by this sudden turn, crashed the bike and fell down,” police said.

Ramesh’s eldest son Vivek (12), a class VII student, and the youngest son Gautham (6), an LKG student, died on the spot of severe head injuries. His other son Vishal escaped with minor injuries. Both Ramesh and Vishal, however, were shifted to a hospital.

“Ramesh’s bike was right behind the bus which was on its way to the RTO office for a registration. The bus took a sudden left turn without switching on the indicator, due to which Ramesh lost control,” Yacharam inspector M Madhu Kumar said.

The bus belongs to St Gregorios Public School in Yacharam. It was empty at the time (12.45 pm) of the mishap. The function hall was less than 2km from the accident site, police said. Ramesh is a lorry driver. Bus driver Mahipal Reddy (35) was booked under various sections of the IPC.

Title: Constable killed in road accident
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

A 34-year-old constable died after an unknown vehicle rammed his bike. The victim, Sirikonda Ravinder, a native of Nalgonda was proceeding towards LB Nagar when the vehicle crashed into his bike. He sustained blunt injuries and was declared dead on arrival at a hospital. A case was registered under section 304-A (causing death by negligence) of IPC. TNN

Title: Driver gets 6 yrs jail for reckless driving
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

A 27-year-old driver was sentenced to undergo imprisonment for six months for causing grievous hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others. The accused was identified as Ramannagouda Wathar, a resident of Bijapur. The accused was convicted and asked to pay a fine of Rs 1000. TNN

Title: Bengaluru: Four held for raising Rs 2 crore loan in the name of fake firms
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative Image

BENGALURU: Sleuths from Criminal Investigation Department ( CID ) arrested four men who cheated different banks by borrowing Rs 2 crore from them in the name of fake companies. Two of them were arrested earlier for cheating and human-trafficking.

The arrested are Uday Pratap, 48, of Arakere Layout on Bannerghatta Road, Ayub Ali, 42, Mahesh alias Madesha, 36, of Shivamogga and Ramegowda, 30, of Rajajinagar. Police recovered Rs 80 lakh cash, a new SUV and various documents, including fake Aadhaar and PAN cards from the quartet.

B Dayananda, additional director general of police, CID said the accused had opened accounts in 40 different banks in Bengaluru and Mysuru with an intention to cheat them. Six of these banks granted loans of different amounts to the accused.

Uday has 16 cases of human-trafficking pending against him, while Ayub, whose details are yet to be ascertained, faces five cases of cheating, where he had promised his victims medical seats.

CID SP ( cybercrime ) MD Sharath said the accused would open salary accounts in the banks. “First, they would open a bank account in the name of a fake company. Then, they would open salary accounts of their non-existent staffers. The accused furnished fake Aadhaar and PAN cards to these banks to open these accounts,” he added.

Over the next few months, cash would be deposited under ‘salaries’ category into these accounts and would be withdrawn from them. “Seeing a healthy transaction, the bank would extend loan facility to their employer-company. Uday and Ayub would introduce themselves as managing directors of the company and apply for loans,” said Sharath.

According to investigating officials, the accused would hire a small office premises for a few months. “When bank officials came for physical verification, the accused would take them to the office. The nameplate of the office would be changed when officials from other banks came visiting,” investigating officials said.

Trusting the accused, six banks granted loans to them, totalling to around Rs 2 crore, police said.

“The accused would pay the first six or eight equated monthly instalments (EMIs) before vanishing. They had two reasons for doing this: firstly, they’d empty their office and destroy all possible evidences during this time. Secondly, the banks would have penalised the agents or middlemen helping the accused, if no EMI was paid. The accused would continue their relationship with the agents to take their help in future, ” sources said.

Title: Bengaluru: Citizens claim 17 new sweeping units not functional; BBMP says 8 in use
Content:
The 17 mechanical sweepers, purchased on February 8, were an addition to BBMP’s existing fleet

BENGALURU: Almost three weeks after Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike ( BBMP ) purchased a fleet of 17 mechanical sweepers, none of them has hit the road to clean the city’s streets, allege citizen activists. However, the civic agency maintains eight of them are functional.The 17 mechanical sweepers were purchased for Rs 70 lakh a piece on February 8 and were an addition to BBMP’s existing fleet of nine such machines.The civic agency is drawing flak from citizen activists for spending lakhs of rupees on brand new mechanical sweepers but allowing them to gather dust in its parking lots. They suspect the Palike’s nexus with the garbage mafia is behind the vehicles lying in disuse.In a video uploaded on Twitter, Kavitha Reddy, a civic activist, is seen standing next to a line of mechanical sweepers parked in HSR Layout. She’s complaining about the vehicles gobbling up space instead of cleaning roads. Kavitha alleged BBMP wasn’t using even its old fleet of nine machines it had purchased in 2018. “It has been over two years and the mechanical sweepers are lying on a service road. They are not being used,” she claimed.BBMP officials said in all 17 machines, including eight new and nine old, were operating and the other new ones will be deployed by first week of March after they are fitted with GPS.“A few days ago, these mechanical sweepers were repainted and chief minister BS Yediurappa took a picture with them,” Kavitha said, adding the civic agency doesn’t want to keep the city clean as the garbage mafia doesn’t allow it.The mechanical sweepers are used only when a minister is visiting an area or a vehicle is launched, alleged Narayan K, another resident of HSR Layout. “BBMP claims to be cleaning roads at night but not a single one appears clean in the morning. The roads are full of dust,” he added.TOI spoke to a contractor about the machines he was supposed to operate not being used. He said councillors don’t allow mechanical sweepers to function in their wards. “When we take out the vehicles at night to clean the streets, councillors send their men and ask us to stop,” claimed the contractor. “They, in fact, harass us and even take away the keys,” he added.Leaving behind a trail of dustBBMP often flaunts its fleet of mechanical sweepers to underline its commitment to keep Bengaluru roads spick and span. But it has only drawn flak because of the machines, with citizens alleging they only leave behind a trail of dust. In fact, the civic agency’s decision to deploy the machines only at night is due to the backlash it fears in case they are used during the day.On December 9 last year, a mechanical sweeper was deployed in Yelahanka zone for cleaning roads ahead of a VIP visit. But the road users were aghast after the machine kicked up a cloud of dust it had lifted. BBMP zonal officials promptly admitted they were forced to use the machine during the day due to the VIP visit.The 17 new machines are to be equipped with GPS. According to BBMP's plans, they will be deployed on a stretch once every three days.Some being equipped with GPSSome mechanical sweepers are parked in HSR Layout every day after being used in their respective jurisdictions. That seems to have been construed as disuse. Deployment order for the new sweeping machines has been issued and eight of them are operational. The rest are being equipped with GPSD Randeep, special commissioner, SWM

Title: Pune: New MSRTC facility lacks compound wall, rest rooms
Content:
New bus stand at Wakdewadi

PUNE: The state transport utility has urged MahaMetro to complete on a priority basis the basic facilities at the makeshift bus terminus in Wakdewadi.The Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation (MSRTC) on January 1 shifted the operations from its Shivajinagar depot to Wakdewadi to facilitate Metro work. The Maharashtra Metro Rail Corporation Limited was entrusted with the task of setting up of the Wakdewadi facility.Two months have passed since then, but the newly developed facility is yet have a compound wall, rest room for drivers and conductors and toilets. “Most facilities for the commuters are in place at the new site. Some work pertaining to rest rooms for our drivers, conductors and staffers are yet to be completed. We are following up the issue with the MahaMetro administration and have urged them to take up the pending construction on a priority basis,” a senior MSRTC official said.The MSRTC is in the process to shift the bus maintenance depot to Wakdewadi. A shed has been constructed by MahaMetro for repairs and maintenance of the buses. The shed will have some amenities for passengers.An MSRTC official said among the civil works proposed at the new location were water tanks and separate toilet facilities for its drivers and conductors.MahaMetro officials said they would complete all the work mentioned in the contract signed with the MSRTC. “We will provide all necessary assistance to complete the pending works at the earliest,” a MahaMetro official said.MahaMetro has, in the meantime, started construction of the underground Metro work at Shivajinagar. “Demolition of building structures and piling work have started. We have deployed machineries at the site to expedite the station’s work,” a MahaMetro official said.

Title: Bengaluru: Taxmen unearth 60 kg gold sans documents
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative Image

BENGALURU: At a time when gold prices are soaring, a surprise inspection of jewellery dealers in Chickpet by the state commercial taxes department has unearthed massive Goods and Services Tax (GST) violations and unaccounted gold.

The raids on 23 jewellers in Chickpet found 60kg of gold ornaments worth Rs 21 crore without valid documents. Officials also detected evasion of GST to the tune of Rs 1.3 crore.

Officials said they conducted the raids on wholesale jewellery dealers on Tuesday. “The raids were based on credible information and data analytics available in the backend system with the department,” said MS Srikar, commissioner of commercial taxes.

“The raids were based on information that many traders from other states visit the city and carry gold jewellery without any valid documents and supply it to local jewellers without invoices,” he said.

Officials said penalty was levied on the ornaments for which dealers couldn’t produce documents. “During the inspection, the officials caught two people carrying 3.5kg of gold ornaments in their bags without documents and collected penalty for the same,” they said.

In December 2019, a similar inspection was conducted on silver dealers in Raja Market. “The enforcement wing is keeping a close watch on the interstate movement of gold and silver. All dealers in the state have been advised not to buy any goods without valid invoices,” said Srikar.

Title: Azam Khan: SP leader Azam Khan, wife and son shifted to Sitapur jail
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

SP leader Azam Khan

RAMPUR: A day after surrendering before a local court, which remanded them in judicial custody for six days, senior Samajwadi Party leader and Rampur MP Azam Khan , his wife Tanzeen Fatimah and son Abdullah Azam were shifted to the Sitapur district jail — nearly 250km from Rampur — for “security reasons” early on Thursday morning.

“The decision was taken jointly by the district police, Rampur jail authorities and the administration for security reasons,” district magistrate Aunjaneya Kumar Singh told TOI.

Around 5am, the trio — accused of forging documents to help Abdullah get two birth certificates — was moved out of the Rampur district jail in a van for Sitapur under heavy security cover. The next date of hearing is March 2.

The DM said, “Many inmates lodged at the Rampur jail for different crimes were rounded up and chargesheeted by the SP government, in which Azam was a Cabinet minister, and officials suspect that the MP and his family could be attacked by inmates out of vengeance in the jail. Thus, they were shifted.”

Meanwhile, Azam’s counsel Khalil Ullaha Khan approached additional district and sessions judge Dhirendra Kumar Kamboj against the decision to shift his clients to the Sitapur jail , following which the ADJ sought a detailed report from the jail superintendent in this connection.

Meanwhile, SP chief Akhilesh Yadav, who visited Sitapur jail, termed the action against Azam and his family “a political vendetta”.

Title: 122-year-old Vedic scholar, freedom fighter dead
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Bengaluru: Freedom fighter and Kannada Rajyotsava awardee Pandit Sudhakar Chaturvedi passed away at his residence on Thursday. He was said to be 122 years old.

Chaturvedi had a long association with Arya Samaj and retired from active social work a decade ago. Living with his family in Jayanagar, he passed away in his sleep at 3am.

Born Sudhakar Krishna Rao in Balepet in 1897, according to reports that couldn’t be independently verified, his family was originally from Kyatsandra near Tumakuru. They settled down in Bengaluru after Chaturvedi’s father became an inspector with the education department of the then Mysore government. Chaturvedi studied in the government primary school at Chamarajpet, but moved to Haridwar when he was 10 to join Arya Samaj.

During his gurukul days, he was inspired by the works of Swami Sharaddananda and later joined the news daily Vijay, started by Sharaddananda to support the freedom struggle soon after World War 1. Chaturvedi’s stint as a reporter took him to Jallianwala Bagh in Amristar on April 13, 1919. He recalled the massacre in his biography, Shataayushi Pandita Sudhakara Chaturvedi, penned by N Nagalaxmi.

Chaturvedi joined the freedom struggle and was an ardent supporter of Mahatma Gandhi. “He remained close to the Mahatma and worked for the upliftment of Scheduled Castes, mainly in Karnataka. Gandhi was fond of Chaturvedi and often called him Karnataki,” recalled Gandhian and Kannada historian Vemagal Somashekar.

An expert in Vedas, Chaturvedi conducted seminars and wrote extensively on Vedic practices after Independence. He was well-versed in Kannada, Sanskrit, Hindi and English.

Title: Giving animals a new leash of life
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

From rescuing and rehabilitating injured, disabled and abandoned animals to counselling people involved in acts of cruelty to animals, Panneeru Prudhvi and Panneeru Teja have spent more than 10 years rescuing countless dogs, cats, birds, camels and several species of birds.

Narrating their journey, the two brothers say they knew right from their childhood that they wanted to dedicate themselves to help animals.

“As kids, we used to buy accessories for a dog even before we could bring one home,” said Teja. “Our parents never encouraged us to have a pet because they were worried we will not be able to take responsibility. And then, one day, my brother just brought a dog home. My mother was not very happy initially, but she got convinced after we promised to take good care of it.”

However, they say their journey towards becoming full-time animal caretakers and rescuers began only after getting introduced to an animal activist who inspired them to start volunteering for Blue Cross. They worked there for a while before training themselves in canine behaviour. Prudhvi is planning to pursue a course in animal law.

The brothers set up their own kennel at Cherlapally in 2018. “We want more people to come forward and help animals. Our aim is to build a network of like-minded people who can help animals and ensure they are able to co-exist peacefully with people,” said Prudhvi.

Teja and Prudhvi were part of the animal rescue operation during the Mahabubnagar floods and mission rabies project, where several dogs were vaccinated. “It is alright if you do not want to help animals but at least do not buy them from illegal breeders or abuse them,” Prudhvi said.

Speaking about their work, Mathew Christopher, a resident of Lalapet, said: “I met the brothers four years ago and since have been associated with them. Once Teja and his brother went down a well — around 40 to 50 foot deep — to rescue a cat.” He said, “Another time they rescued a badly beaten and abused dog, Fighter. We never imagined the dog would survive, and it is one of the happiest dogs in their kennel today.”

Title: History-sheeter killed by rivals, body burnt
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Hyderabad: A history-sheeter was murdered near his Venkatapuram house in Alwal by unidentified assailants who later torched the body also. Michael DSouza (30) was attacked with a blunt object in the early hours of Thursday, police said. “Michael was an accused in multiple assault and intimidation cases. We suspect his rivals might be behind the murder ,” Alwal inspector P Yadagiri said.

“The assailants attacked Michael with sharp-edged objects and killed him. They later dragged the body near his house and set it ablaze with kerosene,” Yadagiri said. Cops suspect the victim could have been killed between 1 am and 3 am. A local alerted the cops. Police are analysing CCTV camera footages to identify the assailants.

Petbasheerabad ACP AVR Narasimha Rao said Michael’s parents died when he was a child. “He was living alone at Kotha Basthi in Venkatapuram. Eight months ago, he was involved in an assault case and fled from his house. Locals saw him near his house on Wednesday,” Rao said.

Locals told cops that Michael was roaming in the lanes and causing nuisance. He is survived by his younger brother and sister.

Title: Bihar now passes resolution seeking caste-based census
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Bihar CM Nitish Kumar

PATNA: The state assembly on Thursday unanimously adopted a resolution that the coming 2021 Census in the country should be based on caste, as the preparatory process for the launch of the enumeration of the country’s population and various aspects of their life has already been started by the office of the country’s registrar general and census commissioner, a subsidiary of the Union ministry of home affairs. Political parties have welcomed it.

Bihar is the second state to seek a caste-based census. Earlier on January 8 last, the Maharashtra House had passed a similar resolution.

Assembly speaker Vijay Kumar Choudhary on Thursday moved a one-line resolution in the pre-lunch session that the country’s Census 2021 should be based on caste, which the House adopted and passed it unanimously by thumping the desks. The resolution passed by the House would be duly sent to the Centre.

This followed the proposal of chief minister Nitish Kumar made in the House on Tuesday that it should adopt a resolution regarding holding the caste-based census in the country. “The last time, the caste census in the country had been made was in 1931. Several decades had passed since then. It has become necessary to hold the caste-based census again,” the CM had said on Tuesday.

Responding to the suggestion of the CM, Choudhary had said that it would be taken up at an “opportune time,” and accordingly, he proposed it on Thursday for adoption by the House. Explaining the government’s position on the caste census, the CM had said that both the state assembly and the legislative council, earlier in 2013, had also passed a resolution regarding the need for caste-based census. Further, the socio-economic survey and caste enumeration done in 2011 was for a limited purpose and was also found to be flawed, the CM had also said.

Observers felt that the political parties, like the RJD, had insisted on its demand that the details of the socio-economic and caste census should be made public, and had also made it an election issue, since it was made the basis for the demand for an increased number of “job quota” in proportion to the population figures of various castes falling in the intermediate caste groups (backward castes and extremely backward castes).

In fact, it had become a major issue during the 2015 Bihar assembly elections in which the NDA lost to the grand alliance, then comprising the JD(U), RJD and Congress. On Thursday, after the resolution regarding the caste census was adopted in the state assembly, reactions of political parties were on expected lines.

Talking to mediapersons, senior BJP leader and road construction department minister Nand Kishore Yadav said, “No, there is nothing new about it. Earlier too, the House had passed a resolution for a caste-based census.”

Similarly, the RJD chief whip Lalit Kumar Yadav said that his party has long conducted a popular struggle from “sadak (road)” to “Parliament/legislature” demanding that caste-based census be also held. “Today, the state assembly adopted a resolution on it again. We welcome it,” Yadav said.

Title: Telangana: Attempt to murder case against man for assaulting his wife
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A tipper driver was arrested for allegedly assaulting his wife at Kokapet on Thursday. He reportedly asked his son to record the assault on his mobile phone. Narsingi police have slapped attempt to murder and domestic harassment charges against tipper driver P Srinivas for harassing his wife, Manjula.

Srinivas had married Manjula of Wanaparthy 15 years ago and they have a 11-year-old son, police said. “Suspecting his wife’s character, Srinivas had been physically and mentally harassing her for the past few years. On February 25, Srinivas assaulted Manjula with an iron rod and made their son video record it on a cell phone,” Narsingi inspector Gangadhar said. Manjula suffered multiple injuries, including bleeding head injuries, in the assault.

Title: Convoy halts, Telangana CM K Chandrasekhar Rao grants a disabled man house, pension
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

KCR came across the 62-year-old with disabilities on his way back from a function near Tolichowki

HYDERABAD: On his way back to Pragathi Bhavan after attending a private function in Tolichowki on Thursday, chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao suddenly stopped his convoy midway, catching senior officials and security entourage off guard.

KCR got off his bullet-proof car on the roadside and approached a person holding a piece of paper. He made enquiries about the disabled person who introduced himself as Mohammed Saleem to the chief minister. The CM gave a patient hearing to the plight of Saleem and on the spot granted him pension and a double bedroom house.

Saleem told the chief minister that he was a driver and had been suffering from various ailments for the last nine years. Saleem broke his leg four years ago when he fell from a building.KCR responded immediately and instructed Hyderabad district collector Swetha Mohanty to disburse the disabled pension to Saleem and allot a two-bedroom house. Since Saleem had a disabled certificate, the collector sanctioned pension immediately and handed over Rs 3,016 pension for February. She said a house was sanctioned to Saleem at Jiyaguda.

Title: Saudi Arabia suspends Umrah visa over coronavirus, pilgrimage plans of thousands from Hyderabad hit
Content:
Pilgrims who were supposed to depart for Saudi Arabia on Thursday had to return home from the airport after be... Read More

HYDERABAD: Hyderabad: The suspension of entry on Umrah pilgrims by Saudi Arabia will hit several Muslims from Hyderabad. The suspension, announced on Thursday, has been put in place to restrict the entry of citizens of countries where cases of Coronavirus have been reported. The Umrah is a minor pilgrimage performed any time except during the Haj season. Thousands of Muslims from Hyderabad and other parts of the state perform Umrah every year, particularly during the Islamic months of Rajab, Shaban and Ramzan.Rajab, which set in a few days back, marks the beginning of the peak season for Umrah. The number of pilgrims for Umrah goes up manifold during Ramzan, the Muslim month of fasting. The annual Haj season is five months away and Saudi authorities have not stated if they will continue the curbs during Haj too or restrict the number of pilgrims. The Haj season this year will begin in July.Several pilgrims who went to airport on Thursday had to return home as a result of the ban. There was confusion among pilgrims as the announcement from Saudi authorities had come at the last minute. Salahuddin Ansari, officer on special duty in Telangana state waqf board, told TOI that he and his family members were scheduled to leave for Jeddah on Friday but then their travel agent informed him about the ban on Umrah. “I had prepared for Umrah for several months. We had packed our luggage and everyone in my family was ready for the pilgrimage. Now, I have cancelled my leave and am joining duty,” Salahuddin said.Waqf board chairman Mohammad Saleem said he too had put off his plans for Umrah in view of Coronavirus threat . “We have prepared the itinerary for mid-March. But the sudden ban on Umrah has come as a shock for us,” he told TOI. Wahiduddin Khaja of Aero Wings Travel and Cargo Agency, which processes Umrah and Haj travels, said that around 500 people from Hyderabad leave for Umrah every day. “The ban is likely to last long as there is no respite from Coronavirus. It is a huge financial loss to travel agents in the country,” he said hoping that the ban would be lifted at least during Ramzan.According to World Health Organisation (WHO), novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) is a cousin of the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS), which is currently prevalent in Saudi Arabia. COVID-19, MERS and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) are caused by members of the Coronavirus family. Between December 1, 2019 and January 31, 2020, Saudi had reported 19 new cases of MERS including eight deaths. In view of the virus reaching Iran, Saudi authorities had imposed the travel ban.Though Saudi authorities have not specified the period of ban on Indian pilgrims for Umrah, in a separate circular the Saudi ministry of health has imposed restriction on travel and cancelled leaves of employees in the Mecca health care cluster from March 15 to May 30. Imposing ban on travel for those in Mecca cluster, the health ministry said except for urgent cases, travel outside the station should not be allowed.

Title: No one will be sent away with Telanaga CM K Chandrasekhar Rao in power: TRS MLA Arekapudi Gandhi
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

TRS MLA Arekapudi Gandhi (Image credit: Twitter)

HYDERABAD: Arekapudi Gandhi sparked a fresh controversy on Thursday by claiming that no Muslim would be sent away as long as CM K Chandrasekhar Rao is at the helm. His remarks came at a time when CAA, NRC and NPR have generated a lot of heat in Telangana.

Speaking to a group of Muslims from his constituency, Gandhi said: “Nobody can throw you (Muslims) out even if you come from Pakistan, Rajasthan, Maharashtra or Karnataka as long as CM KCR is alive. If such a situation arises, local corporators and I will come out with you and support you,” he told them. A video of this had gone viral already. He also said some BJP workers were working as agents and moving around in Hafeezpet, Hydernagar and Allwyn Colony areas by conducting an internal survey on CAA and asked locals to revolt against them.

Title: Karnataka State Road Transport Corporation accidents dip; officials say preventive systems in place
Content: BENGALURU: Last week’s accident in Tamil Nadu, where a rashly driven container truck collided with a Kerala State Road Transport Corporation bus killing 19 people, has put the spotlight on passenger safety. However, Karnataka State Road Transport Corporation (KSRTC) has seen a drop in the number of accidents involving its buses — from 1,266 in 2013-14 to 1,018 in 2018-19 — thanks to a slew of measures.In a first, KSRTC had piloted the Artificial intelligence (AI)-based anti-collision and anti-drowsiness system in two buses, which detects any vehicle/obstacle up to 50 metres and automatically reduces the speed and stops it. The system also monitors the driver’s eye movements and sounds an alarm in case he appears sleepy. “We are planning to extend this technology to 400 premium buses in a phased manner,” a senior KSRTC official said.Officials said seat belts are provided in front and last rows in most premium buses but only a few passengers use them.KSRTC also has check points at places like Krishnagiri, Palamaner, Bagepalli and Sakleshpur, where long-distance buses are stopped for about 10 minutes. The crew of buses plying between 1am and 5am has to halt and wash their faces, have tea and provide feedback on the vehicle condition and journey. “Alcometers are used to check whether the staffers are under the influence of alcohol,” said an official.Bengaluru-Chennai and Bengaluru-Coimbatore routes are more prone to accidents. “These are poorly designed highways and have more curves. Most sections along these two routes are not barricaded properly and are more vulnerable to accidents. Height of road dividers should be increased to prevent accidents,” pointed out officials.KSRTC ensures its staffers get rest. Buses running for more than 450km must have a driver and driver-cum-conductor so that one person is not at the wheel for long. “There’s a break of 48 hours after two trips. In private buses, staffers work continuously for 20 days and then take a 10-day break,” the officials said.Another official said most buses are fitted with an electronically controlled speed-locking system , which limits the speed at 80kmph. The corporation conducts redressal meetings with crew every month and also focuses on fuel efficiency. “We train drivers to achieve high fuel efficiency so that they are focused and don’t indulge in rash driving and sudden braking,” he added.

Title: Bengaluru: Rowdy facing 43 cases shot dead
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative Image

BENGALURU: A 32-year-old rowdy-sheeter and murder suspect was shot dead when he allegedly attempted to flee from police custody near Hesaraghatta, northwest of Bengaluru, in the wee hours of Thursday.

Bharath alias Slum Bharath, resident of Rajagopalnagar, succumbed to bullet injuries before cops could shift him to hospital from the scene of encounter around 5am. He was facing at least 43 criminal cases, including five of murder and seven of attempt to murder, besides dacoity and kidnap, across the city. He was arrested from a hideout in Uttar Pradesh recently and was brought to the city for questioning on Monday.

DCP (north) N Shashikumar said his men fired at Bharath in self-defence after he opened fire on them. Trouble began around 2am when Bharath was being taken for spot inquiry when at least two dozen associates came in two SUVs and several bikes and attacked the police party near Rajagopalnagar. Unprepared for the attack, police could not catch hold of Bharath, who jumped off the jeep and began running.

“Bharath sped away in a maroon Maruti Zen, while his associates were in a Toyota Innova. The news of his escape was flashed across the city. Around 5am, a police patrol vehicle spotted the Zen and Toyota Innova on Soldavanahalli Main Road. Soon, four teams headed by two inspectors rushed to the spot,” said Shashikumar.

This time, Bharath was inside the Innova with his aides. On reaching Hesaraghatta Main Road, police blocked Bharath’s vehicle. To their shock, he whipped out a pistol and fired five rounds at them, while his associates fled.

Questioning associates

Inspectors BN Lohit Kumar of Nandini Layout and Dinesh of Rajagopalnagar were wearing bulletproof jackets and remained unhurt, Shashikumar said. “In self-defence, the inspectors opened fire on Bharath, and the bullet hit his stomach. We shifted him to a nearby private hospital where doctors declared him brought dead.”

Police have now rounded up several of Bharath’s associates and are questioning them.

Title: War memorial, 7D theatre & yoga centre in PCMC budget
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Pimpri Chinchwad: Supplementary proposals for construction of a 7D theatre, competitive exam centres, a vipasana centre, a national war memorial , a health scheme and other projects were approved and included in the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC) budget for 2020-21 presented on Thursday.

Speaking to TOI, Vilas Madigeri, chairman of the standing committee, said six supplementary proposals amounting to Rs 700 crore were made to the Rs 6,627.99 crore draft budget presented by municipal commissioner Shravan Hardikar on February 17.

Madigeri said seven wonder theme park in Chinchwad assembly constituency at Rs 5 crore and a competitive exam centre each in Pimpri, Chinchwad and Bhosari assembly constituencies at Rs 1 crore were approved.

Approval for Rs 1 crore to construct a national war memorial for Paramvir Chakra awardees in Pimpri assembly constituency was given. A Rs 3 crore yoga bhavan and a Rs 1 crore vipasanna centre in Bhosari assembly constituency got the nod.

The 7D theatre would come up at Pimple Gurav and Rs 1 crore for construction of children’s traffic park at Pimple Saudagar was okayed. Approval for provision of Rs 2 crore for ‘Padma Bhushan Sushma Swaraj Arogya Yojana’ was also given at the meeting.

Financial assistance of maximum of Rs 50,000 will be provided for treatment of heart, kidney transplant and cancer patients.

The civic body now provides a maximum financial assistance of Rs 5,000 for treatment from mayor’s fund. Approval was also given for making provision of Rs 1 crore for picnics of Std VIII, IX and X municipal school students to forts. “The location for the war memorial will be identified later,” Madigeri said. The general body will approve the budget in March.

Title: Resign if you can’t crush it with an iron fist, Rajini tells Union govt
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Chennai: Actor Rajinikanth on Wednesday blamed intelligence failure for the violence in New Delhi. Any violence should be put down with an iron hand, he said and added that this should not have been allowed to happen when world leaders like US President Donald Trump were in India.

“It is a total failure of central intelligence. The Union home ministry’s intelligence failure. I strongly condemn it. They should put down violence with an iron hand or else they should resign and go,” Rajinikanth said, his tone sharp with anger, while talking to media representatives outside his Poes Garden residence. “They should have been so careful when US President (Donald) Trump had visited (the country). The intelligence didn’t do its job properly. It (violence) should have been completely crushed with an iron fist. We expect them to be careful at least from now on,” he added.

The actor said such protests should be nipped in the bud. “The protests in Delhi have gone too far. If they are not controlled now, it will lead to larger problems in future,” he said. “I always speak the truth. But it hurts when certain people, especially senior political observers and critics, say that I am promoting BJP’s thoughts and that BJP is behind me. It is not true,” he said.

Rajinikanth’s condemnation of the Delhi violence found immediate support in actor and Makkal Needhi Maiam president Kamal Haasan. “Sabaash my friend Rajinikanth,” Kamal tweeted in Tamil, welcoming his stand. “This is the right path. Not a lonely path, but one along which the entire state walks. Welcome and Congrats,” Kamal Haasan tweeted. Kamal was ostensibly taking a dig at Rajnikanth’s famous movie dialogue with a political innuendo, ‘En vazhi, thani vazhi’ (My path is a separate path).

Earlier, to a question on a Union minister making an incendiary speech that allegedly triggered the violence, Rajnikanth said just because one person said so, it is not right to blame the entire government for it. “I condemn anyone instigating people in the name of religion. I request the media to be neutral and not to give space for provocative speeches and violence,” he said.

“I had clearly mentioned earlier that if any single Muslim is affected by the CAA, I will come out and lead the protests,” Rajinikanth said, reiterating his earlier statement. “The CAA law has been passed by both houses of Parliament and it has received the President’s nod. I don’t believe it will be withdrawn by the Centre . People can protest. But, there should be no room for violence,” he said.

Title: Volunteers take on rough roads
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Every year thousands of people lose their lives on the road because of potholes. Rather than complaining and waiting for the civic body to repair them, 29-year-old Karthik Pallam, a techie from Sircilla town, decided to take matters into his own hands. In 2017, he filled his first pothole in Hi-Tec City with a meagre Rs 2,000, from his own pocket. Soon after, We Can Make a Change (WCMAC) was born.

Two years later, the NGO has 200 volunteers, mostly software engineers, who have fixed over 300 potholes across Hyderabad in areas such as Begumpet, Hi-Tec City, Panjagutta and Ameerpet among others. The Rs 2 lakh spent on the job has entirely been from their savings.

“When I was in Bengaluru previously, I had noticed that a pothole remained unattended for 45 days despite complaints. I later found that more people die owing to potholes than in terrorist attacks. So, I decided to fill potholes and thought it would be great achievement even if I could save one life,” Pallam told TOI.

Another volunteer from the group, Sudeepth Katkam, chipped in: “While travelling to office I once saw a bike skid on a pothole and fall right next to me. A motorist who veered to prevent hitting this bike fell too. And all because of a pothole. So, the next weekend we fixed the pothole.”

Along with fixing potholes, the NGO has now simultaneously started repairing government schools, including Anganwadis, in remote areas. They have repaired six school so far. Among them is Andhra Vidyalaya in Chikkadpally. TOI spoke to its principal B R Vidya Sagar, who said, “We get a meagre allowance, which is only enough to pay bills. We are happy with what WCMAC did. After the repairs, our attendance has increased and many dropouts too have returned to school.”

Volunteers said that the job is extremely gratifying. “After the repairs the children hug you and thank you…there is no greater reward than that,” said Chakradhar Ayachitula.

Title: Railway cops arrest three at station
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Vijayawada: The government railway police arrested three persons at the railway station on Thursday. All three people stand accused in several cases.

The three offenders have been identified as Challa Mahesh (35) of Devarampalli, Karimnagar district of Telangana, Nageli Vara Kumar (23), from Muthugudem in Khammam district of Telangana and Dasari Srinu (33) of Sathenapalli in Guntur district.

Mahesh stands accused in a rape and murder case and over 40 property offences and an non-bailable warrant is pending against him in Karimnagar and Warangal district. Mahesh was handed over to Karimnagar police. Kumar has been involved in over 15 property offences and was handed over to Vijayawada railway police. Dasari Srinu is a chain snatcher and stands accused in 24 cases. Police recovered 64 gms of gold jewellery from Srinu.

The GRP has been making use of the mobile security check device, which was given to them a month ago. The device, which comes equipped with a fingerprint database of criminals, allows police to take a fingerprint on the spot and run it against the database.

Title: If enforced, NRC may exclude 10.5 lakh from Hyderabad
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

Title: ‘Not bruises, illness could have caused Sinthee custody death’
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

KOLKATA: The autopsy report in the Sinthee custodial death case indicated that Raj Kumar Shaw (50) suffered cardiac arrest due to cardiovascular and renal problems. The report, however, pointed out that two bruises — one on the left elbow and another on the skull — were caused by “blunt trauma” that had taken place 12-24 hours before the autopsy, which coincided with the time Shaw was at the Sinthee police station on February 10. The report added the bruises could not have led to his death.

Police refused to comment on the report, which has been submitted to Calcutta High Court and sent to National Human Rights Commission. Shaw, the report said, was brought dead to RG Kar Hospital at 6.50pm on February 10 and an autopsy was carried out at 2pm, the next day. It was preceded by a judicial inquest, which, conducted over one hour, 10 minutes, indicated a final report could be given only after a histo-pathological examination of the viscera. On a query on whether the injuries alone could have caused the death, the report stated, “Injuries as noted above are singly or collectively not sufficient to cause death in ordinary course of nature.”

Lawyer Jayanta Narayan Chatterjee said, “Post-mortem report shows injuries on his head and elbow. This shows the version of eye witnesses—Shaw’s brother and son—who were present at the police station was right. He was assaulted and thereafter, he died. Police are responsible when a person expires due to cardiac arrest hours after he is assaulted inside a police station. A murder case should be started.” Police refused to comment. “The matter is sub judice”. It is being heard by the Calcutta HC. Two officers have been closed, one suspended,” an officer said.

Title: Avatarotsavam on March 1
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Tirupati: TTD will mark the 966th Avatarotsavam of Sri Vaishnavaite Sri Ananta Alwar, who wrote Nalayira Divya Prabandham in praise of Lord Maha Vishnu, at Tirumala on March 1.

TTD’s Alwar Divya Prabanda Project has been organising the event for the last nine years and there will be lectures on Alwar’s works.

Avatarotsavam will be held under the supervision of Acharya Rajagopalan, secretary, DPP and special officer, DPP. Descendants of Anantalwar will gather at the Purusaivarithota and perform Divya Prabanda Pasura Parayanam.

Title: AI for social good at CoEP
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Pune: Women from various organisations will discuss the use of artificial intelligence for social good at a conference at the College of Engineering Pune on Saturday.

Organised by Women in Data Science, which is dedicated to involving more women in data analytics and promoting the idea that data is gender neutral and can be used for socially-relevant activities, the event will start at 9am and end at 7pm. The Global Women in Data Science (WiDS) is a Stanford University initiative that aims to inspire and educate data scientists worldwide, regardless of gender, and support women in the field. People who have no knowledge of data sciences can also attend. There will be an online test for those who want to figure out whether they are suited for data science. “This talk is important for people who fear being laid off,” said Sucheta Dhere, a WiDS Pune ambassador.

Title: HC directs disciplinary action against 2 govt officials
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Madurai: Taking serious note of the dereliction of duty by a multipurpose health supervisor at the Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) and an inspector of police of the K Pudur police station in handing over the death certificate and postmortem report to the family of a woman who died due to medical negligence, the Madras high court has directed disciplinary action against them.

S Manimuthu, the husband of Sakthikali, filed a petition seeking Rs 10 lakh compensation for his wife’s death. The petitioner also sought to issue the death certificate and postmortem report. Sakthikali was admitted for delivery at the K Pudur urban primary health centre on September 14, 2019. The duty doctor stated that the delivery would be normal and there is no complication. After the doctor left the hospital, his wife went into labour and the doctor did not return till 11pm.

Few minutes later when the nurse called him inside the UPHC, he noticed that his wife was lying in a pool of blood and immediately he took his wife to the GRH in an ambulance where the doctors declared her brought dead. Based on his complaint, the K Pudur police have registered a case under Section 174 CrPC.

Justice Pushpa Sathyanarayana observed that the court had directed the authorities to file an affidavit explaining as to why the reasons for the death of woman was not informed to the petitioner. Refusing to accept the reasons cited by the officials for the delay, the judge observed that officials are pointing fingers at each other without performing their duties. “When it comes to uniformed services and health service, it is round-the-clock service and they have more rigid duty cast upon them than the other public servants,” observed the judge. The judge noted that only after the intervention of this court, the death certificate was handed over to the petitioner. The judge observed that it is abundantly clear that multipurpose supervisor Theenathayalan and inspector of police Muthukumar are prima facie liable for the lapses committed by them in the discharge of their duties. Hence, the judge directed the Madurai deputy director of health services and Madurai city commissioner of police to initiate appropriate departmental action against Theenathayalan and Muthukumar respectively within a period of four weeks.

The judge further directed the commissioner of police to hand over the investigation to some other inspector of police who should file a final report before the jurisdictional magistrate not later than three months.

Justice Pushpa Sathyanarayana also took cognizance of a government order (GO) passed by the health and family welfare department notifying the Tamil Nadu Clinical Establishments (Regulation) Rules, 2018, which prescribed minimum facilities of a clinical establishment including the number of staff and equipment. The judge directed the state government to ensure that all hospitals strictly comply with the rules and directed the health secretary to issue circulars to refer the patients to the district headquarters hospitals or other hospitals if the required facilities are not available at any hospitals rather than waiting for the patient to reach a critical condition.

Title: Kurnool girl back in India from China
Content: Vijayawada: The coronavirus Covid-19 ) has managed to destroy wedding plans of engineer Annem Jyothi from Kurnool district who has been struck in Wuhan city in China. Jyothi was supposed to marry Amarnath Reddy on March 15, but the wedding has been postponed.The 22-year-old engineer—and trainee engineer Satya Sai Krishna, from Srikakulam district—have been stranded in coronavirus-hit Wuhan. Relatives of Jyothi said Jyothi has been surviving on rice and pickle for the past month. With only non-vegetarian food available at the Chinese company’s dormitory, Jyothi has no other option to eat the rice and the pickle which she carried with her from India, they said.Earlier this month, Jyothi was not allowed to board the flights to India as her body temperature was higher than normal.Sources said that an Indian Air Force plane which had taken medical equipment to China’s Hubei province, returned today with 76 Indians and 36 nationals from seven other nations. They are being kept under observation for two weeks at an isolated ward in New Delhi. Jyothi and Satya Sai Krishna are among the 76 Indians.Amarnath Reddy—who is a relative of Jyothi and a charted accountant by profession in Nandyal in Kurnool—has been anxiously awaiting her return. However, the wedding was postponed as Jyothi’s relatives said that she would have to undergo tests following her return and would also need time to recover from the trauma.Seventy six Indians and 36 foreigners have been sent to an ITBP facility on the outskirts of New Delhi. They will be kept in quarantine for the next 14 days to ensure that they don’t have the COVID-19 virus.

Title: ‘Encourage women to become entrepreneurs’
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Julfesh Shah addresses women entrepreneurs at VIA auditorium

Nagpur: Women should be encouraged to become self-sufficient and turn entrepreneurs so that they also could generate employment opportunities for others also and help in boosting trade, said chartered accountant Julfesh Shah at Vidarbha Industries Association (VIA) auditorium on Wednesday.

He was addressing a session organized by VIA Lady Entrepreneurs ‘(LEW) wing on ‘New budget: Women entrepreneurs’ perspective and government schemes’. Reeta Lanjewar, chairperson of LEW and Sneha Trivedi from Burn Smooth Petrochem were present.

Shah highlighted various schemes the government launched to promote women entrepreneurship. It is time aspiring businesswomen make optimum use of technology to get details of schemes and start their units, he said.

Micro, small and medium scale (MSME) enterprises provide ample scope to avail benefits extended by the central and state governments and women should help bring about a change to usher in economic and social development, he said.

At present, the share of women entrepreneurs in Maharashtra is 9% which the government plans to increase to 20% by introduction of various schemes, he added.

Schemes like Mudra Yojna, Trade-related entrepreneurship assistance and development (TREAD), Mahila Udgam Nidhi, Annapurna, Stree Shakti, Bhatiya Mahila Business Bank Loan, Dena Shakti, Cent Kalyani and Udyogini. Women entrepreneurs should go through these schemes thoroughly and pick them according to their areas of interests, Shah said.

A question and answer was held later in which Shah replied to the queries raised by the participants.

Vandana Sharma, former chairman of LEW and Manisha Bawankar, secretary, were present. Manisha Bawankar proposed a vote of thanks.

(Reporting by Shivam Wagh)

Title: Rs 25cr to IISER team to work on bits for quantum computer
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Pune: Scientists at the Indian Institute of Science Education and Research (IISER), Pune are working on the 'bits' in the processor of a quantum computer.

In classical computer processors, one has 32 or 64 bits to carry out computations and processing of information.

IISER scientists are trying to increase a similar number of mechanical bits in a quantum computer. They have received an allocation of Rs 25 crore. The project is part of the National Mission on Quantum Technologies and Applications (QTA) which received Rs 300 crore from the department of science and technology for 51 projects across India.

The Interdisciplinary Cyber Physical Systems division of the department recently released the financial sanction under 'Quantum Enabled Science and technology (QUEST)' programme, Umakant Rapol and T S Mahesh said. Both are leading two experimental projects of the 51 in this programme.

Co-principal investigators include MS Santhanam, Rejish Nath, and GV Pavan Kumar.

“Like in classical computer processors, one has 32 or 64 bits to carry out computations and processing of information that finally will be used to convert, store, display, process and transfer data among different devices. To get to a similar number of quantum mechanical bits in a quantum computer is a big technical and scientific challenge,” Rapol added.

Title: Forest department rescues leopard from trap for wild boars in Pargaon
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Pimpri Chinchwad: The forest department on Wednesday morning rescued a leopard from a trap laid by some unidentified people for hunting wild boars at Pargaon village in Daund taluka.

Daund range forest officer (RFO) MN Hazare said the forest department has lodged a complaint against unknown persons under section 9 of Wildlife Act 1972 for trying to hunt wild animals.

He said, “The leopard was found in a field owned by a farmer, Sunil Shelke, in Pargaon. When Shelke went to the field around 7am, he spotted the animal with its leg entangled in a trap laid for catching wild boars. A rescue team rushed to the spot after he informed the forest department and freed the leopard”

Forest guard Nana Chavan said some villagers had informed the department about the trapped leopard around 7.30am. “We reached out to the animal rescue team from Pune. The team reached the spot within 1-1.5 hours. Our team prevented the villagers from going anywhere near the spot. The sight of human beings could have made the leopard aggressive and hindered our rescue operation,” he said.

The guard added that around 40 people from the forest department and the rescue centre were involved in the operation. The rescue team tranquillized the leopard and took it to Pune for treatment.

Shelke said, “The leopard growled at me when I was 20-25 feet away from it on the field. I noticed that it was unable to move, as its hind leg was trapped. I informed the forest department.”

Chavan said, “Sugar cane is cultivated on a large scale at Pargaon and its surrounding villages. Sugar cane fields provide good hiding places for leopards. This village is located close to Shirur taluka and Ahmednagar district. Leopards are regularly sighted in these villages.”

Title: Act on bogus institutes offering unrecognized med courses: HC
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Madurai: Madras high court has dismissed a batch of petitions filed by electropathy practitioners taking cognizance of the fact that they obtained unrecognized medical diploma degrees from unrecognized institutions. The court directed the central and state governments to take immediate action against bogus institutes offering such courses putting at stake the lives of youngsters.

The petitioners had sought to forbear the registrar of Tamil Nadu Homeopathy Medical Council from interfering with their practice by asking them not to practise without registering their diploma certificates in their council. They said the police were carrying out inspections in their clinics. When they approached the council seeking recognition, it was not granted. On perusal of the submissions, Justice Pushpa Sathyanarayana observed that most of the certificates produced by the petitioners of their diploma degree were issued by private institutions without affiliation to any statutory body or university recognised by Acts of Parliament. Having joined such courses, they were stopped from claiming any right to register themselves in the statutory council or practise.

Taking cognizance of the fact that Electro Homeopathy System of Medicine (Recognition) Bill has not been passed in Parliament, the judge dismissed the petitions. The judge noted that this was a classic example of students taking up an unrecognized course and being forced to linger around the court even after completing the course successfully, wasting time, money and risk for which they are not responsible. “The right of every Indian citizen to health and the right to receive proper medical care by qualified medical personnel is violated not only by the existence of quacks, but also by the practitioners with unrecognized medical degree. Eventually, the life of the patient is at risk,” the court said adding the quality and faith in the medical education would come down significantly if such unrecognized medical certificates are permitted to be issued.

The judge observed that the union ministry of health and family welfare had issued an order in 2003 directing the state governments and union territories to ensure that no institutions offer any degree or diploma in the stream of medicine which have not been recommended for recognition. Despite this, the institutes in which the petitioners studied were able to offer such course. The issue cannot be weighed lightly and the authorities concerned should be held accountable. The judge directed the central and state governments to take immediate action against such institutes and have a serious check on these issues without any delay. The judge also asked the students to be cautious before choosing a course and institutions.

Title: No govt grants, widening of 5 roads stalled: NMC to Mayor
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Nagpur: Widening work of five roads has been stuck for want of over Rs371 crore government funds. Mayor Sandip Joshi on Thursday directed the civic administration to follow-up with the government to get the funds released.

The five roads — Kelibagh Road, Pardi Road, Old Bhandara Road, Ramji Pehlwan Road and Wardha Road-Ajni-Somalwada — are part of city’s development plan and as a planning authority, the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) is supposed to carry out the work.

Following complaints from residents over no progress of these five roads, the mayor on Thursday convened a meeting with officials of project department and zones.

For widening of all the five roads, the civic body has calculated Rs642 crore as cost towards acquisition of properties. Of this, the NMC will bear 30% (over Rs192 crore), while government will contribute over Rs449 crore. Of its share, the government has sanctioned only Rs77 crore, the mayor was informed by the officials.

The non-receipt of government’s share has forced the NMC to stop the widening work, officials informed and added that the NMC has already completed all the procedures.

Title: Setback for state as Centre notifies Mhadei final award
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Panaji: In what appears to be a huge setback to Goa’s plans of stopping Karnataka from going ahead with its Kalasa-Bhandura project, the Centre on Thursday notified the Mhadei Water Disputes Tribunal ’s final award that was given on August 14, 2018.

Chief minister Pramod Sawant said the state will challenge the notification. “We will move the Supreme Court to obtain a stay against the notification,” he told TOI.

The notification comes two days after the state government sought a stay from the SC to restrain Karnataka from starting construction or any other activity on the Mhadei for the Kalasa-Bhandura project, which will come up for hearing on March 2.

Last Wednesday, the Centre had extended the tribunal’s term by six months till August 19 to give the final award.

But with Karnataka moving the Supreme Court for notifying the award and Goa and Maharashtra—the other riparian states in the Mhadei dispute—not objecting to it, the apex court had directed the Centre last Thursday to notify the award, but had said it was subject to the outcome of the petitions filed by the riparian states against the award.

The Supreme Court also admitted Goa government’s special leave petition challenging the award and posted it for final hearing on July 15, 16 and 24.

“If the judgment comes in favour of Goa, this notification becomes null and void,” Sawant said.

Karnataka has always claimed that once the award is notified, it can take up construction of the Kalasa-Bhandura drinking water project without hurdles.

In a tweet, Goa Forward Party president Vijai Sardesai said the worst fears have come true. “With the government notifying the final decision of the tribunal, all hope has faded,” he said.

Questioning the state government and the chief minister, Sardesai said: “Everything you said and claimed you did on Mhadei was nothing but lies and falsehoods? The government stands exposed!”

Title: Youth dies after falling into lift duct
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Pune: Rupan Raju Rokade of Shantinagar in Wanowrie died after falling in an elevator duct from the sixth floor of a residential building, Sacred Heart Society, located near Jagtap Chowk in Wanowrie late at around 11pm on February 21.

The Wanowrie police has registered a case of accidental death in this regard. Assistant inspector Bhagwan Kamble of the Wanowrie police said, “Rokade (20) was unemployed and son to a retired policeman.”

“We are investigating the case. It is suspected that he either jumped into the duct or accidentally fell down because there are no signs of anyone having pushed him,” he said.

“It is not known why he went to the society. It is also unclear as to how the doors of the elevator shaft on the sixth floor opened,” he said.

Kamble said there was a loud noise when Rokade fell down on the roof of the elevator bucket. “The residents of the society then called the police,” he said.

“We have taken down his parents’ statements and they informed us that he was under tremendous stress and had hardly spoken to his family in the last few months,” he said.

Title: APNGO asks Jagan to honour promises
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Vijayawada: Andhra Pradesh Non-Gazetted Officers Association ( APNGO ) on Thursday demanded the state government to clear the uncertainty over the long pending demands of government employees.

APNGO Association on Thursday observed ‘demands day’ as per the national-level call given by All India State Employees Federation.

The APNGO state president N Chandrasekhar Reddy participated in the demonstration held at Irrigation Offices Complex in the city along with hundreds of employees.

APNGOs alleged that chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy is ignoring the problems faced by the government employees in the last nine months of his ruling.

“Jagan promised to remove contributory pension scheme during his election campaign. Government employees trusted him and eagerly waited for a positive decision after he came to power. But there is no response from him after becoming chief minister. Deceiving government employees has become a routine for the political parties,” Chandrasekhar Reddy said.

He said the government is deliberately delaying the pay revision commission (PRC) by constituting a number of committees.

Amaravati Joint Action Committee (APJAC) state secretary-general Joseph Sudheer Babu demanded the CM to fulfill his election promises. “ The CM made a number of promises for the welfare of employees but has ignored them. We will intensify our protests if he does not deliver,” he said.

The employees also demanded the government to increase the retirement age to 62 years.

Title: Invasive plants spreading faster & wider, say experts
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Pune: Invasive plant species are affecting native species of biodiversity more adversely now, ecologists said.

Sachin Punekar, an ecologist and founder-president of Biospheres, said, “ Invasive species can sweep away local biodiversity and are the second biggest threat, after habitat destruction and alteration.”

Punekar has been actively involved in weed eradication programmes that he started in 2016. The commonest invasive plant species was cosmos bipinnatus or the Mexican weed and eupatorium odoratum.

The post-monsoon invasion of cosmos bipinnatus can wreak havoc on local flora. They grow along the roadside and the hill slopes.

Cosmos can be seen growing in clumps at Katraj Ghat, Sinhagad and Shivneri forts. “The species is growing near the forts, ghat regions and along the roadside. Earlier, it was in some pockets of Taljai hill. It has spread everywhere,” he said.

Their growth hampers native grasses which are fodder species that herbivores and livestock feed on. Invasive species is are allelopathic and as such poisonous to native crops, Punekar added.

Eupatorium odoratum is commonly seen in the outskirts of deciduous as well as moist deciduous forests throughout the Western Ghats. “Both the species form dense clumps, hardly allowing other native species to grow,” Punekar added.

Amateur botanist Shrikant Ingalhalikar said there was a problem of incorrect interpretation of native and invasive species. Many native trees have disappeared from Pune out of sheer negligence and people are fighting to save the invasive plants, he added.

“The problem lies in the interpretation of native and invasive varieties. Considering examples of native and exotic species, it is important to understand that all exotic species are not invasive. As a blanket, when everyone talks about exotic, they think every exotic species is invasive. There has to be focus on eradication of invasive species like cosmos or water hyacinth,” he said.

The area under cosmos species is doubling each year, he said. “Cosmos is a harmful species and has to be nipped before it flowers. I have been observing it for about 40 years and each year it is doubling. Now, it is beyond control,” he added.

Title: Bail for two women Maoists in 1 of 4 pending cases against them
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image
