MADURAI: The Madras high court has granted bail to women Maoists in one of the four cases pending against them, after taking into consideration their age and the fact that they are languishing in prison for more than three years as their right of speedy trial has been infringed.

Justice G R Swaminathan passed the order while hearing the bail plea of Kala, 59, and Chandra, 52, in a case which was registered against them by the Q Branch CID in 2016. The case is under trial on the file of the Karur principal sessions judge.

The government advocate very strongly opposed the granting of bail pointing out that the petitioners are ardent members of a terrorist. He also told the court that while attending the funeral of Manivasagam, Kala’s husband and Chandra’s brother who was shot dead recently by the Kerala police, the duo made highly provocative speeches. He said the petitioners were put on terms when a division bench had granted leave to them to attend the funeral.

The judge observed that the government advocate also passed on the video recording in which Chandra is seen making highly provocative and offending statements and called for bloody revenge for Manivasagam’s death.

Taking note of the government counsel’s contention, the judge observed, “We are a functioning democracy. Free speech is a cherished fundamental right. The petitioners are ideologically committed. Therefore, on occasions of such as arrest or remand, they are bound to raise slogans. It is not the case of the prosecution that the something untoward happened as a result. Slogan shouting itself and in the absence of any other adverse consequence, ought not to attract criminal prosecution.”

The judge noted that when their home was searched, they found mobile phones, sim cards and some party literature including the bylaws of banned organisation. The judge observed that the petitioners are facing three other cases apart from the case on hand. The judge observed that the case on hand does not involve any violence as no witness deposed that the petitioners attempted to recruit anyone for committing any terrorist act. “There are some material to come to a conclusion that the petitioners are members of a banned organisation. But whether that can be called as a terrorist organisation is to be established only in a regular trial and the material on record is not sufficient to come to that conclusion,” observed the judge.

The judge noted that though the final report was filed in 2017 and the case was pending for more than three years, the right of the petitioners to speedy trial has been infringed. Hence, the judge granted bail to the petitioners in this case. When the petitioners’ counsel stated that the petitioners are in confinement in connection with other cases also, the judge observed that the petitioners are entitled to come out of prison if they are granted bail in the other cases as well.

Title: 17-year-old girl rescued from child marriage
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: A 17-year-old girl in Madurai city was rescued on Wednesday by police from child marriage . Police arrested four people, including the girl’s parents in this connection.

Police sources said that they acted on a tip-off from the child helpline and rushed to Sakthi Mariamman Kovil in Subramaniapuram . On reaching the temple, they found that the girl had been married to a 21-year-old youth. The child bride and groom, Muthukumar, tied the knot in the morning. The two families were from the same community. Police arrested the groom and his mother Kavitha. The girl’s parents Kadhiresan and Karuppayi were also arrested. During questioning, parents said that they arranged the marriage only after the bride and groom gave consent. However, as per law, any marriage, even with consent, of a girl under 18 years and a boy under 21 years is illegal.

Title: Coronavirus in Ahmedabad: All 23 samples tested -ve in Gujarat
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: All samples tested for COVID-19 or novel coronavirus at the BJ Medical College so far have been declared negative. One sample from Ahmedabad, which was referred to BJ Medical College for the test, was also found negative on Thursday.State health department officials said that since the outbreak of coronavirus in China, 1,183 passengers from the state having the travel history to the country, have been screened and placed under surveillance. Of these, 283 have completed the 28-day observation period, 1,105 have completed the 14-day observation period and 78 are under observation. None of the passengers have reported any symptoms of COVID-19, the officials said.On Thursday, 12 passengers were screened at airports by teams of the health department. Of these, six are from Ahmedabad, two are from Mehsana and one each are from Aravalli, Junagadh, Kutch and Vadodara districts.Civil hospital, the base hospital for coronavirus, has been equipped with facilities like triple-layer masks to deal with possible cases. Isolation wards have also been started in all district hospitals. Two thermal scanners have been made available at the Ahmedabad airport with other facilities like ambulance, masks and PPE kits.

Title: Activists want more from grievance redressal cell for schools
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Pune: A special committee to address the grievances of school employees, students and parents has been set up by the state education department.

The redressal cell, headed by the divisional chairman of Maharashtra State Board of Secondary and Higher Secondary Education, will induct three government representatives. The committee will address issues on the first Monday of every month, a notification issued by the state government on Wednesday said.

Issues related to Right to Education Act (RTE), compulsion of buying books and uniforms from the respective private schools, corporal punishment, sexual or mental harassment, difficulty in obtaining no objection certificate mandatory for various works, among others, would come under the purview of the committee, the notification added.

Parents of school-goers across the city had complained of a spurt in fees for admission to private schools. Previous TOI reports show that despite parents having staged protests and written to the respective deputy directors, the administration had not implemented corrective measures.

Proper implementation of RTE Act, which stipulates that private schools reserve 25% of seats at the entry-level for children belonging to ‘disadvantaged groups’ and ‘weaker sections’, was mired in controversies. Several complaints of schools refusing to admit such students, or even asking for money beyond the tuition fee, have emerged.

The activists said the panel needed more diverse representation. “The deputy directors always had the power to act against the erring schools. But, they failed to even file an FIR against the violators. The special committee has the same people. We need a third party in the committee, which will audit the panel’s work. A grievance redressal cell is necessary and it should do more than just being present,” education activist Vaishali Bafna said.

Title: Science Day celebrated at SRM University
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Vijayawada: National Science Day was observed at SRM University, Amaravati campus, on Thursday. Professor M Lakshmi Kantham, distinguished professor at Institution of Chemical Technology, Mumbai, attended the celebrations as chief guest. A programme was held on the theme of “Women in Science.”

Speaking on the occasion, Kantham remembered the women who contributed to science and technology. She recalled Anandibai Gopalrao Joshi, the first woman physician, Anna Mani, Indian physicist, and meteorologist, Ashima Chatterjee, inventor of anti-malarial drugs, to name a few. She used this opportunity to spread awareness among the students to avail various fellowship programmes offered by the government to women students.

She said the challenges faced by India can be solved by encouraging more female students to undertake research. She said, “Invention of technology is a result of teamwork. Passion, perfection, and persistence are key to research whereas hard work and innovation lead to success”.

D Narayana Rao, vice-chancellor of SRM, AP, said, “Science Day is observed to recognise the scientists’ contribution to society, to provide a platform to young scientists and kindle their interest in science, to create awareness regarding the significance of science and its applications, to discuss issues, and to popularise the opportunities offered by science.”

Title: Ensure lawyers for sedition-accused: HC
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

BENGALURU: To uphold the best legal traditions, a member of the Hubballi Bar Association (HBA) should appear on behalf of the three Kashmiri students charged with sedition for allegedly raising pro-Pakistan slogans in their engineering college hostel in Hubballi on February 14, the Karnataka high court observed on Thursday.

The observation came a day after the court slammed the local bar for allegedly heckling a group of Bengaluru lawyers who had appeared on behalf of the students, calling it “sheer militancy”.

On Thursday, HBA officer-bearers appeared before the court with a fresh resolution, modifying the one passed on February 15 that had barred its members from appearing for the accused. However, the court was still unhappy with the resolution, which now left the issue to individual members.

A division bench headed by Chief Justice Abhay Shreeniwas Oka noted that instead of modifying it, the association should have simply recalled the contentious resolution. The association agreed to take back the resolution.

Meanwhile, despite assurances from HBA office-bearers to ensure that proceedings are conducted in a peaceful manner, the bench said its February 20 order directing the local police to provide security to advocates appearing for the three students will continue.

“We would have transferred the case here (from Hubballi-Dharwad to Bengaluru). That was a simple task. However, as far as possible, it should be heard there. That will send the right signal. It is not good that lawyers have to seek police protection for appearing in a court,” the chief justice observed.

Advocate Maitreyi Krishna and others were allegedly heckled by HBA members on Monday, when they attended the Dharwad court to file bail applications on behalf of the accused students.

On February 15, the bar association had passed a resolution, asking its members not to represent the students. It had also called upon members of other bar associations to follow suit.

Advocate B T Venkatesh and 23 other lawyers then approached the HC through a PIL, seeking the quashing of the resolution. The next hearing on the PIL is scheduled for March 6.

Title: Bus shelters barely useful, and absent where needed
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Madurai: Madurai boasts many bus shelters, but they hardly serve their purpose at the places where they exist. And they are absent where they are required the most. Almost all bus shelters in the city have been converted into steel structures with benches to facilitate seating for the waiting passengers, but many of these seats are unusable for some reason or other.

For instance, there is a shelter with a badly damaged roof at the Aravind Eye Hospital junction in Anna Nagar but no bus has halted here till date. To make matters worse, the seat is about 4 feet above the ground making it impossible for an elderly person or child to sit on it comfortably. This is the situation at many shelters in the city.

On the opposite side, there are three shelters one after another from Aavin junction to the Wakf Board College at K K Nagar. The one in the middle has never seen a bus stop by thereby making it an ideal spot for people to doze off in the scorching afternoons. Similarly, there are several shelters in front of the district court which are rendered useless. The roof does not do much to keep the sun away and seats are not comfortable for all ages. “There are so many shelters here that are actually encroaching on the space for pedestrians,’’ said K Sugumar of K K Nagar.

With the Periyar bus stand being closed for renovation, many city buses now stop at South Marret and East Marret street, but these roads have no proper shelter for commuters. Since the corporation claims that it cannot provide temporary shelters near the Periyar bus stand as work is going on, people are forced to stand in the hot sun. On Thursday, members of the DYFI conducted a signature campaign demanding that the corporation provide temporary shelters near Periyar bus stand till the work is completed. “Lack of shelters will put the lives of people who commute through this bus stand every day at risk,’’ said DYFI district president R Selva.

“At many places, they are just steel structures which may give an aesthetic appeal , but steel becomes hot when it is not used for long periods. The roofs are also narrow and don’t provide much shelter,’’ said A Asokan of Makkal Sakthi Iyakkam. City engineer S Arasu said they expected the Periyar bus stand works to be completed by May-June. Bus shelters were an important part of ongoing smart city projects and would soon be reorganised in coordination with transport department, he added.

Title: High on booz, more women drinkers opting for rehab to kick the habbit
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: After school hours, Anita* waited for her mom at the school gate for an hour, sobbing. Her mom hadn’t turned up, again.“I forgot to pick up my child because I was drinking at home,” said Pratibha*, a homemaker who is undergoing treatment at a de-addiction centre in Chennai. “When this repeated, I realised I needed help.”Three years ago, the number of women in the city who sought help for alcohol de-addiction was very few. Today rehab centres are teeming with them. In the past two years, the TT Ranganathan Clinical Research Foundation (TTK Hospital) has received around 90 such women.Not all of them get admitted; most of them opt for outpatient services. “This is because there is still a stigma associated with women drinking. While it is normal for a man to seek help, a woman hesitates,” said Jacqueline David, senior counsellor at TTK.The number is less compared to men, which is at least 50 a month. “There was a time when we would hardly get a woman alcoholic a year. And the few patients were from economically weaker sections. Today we see cases from all socio-economic backgrounds,” said Jacqueline.Dr Lakshmi Vijaykumar, head of the psychiatric department at Voluntary Health Services (VHS) which provides de-addiction services, said her centre has seen a considerable rise in the number of women battling alcohol addiction . “We used to get two a year, now we get around 20,” she said. Most women start with social drinking. “In many cases, we found that the habit was introduced to them by their husbands,” said Dr Vijaykumar. She cited an incident where a young IT employee began with a glass of wine a day after work, with her husband. A few months later, he passed away and the woman became an addict. “When she came to us for help, we found that she had become an alcoholic and had withdrawal symptoms every time she tried to stop,” she said.Experts said women are prone to have more health and psychological issues. “They are at a higher risk of being victims of sexual assault and acts of violence,” said Dr Sujatha Velmurugan, consultant psychiatrist at Kauvery Hospital. Though women today are more independent and financially secure, when it comes to having serious conversations on substance abuse, they are often left out. “Once branded an alcoholic, she will have to work harder and restart her life, but the tag may remain. Because women are expected to uphold honour of the family,” said Dr Sujatha.TTK has been holding awareness programmes on alcoholism. “We speak with women of all age groups and explain the ill-effects of substance abuse,” said Maya Varadarajan, managing trustee of the organisation. “We have to understand that alcoholism is a health hazard and has no gender.”(* names changed)

Title: Gujarat has 2.4 lakh more malnourished children in six months!
Content:
Representative image

GANDHINAGAR: The number of malnourished children in the state has increased by 2,41,698 in nearly six months from July 9, 2019. The state government told the house on Thursday that there are 3,83,840 malnourished children in the state.Leader of opposition Paresh Dhanani said that the figure of 3.84 lakh was arrived from various questions asked by our MLAs whose reply were tabled today. In reply to similar questions on July 9, 2019, the government had stated in the assembly that there are 1.42 lakh malnourished children. Dhanani said that if the statements of the state government are compared, the number of malnourished children in the state grew by 2.42 lakh in six months!The Socio-Economic Survey 2019-20 has revealed that Kuposhan Mukt Gujarat Maha-Abhiyan (Phase V) started from July 8, 2019 in the state. Under this programme 55.64 lakh children were screened by field officers. At the end of February 4, 2020, 37.21 lakh children have been screened by and 2.97 lakh children were identified as severely malnourished.Dhanani said that in Adivasi areas, the government has failed to address the issue and people are dying because of hunger. Every third child who is born in the state dies before his/her first birthday, he said.Neeta Hardikar, director, Anna Suraksha Adhikar Abhiyan, said that it appears that the Gujarat government was hiding figures and now with the national survey pointing out that number of malnourished children was more in Gujarat, it has realized that it cannot hide the figures. She said that the government has been claiming that the malnourished children were more because of migrant population. “Does it mean that the migrant population was only in Adivasi areas,” she questioned.Replying to another question of Deodar MLA Shivbhai Bhuriya, the government claimed that the government spends Rs 8 for malnourished children between 6 months and 72 months, while for severely malnourished children, the government spends Rs 12 per children.

Title: Pune: Work begins for all five underground metro stations
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Ongoing work at Shivajinagar underground metro station. (File photo)

PUNE: The civil work of all the five underground Metro stations on the 5km stretch between Agriculture College and Swargate has started.

The Maharashtra Metro Rail Corporation Limited (MahaMetro) said it had begun excavation at two crucial sites — Budhwar Peth and Mandai stations — in the past few days. The ground work of Civil Court and Shivajinagar stations is in advanced stage. The work on Swargate station — the fifth and the last station on the route — started this week.

The Swargate station will be constructed using the New Austrian Tunnelling Method (NATM) because it is at the end of the tunnel. A plan was finalised recently on how to initiate the work.

A senior official from MahaMetro said, “We have started the tunnelling work from the Agriculture College-end with two tunnel boring machines. There is a plan to expedite the work of the underground stations. The locations of all the five stations have been finalised. The MahaMetro had to change the site of Budhwar Peth station from its earlier location because of opposition from the residents of the area. The plan for the new site is now ready.”

The Civil Court station would be an interchange station because two Metro lines Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC)-Swargate and Vanaz-Ramwadi would converge there. The underground and overhead stations would be constructed in the same building structure. MahaMetro has initiated the work for the underground station.

Officials from MahaMetro stated that the tunnelling and construction work of stations would progress simultaneously. “We have prepared a plan in such a way that both the works can go on. The tunnel boring machine that started the tunnelling work from Agriculture College has reached near the site of Shivajinagar station. Though the station work is yet to be finished, the tunnelling work will not stop. Coordination will be maintained in both the works. The machines will be pulled out from Mandai instead of Budhwar Peth,” an official said.

All the underground stations are located about 20 metres below the ground. Every station will have entry-exit points from the ground level.

MahaMetro said the commuters would be able to reach the concourse-level using staircases and elevators. Sites for entry-exit points have been identified for all the stations.

Title: Pune: Sensitise people against COVID-19, experts urge govt machinery
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Spreading awareness against novel coronavirus COVID-19 ) infection should be the government’s mantra at the moment when quite a few neighbouring countries are scrambling to contain the contagion spread, experts said on Thursday.“The knee-jerk reactions, we are used to, unfortunately won’t work when it comes to containing the virus when it strikes,” senior public health expert Subhash Salunke, the former director general of Maharashtra’s public health department, said.He said though no positive case had been found in Maharashtra, the authorities should avoid any laxity. “We should make most of the current period to reach out to common people and sensitise them. Educating the masses when the virus is already in community is just like digging a well when one is thirsty,” Salunke said.Making judicious and extensive use of mass media tools, including newspapers, radio and television, among others, can make a huge difference in creating awareness. “What a household should do when a family member is diagnosed with the infection ? How other members can remain safe? What are common dos and don’ts when the virus enters the community? People should know how basic measures like frequent washing of hands and personal hygiene practices like coughing and sneezing etiquette can help immensely in fighting the virus,” Salunke said.Medical practitioner and health activist Abhijit More said, “The main thrust is presently on screening the travellers returning from the affected countries, following up with them, isolating those complaining of minor illness and testing them for the coronavirus infection. But the focus on disseminating information to the masses, creating awareness and educating them via media is sourly lacking. If we fail to make the most of the current time when there is no positive case, we may have to face similar havoc and chaos that ensued when swine flu had claimed country’ first victim in Pune in August 2009.”Activist Sanjay Dabhade said, “The World Health Organisation has urged countries to “prepare for a potential pandemic” – an epidemic that spreads throughout the world. Pakistan and Nepal also detected their first cases of the contagion, days after shutting border with Iran, which has also emerged as a major coronavirus spot.”Infectious diseases expert Sudhir Patsute, head of the Naidu Infectious Diseases Hospital that is the only designated isolation facility in Pune, said, “ China imposed extraordinary quarantine measures in several cities, locking in tens of millions of people as it sought to curb the rapid spread of the virus. Preparing citizens by sensitising them about ways to ward off infection can save us from such extreme measures.”

Title: Gujarat: 49 cases of malaria, 36 of dengue daily
Content:
Representative image

GANDHINAGAR: Data on the vector-borne diseases and swine flu were tabled in the assembly on Thursday. The data mentioned that on average 49 cases of malaria , 36 of dengue and 10 of swine flu were recorded in Gujarat between January 1, 2018 and December 31, 2019.The state government said that 251 persons lost lives to swine flu and 22 to dengue in the last two calendar years. A total of 17 persons also succumbed to Congo Fever, mentioned the data. Ahmedabad city reported an average of 15 cases of malaria, eight of dengue and three of swine flu daily.Deputy CM Nitin Patel, who is also the state’s health & family welfare minister, told the assembly that dengue, swine flu and malaria cases were reported because of unhealthy practices adopted by the people. He added that waterlogging in areas was also behind rise in dengue, swine flu and malaria cases. “Special laboratories have been set up by the state government for swine flu test,” Patel said. Medical practitioners said that the figures have increased compared to past few years due to two reasons, better reporting and cyclic trend. Dr Pragnesh Vachharajani, a physician, said that reporting of the diseases have improved from patients, doctors, and authorities. Dr Sanjay Shah, head of the emergency department at a private hospital, said that compared to 2018, the year 2019 witnessed more cases of dengue vis-à-vis malaria. “It’s a cyclic trend. The mortality diseases have not changed if we observe the trend of past few years,” he said.The government data mentioned that four people from Surendranagar were affected by the Crimean–Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF) and all four died during treatment in 2019. Two more persons had died in Kheda and Anand – one person each. Maximum cases of CCHF, however, were recorded in Bhavnagar district.

Title: Union government cancels 500MW solar park project in Ramanathapuram
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: In a major setback to Tangedco and the Tamil Nadu government, the Union ministry for renewable power (MNRE) has cancelled the proposal for a solar park at Kadaladi in Ramanathapuram district . The decision was made at a meeting convened by the MNRE secretary recently to assess the performance of solar parks. The reason for cancellation, sources said, was tardy progress in its implementation.

It was in 2017 that the government announced that a 500 MW solar photovoltaic park would come up at Kadaladi. Former CM J Jayalalithaa had in 2016 announced a 4,000MW thermal power plant at the same site. Problems in obtaining environmental clearance for the thermal power plant is what prompted the state government to shift to the solar park, said sources. When the government announced the setting up of the Kadaladi solar park, it had claimed that the park would be the first ever to be set up by any discom. But even after three years, there was no progress on the project . Even land acquisition is not complete, said officials.

Tangedco representatives did not attend the recent review meeting convened by the MNRE secretary. “We were not aware of the meeting. Our information is that the Union government cancelled the project as no one representing Tangedco attended the review meeting. The decision came as a surprise to us,” a senior Tangedco official told TOI. “Solar Energy Corporation of India (SECI) had offered to invest and develop the solar project on land to be provided by Tangedco on build-own-operate (BOO) basis. Tangedco would have got 100% of power generated by the park,” said the official.

Tangedco plans to approach MNRE to reconsider its decision to cancel the project. “A lot of ground work has been done to identify the land, measuring about 1,500 acres,” said the official.

This is the second setback for Tangedco in recent times. In December last, Union power minister R K Singh wrote a letter to chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami stating that it will be difficult for PFC and REC to provide loans based on the present financial situation of Tangedco. Around 5,000MW of thermal and solar power projects will get stuck if funding stops.

Title: Patole directs NMC to expedite works obtained from NIT
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Nagpur: Speaker Nana Patole directed municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe to expedite works and projects obtained from the Nagpur Improvement Trust (NIT).

Patole, who unsuccessfully contested the Lok Sabha elections from the city and was later elected as MLA from Bhandara district, held a meeting to review works related to Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC), NIT and MahaMetro at Vidhan Bhavan, Mumbai, on Friday.

Urban development minister Eknath Shinde, Backward classes minister Vijay Wadettiwar, West Nagpur MLA and Congress City President Vikas Thakre, Mundhe, NIT chairman Sheetal Teli-Ugale and officials of the urban development department were present.

Patole reviewed works and projects transferred from NIT to NMC after the state government declared NMC as the sole planning authority of the city in August last year. He asked Mundhe to ensure that projects from the NIT are not affected.

Thakre demanded total dissolution of NIT soon. He said people are confused as NIT is still functioning in the city.

During the regime of the leader of opposition Devendra Fadnavis as CM, government had removed the planning authority status of NIT and made NMC as the sole planning authority of the city. But the government is yet to hand over NIT’s land bank, funds and other responsibilities and liabilities to the NMC. Therefore, NIT is still functioning.

Patole also gave some directions to MahaMetro officials.

Title: This Lent, an appeal to take trolling off menu
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Stephen says he feels refreshed after he gave trolling a break

CHENNAI: After Pope Francis said it, and then his own parish priest reiterated it, Stephen Arputha Raja decided he was going to give the “no trolling for lent” appeal from the Roman Catholic Church a go. So on Thursday, the 23-year-old BPO employee from Chennai refrained from trolling friends and strangers on Twitter and Facebook.

“It was difficult,” says Stephen. Especially since, as he says, he jumps at every chance to pass a snide remark or poke fun at a person online, sending out at least 40 comments a day. On Thursday, he said nothing. But admits he felt something. “Refreshed, happy, like there was a weight off my shoulders.”

On Ash Wednesday, as part of his customary message for the season of Lent – for Christians, the 40-day period of reflection and preparation before the celebration of Easter, usually marked fasting, both from food and festivities – Pope Francis urged people to stop being internet trolls and insulting “each other as if they were saying, Good Day”. Pope Francis too, incidentally, has been the target of online trolls himself.

In his Lenten message, Father Michael A D of the Chengelpet Diocese, where Stephen is a member, said the internet, which is a good thing in itself, has become a space for verbal violence. “This lent, I’ve urged the parish to fast from electronic gadgets, from forwarding unauthorised messages, from mob mentality, intolerance, from passing unnecessary hurtful comments,” says Fr Michael.

Other parish priests too are trying to take the message of the Pope forward. To his congregation in Kilachery, for instance, besides the issue of trolling and the excessive use of social media, Father Praveen M W asked his parish to refrain from forwarding fake news. “This Lenten season, begin to verify, then forward.”

The Pope’s message is relevant from a mental health perspective as well, say experts. Consultant psychiatrist Dr Vinayak Vijayakumar says with trolling there appear mental health issues from the point of view of the troll as well as the person being trolled. “Those engaged in cyber bullying and trolling have been found to be six times more likely to be part of mental health forums. They also tend to exhibit reduced self-esteem. The ones at the receiving end of the trolling do tend to have anxiety,” says Dr Vijayakumar.“I have had celebrities for instance come to be facing mild depressive episodes or anxiety because of being trolled.”

Stephen though says he feels like a whole new person after day one of his troll-fast. “Usually, I never even bother to read people’s posts fully. I’m always looking at how I can troll them. For the first time, I actually began to read people’s posts and tried to understand their point of view. It’s given me a positive energy.”

Title: Bangaram chilli turns up the heat in Guntur market, sells for Rs 14,000/quintal
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Guntur: A new variety of dry chilli with light gold colour arrived in Guntur market on Thursday.

The gold coloured chilli fetched Rs 14,000 per quintal—the highest price for dry chilli in recent history. The price went up as traders competed with each other to buy the gold-coloured stocks in Guntur agriculture market yard.

Market committee officials said that a farmer from Kurnool brought a few quintals of Bangaram stock which was sold out within no time. The popular brand of Teja variety is commanding a price of nearly Rs 9,000- Rs 10,000 per quintal for the past few days.

Sources said that gold colour chilli, known as Bangaram, is considered to be precious seed. The experts said that Bangaram chilli comes with high pungency level and it is expected to reap high price in export market. However, the Bangaram variety is cultivated only in select areas of Kurnool and Guntur districts, said AP Commission Merchants Association secretary P Suresh Reddy. Sources said that farmers were not taking risk to cultivate the variety as it is considered to be high sensitive seed and could not withstand viruses. In fact, the Teja variety, which has the highest demand in the market, is not being cultivated by all farmers due to high cost of cultivation.

Meanwhile, about 90,000 bags of dry chilli arrived in the agriculture market yard on Thursday. The yard handled a total stock of nearly 1.2 lakh bags on a single day.

The chilli arrival has picked up momentum in the last few days as season and picking operations have reached peak. “Normal varieties are fetching around Rs 90-Rs 110 per kg while premium varieties of Teja and Byadiga are around Rs 120-Rs 135 per kg,” said L Kranti Sekhar, a leading chilli trader.

Agriculture market committee chairman Ch Yesurathnam said it was relatively a good season for farmers as prices have not gone down during the peak sale season.

Title: East-West Metro tunnelling: New cracks surface in Bowbazar homes, KMRC allays concerns
Content:
Residents point at cracks in their homes on Chaitan Sen Lane, claiming they appeared after the Metro tunnellin... Read More

KOLKATA: As tunnelling for East-West Metro began under Bowbazar after a hiatus of 170 days, fresh cracks appeared in some houses on Thursday, claimed residents. Engineers of Kolkata Metro Rail Corporation ( KMRC ), the implementing agency of the project, visited the affected houses and promised to repair the cracks and ensure no damage was done afresh.Though the tunnel boring machine has been moving slowly and digging less than 10m a day and implementing agency Kolkata Metro Rail Corporation (KMRC) has been taking all safety measures to avoid a repeat of the tunnelling disaster, some residents alleged the borer’s movement had already started taking a toll on their houses. TOI visited 11, Chaitan Sen Lane, where Aditya Dutta, who is appearing for this year’s ICSE, pointed at a hairline crack at the corner of his study. “The crack wasn’t here earlier. We noticed it four or five days ago,” he said. His father, Sukalyan Dutta, sounded anxious: “As you can see, our house is well maintained. The interiors are painted every September because we have Durga Puja in the house. The cracks you saw upstairs are new.”KMRC sent a team of engineers to inspect the houses on Thursday evening. “Even though the TBM has not passed below these buildings yet, we are carrying out inspection to check for any kind of settlement. We shall repair the cracks accordingly,” a KMRC spokesperson said.East-West tunnelling resumed on February 18, 170 days after one of the TBMs on August 31 hit an aquifer, which flooded the west-bound tunnel under Bowbazar, leading to largescale subsidence and collapse of multiple buildings in quick succession. Around 700 residents had to be evacuated during that time. This is the last leg of tunnelling for one of the most ambitious infrastructure project of the city slated for completion by March, next year.Dutta said his house was spared when TBM Chundee, which was digging the west-bound tunnel, ran into an aquifer last August. “I am aware that TBM Urvi is digging along the line of houses on the opposite side of the street. But we can’t help linking the new cracks to Urvi’s movement,” Dutta said.The Basaks of 10, Chaitan Sen Lane, too, claimed some of the cracks in their house were due to the second TBM’s movement. The house was badly damaged during the August-31 disaster and KMRC repaired it. “Cracks have again surfaced during the current tunnelling,” said Kajol Basak. His wife, Mitra, said, “My son’s study has cracks all over.”

Title: Man stages abduction after stalking girl, held
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

TIRUPATI: Thirty-three year old Derangula Krishna Mohan attempted to abduct a 21-year-old at Kadapa on Wednesday but was thwarted by the police in time.

Addressing the media, police said that Mohan started off as an assistant professor at a private college and later became a ward secretary in Fakirpalli ward. He fell in love with the girl who studied in the same college. When the girl moved to Bengaluru, Mohan followed her there. Fed up with him, her parents brought her home.

On Wednesday, when her parents were not at home, Mohan entered the house wearing a burqa and abducted her.

Alert neighbours, who saw Mohan, informed the parents, who in turn called the police. Both the parents and the police reached the house to find bones and a skull, a burning candle next to a LPG cylinder and the girl’s spare dress drenched in petrol. Mohan, police said, wanted to stage an accident and make it appear as if the girl died in the fire accident.

DSP Suryanarayana formed two teams and rushed them to Nellore and Vellore (in Tamil Nadu ). Using technology, the accused was traced near Vellore railway station and was arrested around noon on Thursday.

Title: Hundreds of Indian fishers stranded in Iran seek help to return
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Madurai: The Covid-19 outbreak and halting of flights by Gulf countries have left hundreds of Indian fishermen stranded in Iran who are pleading to the Government of India to fly them home just as it airlifted Indians from Wuhan and Yokohama.

“There should be about 800 to 900 Indian fishermen in Iran, of which about 700 are from Kanyakumari,” M Sahaya Askar, one of the nearly 350 fishermen stranded at Zero fishing harbour, told TOI. “We are in fear, not going for fishing, clueless about our return and desperately in need of help,” he said. Other than Zero, Kish Island and Asaluyeh are the fishing harbours where Indian fishermen work in large numbers. Indian fishermen are also employed in Lava Island, Kamku and Staraq in smaller numbers.

“We were initially told that corona virus had spread to places that are a few hundred kilometres from Zero. Yesterday we were told that it is as close as 160 kms. Our employers are ready to relieve us but we don’t have flights to return. We have limited food supplies and are managing with it on our boats,” Askar added. The fishermen said they are dependent on connecting flights from Iran to one Gulf country or the other to fly to India. For those in Zero, it is an hour by boat to Kish and to the airport in 10 to 15 minutes on road to fly to Dubai and then to India.

The journey through Tehran is more time-consuming. “We have to take a connecting flight to Qatar or Saudi Arabia and then fly to India. Now, all neighbouring countries have cut off their flights to Iran due to Covid-19 oubreak. Please help us return home,” pleaded another fisherman. Jelastin Mary, 47, of Arockiapuram is worried about her sons Arun Prasad (27) and Sahaya George Vijayan (25). “Arun is working there for a year and Vijayan went there only six days ago. The poison (virus) is spreading quickly by air. So please bring my sons here soon,” she said.

Kemila, 47, the mother of 27-year-old M Sahaya Dinesh, said he got married only four months ago and had gone to Iran for the first time. “He said fever and virus are spreading there and that they have not been to work and there is no proper food. We want him back home safely,” she said. “We have lots of dreams about our wedding and future. Please bring him alive soon before he and his friends get affected by corona virus,” says 20-year-old Princa, the fiancé of fisherman M Alden, 24. Most of them are in their early 20s and are the breadwinners of their families.

Charles Johnson, the secretary of Meenavar Orunginaipu Sangam, said they have brought up the matter before fisheries officials in Chennai. “We are taking stock of the number of Tamil Nadu fishermen in Iran and the pressing issues that have to be addressed. If there are no flights we want the men to be rescued by sea,” he said. Fisheries director G S Sameeran told TOI that they are aware of the crisis and are in touch with the Indian high commission in Iran to take stock of the number of fishermen. He said they will write to the ministry of external affairs if needed to airlift them.

Title: Rs 48,439 crore tax dues to be collected in Gujarat
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

GANDHINAGAR: Goods and service tax collection in 2019 registered an increase of 8% compared to 2018. The GST collection in 2019 was Rs 2,577.29 crore more as compared to 2018.

The state government was replying to a question by Tharad MLA Gulabsinh Rajput. The state government stated that between January and December 2019, the GST collection was Rs 34,446.14 crore which was Rs 31,868.85 crore in 2018 during the same period.

In reply to another question by Gandhinagar North MLA C J Chavda, the state government stated that the government has to recover Rs 16,955.48 crore from 24,747 units in Ahmedabad. Action has been initiated against 1,553 units in Gandhinagar and 22,850 units in Ahmedabad. The government stated that it has to recover Rs 48,439.10 crore from various units as tax dues from 77,523 units across the state.

Ahmedabad led in the number of units that have defaulted, followed by Vadodara and Surat.

Title: IIT-Kharagpur focuses on EM Bypass to make it safer
Content:
A jaywalker scales a barricade on Bypass

KOLKATA: IIT Kharagpur ’s civil engineering department is conducting a study to improve safety of pedestrians and drivers and improve traffic management within six month.“The survey, done on behalf of state’s urban development department, has been going on for the last two weeks. The researchers are evaluating various parameters like road safety, use of signals by pedestrians and drivers, etc,” said Bhargab Maitra from the IIT. He said, “We are consulting various stakeholders like KMDA, KMC, transport department, Kolkata Police and Bidhannagar Police as well as Metro authorities for the safety audit of Bypass. We are focusing on 25 intersections between Ultadanga and Garia so that Bypass can be a model road.”“We are also auditing the bus stops and the sheds at the bus stands and how they are used by passengers,” Maitra said. He added that as they will submit their report within three months.“We are also checking the accident-prone zones. Chingrighata is one such spot, for which we are trying to find solutions. The study is being conducted both in the morning and at night. At night, poor illumination, blocked road signs and potholes are major issues. Motorists bypassing signals and jaywalkers are also being looked into.”Maitra further said that the standard of the survey will be similar to the one that the institute conducted on national highways. “The researchers will suggest inexpensive changes with little change to the infrastructure after the study is complete. He pointed out that pedestrians lack proper access to the bus stop in front of Paribahan Bhavan .“In some places, the pavements, which need cleaning and better illumination, are not used by the pedestrians. Proper design of the service roads and pavements where they merges with the Bypass can reduce accidents. The median is also being studied as people are seen scaling it to cross over to avoid walking longer distance,” Maitra said.On Thursday evening, five IIT researchers — Saurabh Dandapat, Kinjal Bhattacharyya, Sudipa Chatterjee, Kaustubh Saysardar and Dipanjan Mukherjee — stood at the VIP Bazar crossing to jot down adherence to traffic signals and the behaviour pattern of the pedestrians. They noticed that the road signs were not properly visible as with shops had encroached upon the roads and pavement. Dandapat showed that crossing the road at that point was a tough task in the absence of a zebra crossing. Moreover, hazard markers on the Metro infrastructure were not properly visible at all the spots.Bhattacharyya pointed out that the subways near Science City were underused, though motorists followed traffic laws at that junction.

Title: AICTE makes online courses mandatory for new engineering faculty
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: All India Council for Technical Education ( AICTE ) has made eight online courses mandatory for new faculty members and faculty members with less than five years of experience in technical institutions.

Called national initiative for technical teachers training, the courses include orientation towards technical education and curriculum aspects, professional ethics and sustainability, communication skills, modes and knowledge dissemination, instructional planning and delivery, technology enabled learning, life long self-learning, student assessment and evaluation, creative problem solving, innovation, institutional management and administrative procedures.

In a recent circular, AICTE said the courses have been made mandatory to new inductee teachers and teachers with less than five years experience in the gazette notification for seventh pay commission scale salary. “It is requested that maximum new inductee teachers and teachers with less than five years of experience be advised to register under this initiative,” the circular said.

Roughly, up to 25% faculty members in tier-1 engineering colleges and more than 50% of faculty members in tier-2 and tier-3 engineering colleges in the state will have less than five years experience.

“We have made it mandatory for all faculty members in our college with less than five years to finish the online courses. For faculty members above five years we have made it as on optional training programme,” said B Chidambararajan, principal of Valliammai Engineering College.

“The faculty members are undergoing various online training programmes as the same was linked with pay hike. But these courses are offered subsidised fees. AICTE also should consider offering these courses for a subsidised fee,” he added.

The faculty members need to pay Rs 2,000 as registration fee and Rs 1,000 for each of the eight modules.

Maluk Mohamad, chairman of MAM College of Engineering and Techology in Trichy, said teachers would take it seriously if the fee is fixed for online course. “AICTE is not asking the teachers to get extra degree. The candidates are spending lakhs of rupees for UG and PG programmes. It is not a big amount,” he said.

Faculty members said the course fee of Rs10,000 is almost one month salary for new faculty members.

“New faculty members and faculty members are receiving around Rs 10,000 a month. It would be difficult for them to pay the amount. AICTE should make it free for the faculty members till it ensures pay as per the seventh pay commission scale of pay,” said K M Karthik, president of Private Educational Institutions Employees Association.

Title: Marathi play ‘Ulgulan’ depicts stark reality of tribals’ suppression, plight
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

A one-act play ‘Ulgulan’ was staged by employees of Mhada at Vasantrao Deshpande Hall, Civil Lines, on Wednesd... Read More

Nagpur: Tribals facing hardships in the shadow of Naxalism and unscrupulous politicians exploiting the situation to the hilt for personal gains was effectively portrayed by the employees of Maharashtra Housing and Area Development Authority (Mhada) in Marathi drama ‘Ulgulan’ at Dr Vasantrao Deshpande Hall on Wednesday.

Led by Bhiva (Sudhir Wankhede), the tribals try to usher in a revolution (ulgulan) and lead a happy and peaceful life. But in Naxal-infested areas, development does not come so easily. Bhiva pitches for development and raises voice against the injustice meted out to the adivasis. But his voice is stifled.

The story unfolds with flashback sequences in which struggles of tribal people are highlighted. In between Anna (Anant Dhole) wants to set up a paper industry to which the tribals are opposed.

When Bhiva takes up the development issue, Naxals, wily Anna and some corrupt police officials conspire against him. Bhiva is imprisoned on flimsy grounds though his wife Chanda (Dakshata Gone) stands by him so also the tribals, but in vain.

As the play progresses, solo dance ‘Tipura tipura’ catches eyes. The composition of song highlighted various aspects of a well-settled locality that the tribals dream to live in. But that is not to be.

Group dance on the song ‘Aamhi adivasi re’ depicts the indomitable spirit of tribals who always try to lead a happy life despite facing adversities. Songs and dance of adivasis was a treat to watch.

With tribals engaged in routine work, Bhiva is released from jail which raises their hopes that there will be a dawn in their life. But the jubilation does not last long as Anna incites Durga, who is hostile to tribals. An angry Durga opens fire at tribals and silences them forever, leaving the audience stunned.

The play, written by Harshad Salve and directed by Danish Khan, painted the stark reality of tribal life. They were inspired by the book ‘Goomfan’, written by Shivkumar Aney.

(Reporting by Janhavi Dave)

Title: Congress to seek discussion on playground numbers
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

AHMEDABAD: The state government has in the last two years provided playground facilities in only 261 primary schools while another 4,612 are still awaiting playgrounds of their own.

The government in the tabled reply said that of the 261 schools with playgrounds, 173 are in Narmada and 20 each are in Tapi and Botad. Another 19 schools in Porbandar were given playground facility. Opposition leader Paresh Dhanani said that as on December 31, 2019, 4,612 schools did not have playground facility. “If we add 261 schools which have been given this facility in the past two years, the figures become 4,873. But, the government on December 31, 2017 had stated that 7,209 schools have no playgrounds,” he said.

“The number has come down drastically. The Congress party will demand a discussion on the present number of 4,612. We will demand a discussion for presenting wrong figures in the assembly. As per rules, the government will have to permit discussion on the issue,” said Dhanani.

Shailesh Parmar, the deputy leader of opposition said either the figures are wrong, or the government has closed or merged 2,336 schools which have disappeared in the last two years.

Title: Riots in Delhi: Rioting mobs leave behind ghost town, over 3,000 houses deserted
Content:
Areas surrounding Phase 8 and 9 in Shiv Vihar along the Loni border have the eerie look of abandoned habitatio... Read More

NEW DELHI: On the roads of certain areas of Shiv Vihar you will not spot a soul. While everyone’s attention has been on the key riot zones like Chand Bagh, Gokulpuri and Maujpur-Jafrabad, areas surrounding Phase 8 and 9 in Shiv Vihar along the Loni border have the eerie look of abandoned habitations.More than 3,000 houses lie abandoned, hundreds have been ransacked. The untended shops and factories of the deserted Shiv Vihar were being looted even when TOI visited the area on Thursday evening. Sudha Devi, 45, one of the few Hindu residents of the area, alleged that police and the city administration had forsaken them. “Where were you when gas cylinders were being used to burn down houses here?,” she asked, her eyes surveying the half burnt houses and charred skeletons of cars.Devi’s husband, a transport department employee, said the family has moved in with relatives in Shanti Nagar. “A crowd of more than 2,000 burnt down these houses on Monday night. It was a nightmare,” he shuddered, adding, “Bhagwan na kare kabhi kisi ke sath ab aisa ho.” The only reason they were in Shiv Vihar was to save their house from arsonists.A mixed locality dominated by Muslims, the houses there still had smoke billowing out on Thursday. Two places of worship were damaged, with the shells of exploded cylinders lying there a tell-tale sign. Rioters, in particular, targeted religious inscriptions. Gaurav Kumar said that all the Muslims had left the colony. “There is no one to talk to even,” the dejected man said, glancing at the charred remains of his neighbours’ houses.A Muslim family, hurrying to leave the area, did not want to say anything. “There is nothing for us here now. We will start our lives somewhere else,” one of the women said. Their voices were the only sound save for the cawing of crows on the entire 25-Foota Road, where some houses had ‘Jai Shri Ram’ scrawled on their doors, obviously to save themselves from the rioters.One landlord talked of his tenants for the past 15 years. “Saleem Sahab and his family packed their bags and left when passions started to intensify on Monday. I never had any problem with them. But seeing what is left now, it is good they left for Bijnor,” he remarked. The water and electricity supply remain cut.Residents said that despite the presence of the Rapid Action Force, there still is fear. “The security personnel are on the main road, not on the interior lanes. It has been four days since we slept properly,” said Gaurav Kumar’s father. “When it turns dark, we sit outside our houses because inside we won’t even come to know if someone comes to burn the house down. At least outside we can run to safety.”The many bakeries in the area were owned by Muslims who had employed mostly Hindu workers and salesman. Ram Kumar, a supply agent for the bakeries, said he had surely lost his source of income with the bakeries all lying shuttered now. He looked dejectedly at children helping themselves to rusks at a bakery he once worked for.Read this story in Bengali

Title: Life bounces back: Riot-hit areas in northeast Delhi picking up the pieces
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Northeast Delhi is slowly trying to move on from the horrors of the last few days.

NEW DELHI: With some grocery shops having reopened, damaged electrical lines being restored, metro stations functioning and at least a few people starting to go about their daily chores, northeast Delhi is slowly trying to move on from the horrors of the last few days.

Roads leading to Jafrabad and Maujpur-Babarpur were visibly more active on Thursday. Shops selling essential commodities opened and vegetable and fruit vendors could be seen moving around. However, the pall of gloom persisted.

Other riot-affected areas, such as Chand Bagh, Mustafabad, Kabir Nagar and Kardampuri, also saw a semblance of normalcy. Maujpur Chowk, which was until Wednesday occupied by police, was bustling with activity. On Maujpur main road, medical shops opened in the morning.

A shopkeeper, Sunil Tyagi, told TOI: “I opened my shop after three days...many people were calling me with urgent requirements. We don’t have enough stocks though. I plan to down the shutters at 1.30pm. I will take a call later about reopening in the evening.”

At another shop, senior citizens queued up for medicines. Painkillers were most in demand. Paramilitary forces were stationed in heavy numbers in the inner lanes. Some local traders from both communities could be seen serving refreshments to them. Shashank Sharma (25), a resident of Maujpur, said they were thankful to the forces for restoring normalcy.

Rajesh Sharma, who owns a garment shop, said rumours were giving them sleepless nights. “After a generator caught fire near a market in Maujpur, it triggered rumours of arson.” At several places in Maujpur, Shiv Vihar and Gokulpuri, officials were busy restoring the damaged power lines. “Some poles have been burnt down, while at other points arsonists cut off the lines,” a BSES official said.

At a bangle shop, Hema Bisht was seen shopping for a relative’s wedding. “No one could come for the pre-wedding celebrations. We couldn’t even purchase anything as shops and roads were shut. I have come out today to buy bangles for the bride,” she said.

On the other side of the canal in Kabir Nagar, some shops had reopened. In Chand Bagh, people ventured out on the streets. Police prevented crowds from gathering. The narrow alleys leading from the arterial road between Chand Bagh and Karawal Nagar, which had been blocked by locals, were being opened again. An earthmover was being used to clear the rubble and glass shards.

However, uncertainty still haunted those affected by the riots. “My shop was torched and I lost most of my belongings. I have no insurance. How will I rebuild my life?” asked a distressed Bhure Khan, a shop owner who sold fruits and other utilities.

Shama Parween, a 45-year-old widow who stitches clothes for a living in Chand Bagh, showed her plastered left foot. “I cannot use the sowing machine right now. I have a house to run and three children to feed. A neighbourhood doctor treated me and told me to keep the plaster on for at least a month. How will I earn a livelihood?” she asked.

An East Delhi Municipal Corporation spokesperson said that debris and burnt vehicles were being removed. “We are giving priority to the least-affected areas so that our officials are not attacked and equipment damage. That can demoralise the workers,” he added.

Title: West Bengal: Pay traffic fine and tax by March 31, get waiver
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Cops during a similar penalty-waiver drive early last year

KOLKATA: The state government has offered 100% waiver on penalty on tax of any kind accrued by any vehicle, if the amount is paid within March 31. Moreover, the transport department is also offering a waiver of 50% of the compounding amount for the motor-vehicle offences, irrespective of date of when it was committed, imposed by the enforcement authority (police or motor vehicle inspectors), if it is paid within the same deadline. The scheme was kicked off on Thursday.

The period for waiver on the pending fitness certificate cases of vehicles has also been extended from February 29 to March 31. The state government could mop up a revenue of Rs 64 crore from fitness certificate fees alone by offering the waiver on the penalty against non-compliant vehicles.

More than 1 lakh vehicles have undergone fitness test since January, said a transport department officer.

Apart from providing errant vehicle owners relief, the settlement schemes can help the state mop a considerable amount of revenue. According estimates, Rs 800 crore is due only on account of road tax against the commercial and non-commercial vehicles in the state.

Bus and minibus owners need to pay road tax every three months. Owner of a non-AC bus pays Rs 1,516 while that of a minibus pays Rs 1,100 every quarter. If the road tax is pending for one quarter, the penalty will be 100% of the actual amount and if it is pending for more than that, it is 200%. Thus, the pending road tax becomes a huge liability, which most of the operators fail to pay. This is why bus operators were demanding a waiver scheme, said Tapan Banerjee, secretary of the joint council of bus syndicates.

Title: Farmer ends life unable to repay loan
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: A farmer, who was unable to repay a loan he had obtained from a private bank a few years ago, allegedly committed suicide in Theni on Thursday.

Police said Dharmalingam, 52, of Sirapparai village in Theni district obtained a loan of Rs 12 lakh from a private bank a few years ago. He couldn’t repay the loan as he had faced heavy losses in agriculture. Two days ago Dharmalingam received a notice from the bank stating that his house would be attached if he failed to repay his loan. His family told police that he had been forlorn since then and consumed pesticide two days ago. He was admitted to the Theni Government Hospital, but he died later.

Title: Depriving a person of liberty can’t be left to whims of police: HC
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Nagpur: Coming down heavily on the illegal detention of a father-son duo, Nagpur bench of Bombay high court slapped a fine of Rs2.20 lakh on a Wardha police inspector (PI). It also tersely observed that “depriving a person of his liberty guaranteed by Article 21 of the Constitution of India can’t be left to the whims and wishes of the police officer”.

“If (illegal detention) is permitted, it would be conferring arbitrary and unbridled powers on the police authorities. Knowledge of the police officer about design to commit any cognisable offence by a person has to be reflected from the record, showing the details of proposed preventive action against that person,” the HC observed, before directing authorities to record its observations in the PI’s service book.

There was a dispute over petitioner Kishor Futane’s trusteeship, and his post as secretary at Shri Mirannath Maharaj Deosthan at Deoli in Wardha district. This was pending before the authorities under Maharashtra Public Trusts Act since 2013-14.

On December 25, 2013, a report was lodged at Deoli police station against Futane, alleging that he tried to break open the trust’s cupboard to take away documents. Another report was lodged on January 19, 2014, against him and his son Dr Indraprasad, claiming that they were examining trust documents in its office and also abused the complainant. After enquiry, the police authorities found that the offences were non-cognizable in both complaints.

On February 5, 2014, Deoli police inspector Dhananjay Sayare suddenly initiated action under Section 151 (1) of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) and detained the father-son duo for over seven hours, before they were released by the executive magistrate.

Terming themselves as reputed citizens, the aggrieved petitioners moved HC contending that their detention was illegal and “abuse of power and authority” by Sayare and Burle.

The judges observed that police officer may take action as per CrPC Section 151(1) against a person only if he has knowledge of a design of commissioning of any cognisable offence, or if it appears to him that cognisable offence can’t be prevented unless preventive action is taken against the person who may commit it.

“The PI hasn’t pointed out anything from the record of having knowledge that the petitioners were designing to commit any cognisable offence. To say the least, the justification given for taking action as per CrPC is misleading and an attempt to cover up the illegal act. We find that the petitioners have suffered due to PI’s illegal and high handed action, which appears to be motivated,” the HC said.

WHAT HC SAID

* Petitioners suffered due to PI’s illegal & high handed action which appears to be motivated

* If (illegal detention) permitted, it would confer arbitrary & unbridled powers on police officers

* Police officer should have record of knowledge of design to commit cognisable offence

* Justification given for taking action as per CrPC is misleading & an attempt to cover up illegal act

* Except two reports against petitioners, nothing is placed on record to justify preventive action

* Petitioners should submit affidavit if they wish to donate Rs2.20 lakh to Mirannath Maharaj Trust

Title: Justice Haq takes charge at Aurangabad
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Nagpur: Scores of city lawyers heaved a sigh of relief after Justice Zaka Haq finally took charge at Aurangabad bench of Bombay high court from Monday. He is heading the division bench also having justice SM Gavhane, as per the lawyers.

On first day of his sitting, he granted a relief to a 78-year-old retired labourer, Sambha Jondale, who was earlier working with Vasantrao Naik, Marathawada Krushi Vidyapith in Parbhani, by directing the government to release his pensionary benefits.

Upset by sudden transfer by former chief justice Pradeep Nandrajog, the city judge was reluctant to take up the new post and even went on long leave till further notice. There were speculations that he may even resign, which led to protest by the lawyers, including senior ones like former advocate general Shreehari Aney, senior counsels like Surendra Kumar Mishra, Anil Mardikar, Anand Jaiswal apart from noted ones Firdos Mirza, Shreerang Bhandarkar and others.

According to lawyers, Justice Haq took up the new assignment on same day when former CJ retired, and city-based Justice Bhushan Dharmadhikari took up the charge being the senior most in the hierarchy.

“Since, Justice Haq had joined the new post and the new CJ has assumed charge from this week, we will wait for some positive outcome. We have high expectations from the new CJ, who’s native of the city and is well familiar with Justice Haq. We have therefore decided to hold our protests against the judge’s abrupt transfer to Aurangabad,” the lawyers told TOI.

Enraged over Justice Nandrajog’s move, even the High Court Bar Association (HCBA) here had passed a resolution protesting against the judge’s transfer. Over 300 lawyers had signed a resolution on January 21 and HCBA office-bearers handed it over to former CJ in Mumbai in presence of Aney in first week of this month.

However, the CJ defended his decision stating that he wanted a dynamic lawyer at the Aurangabad bench who could also effectively look after Public Interest Litigations (PILs), besides regular civil and criminal cases. TOI has been following the issue with series of reports since HCBA passed resolution.

After CJ’s refusal to cancel Justice Haq’s transfer, the lawyers restarted their protests on February 17 where over 500 of them tied white bands on their coats in the first session. They had planned to intensify the protests in coming days while terming the transfer as “humiliation” for entire legal fraternity from the city. “But those were put on hold for few days, on hopes that new CJ would take an “appropriate decision”. In Aurangabad, he would be at fifth position and retire in May 2021 in same position. In Nagpur, he would retire on second position,” the lawyers said.

Title: Delay in payment of paddy procurement price alleged
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Madurai: Farmers in Madurai district have alleged that paddy procurement centres established by the government have not yet paid the dues amounting to Rs 35 crore for the procurement made from them nearly a month ago.

The issue was raised in the farmers grievance meeting held at the Madurai district collectorate on Wednesday. Paddy was cultivated in 38,235 hectares in the district last season, and 1.5 tonne was harvested from 32,000 hectares. Ravi, a farmer from Kottakudi, said that they had not been given their dues for the procured paddy for over a month. He was told that payments had been made for paddy procured till February 16, but the farmers claimed that payment has not been made for paddy procured on February 3.

Farmers in Melur alleged that the procurement process was getting delayed and their paddy bags were lying in the open without any protection. “The skies turned cloudy on Wednesday evening, and we prayed that it would not rain because, the slightest drizzle could result in our paddy sprouting and going waste,” said Sethu, a farmer from Melur. A demand was made at the grievance meet to increase the number of paddy procurement centres in Madurai.

Officials of the Tamil Nadu Civil Supplies Corporation said the number of centres had been increased to 100 from the previous 45 this year. The delay was due to lack of sufficient labour and problems with the transport, they said. Farmers also said that they had to pay about Rs 50 for each bag that they gave at the procurement centres.

Madurai collector Dr T G Vinay said that payment for the procured paddy had been given to 2,355 farmers till date and deposited in their bank accounts, the remaining amount would be deposited to 1,384 farmers in a week’s time.

Title: Ahmedabad: Grandparents and grandchildren ‘adopt’ each other
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

The initiative was announced and commenced to coincide with 60th birthday of a city-based management thinker S... Read More

AHMEDABAD: It was a teary-eyed moment for senior citizens at Jeevan Sandhya old age home in Naranpura on Thursday morning when they were handed kids ranging from a few weeks to a few years as part of ‘ adoption ’ initiative.

C K Patel, president of Ahmedabad District Probation and Aftercare Association that runs ‘Shishu Gruh’ - children home for the orphans - said that it was a novel experiment where the senior citizens who don’t get to live with their grandchildren, and the children who have not seen their grandparents, will find each other. “They have so much love to give and I am sure it would benefit both the groups emotionally,” he said.

The initiative was announced and commenced to coincide with 60th birthday of a city-based management thinker Shailesh Thaker, also a member of the association. “What could be a better event than a child getting his/her parents?” he said.

Officials at Jeevan Sandhya old age home said that distance from their families often make the senior citizens feel incomplete and doubt their roles in active society. “We are hopeful that with this initiative, they would feel that warmth - even for a few hours - to find purpose in life,” said an official.

Title: Jetty pumping station on Hooghly to solve water woes in Kidderpore
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Water drawn from the Hooghly will be sent to Watgunge treatment plant

KOLKATA: A new water intake pumping station constructed on a jetty on the Hooghly at Watgunge will take care of water scarcity in large areas of Kidderpore and Watgunge. The pumping station will draw water from the Hooghly and supply it to Watgunge water treatment plant. The plant will then carry out filtration process and finally potable water will be sent to several parts of Watgunge and Kidderpore.

According to an estimate, the new pumping station with a capacity to draw 15million gallons water in a day will be able to resolve water crisis in at least five wards and cater to at least 1.5 lakh people in Kidderpore and Watgunge. “We will inaugurate the intake jetty on Sunday. All we can say is that residents of Watgunge and Kidderpore will immensely benefit from the project,” a KMC water supply department official said. He added that once operational, the new intake pumping station will be instrumental in supplying potable water to five wards (75 to 80) four times a day. Now, the civic body supplies drinking water twice a day.

Construction of the jetty was planned following Kolkata Municipal Corporation’s decision to do away with ground water in the Watgunge-Kidderpore belt and augment supply of piped water in the area.

According to a KMC official, the new facility has some some unique features. “This is the first jetty-mounted intake pumping station designed for the city with a capacity to draw 15 million gallons of water per day. It will go a long way in mitigating water crisis not only in Kidderpore and Watgunge but large parts of Metiabruz also,” he said.

Explaining the advantages of such a pumping station, the official said since the intake pumping station was constructed on the river, the supply of raw water will never dry up. On the contrary, the station with a greater withdrawal capacity will be able to supply raw water according to demands of Watgunge water treatment plant and some other plants coming up in Kidderpore-Metiabruz areas,” said the official.

Sources in the KMC said the raw water to be drawn from the Hooghly will also be supplied to Manasatala water treatment plant once it’s ready and at least three capsule water booster pumping stations that will come up in the neighbourhood.

Title: Judge loses job for ‘sexist’ language during lecture
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

NEW DELHI: Use of “highly sexist” language during a lecture for civil service probationers cost a judge his job as the Supreme Court upheld his compulsory retirement saying even a single aberration cannot be tolerated in the judiciary .

Though the allegations were levelled by 10 women civil service probationers years ago and the judicial officer had since got promotion, the apex court said past adverse record of a judge does not lose the sting at any stage and action can be taken on that basis. The judge had addressed the probationers as deputy director of the Administrative Training Institute in Ranchi.

A bench of Justices L Nageswara Rao and Deepak Gupta also took into account the allegation that the judge who was number two principle judge of the family court in Godda in Jharkhand had put a hot iron on the head of a washerman who had not ironed his clothes properly.

While upholding the Jharkhand High Court decision to compulsory retire the judge, the apex court went through the complaint filed by women probationers and found that the language used by him was “highly sexist”.

“There are two very serious allegations against him. The first is that when he was working as deputy director, Administrative Training Institute at Ranchi, as many as 10 women, who were civil service probationers, made allegations that he was using unwarranted and objectionable language during his lectures, citing indecent examples and using words having double meaning, thereby causing embarrassment. We have perused the complaints which are filed with the reply and the common refrain is that the language used by him during his lectures was highly sexist. There is also another allegation that he had physically hurt a washerman by placing a hot iron on the head of the washerman who had allegedly not ironed his clothes properly,” the bench said.

The court also upheld compulsory retirement for another judge whose integrity had been doubted more than once. The court noted that even his knowledge of law and procedures was found to be average and his relations with members of the Bar was found to be not very good.

“There are also allegations against him of having granted bail for illegal gratification and substance has been found in this allegation in the report of the judicial commissioner, Ranchi. The officer had granted bail by noting in the order that Section 327 of the Indian Penal Code , 1860 was bailable whereas the offence is non-bailable and an unrecorded warning regarding the integrity of the judicial officer was issued to him in 2012,” the bench said.

Challenging the administrative order of the HC, the judicial officers had contended that their entire service record, especially the contemporaneous record, had not been taken into consideration. They said they had been granted various promotions which would have the effect of “washing off” their previous adverse entries, if any.

But the court refused to accept their contention. “While considering the case of a judicial officer for compulsory retirement the entire record of the judicial officer should be taken into consideration, though the latter and more contemporaneous record must be given more weightage. Subsequent promotions do not mean that earlier adverse record cannot be looked into while deciding whether a judicial officer should be compulsorily retired,” the bench said.

Title: Madurai: 16 people get life in murder case
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Sivaganga District Sessions Judge Karthikeyan has awarded life sentence to 16 people in a murder case on Thursday. The incident relating to the murder happened in 2010. A group of men from Muthukulathor in Ramanathapuram district were staying in Sivaganga to set up sheep pens. Goats belonging to these men were allowed to graze on lands of farmers in Avarankadu in Sivaganga district.

As they had been staying on a land belonging to Muniyandi , they were allowed to graze their goats only on the lands of people specified by Muniyandi. Chandrakumar of Avarankadu had approached the men and asked them to bring their goats to his land. Muniyandi opposed this, following which trouble brewed between the supporters of Muniyandi and Chandrakumar.

On August 10, 2010, Chandrakumar and some of his kin including Alimuthu, 55, were talking in front of a shop. An 18-member gang including M Sekar, 39, M Poosaimani, 32, M Pandivel, 38, M Veerabathiran, 35, K Muniyandi, 61, V Alagupandi, 30, P Muniyandi, 23, C Palaniyandi, 40, T Rajangam, 45, B Prabu, 19, R Muthupandi, 23, P Rathi, 28, M Ramayee, 60, K Veerabathiran, 31, M Michael, K Ganeshan, 32, K Karuppiah, 63 and K Selvaraj, 35, attacked them with deadly weapons. Alimuthu, who sustained serious injuries, died on the spot. Police registered a case and arrested 18 people. Two of the accused, Sekar and Karuppiah, died during trial.

Title: Save Merit activists meet CM Thackeray
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

SMSN delegation handing over the memorandum of demands to CM Uddhav Thackeray on Wednesday

Nagpur: A delegation of the Save Merit Save Nation (SMSN) forum, affiliated to the Save Merit Foundation in the city, met chief minister Uddhav Thackeray in his office in Mumbai on Wednesday.

State president of SMSN, Dr Sanjay Deshpande, claimed that the meeting was positive. “I think the CM will understand the seriousness of this issue and render justice to the open category and meritorious students,” he said.

“Our team drew the CM’s attention towards the alarming situation in Maharashtra due to the increase in the percentage of reservation, which has escalated from 74% to 85% with further lateral reservations. The chief minister gave us a patient hearing after which we were assured that all the concerned departments would be given instructions to review the announcements made by the previous government,” added Deshpande.

The CM also assured the delegation that he would call for a meeting with SMSN activists soon. Shiv Sena MLC Gopikishan Bajoria from Akola coordinated the meeting with the CM.

“When Devendra Fadnavis was CM, he had called SMSN members for a confidence building meeting in July 2019. After the meeting, the state government had issued five GRs, including fee reimbursement for open category students who were forced to take admission in private colleges. We want these decisions to be implemented this year as well. It will provide at least some relief to merit students of the unreserved class,” said executive president of the forum Shreekrishna Buty.

The main demand of the SMSN forum is that reservation in education should have a maximum limit of 50% as capped by the supreme court. SMSN state office-bearers Utpala Mulawkar, Sachin Poshettiwar, Abhijeet Ambhaikar, Mahesh Karwa, R B Heda, Aparna Randive and Ashutosh Pradhan were part of the delegation.

Title: Fake cops kidnap woman in Ahmedabad
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image
