AHMEDABAD: Two men who introduced themselves as crime branch personnel allegedly kidnapped a 27-year-old woman from Narol Road in an autorickshaw on Wednesday. Inspector of Isanpur police station, J M Solanki, said the woman is currently admitted in a hospital and still unconscious and unable to talk. They are hunting for the two accused, one of who had said his name was Rajbha and that he was from crime branch. Solanki said the woman had injuries from assault.

“If we find that the woman has also been assaulted sexually, we will add relevant sections of molestation or rape,” Solanki said.

The woman’s boyfriend, who lives in Bapunagar, has filed the FIR in the case. He stated that on February 26, he received a call from a friend who was an autorickshaw driver that while his girlfriend was travelling in his auto, two persons had intercepted them on Narol Road.

“One of them sat in his auto and said the woman has committed a theft and she needs to be taken to crime branch office at Gaekwad Haveli for identification. One of the men introduced himself as Rajbha, took the woman to an auto and asked the complainant’s friend to follow him,” said a police official.

The complaint states that they took the auto near NID Circle and told the complainant’s friend to wait for them and went away with the woman. “After about 15 minutes, one of the men called the auto driver and told him to leave and said that if wants the woman returned he will have to pay Rs 30,000 in the account he mentions,” police officials said.

The complainant’s friend then went back and along with the woman’s boyfriend searched for her at several places but as they could not find her they called up the police control room. “We searched for the women but couldn’t find her. The woman’s boyfriend then lodged a complaint under sections of kidnapping and extortion,” said a police source.

Title: Lift kara de: Homes installing elevators
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Nagpur: Demand for real estate is sagging and this should have hit the market for elevators too. On the contrary, demand for it is zooming up with residents choosing to fit it into not only newly built bungalows but even older independent houses.

A single company managed to sell 100 units last year in Nagpur and has upped its target by another 50 in the coming year. The overall national market of such lifts is pegged at 18,000 units a year, an industry growth projection of 20%.

Gaurav Agarawala, of Confederation of Real Estate Developers of India (CREDAI), said builders are seeing an overal revival in demand too. On elevators, he said a trend has been seen in “existing bungalows where lifts are being installed, especially if there are elderly in the home”.

The Chennai-head quartered Johnson Lifts and Escalators, which has a manufacturing unit here, has bagged an order worth Rs24 crore to make 104 lifts for the All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) in Nagpur. It also expects a 50% boom in individual home building segment.

“The overall real estate demand through builders has gone down from 85% to 70% of the turnover, but our company is seeing a jump in orders for independent homes for elevators,” says Albert Dhiraviyam, the company’s country head (marketing). The company has launched a new product in the segment in the city.

Krishna Singhania, one of the buyers, said that he had installed a lift in his two-storied bungalow as his parents were old and had difficulty in climbing stairs. “Otherwise there was no need for a lift. This lift does not need a machine room. Its maintenance cost and power consumption is low,” he added.

Praful Rewatkar, another customer, said that many bungalow owners were installing lifts as they had become quite cheap. “The maintenance cost and power consumption are low. My parents are above 75 and if they want to go to the terrace they will need a lift. I am also above 50 and who knows I may need it someday,” he added.

Johnson’s Nagpur unit has a capacity to make 5,000 lifts a year. “At present over 4,000 are produced at the plant set up in the Butibori industrial estate in 2003,” said Dhiraviyam. “As against 1,000 lifts sold to individual homes, in the current financial year, our company expects to sell 1,500 in the coming fiscal.”

Nagpur too is seeing a similar growth, according to Sudhir Ghike, the plant’s regional manager here. “Last year the company clocked a sale of 100 lifts in the home segment which is expected to go up to 150 in the coming fiscal,” he said.

Johnson has also bagged orders to make lifts for AIIMS’ buildings in Guntur in Andhra Pradesh and Kalyan in West Bengal. Other major orders are from Metro rail projects in Mumbai and Pune.

Title: Ahead of Friday prayers, Aligarh cops send ‘warning’ to 4,000; to invoke Goonda Act against 50
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Agra: The Aligarh police on Thursday issued “red notices” to 2,000 “anti-social” elements restricting their movement and asked another set of 2,000 to sign bonds as an assurance that they not breach peace, apparently apprehending trouble after the Friday prayers.

The district police also issued notices to another 200 people -- having criminal background-- under section 110 (G) of CrPc and initiated process of Goonda Act against 50 people.

Over 100 arm license holders, who are residents of Shahjamal, Jamalpur and Jeevangarh areas -- where anti-CAA protests are going on-- have also been issued warning notices, threatening cancellations of their licenses if they are caught in any trouble.

Mobile Internet services remained suspended in Aligarh for the fourth consecutive day on Thursday.

Aligarh SSP Muniraj G said, “Red notices were issued to 2,000 anti-social elements, informing them about restriction on their movement and 2,000 other people have been issued notices under section 107/116 of CrPC, asking them to sign bonds wherein they would undertake not to breach peace.”

The SSP said that police are on high alert and patrolling on highways has been intensified in view of the communal disturbances in the national capital.

“Additional police force including nine companies of PAC and four companies of RAF along with three additional SPs, eight deputy SPs and eight station house officers (SHO) of neighbouring districts have already been deployed in the city as a precautionary measure,” he said.

Police have identified eight spots in the city which fall in sensitive areas and mohalla meetings were organised with local leaders to maintain peace.

ADG (Agra zone) Ajay Anand told TOI that all stakeholders are engaged to help preserve peace. “We are trying to instill confidence among both communities,” he said.

Title: Madurai police nab gang which killed woman 5 years ago
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: The city police have cracked the murder case of a 59-year-old woman that was committed in November 2015 by a gang of five boys aged 15 to 19 years.

While the prime accused M Kannan alias Oojadi Kannan (now 24 years old) was arrested on February 23 and four knives used in the offence recovered from him, police nabbed his accomplice M Vijay, 22, and R Chellapandi, 19 based on Kannan’s confession, on Tuesday. Two others Prem and Bala who were involved in the murder are already in jail for the last three months for their role in other cases in the city.The victim, R Suriyapriya was alone at her house in the afternoon, when the accused entered and inflicted 72 cut injuries all over her body and fled with the 17.5 sovereigns gold jewellery from her possession.

The case registered by the Keerathurai crime police as a murder for gain was tough to crack with no clue of the accused and was transferred to the ‘Serious Crime Squad’ of the city police four years ago. An officer who was part of the team said the accused who are from the same locality could not be traced as they fled to Coimbatore, Tirupur and other places for work when the police closed in on them.“All of them are school drop outs. Police inquired those who were close to them but the accused did not appear for inquiry too. Fearing arrest they split and worked in other places. But they were in touch over phone and used to meet here rarely when they came for the local temple festival,” he said.

“The arrested confessed that they watched the victim for a few days. On November 2, 2015, they saw her husband and son go to work, her daughter-in-law had gone to town for purchase and that she was alone. One of the accused stood guard in the ground floor to alert others. The four others murdered Suriyapriya and the gang fled with the loot,” the officer added. Kannan, Vijay and Chellapandi were produced before the court and lodged in jail. Prem and Bala will be taken into custody to record their statements.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Five Sri Lankan fishermen held for entering Indian waters near Dhanushkodi
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Five Sri Lankan fishermen who entered Indian territorial waters were detained by the Indian Navy with the help... Read More

MADURAI: The Indian Navy on Thursday seized a Sri Lankan boat and arrested five fishermen from the neighbouring country who entered the Indian waters near Arichal Munai near Dhanushkodi in Ramanathapuram district. This is the second time in less than two weeks that a Indian Navy chopper from INS Parundu in Uchipuli has trapped the Sri Lankan fishermen when they tried to return after illegally entering the Indian waters.

The boat had crossed the International Maritime Boundary Line (IMBL) on Thursday morning was found by the chopper during a regular patrolling. Navy personnel from the chopper instructed the Lankan fishermen to head towards Arichal Munai.

Despite repeated warnings the boat tried to flee and attempted to cross the IMBL. Finally, the chopper flew at a very low height and prevented the boat from leaving the Indian waters and forced the boat to head towards Arichal Munai. The fishermen were quizzed by the Indian Navy personnel before the Mandapam marine police and intelligence agencies picked them up for questioning.

The five men have been identified as R Stephen Raj, 28, V Yesuraja, 46, T Uthayakumar, 40, Ravindiran, 29, and Kanapathipillai, 29, all from Talaimannar in Mannar district, Sri Lanka. They started from Talaimannar pier around 7am on Thursday and told the officials that they had come for fishing and were not involved in smuggling or acts of mischief.

Inquiry revealed that the fibre boat they used was very new and had a powerful engine, which is too high for a fishing boat. Contrary to the claim made by the fishermen, the investigating officials said there wasn’t any fish in the boat and the nets on the boat were also dry, with no hint of fishing activity. Customs officials took custody of the boat to search if they were smuggling gold, valuables or any contraband.

On February 15, a Navy chopper cornered a Lankan boat with three fishermen who crossed the IMBL and were within the Indian waters. They were forced to reach Arichal Munai. While they initially claimed that they had come to catch shoals of fish, inquiry revealed that they were smugglers and 3.5kg gold with 24 carat purity worth Rs 1.48 crore was seized from them. Four of their Indian accomplices were also arrested.

Title: Delhi’s Apollo Hospital room turns into exam centre for Class X girl fighting grave illness
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Sarbjot Kaur

NEW DELHI: Room no. 2343 at Delhi’s Apollo Hospital was witness to a rare exercise on Thursday — the conducting of Class X board exams. Sarbjot Kaur , a student of Mount Carmel in Hoshiyarpur who was diagnosed with a life-threatening illness three weeks ago, couldn’t go to her examination centre but insisted she wanted to give the exams.

Accepting her request, the ICSE board allowed her school to hold the exam in the hospital. Room no. 2343 was chosen and on Day 1, an examiner arrived there around the noon with the English question paper and answer sheets in a sealed envelope.

“During the exams, only the student and the examiner were allowed inside. A doctors’ team was on standby for any medical help but, fortunately, that wasn’t required,” said Dr Shishir Seth, senior consultant of haematology and bone marrow transplant at Apollo Hospital.

The next subject is mathematics, and the exam is on March 3. “We are hopeful that Kaur will be fit enough to be discharged by then and will be able to go to the examination centre. Otherwise, it may also be held here,” a senior official said.

Reham Kaur, the girl’s mother, said her daughter was among the toppers in the school. “She was preparing very hard for the exams, but suddenly fell ill. Tests revealed she has AML. She is undergoing treatment,” she said.

Acute myeloid leukemia is a life-threatening illness that starts in the bone marrow — the soft inner part of certain bones where new blood cells are made. The main treatment for most types of AML is chemotherapy, sometimes along with a targeted therapy drug. This may be followed by a stem cell transplant.

The mother added that the illness hadn’t been able to deter her daughter’s determination a bit. “I am sure she will do well in the exams. My daughter wants to become an IAS officer.”

The hospital authorities said the girl’s courage and determination in the face of a health crisis would be an inspiration for other patients, who, if diagnosed with critical illnesses, often lose hope. “We are happy to see this child pursuing her dreams despite all challenges,” said a senior doctor.

Title: Inner ring road traffic eases as toll collection stops
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Madurai: Though Madras high court had restrained the company which had been collecting toll at the Vandiyur toll plaza, on the inner ring road in Madurai, from collecting it from 9 am on Thursday, the vehicles passing through it were asked to pay up as usual in the morning. However, after it was stopped in the evening traffic movement became smoother and easier.

The court had taken cognizance of the fact that the toll plaza did not have a separate lane for ambulances and other vehicles, which were exempted from toll, at the Vandiyur toll gate leading to chaos and traffic congestion. A division bench had passed the interim order while hearing a batch of petitions against collection of toll fee at three new toll plazas set up on the ring road in Madurai. They restrained the collection at the first toll gate at Vandiyur. Centre for Environmental Sciences founder S V Pathy said he passed through the Vandiyur toll plaza while going home to Gomathypuram from the Madurai airport on Thursday morning. “The bar was placed across and I was asked to pay the toll fee. When I told them that I had read that they should not collect fee at this gate, they told me it was a court matter and that they had been told to collect fees till further information,’’ he said

There is much chaos at this toll gate that they have personnel diverting the traffic on to the opposite lanes during heavy congestion on one side. As the gates opened in the evening, there was nobody manning the collection centres at the toll gate and traffic moved smoothly.tnn

Title: To save tigress, cubs, trees chopped in Tadoba buffer
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

NAGPUR: Call it what you may — an irony of conservation or lack of physical protection measures — but the Tadoba-Andhari Tiger Reserve (TATR) had to resort to felling and trimming of trees in the buffer zone between Mudholi-Katwal on the western side of the park.

At a time when the Supreme Court has asked to recognize trees as living entities, tree felling and trimming close to Tadoba’s core has raised many eyebrows. Wildlife lovers are peeved to see the clearing of vegetation under the guise of trimming, in the 3km stretch between Mudholi-Katwal villages.

According to official sources, trees have been trimmed as a tigress with 3 four-month-old cubs could have met with an accident, three days ago on Katwal road.

Deputy director (buffer) G Guruprasad clarified, “A tigress with cubs is regularly crossing the said road near Katwal, and vehicles move at a breakneck speed. As there are no speed breakers between Mudholi-Katwal, there are chances of accident.”

Guruprasad added, “The road patch belongs to PWD and is too dense; the visibility of vehicles coming from two directions is almost nil. Hence, for precaution, we thought of clearing 3 metres on either side of the road to increase visibility.”

“Nearly 20-30 palash trees were chopped, besides removing lantana and bushes. The area is revenue land adjoining the core. The cleaning of vegetation will also act as a fire line during summer,” said Guruprasad.

However, wildlife experts and local NGOs have flayed TATR’s action. “When the park is generating revenue from PWD roads by way of implementing night safari, why can’t it invest on speed breakers on the said road?” they asked.

“Instead of chopping trees, the forest officials should keep a monitoring team at the spot. Tigers with cubs moving out of Tadoba to the nearby hills and forest in buffer is a temporary phase. Instead of chopping trees, a barrier should be installed to check traffic,” they said.

Chandrapur-based Deepak Dixit of Prakruti Foundation said, “Ideally, vehicular traffic should be banned during night on the road from Sitarampeth to Mudholi and further. However, the park management is more interested in night safari, so how can tiger conservation be achieved. Last month, a leopard was knocked dead by speeding vehicle in the same area.”

Dixit alleged, “The decision to chop trees shows that everything is to control animal movement, and steps to control humans who have free run on the said patch are not stringent. Many guests at the resorts near Mohurli venture during night on these road stretches for sightings.”

Guruprasad said that the department would write to PWD to install speed breakers at every 500 metres to avoid animal deaths.

Title: Centre finally notifies Mahadayi tribunal order
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Bengaluru: In a huge relief for Karnataka and in a perfect birthday gift to chief minister BS Yediyurappa, the Centre on Thursday issued a gazette notification for the implementation of the Mahadayi water dispute tribunal’s August 2018 verdict. The move comes after a nudge from the Supreme Court, which, on February 20, ordered the Centre to issue the notification.

The decks are now clear for Karnataka to go ahead with the implementation of the Kalasa-Banduri project, which aims to use 13.4 tmcft allocated to it by the tribunal, for irrigation.

“We are happy the Centre has notified the tribunal's verdict. With this, the long pending Kalasa-Banduri project will be a reality. We thank PM Narendra Modi and Union water resources minister Gajendra Singh Shekhawat for responding to our request with such a speed,” said Union parliamentary affairs minister Pralhad Joshi.

Karnataka ministers Ramesh Jarkiholi, Jagdish Shettar, Basavaraj Bommai and Joshi had met Shekhawat on Wednesday in Delhi to press for early notification of the tribunal’s verdict. Shettar said the government will take necessary steps to implement the Kalasa -Banduri projects at the earliest while expressing happiness over the notification.

Title: Std XII student goes missing from exam centre
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Nagpur: Sadar police have launched a search operation to trace a 17-year-old girl who went missing from the exam centre on Wednesday. Police have registered a case of kidnapping, as per the directions of the Supreme Court regarding missing minors.

Police said the pressure of HSC exam might have driven the teenager to run. Even her family members suspect the same thing.

According to police, the teenager was taken to the exam centre by her mother. The teenager’s mother went home after leaving the daughter at the centre.

After examination, the mother went to pick her up but could not find her even after all the students came out. She later contacted her daughter’s friends who told her that she did not appear in the exam.

The worried woman started looking everywhere for her daughter and also informed her relatives. After looking for her for a long time, the woman approached Sadar police and filed a complaint.

Sources said the teenager had a mobile phone and police are currently trying trace its location. Cops are also scrutinizing CCTV footage from nearby spots to ascertain where the teenager might have gone.

Title: One more held for uploading child porn in Madurai
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: A 33-year-old man from Othakadai in Madurai was arrested on Thursday for uploading child pornographic content. This is the second such incident in Madurai, after two people from Arapalayam were arrested on Tuesday.

The accused, Sundarapandi B, a driver residing in Ayyapa Nagar, Othakadai, was arrested based on information from the National Centre for Missing and Exploited Children (NCMEC) Cyber Tripline Report. Police sources said that in 2019, he was found uploading and watching child pornographic content online. He had also uploaded the content on an Instagram page. Police identified the accused by tracing his IP address. Around 10-15 videos and a number of images of child pornography were seized from him, police added. The Othakadai police have registered a case against Sundarapandi under the Protection Of Children from Sexual Offences (Pocso) Act and sections under the IT Act regarding misuse of technology, and are investigating.

On Tuesday night, N Kumar and his friend N Senthilkumar were arrested for uploading and sharing child pornographic content on social media sites.

The Tamil Nadu police are cracking down on those involved in watching and distributing child pornography across the state.

Title: Farmers, students interact at science expo
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Madurai: A two-day science exhibition for school and college students kicked off at Mu Va Arangam on Thursday. Farmers took the centrestage at the event, exhibiting their traditional farming tools and speaking about climate change .

The National Science Day 2020 exhibition, jointly organized by Madurai Kamaraj University (MKU) and Tamil Nadu Science Forum (TNSF) saw the participation of over 600 students on the first day. The event was inaugurated by the MKU vice-chancellor, Dr M Krishnan, in the presence of TNSF district president, M Rajesh. Students from around 25 departments from MKU exhibited their research work . Providing a unique experience for students at the exhibition, farmers from five villages exhibited various traditional equipments used by them in agriculture. They displayed earthen vessels used for storage of grains, cart wheels, sickles and ploughs.

“Students are not aware about traditional farming equipments. They are able to learn about this through farmers. The farmers spoke about climate change and how ground water depletion is impacting farming,” said K Malarselvi, district secretary, TNSF. A free computer coaching centre sponsored by MKU and Thulir Science Centre, was inaugurated at Palkalai Nagar school.tnn

Title: Used IV fluid bottles from GRH dumped nearby due to lack of bins
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Madurai: The lack of proper disposal method for used-up IV fluid and saline bottle at the Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH), is resulting in them being unceremoniously dumped in a compound near the hospital’s sewage pumping station. As contractors don’t turn up regularly to collect them, they pile up and get mixed with other wastes.

“Sometimes, contractors turn up after 15 days or more. So, the bottles tend to get piled up and gather dust. Sanitary workers also dump other wastes they sweep up like fallen leaves and plastic covers over the bottles. Since the corporation dust bins are located towards the other end of the hospital near the mortuary, workers sometimes lazily dump the waste here instead of carrying it there,” said a hospital source.

“The bottles are not hazardous waste, so there is no issue of it causing harm. As of now, we lack a proper space to store them properly before they are collected periodically. The particular compound is vacant and unused so they are being kept there. It is also easier to transport them outside the hospital from there since it is an open area,” said GRH dean Dr Sangumani J. The dean added that, if possible, they will make arrangements in future to shift and store them properly.

GRH, which has a bed strength over 2,000, generates hundreds of used-up IV fluid bags and saline bottles every day. However, contractors who are supposed to collect them come only after the waste piles up to a certain amount, which is at least a week. The bottles often pile up randomly across the entire stretch of the compound wall.

Sources added that workers find the particular spot convenient because it is right opposite to the surgical supply store. Hospital staff pointed out that bottles are not considered medical or pharmaceutical waste, so it is enough to simply store them in regular dust bins.

Title: Three-level plan to fight air pollution in Delhi, says Gopal Rai
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Gopal Rai

NEW DELHI: Delhi environment minister Gopal Rai on Thursday said the AAP government might consider preparing a three-level action plan to reduce air pollution in the city.

Track the pollution level in your city

“As experts suggested, action plan needs to be prepared for all 40 air quality monitoring stations in the city, that, too, from March to March, all year round. There will also be a special plan for winter, when the cold weather aggravates the situation. And also, a five-year one regarding what we can achieve in that time,” Rai said, while talking about various suggestions by experts and stakeholders given during a meeting at Delhi Secretariat on Thursday.

The minister said, experts suggested that a construction awareness campaign be held asking residents to plan and finish outdoor construction activities by October. “After that only indoor construction work could be allowed. If this could be done, then there may not be a need to ban constructions,” Rai said.

The experts also suggested that there should be an inter-state action committee to take steps to curb pollution due to biomass burning. “All the suggestions from Thursday’s conference would be sent to chief minister Arvind Kejriwal next week and a final action plan would be prepared after that,” Rai said.

Other suggestions included bigger environment budget and people’s charter with 20 points, through which residents could contribute to curbing pollution.

Experts from IIT Kanpur, Teri, IIT Delhi, University of Washington, among others, were present at the meeting along with officials of the civic bodies, PWD, Delhi Cantonment Board, transport department, DSIIDC, and DJB.

Title: Bangladeshi national with Indian passport held in Hyderabad
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A Bangladeshi national travelling on an Indian passport obtained illegally by submitting Aadhaar , voter ID and PAN cards was apprehended by immigration authorities at the city airport early on Thursday.

A top Telangana police officer told TOI that the Bangladesh national, Mohammed Jalal Haque, had obtained the Indian passport by showing Warasiguda, in Secunderabad, as his permanent address in 2014. They said he had been on the police radar for some time along with a few others.

Acting on a tip-off, Mohammed Jalal was held by immigration authorities when he landed from Sharjah. During questioning he said he had married a Hyderabadi woman several years ago; he said he had met her when he was working in one of the Gulf countries .

The Telangana police have seized the illegally obtained documents Jalal used to get the Indian passport to travel to Saudi Arabia for work. Jalal travels in and out of India on his Indian passport to meet family members.

“How he could manage to get hold of the sensitive Aadhaar, voter ID and PAN cards needs to be investigated. He had been to Saudi Arabia on several occasions and worked as a driver there,’’ a source told TOI.

Jalal is still being questioned by intelligence officials.

“Since his wife and children are in Hyderabad, Jalal illegally moved to India. He was booked under the Indian Passport Act and relevant sections of the IPC. He might be declared arrested on Friday and produced before the concerned court,” the official said.

State intelligence officials have over the past one year caught at least two Bangladeshi nationals residing illegally in India and say they have dozens of foreign nationals on their radar for sneaking into Telangana using fake or illegally obtained documents.

Title: Karnataka minister praises Maharashtra, lands in a soup
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Mandya: Minister KC Narayanagowda stirred a row after allegedly praising Maharashtra and Marathi in a programme held in KR Pete a week. A video of the alleged incident surfaced on Thursday and was widely shared on social media.

In the video, Narayanagowda allegedly boasts of his growth as an hotelier and realtor in Maharashtra and attributes all his good fortune to the neighbouring state.

“Maharashtra is my strength,” Narayanagowda purportedly says. “Whatever I’ve achieved in my life as hotelier, realtor and now as a minister, Maharashtra is the reason for that. If I have strength and power, then it belongs to Maharashtra only. I have no qualms in praising Maharashtra and Shivaji.”

Narayanagowda’s purported comments have, obviously, not gone down well with pro-Kannada activists, who held a protest in Mandya on Thursday. Various organisations also demanded an apology from Narayanagowda and sought his resignation.

Karnataka Raskhana Vedike (KRV) activists, who held a protest at Sri Nalvadi Circle on the Mysuru-Bengaluru highway, raised slogans against Narayanagowda and dubbed him a Marathi.

“How can he continue as a minister in Karnataka when he has openly declared allegiance to Maharashtra? Whose side is he on with regard to the border dispute with Maharashtra?” asked protesters.

Protesters warned of a fierce agitation if chief minister BS Yediyurappa did not remove Narayanagowda immediately from his cabinet.

Title: Fined for traffic violation, man attempts to mow down cop
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Nagpur: Angry over being challaned for violating traffic rules a few days ago, a 34-year-old van driver allegedly attempted to mow down a head constable at Bhande Plot Square on Thursday. The cop Subhash Lande, attached to Sakkardara traffic zone, sustained injuries on his right leg, while the van driver fled leaving the vehicle on the spot.

The accused has been identified as Arvind Mete, a resident of Old Bidipeth. Lande is undergoing treatment at a private hospital in Sakkardara.

According to sources, on Monday (February 24), Lande had caught Arvind for violating traffic rules. The cop had detained Arvind’s van and issued him a challan. An infuriated Arvind had then threatened the cop of dire consequences. On Thursday, Arvind paid the fine and collected his vehicle.

After getting his vehicle back, Arvind kept watch on the movement of the cop to “teach him a lesson”. In the evening, when Lande was riding a bike he stopped the two-wheeler by the roadside near Bhande Plot Square to receive a call. While he was talking on mobile, Arvind allegedly tried to mow him dowm. As the cop noticed the van, he tried to dodge it but in vain.

Cops have registered attempt to murder case against the driver.

Soon after the incident, Sakkardara police led by senior PI Ajit Sid and traffic cops rushed to the spot and shifted the injured cop to a private hospital. Sakkardara police have registered a case of attempt to murder against Arvind and have launched a manhunt to nab him.

Title: 2,500 stage protest to condemn Delhi violence
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: More than 2,500 people hit the streets on Thursday at Goripalayam Pallivasal to take part in the protest organized by members of the Tamil Nadu Towheed Jamath (TNTJ) condemning the violence in Delhi.

The protesters, led by TNTJ Madurai district president M Habibullah, condemned the ruling BJP government for failing to stop the violence in the national capital. TNTJ state vice-president B Abdul Rahman also addressed the gathering.

“It was not a riot in Delhi but a pogrom. BJP leaders have openly incited mob against anti-Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) protesters in Delhi. Even the Delhi police appear to be hand-in-glove with the attackers. These attacks targeting Muslims are highly condemnable,” he said. He also condemned the Prime Minister Narendra Modi for not

meeting the victims and showing little concern. The protesters raised slogans and held banners against inaction by the Delhi police and sought the resignation of home Minister Amit Shah.

Meanwhile, anti-CAA, NRC, and NPR protests entered the 14th day at Jinnathidal in Mahboopalayam. Police personnel were deployed at both venues.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Pastor, 52, arrested for sexually abusing girl
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

Title: Delhi government to pay for treatment of all riot victims, to speed up rehab
Content:
Eighteen SDMs have been deployed to monitor the relief and rehabilitation operations

NEW DELHI: Delhi government will bear all medical expenses of the riot victims even if they are admitted to private hospitals, give up to Rs 10 lakh as compensation to the kin of the dead, and up to Rs 5 lakh each to those who have lost houses in this week’s violence in northeast Delhi. The government has also announced a Rs 1 crore compensation to the family of head constable Ratan Lal who was killed in the riots, besides a job to one member of his family.Eighteen subdivisional magistrates (SDMs) have been deployed to monitor the relief and rehabilitation operations, which were announced by chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Thursday at Delhi Secretariat.While Rs 10 lakh will be given for the death of each adult and Rs 5 lakh for that of a minor, Rs 5 lakh will be provided for permanent disability, and Rs 2 lakh for serious and Rs 20,000 for minor injuries. Kejriwal also announced a compensation of Rs 3 lakh for each child who had been orphaned.A compensation of Rs 5 lakh for each home set afire and that of up to Rs 5 lakh for loss of a shop will be provided. An immediate relief of Rs 25,000 will be released to each household damaged substantially or totally and for the loss of household items. For each burnt rickshaw, the compensation amount will be Rs 25,000.“The incidents of violence in Delhi in the last few days are worrisome, and we have taken whatever steps we could to help all those affected,” Kejriwal said. “Everyone has suffered losses in the riots. Hindus and Muslims have died. A head constable of Delhi Police, Ratan Lal, died in the violence, while an IB officer, Ankit Sharma, was found dead in a drain. No one has benefitted from the violence,” Kejriwal said, adding that it had reduced since Wednesday.The Farishtey Dilli Ke scheme of Delhi government, which provides free treatment to the victims of road accidents in private hospitals, will cover the treatment of the riot victims, the chief minister clarified.The revenue department will carry out a quick survey to facilitate distribution of the compensation amounts. A software application will also be developed where people can upload the details of lost properties/vehicles, damages to the businesses and those related to injuries and deaths.Special camps will be set up by the department for urgent availability of lost important documents, such as voter ID and Aadhaar cards, community and income certificates, and copies of property deeds.The government is providing food, water and other necessities in the curfew areas through residents’ welfare associations, NGOs, assembly members, and local people. Round-the-clock helpline numbers have also been set up in the offices of two district magistrates and four SDMs.East Delhi Municipal Corporation has been told to undertake a clean-up exercise of the entire affected zone under the supervision of the revenue department. “Peace committees are being constituted at the mohalla level to restore normalcy,” the chief minister added.The department will also ask the heads of insurance companies to organise special camps for immediate disbursement of claims. “An insurance loss assessment has to be carried out transparently with very little documentation,” Kejriwal pointed out.

Title: Wear ID cards while at work or face action, Tamil Nadu govt tells staff
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Be it to seek transfers or appointments or bid for contracts or redress grievances, the footfalls in the corridors of power are admittedly huge every day. With complaints aplenty about the gullible falling prey to conmen and women, the state government has ordered its staff across Tamil Nadu to wear photo identity cards or face disciplinary action.

An order issued by the personnel and administrative reforms department reiterated an earlier order. Heads of departments and district collectors will instruct staff to wear ID cards without fail. “Not wearing photo IDs may be viewed seriously, and disciplinary action may be initiated against erring individuals,” said an official directive. It also stems from the fact that half the government workforce, including those in the secretariat, move around without ID cards.

In a suo motu writ petition, the Madras high court in July 2018 directed the state to ensure that the rule on ID cards be strictly enforced and action be taken against violators. The government issued an order a month later reiterating the instructions, but complaints continue to pour in. As early as March 1986, the state government issued its first order that staff of public sector undertakings and local bodies, especially those who deal with public, should wear name badges.

All 575 sub-registrar offices come under CCTV surveillance but not many officials sport IDs. “There is no denying that offences take place. There are incidents where public with complaints have clear physical descriptions but don’t know the name of the staff. It is impossible to act,” said a senior officer, seeking anonymity. The bidders of government contracts or partymen and women, who frequent the government offices, enjoy clout in the administration. First-time visitors or the elderly are easy prey.

Unlike the commissionerate of police in Vepery that hands out colour-coded cards for visitors, a majority of the government offices, including Ezhilagam in Chepauk or Panagal Maligai in Saidapet, have visitors’ books. Digital ID cards and swipe card machines for both staff and visitors could make access to government offices more effective, say law enforcers.

Title: Law minister inaugurates circuit bench of Income Tax Appellate Tribunal in Doon, wi-fi at Jolly Grant
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Dehradun: Union law minister Ravi Shankar Prasad, on Thursday, inaugurated the circuit bench of the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal (ITAT) in the city. The facility would start functioning from Friday. He said that the ITAT would help state residents by saving them the trouble to travel all the way to Delhi for income tax litigation.

During the launch, he was asked about the allegation made by the Opposition parties that Justice S Muralidhar has been transferred because he pulled up Delhi police for its sloppy response during the violence that ensued in north-east Delhi a few days back. To this, he said, “The transfer order was in accordance with the recommendation made on February 12 by the Supreme Court collegium headed by Chief Justice of India. Before making the formal announcement, the consent of three judges was taken.”

The law minister attacked the Congress for questioning the transfer order saying, “Congress is hell-bent on destroying all institutions like CAG, courts, CBI, and CVC. Everyone knows what the Congress did during Emergency and how it muzzled all democratic rights.”

When asked about the CAA, Prasad said, “There is no question of stepping back on the law. The CAA does not threaten citizenship rights of the Muslims of the country. Although we are open to listening to any objections that the people have on this law.”

Meanwhile, the Union minister also launched WiFi facility at Dehradun ’s Jolly Grant Airport on the day.

Title: Delhi riots: Kapil Mishra pays ‘silent’ tribute to cop Ratan Lal and IB man Ankit Sharma
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Kapil Mishra paying tribute to Martyrs Ankit Sharma and Rattan Lal

NEW DELHI: BJP leader Kapil Mishra , whose speech on Sunday allegedly played a role in inciting mobs in northeast Delhi, took part in a silent peace march organised at Jantar Mantar on Thursday to pay tribute to Ratan Lal , the Delhi Police head constable , and Ankit Sharma , an Intelligence Bureau staffer , both of whom died during the riots.

The former MLA alleged, “No question is being asked to people who are talking about dividing the country or those on whose terrace petrol bombs were found. Someone who only requested for a road to be cleared to help 35 lakh people is being called a terrorist.”

Claiming that there was nothing inciting in his statement, he said, “I was just talking to a police officer. I don’t want to comment on a sub judice matter.”

On Sunday, Mishra led a gathering in support of the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) at Maujpur Chowk in Jafrabad, and issued an ultimatum to police to vacate the roads in Jafrabad and Bhajanpura in three days, following which violence erupted between pro- and anti-CAA groups.

The march, under the banner of Youth Against Jihadi Violence, ended at Parliament Street police station with the national anthem. Around 200 people took part in the two-hour event.

The organisers urged participants not to shout any slogan at the peace march. “However, we are calm, not weak,” one of them said. Ankita, a DU second-year student, said they had come to “show how you can protest peacefully in a democracy”. Seshmanee Sahu, a JNU research scholar, said the common man, irrespective of religion, was suffering and that needed to stop.

Title: Nag river project loan agreement to be signed in March
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

NAGPUR: The loan agreement between Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) and the department of economic affairs (DEA) for Nag river pollution abatement project will be signed in the third week of March. Execution of the project will start soon thereafter.

Recently, DEA director Avinash Kumar had held a meeting which was attended by officials of National River Conservation Directorate , Union environment department, JICA and Nagpur Municipal Corporation ’s ( NMC ’s) Shweta Bannerjee and Mohammed Israel.

The cost of the project is Rs2,412.64 crore. The share of the Centre, state government and NMC is 60%, 25% and 15%, respectively.

Title: Delhi Riots Latest News: Marauding mobs vent fury on schools too
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

DRP School

NEW DELHI: There were at least 300 students in Victoria Senior Secondary School near Chand Bagh when it came under attack on Monday around 12.30pm. The school is a CBSE examination centre, and the students were writing their Class XII exam when a hundred-strong crowd gathered outside, pelted stones and charged at the gate, lathis in hand.

“We managed to secure the main gates and our boundaries, but we had no way of sending the students home because they were candidates from other schools. It was only around 6pm that their parents arrived and they left from the back door,” said caretaker Parveen Sharma. Principal Nawaz Farooq Ahmad ensured everyone exited the premises safely before closing the school indefinitely.

When TOI visited the school on Thursday, the building was eerily silent. The windows were shattered, there was a burnt bus outside, its scorched skeleton an indication of the mob frenzy. Two cars stood charred within the school premises. Ironically, the last news update on the bulletin board read, “Pro- and anti-CAA protesters clash in northeast Delhi.”

The aftermath of the riots will most impact the students — who have no institutions to return to. Nearby, Arun Modern Public School, which shares it walls with a mosque that was burnt down, resembled a battleground. Its yellow walls were covered in soot, the air was thick with smoke and some parts of the building were still afire. A group of workers was demolishing a wall that had been declared unsafe.

According to school owner Brahm Kumar Sharma, “hundreds of people” came and burnt down the building around 5pm. “They vandalised the school and stole computers, water motors, bathroom fittings, everything. We estimate the damage at Rs 2-3 crore,” he despaired.

Cashier Neetu Chowdhury alleged that no help arrived till 9pm. “Police did not stop the horde and the fire tenders took five hours to get here,” she said. But her concern was more about the future of the students. “The school had 1,800 students. Where will they study during the time we will take to rebuild?” she asked, showing TOI a few admit cards of students who were slated to appear for their Class X board exams. “We urgently applied for duplicate admit cards for students who had not collected their papers,” she added.

Neeraj, a Class X student, was at his blackened school on Thursday. “I don’t know where I will study now,” the youngster said.

A student from the madrassa attached to the mosque had a similar story. Mohammad Anas, 11, recounted, “We were praying inside when we heard the mob. Our mufti hid us inside a room. Thankfully the rioters were unable to break down the gates.” He said local residents rescued them and took them home.

Further down the lanes, the damage was more severe. Two adjacent schools on the Shiv Vihar-Karawal Nagar stretch — Rajdhani Senior Secondary and DRP —faced the fury of arsonists on Tuesday. While nearly 1,000 students studied in the former, there were 400 in the latter. Their walls had caved in, and there was ashen remains of what once were desks, chairs and blackboards.

Manoj Kalouni, caretaker of Rajdhani School for 18 years, his wife Sangeeta and their two children lived in a room on the premises. “After noon, parents began taking the students away because of rioters on the road. By 1pm, all the students and staff had left. But some 500 people forced their way in around 4pm and went on a rampage. We managed to stay hidden on the terrace and then fled to a school nearby to save our lives,” said Kalouni. The family plans to return to their home state of Uttarakhand for good.

Kalouni’s friend, who works in the other school, provided him shelter for nearly 60 hours, though there was no food. “The children were hungry but we couldn’t do anything. Security forces finally came to our rescue,” said Kalouni, who lost all his belongings. He doesn’t even have money to return to his village. His only hope is school principal Faisal Farooque. “I hope he gives me some money so I can leave Delhi,” the shaken man said.

As students and staff await the return to classrooms, a hand-made poster on one of the school walls relayed an important message. “Education is the ability to listen to everything without losing your temper or self-confidence,” it says. Pity such messages are lost when the students reach adulthood.

Title: After Coal India nudge, Goa forms panels
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Panaji: The state government on Thursday constituted a selection committee besides a monitoring committee to oversee the utilisation of the Dongeri Tal-II coal block in Madhya Pradesh.

The two committees include members of local industry bodies. The selection committee, which is headed by the secretary of industries Nila Mohanan, will choose the consultant, which will assist Goa Industrial Development Corporation (GIDC) in efficient exploitation of the coal block.

Under-secretary A S Mahatme said the selection committee will devise a standard procedure for selection of the consultant based on their technical qualification and financial offers.

The five-member committee also comprises additional finance secretary, under-secretary for industries, director of industries, trade & commerce department and managing director for GIDC.

In the notification, Mahatme also said the government has constituted a monitoring committee to oversee the development the coal block allotted to GIDC. The committee is headed by industries minister Vishwajit Rane and includes chairman of GIDC Glen nTiclo.

Mohanan along with president of Goa State Industries Association Damodar Kochar, president of Goa Chamber of Commerce and Industry Manoj Caculo and a few others are also on the nine-member committee.

The monitoring committee will frame the broad guidelines on how the coal block is utilised by GIDC, said government sources. Goa is running out of time to complete the formalities for utilization of the coal block and Coal India limited (CIL) has already served an ultimatum to GIDC.

Title: PM was ‘soft’ in handling Delhi protests: BJP leader
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Pon Radhakrishnan

CHENNAI: Former BJP state president Pon Radhakrishnan on Thursday said Prime Minister Narendra Modi was “soft” in handling the Delhi protests , which spiralled out of control on Sunday evening and continued for two days, claiming 27 lives.

“It ( Delhi violence ) should have been handled with an iron hand but he did not do it. It should be done if such a situation arises. But the PM has approached the issue carefully and cautiously and handled it softly,” said the former Union minister, reacting to actor Rajinikanth’s statement that failure of intelligence led to the violence and that it should have been “put down with an iron hand”.

Indirectly hitting out at the actor, Radhakrishnan said, “People should not deliver cinematic dialogues without understanding the problem and the issues in Delhi”. He, however, admitted that there was intelligence failure and failure on the part of the Centre following which several officers have been shunted out.

Several parts of the country are inaccessible to law enforcing agencies due to entry restrictions, said Radhakrishnan. “Muslim community elders have also expressed concern over such issues on several occasions. This resulted in such incidents (the Delhi violence),” he said, adding that the Tamil Nadu and other state governments should ensure that their states were accessible, particularly for police and other agencies,” he said.

The former minister said no more opportunity should be given for creation of another Pakistan. “If it happens, it will be disastrous,” he said. “Whoever it may be, action should be taken. There is no difference between pro and anti-CAA protesters. The Modi government will take appropriate action against them,” he said, responding to questions on BJP leaders and ministers making provocative statements.

Responding to S Ramadoss tweets urging the TN government to pass resolution against NRC, he cautioned political parties against falling prey to “divisive politics” of the DMK and its allies.

Title: Indian Oil invests Rs 6,690cr in state
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Kolkata: Maharatna Oil PSU Indian Oil is investing Rs 6,690 crore in West Bengal that includes its Rs 3,000crore funding in Haldia Refinery for making it BS VI-compliant. IOC executive director Pritish Bharat pointed out that besides BS VI, it is investing in pipelines, modernisation of retail outlets along with others. The PSU oil-marketing company is investing Rs 341 crore in Paradip-Somnathpur-Haldia pipeline project and another Rs 1,199 crore for augmentation of Paradip-Haldia-Durgapur pipeline.

All the pipeline projects are likely to be completed by October 21, though some projects would be operational before that, the IOC ED said.

Earlier, Bharat said that it has already started supplying BS VI-compliant products to retail outlets so that it can gradually mix with BS IV and by April 1, the entire fleet of 1,233 retail outlets of IOC in the state is refilled with BS VI. According to him, 26 new retail outlets and 43 rural outlets will be commissioned this year in West Bengal.

Elaborating future plans, he added that around 300 retail outlets will be coming up in West Bengal, Sikkim and Andaman in the next one-two years. “As on January 2020, 21.3% of overall transactions at retail outlets are digital transactions in the state,” he added.

Besides BS-VI and pipeline, IOC has also embarked on green fuel initiative in the state by converting waste into bio gas. “We have taken up compressed bio gas project where biodegradable waste will be compressed into methane gas which later will be refined further to CNG. IOC has tied up with Dharti Energy and Divya Auto for this. We shall have a buy-back arrangement with them. Our company has already set up a pilot project for this in Tamil Nadu,” he added.

According to him, it would supply CNG initially to two-three retail outlets from these projects. The JV of IOC and Adani, IndianOil-Adani Gas, has won the city gas distribution rights for East and West Burdwan. IOC on its own has also applied for city gas distributions rights for 11 districts in Bengal.

Title: Delhi Riots: How police managed to wrest back control over law and order in northeast Delhi
Content:
Delhi Police regained control of the law and order situation in less than 24 hours.

Police patrolling in northeast Delhi after communal riots on February 27

Nearly 7,000 central paramilitary forces were deployed in the affected areas of northeast district since February 24.

NEW DELHI: Till Tuesday afternoon, there were no signs that the violence in northeast Delhi would come to an end any time soon. Police had evidently failed in stopping the rioters from wreaking havoc and the morale of the force seemed to have hit rock bottom with severe criticism coming from all sides. However, Delhi Police bounced back and regained control of the law and order situation in less than 24 hours.While National Security Advisor Ajit Doval was tasked to ensure that peace returns to the region, special DG (CRPF) SN Shrivastava was given the order to join as the law and order chief immediately. The fresh guard remained on the ground for over 20 hours to fulfil the purpose.The first step was a coordinated and adequate deployment. Three special commissioners, six joint commissioners, an additional commissioner, 22 DCPs, 20 ACPs, 60 inspectors, 1,200 male and 200 women personnel and 60 companies of outside forces were stationed at crucial locations. Union home minister Amit Shah reviewed the situation every two hours.Delhi violence: Live updatesIn the intervening night of Tuesday and Wednesday, the changed attitude of police was clearly visible. The policemen were proactive in dispersing fresh gatherings, which were being attempted by different groups claiming to be protesting against Citizenship Amendment Act.One such group assembled at Khureji and refused to budge on Wednesday noon, but police were quick to use force and move them away. Six of the organisers, including Khalid and Ishrat Jahan, were arrested for allegedly mobilising the crowd and blocking the road.Nearly 7,000 central paramilitary forces were deployed in the affected areas of Northeast district since February 24. As violence stopped, police on Wednesday started holding peace committee meetings to normalise the situation and improve inter-community harmony. In the last two days, nearly 330 such meetings were organised in various districts and they would continue till the situation normalises.East Delhi Municipal Corporation initiated steps to clean the streets and repair damaged public properties in riot-affected areas. Two helplines — 22829334 and 22829335 — were set up for round-the-clock assistance.“Apart from this, meetings with residents’ welfare associations and market welfare associations were also convened in several areas. They were attended by different sections of the society, including civil society groups and representatives of Congress, BJP, AAP and other political parties,” an MHA official said.The home ministry has requested citizens to not lay credence to any rumour. Shah appealed to citizens not to “fall prey to evil designs of miscreants and groups interested in precipitating communal tension”.“Only 12 police stations out of 203 in Delhi (about 4.2% of the geographical area) have been affected by the riots. Normalcy and communal harmony has prevailed elsewhere in the capital. Delhi Police is mandated and obligated to provide security to all sections of society, irrespective of caste and religion,” MHA said.In Video: Special CP holds flag march in violence hit areas in North-East Delhi

Title: Northeast Delhi Clashes: Petrol bombs, stones and bricks seen on terrace of his building
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

In a video, rioters were seen allegedly on the terrace of the councillor's house

NEW DELHI: In the maze of the Chand Bagh neighbourhood, a four-storey building belonging to AAP councillor Tahir Hussain stands out — it’s the tallest structure there. In the past three days, however, it has also become the most talked about since the family of the IB official, Ankit Sharma, whose body was found in a drain, has alleged Hussain’s hand in his death. Several locals have alleged that rioters had used it to carry out attacks in the communal violence that rocked north-east Delhi. A video showing several hundred people throwing stones and petrol bombs from atop the building had gone viral on social media.

When TOI visited the site on Thursday, cops were stationed outside the building but journalists were being let in. While several locals confirmed that the building belonged to Hussain, they said it wasn’t his residence. His house, in fact, is situated just behind the building.

Hussain, 43, represents Nehru Vihar (Ward No 59) under the east corporation. He was elected in 2017 and, according to his affidavit, he does not have any criminal cases against him. He belongs to UP but has been living in Delhi for over 25 years and has a business of interior designing.

On the terrace, one spotted a stockpile of petrol bombs and sharp pieces of stones kept in sacks that could have inflicted serious damage if dropped on people from that height. There were at least three crates, two of them empty, while one had petrol bombs made from cold drink bottles. Piles of rubble with pieces of bricks and cement were scattered on the terrace.

The building was completely bare and either served as a warehouse or a manufacturing unit once. The first floor of the building was labelled “production area”. A room with paint cans was labelled “paint booth”. A small store room with spare computer parts seemed to have been vandalised. The second floor seemed to be under construction without any furniture or fixture and the third floor, too, looked similar.

From the terrace, it was clear that the two buildings adjacent to it were completely charred. These seemed to be shops which were burnt beyond recognition and it was unclear what they had sold when they functioned. The roof of the shop on the right had caved in, probably because of a fire. TOI could not enter these shops because the shutters were down.

Locals TOI spoke to gave contradictory statements. Members of one community alleged that the attack from Hussain’s building was “pre-planned” and the ammunition had been stored there before the riots broke. “We have recorded everything. He sheltered the people who instigated the violence and killed Ankit Sharma,” alleged one of them.

Members from the other community, however, backed Hussain. They did concede that the house was used by a mob but the people came from outside, they said. “Hussain had to be rescued from his house because his house was under attack. It was then that a mob captured his house and used it to wreak havoc in the area,” said a man.

Title: Re-inquiry into beach scam: Govt
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Panaji: The state government has informed the Goa Lokayukta that the anti-corruption branch (ACB) of directorate of vigilance is conducting a re-inquiry into the alleged multi-crore beach cleaning scam.

“Based on directions of the Goa Lokayukta, conducting re-enquiry by ACB Panaji into the allegations on the award of beach cleaning tender by department of tourism, government of Goa is in progress,” director of tourism Menino D’ Souza said in the rejoined filed before the Lokayukta.

When contacted, a senior ACB officer said that they have not initiated any inquiry in the alleged beach cleaning scam yet but if they receive the file they will conduct one.

Social activist Inacio Domnic Pereira had filed a complaint before the Lokaykta with regards to the beach cleaning.

On December 2, 2017, the state government had accepted the Goa Lokayukta’s recommendation in the alleged scam to reopen the investigation through ACB. Earlier, the Lokayukta had found former tourism minister Dilip Parulekar guilty in the scam. The ACB had investigated and closed the case.

Title: Amit Shah to address zonal council meet, pro-CAA rally on first trip to Odisha as home minister
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Amit Shah

BHUBANESWAR: All eyes will be trained on Amit Shah ’s visit here on Friday when he will first chair an Eastern Zonal Council meeting and then address a pro-CAA rally.

Shah’s rally — his first since the death of at least 34 people in New Delhi over CAA earlier this week — is likely to draw more than a lakh BJP supporters. This will also be Shah’s first visit to Odisha as home minister.

The state BJP, which got a new president in Samir Mohanty last month, said the rally was part of the saffron party’s all-India campaign to combat ‘misinformation’ on CAA. “There is great enthusiasm among the people for CAA in spite of efforts by Congress to mislead the citizens. More than one lakh people will attend the programme,” Mohanty said.

What Shah chooses to say about CAA would be keenly watched given the tense situation in the national capital, BJP insiders said. They also said all party office-bearers, MPs and MLAs in the coastal districts of Odisha had been asked to ensure an impressive turnout at Shah’s rally.

Booth-level workers from across the state have been asked to attend the rally at Janata Maidan, which will also be addressed by Union ministers Dharmendra Pradhan and Pratap Sarangi. Roads leading to the site have been decorated with banners and posters publicising the event. Vans fitted with loudspeakers, too, have been deployed in and around Bhubaneswar to ensure a good turnout.

The unrest over the contentious citizenship act may also cast a shadow on the zonal council meeting, which will be attended by a chief minister who have vocally opposed CAA (Mamata Banerjee) and two who have supported it in Parliament (Nitish Kumar and Naveen Patnaik). Jharkhand chief minister Hemant Soren will not be attending the meeting.

The BJD and Congress have both termed Shah’s rally as ‘unnecessary’ and ‘ill-timed’. “There is no need for awareness on CAA in Odisha. The BJP should have reached out to people across the country before enacting CAA. It would have been better if the Centre had created public awareness before implementing it. I don’t see what the rally will achieve,” BJD spokesperson and MLA Pratap Keshari Deb said.

Senior Congress leader and MLA Suresh Chandra Rourtay added, “The rally is a farce and a waste of public money. What will Shah explain when Delhi is burning?”

On Saturday, the second day of his two-day visit to the state, Shah is scheduled to offer prayers at the Jagannath Temple in Puri and the Lingaraj Temple here.

Title: Dismissal from service: PSI Gudlar gets 15 days to reply
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Panaji: Goa police issued a memorandum to police sub-inspector Sunil Gudlar asking him why he should not be dismissed from service due to his official misconduct. Gudlar was arrested in 2011 in the police-politician-drug mafia nexus case.

He was later released on bail.

Currently, Gudlar, who is attached to Goa Reserve Police, Altinho, Panaji, and is temporarily deputed to special branch at police headquarters, Panaji.

Police conducted a departmental enquiry (DE) against Gudlar and the report “partially proved” his official misconduct, a senior police officer said.

“On a careful consideration of the report, I don’t agree with the findings of the report due to the reasons indicated in the disagreement note. I propose to dismiss PSI Sunil Gudlar from service,” deputy inspector general of police (DIG) Rajesh Kumar said.

Gudlar can make a representation about the proposed penalty within 15 days, he said. “Any representation he makes will be considered,” Kumar said.

After submitting his written reply, Gudlar can also meet me and present his defence with documents to support his statements, the DIG said.

“If he does not use this opportunity of personal hearing, I will proceed to decide on the case based on his written reply and other evidence in the enquiry files,” Kumar said.

Earlier, CBI had arrested Gudlar after he was suspended by Goa police in the nexus case. Gudlar, earlier posted with ANC as PSI, came under the spotlight after the arrest of alleged Israeli drug dealer David Driham alias Dudu.

Thereafter, the former ANC PSI was caught in a spy-camera video clipping allegedly selling drugs, demanding a bribe from Dudu’s sister and girlfriend, and threatening to plant charas on person if he failed to pay the amount.

Dudu’s sister Ayala later said she conducted the sting operation to unravel the police-drug mafia nexus after her brother’s arrest for dealing in drugs in Goa in 2009. CBI had filed the chargesheet in the case.

Title: CIL liquidates over 82% of arrears to non-power clients
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Kolkata: Coal India ( CIL ) has liquidated over 82% of its arrears rakes to non-power sector consumers during the ongoing fiscal. These backlog rakes pertain to 2017-18 and 2018-19.

According to officials, muted demand for the dry fuel from the thermal power stations and comfortable stock position at their end provided a window for the Maharatna coal mining behemoth to bring down the accumulated arrear rakes of the non-power sector consumers.

The backlog arrears for this sector which stood close to 5,140 rakes at the beginning of 2019-20 were cleared by 4230 rakes. “By the end of FY 20, we will be able to clear the rest 900-odd arrear rakes,” stated an official of the company. CIL’s supplies to non-power sector registered a growth of 4.4% at 95.45 million tonnes (MTs) during April-January 2020 compared to 91.47 MTs same period year ago.

The combined coal stock at CIL’s own pitheads and at coal linkage based thermal power plants of the country stands at a comfortable 78.25 MTs. Coal stock at power plants increased to a decade high of 36.36 mts (as of February 24), an average 20 day stock, just two days short of CEA mandated 22-day stock.

Title: Fraud case: 11 Visionaries officials booked
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The economic offences cell (EOC) of Goa police on Thursday booked the chairperson, vice-chairman and nine other functionaries of Visionaries Urban Cooperative Credit Society, Loutolim , for allegedly cheating.

The EOC registered a first information report (FIR) under Sections 403 (Dishonest misappropriation of property), 409 (Criminal breach of trust by public servant, or by banker, merchant or agent) and 420 (cheating) against Gracy Vaz, Santano Rodrigues and others.

In his complaint, Emiliano B Mascarenhas, certified auditor, co-op societies, South, said that the society was running in a loss for many years and during 2007-2008 and 2008-2009 there was mismanagement, misutilisation of funds, frauds committed by past managements. “The accumulation of losses of the past years have affected the financial position and working of the society in subsequent years due to non-receipt of any income out of misappropriated funds, frauds, etc. which amount is reflected in the balance sheet of the society every year without monetary gain to the society and contributing for the loss,” Mascarenhas said.

Title: Delhi violence: At hospitals, some look for cure, others closure
Content:
Paramilitary personnel keep vigil in inner lanes of Shiv Vihar on Thursday

NEW DELHI: “When we heard the mob attacking the houses nearby, we hid the men in our family under clothes and inside a cupboard. But the rioters barged in and dragged my brother out though he kept pleading, ‘Main aapka bhai hoon’. After two days of searching for him, we finally came to Guru Teg Bahadur Hospital where we located his body,” wept Farheen, sister of Mohammed Musharraf.Farheen’s household is tragically fortunate to have found Chand Bagh resident Musharraf’s body on Thursday morning. There are many families that are still to locate loved ones missing since violence broke out in northeast Delhi on Sunday and for them there is no sense of closure yet. As more bodies are being found in the smouldering debris of the communal frenzy, the toll climbed to 38 on Thursday.Between big sobs, Farheen narrated, “We were actually preparing to leave the area at the first opportune time, but even as we prepared to go, a mob attacked our neighbourhood. Ours was among the first houses to be attacked. Hindu families occupied the first two floors and the horde skipped them while rushing to our second floor house. I had hidden my husband under a pile of clothes and my brother inside a cupboard. My husband had a miraculous escape, but my brother was discovered, dragged out and beaten in the road before being pushed into a car and taken away. We cried for help but it was all futile.”When the situation calmed down a bit, the family ventured out to trace the 35-year-old Musharraf. “We went to many places. Then an acquaintance of Musharraf informed us of hearing that he had been thrown into the Chand Bagh drain. We went there but didn’t find anything. Today morning, we came to GTB Hospital and finally found him — dead,” Farheen said.Waris Ali Khan had also been searching for his nephew, Mohseen, 24, since Tuesday. “Mohseen owns a generator shop in Noida. Around 5pm that day, he had returned home to Bhajanpura, where he also had to meet someone for a work-related appointment,” Khan said. “Near the temple, a mob surrounded his car and heckled him. He managed to call a friend who was on speed dial on his phone, but before anyone could rush to his aid, the rabble thrashed him and threw him into a drain. His body must have been fished out and brought to GTB Hospital.”Rajiv Saini, a resident of Brahmpuri, was lying on the floor at the hospital awaiting news of the condition of his brother, Naresh, 32. “He is lying in the ICU for the last three days. He was shot in the chest outside our house. He has a five-year-old daughter and a three-year-old son,” Saini mumbled.Waiting for the post-mortem of his sibling to be carried out, Muzammil Khan described Tuesday as the worst day of their life for the family. “We live in Kabir Nagar,” Muzammil said. “When things quietened down after the violence, my brother Mudassir went out to buy food. He never returned. He was shot in his head. His wife and six daughters are left without a bread winner.”GTB hospital director Dr Sunil Kumar said 215 riot victims had been treated there since Monday. “However, at the moment, only 51 patients are receiving treatment in the various departments. The rest have been discharged,” he said. Dr Kumar added that only one of the admitted patients is in a critical state. “In all, we have confirmed 33 deaths. Of these, 22 were already dead when brought to the hospital, while nine died after admission,” the hospital director said.Also at the hospital were those recovering from the murderous attacks. Ashfaq, one of them, said, “I was hit by a rod when trying to save my brother from the mob. Thank God, I am not dead like so many others in my neighbourhood. I think we will shift back to our hometown of Patna.”In Video: Delhi violence: CM Kejriwal visits GTB Hospital, appeals for peace

Title: ‘Third pole’ could shed light on climate change: Scientist
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

While Earth has only two poles in terms of environmental conditions, the Himalayas have glaciers and many of t... Read More

PANAJI: The once permanently frozen parts of our planet are changing, prompting scientists to try and understand the mechanism behind those changes. Canadian geologist David Scott, who is currently in Goa to collaborate with the National Centre for Polar and Ocean Research (NCPOR), Vasco, said it is becoming increasingly important to study the topography of the world’s “third pole”, the Himalayas .

Scott is president and CEO of Polar Knowledge Canada, a federal agency aimed at strengthening Canadian leadership in polar science and technology. He said a study of the topography of the Himalayas, along with that of the North and South Poles, is crucial to better understand what future climate and weather conditions would look like.

The polar research expert explained that while Earth has only two poles in terms of environmental conditions, the Himalayas have glaciers and many of the same characteristics as both the polar regions.

“It’s an important component to study all of the cold regions on the planet – north, south and the middle where the glaciers of the Himalayas are suffering the same response to a warming climate. The reaction to those changes is also important,” Scott said.

Aspects like the quantity of ice being lost, the amount of water running off and the influence that these have on the changing climate need to be studied, he said, especially since they may be connected to the monsoon.

“The monsoon is changing, so there are implications on agriculture and food production. There are very important questions that can be answered by studying things in the Himalayas and the North and South Poles to fully understand how the global system is changing and predict what it might look like in the future,” he said.

Scott said some Canadian researchers who specialise in the study of glaciers may already be working in small ways in the Himalayas.

“But as NCPOR expands its capacity, there will be newer opportunities for others who could come and work with Indian scientists in that region,” he said, even as he clarified that Polar Knowledge Canada is not yet equipped to work on the glaciers.

Title: City continues to battle dysfunctional streetlights
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Aurangabad: The issue of installation and maintenance of streetlights in the city, which has been dominating almost every general body meeting, continues to haunt most corporators even as their term nears completion.

Meanwhile, the civic administration has been failing to meet its deadlines on repair and maintenance of LED as well as old streetlights.

As many as 18 corporators from across parties had launched an attack on the civic administration for failing to take action against their complaints on dysfunctional streetlights . The corporators said that AMC official KD Deshmukh, who is in-charge of the electricity department, does not respond to their calls.

Members, including Manisha Munde, Salima Beghum Khajoddin, Kirti Shinde, Seema Chakranarayan and Jyoti Nade, said that every time the officer is asked about the non-functioning streetlights, he takes a note of the complaints and maintains that the issue will be resolved in eight to ten days; however, the issue does not get sorted on the ground. “It’s been five years but the issues have not been resolved,” Nade said.

BJP member Madhuri Adwant-Deshmukh raised the issue of illumination of VD Savarkar’s statue in the Samarth Nagar area. She said that the lights put up at the statue do not work, adding that several complaints about dysfunctional lights have been made to the administration, but in vain. Mayor Nandkumar Ghodele directed the electricity department to ensure that the lights are in working condition.

After KD Deshmukh failed to give convincing response to the complaints of the members, mayor asked deputy municipal commissioner Sumant More to call official AB Deshmukh of the municipal corporation and demand an explanation in this regard.

Incidentally, the AMC had given the contract of installing 40,000 LED streetlights in the city to a private agency. According to PR Bansode of the agency, 36,000 lights have already been installed. The work on installation of the remaining 4,000 streetlights is underway. He said that every month the agency takes in writing about any complaints related to streetlights from the corporators. “None of the lights installed so far are in poor condition or await repair. The complaints that come are only for old lights which are not included in our contract,” he said.

Title: BJP, Sena race to take credit for state aid for road wok
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

CLEARED SKHER

Aurangabad: Former allies, BJP and Shiv Sena corporators in Aurangabad , vied to take credit for the state government’s decision to give financial assistance for the construction of 23 roads in city. The state government recently approved Rs 152 crore for construction of the roads.

Three agencies are expected to carry out the work — Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC), Maharahstra State Road Development Corporation (MSRDC) and Maharashtra Industrial Development Corporation (MIDC). The three agencies have issued issued tenders over the past couple of days for the construction of the 23 roads.

During the general body meeting on Thursday, Deputy mayor Rajendra Janjal of Shiv Sena brought a proposal to felicitate chief minister Uddhav Thackeray and his cabinet for approving the road project for the city. “This is the highest amount sanctioned by the state government for the road project in the city,” he said.

At that point, BJP corporators rebuffed the Sena members, saying that it was their party-led government that had given a nod for the project. BJP member Raju Shinde said the BJP government too had approved and provided funds for different road projects for the city.

At the same time, BJP’s Raj Wankhede expressed discontent over the road selection. He questioned the criteria on which the roads were selected. Soon after the list of roads, that are either to be concreted or tarred, was released objections were raised on the road selection.

Shinde asked the mayor why the entire amount was not approved. Mayor Nandkumar Ghodele said the AMC had prepared and sent a list of 103 roads with an estimated cost of Rs 462 crore for the concreting and tarring. “A panel comprising the chief minister and district guardian minister took a call on the selection of roads. However, this is only the first phase of the road project,” Ghodele said.

When Shinde asked whether another set of roads would be approved before the model code of conduct for civic elections comes into force, Ghodele said that it is possible that more roads could be approved during the ongoing session of the state assembly.
