Title: Don’t glorify violence: Press Council of India to media
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Situation of Shiv Vihar a day after of northeast Delhi riot (File photo)

NEW DELHI: The Press Council of India on Thursday advised media to not “glorify” violence and desist from publishing or telecasting pictures that are likely to cause “revulsion”. Reminding journalists of their “special” responsibility, PCI said, “Their writings are not a mere reflection of their own feelings but help to large extent in moulding the feelings and sentiments of the society at large. It is therefore, of utmost importance that they use their pen with circumspection and restraint.”

Also on Thursday, a delegation of journalists represented by the Press Club of India, Indian Women’s Press Corps and the Press Association called on Union I&B minister Prakash Javadekar and sought his cooperation and intervention in containing the growing atrocities on mediapersons while discharging their duties, particularly as witnessed during the ongoing violence in Delhi.

Javadekar agreed that it is important that media is permitted to do its work in an atmosphere conducive to accurate and in-depth reporting no matter and assured the delegation that he will take up the issue with the concerned authorities to ensure safety and security of journalists.

The delegation highlighted the brutal and rough treatment unleashed by the police in the recent rioting in north-east Delhi where journalists were shot at, heckled and even attacked by batons and rods and the police was found wanting in rendering assistance.

Title: Govt to enforce newMV Act from Sunday
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Bhubaneswar: The state government will enforce the amended Motor Vehicles (MV) Act strictly from March 1, six months after it was introduced. The government had refrained from enforcing the Act in letter and spirit for the past six months to give vehicle owners enough time to get their papers in order.

“We will start enforcement drive against traffic rule violators from March 1. On September 9, 2019, chief minister Naveen Patnaik had announced the first of the two three-month relaxations in the enforcement of the act. The second relaxation was announced in November last year, keeping in mind the huge rush at regional transport offices (RTO),” transport minister Padmanabh Behera said.

Transport commissioner Sanjeeb Panda said enforcement activities would be carried out by the RTOs and police. He also said people had been given enough time to apply for learners’ licence (LL), driving licence (DL) and pollution under control (PUC) certificates.

“We conducted a number of awareness campaigns among the people about the new Act. We urged them repeatedly to get their documents ready. Extra counters were opened at RTOs to handle the rush of applicants and facilitate smooth delivery of services. A record number of licences — 11,38,475 LLs and 3,66,609 DLs — were issued between September 2019 and February 2020. In 2018, only 3.5 lakh LLs and 2.3 DLs had been issued,” Panda said.

The transport department clarified that leniency was shown only to certain kinds of offences , in the past six months. “There was no leniency in addressing cases of drink driving, dangerous driving, overspeeding, driving against flow of traffic, using mobile while driving, triple riding on two-wheeler, overloading, jumping of red light, not wearing helmet and seat belt,” Panda said.

The transport department also said accident fatalities had come down by 12 per cent in September, 18.7 per cent in October, 6.6 per cent in November and 26.9 per cent in December last year in comparison to the figures for the corresponding periods in 2018.

Title: 2 horses infected with glanders given euthanasia
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Aurangabad: The civic administration’s animal husbandry department euthanised two horses on Thursday after they were found infected with glanders—a contagious disease which can infect and cause death in humans. The decision was taken with the approval of the state animal husbandry department.

According to the dairy department of the animal husbandry and dairying, Government of India, glanders is a contagious and fatal disease of equines (horses, donkeys and mules) caused by the bacterium B. Mallei. The bacterium has been considered as a potential biological warfare or bio-terrorism agent as it can be highly fatal for humans, states the National Action Plan for Control and Eradication of Glanders in India, 2019.

AMC’s chief animal husbandry officer Bhagwat Naikwade said that two horses in the city’s Konkanwadi area were found infected with glanders. Based on the steps outlined in the Infectious Diseases Act, 2009, the horses were euthanized and buried at Padegaon around 10am on Thursday. “First, their blood samples were tested. After they tested positive for the bacteria, they were given a painless death and buried properly. The burial site was sprinkled with calcium carbonate for disinfection,” said Naikwade.

On Wednesday, mayor Nandkumar Ghodele held a meeting with the civic medical officers asking them to check for citizens showing any symptoms of the infection.

Naikwade said that the surveillance team of the state government was examining horses across the city with assistance from the civic body’s animal husbandry department. The AMC has a record of 86 horses in the city.

Title: State can deploy 20 health workers for each patient: Guv
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Hyderabad: Coming down heavily on the state health officials over increasing cases of tuberculosis, governor Tamilisai Soundararajan on Wednesday said that with the number of healthcare staff available at the disposal of the state, each tuberculosis patient can be attended by 20 health workers.

Taking note of a TOI report published on February 25 about sharp increase in tuberculosis cases in the city, the governor called an emergency meeting on Wednesday afternoon to take stock of the tuberculosis control measures being undertaken in the state.

The meeting was attended by officials from the state health department and GHMC’s epidemiology wing and people from Red Cross Society.

The governor told them to work in tandem and come up with a combined action plan and submit it at the earliest.

Expressing her intent to hold another review meeting soon, the governor directed the officials to visit slums to educate tuberculosis patients about nutrition plan essential for them and monitor each patient closely, including contact tracing.

“The governor said it is sad to note that tuberculosis continues to remain a killer disease in the society at a time when we boast of advancement in several areas. She said it is important to get rid of this malice within stipulated time and directed district medical officer Dr J Venkat and general secretary of TB association Dr Sudhir Prasad to formulate a strategic action plan to ensure that every tuberculosis patient has access to quality diagnosis, treatment and support,” read an official statement from the governor’s office.

Title: Airport, GMC inspected
Content: Panaji: Joint secretary, Union ministry of health and family welfare, Alok Saxena inspected arrangements of Coronavirus (Covid-19) at Dabolim airport on Thursday. Saxena was satisfied with the arrangements. He carried out the inspection along with Goa health secretary, Nila Mohanan, airport director Gagan Malik said. He also inspected the quarantine facility at Chicalim Cottage Hospital and Goa Medical College.A meeting was chaired by health minister Vishwajit Rane which was attended by Saxena and health officials.Meanwhile, a Covid-19 suspect was quarantined in GMC on Thursday.

Title: Don’t let the music play: Students dial cop hotline in Uttar Pradesh
Content:
Representative image

LUCKNOW: Class X student Wasim Ahmad was already dealing with grief as he had lost his grandmother a few days before his English exam. A night before, on February 20, as he tried to concentrate, deafening noise from DJ music hit him. His parents tried to intervene to stop the music in vain.Despite repeated requests, the organisers in neighbourhood, did not lower volume. It was then that Ahmad’s mother suggested to call UP 112. “Police came within three minutes and warned the neighbours of legal action in case the act was repeated,” said Ahmad.His case is not the only one.Likewise, Priyanshi Verma of Aliganj was annoyed by noise from a wedding celebration at a nearby lawn while preparing for her Hindi exam. Verma herself dialled UP 112 for assistance and received help.In a first-of-its kind service which began on February 15 and will continue till March 31, students preparing for board exams can directly call UP 112 to complain about noise pollution in their area. They can also post their complaints on the Facebook page or Twitter handle of UP 112.In just 10 days since the launch of the service, UP 112 has received as many as 5,000 complaints from students across the state. In Lucknow district , 770 calls of complaints relating to noise pollution have been received.ADG UP 112 Asim Arun said, “We are expecting more calls from students and will then analyse their nature.”He added that in Lucknow, police faced stiff resistance from those playing loudspeakers/ DJ music, causing noise. “In 35 complaints from different parts of the city, police had to intervene thrice for people to stop loud music . So far, no FIR was lodged in any of the cases,” he said. The officer also said that efforts to improve the service were on.

Title: Delhi riots: Ensure no one is denied treatment, say activists
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Security personnel deployed at Chand Bagh after riots in northeast Delhi on February 27

NEW DELHI: Public health groups have issued a statement expressing concern over the manner in which access to healthcare , including emergency medical treatment to the injured, was not being provided in the context of communal violence in Delhi.

Jan Swasthya Abhiyan and Medico Friends Circle in a statement said the police must not be allowed to stop patients and ambulances carrying them, doctors and drugs and medical supplies to any health facility. “Delays in this regard are absolutely unacceptable and are a violation of the fundamental rights of all people. It can have serious consequences,” said the statement.

Public health activists said it was deplorable that a midnight intervention by Delhi high court was necessary to address the situation at Al Hind hospital in Mustafabad, which had been cordoned off by the police and ambulances, patients and medical supplies were not allowed to reach the hospital for several hours. They pointed out that the hospital was providing treatment to persons injured in the violence over the past two days.

“The right to life is paramount and absolute, and all the state agencies, including medical professionals and the police have a constitutional obligation to ensure the preservation of the right,” said the statement, adding that the right to health is a fundamental human right and the state of Delhi ought to refrain from interfering directly or indirectly with the enjoyment of this right.

The public health groups have demanded the police and the state to ensure medical personnel were not only not prevented, but also protected in fulfilling their duties in providing healthcare and saving lives.

Title: Jaipur: Underground metro corridor to be made operational after CMRS inspection
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

The underground corridor is expected to be operational by March-end

JAIPUR: Jaipur Metro Rail Corporation ( JMRC ) is waiting for the Commissioner of Metro Rail Safety ( CMRS ) to conduct trials before throwing open the corridor to the public.

With the corporation having completed the civil work and is in the last lap of completing the remaining signalling work, a request has been sent to the CMRS to conduct the mandatory trials.

On Thursday, Congress chief whip Mahesh Joshi, MLA Ameen Kagzi along with the JMRC chairman-cum-managing director (CMD) Samit Sharma took stock of the project.

Sharma said, “Civil work of the project is completed and request has been forwarded to the CMRS to conduct trials. We have already conducted a few internal trials. During the inspection, the commissioner will check track parameters, tunnels and the stations, calibration of the trains and firefighting system among others,” he said.

It was informed that due to the coronavirus, installation of automated fare collection has been delayed as machines are imported from South Korea.

The underground corridor, which is expansion of Phase-I (Mansarovar to Chandpole), is expected to be operational by March 2020.

The length of entire Metro corridor Phase 1A and 1B is 12.07km. After BJP came to power, the then chief minister Vasundhara Raje inaugurated Jaipur Metro Rail Project (Phase 1A) in June 2015. This corridor was made operational in 2015 after spending Rs 2,023 crore.

“The project cost of underground Phase-IB project is Rs 1,126 crore. Out of which Rs 969 crore has been provided by the Asian Development Bank (ADB),” said a senior offical

Sources at JMRC said the Metro Phase 1B missed its June 2018 deadline due to various reasons including Supreme Court ban on sand mining, shifting of seven temples and design change of two underground stations. The JMRC officials believe there will be increase in ridership after the Phase 1B) is operational. In absence of Phase 1B, the performance of Phase-IA of Jaipur Metro was ‘poor’ as the average ridership dipped.

“At present, an average 20,000 passengers commute through Metro daily, as against the projected figure of one lakh. But Phase-II is expected to boost the numbers,” said a senior official.

Title: Kerala: Crime branch widens scope of missing cartridges probe
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The crime branch has widened the inquiry into the missing cartridges of the state police as the probe team has decided to interrogate officials up to the rank of assistant commandant , who is responsible for accepting the cartridges from the police chief store.

The crime branch team has decided to interrogate the current assistant commandant and former assistant commandants of special armed police (SAP), as it was found that the cartridges went missing during the custodianship of seven inspectors. The crime branch team has recorded the statements of the officials of the police chief store from where the cartridges are distributed. The probe team also examined the records at the police chief store.

In the SAP, the crime branch team found that during 2012-13 alone, as many as 3,624 cartridges went missing. It is in this context that the crime branch team decided to interrogate all the assistant commandants of various periods in the last 22 years.

The crime branch team had, on Wednesday, arrested a sub-inspector of police who was the quarter master in the SAP after ascertaining the officer’s role in replacing the missing cartridges with forged ones. Crime branch sources said that though he was among the 11 lower ranking officers against whom the case was originally registered, his role was evident as he was found to have committed forgery. “The probe will go beyond these 11 lower ranking officers, as they are only immediately responsible for handling the cartridges. But the responsibility of maintaining the cartridges goes to the higher officers as well,” a top crime branch source said.

Meanwhile, a section of the officers is unhappy with the crime branch action of arresting a sub-inspector on criminal charges. “There is a section who feels that only departmental responsibility should have been fixed on the official and not criminal charges. But forging cartridges is not a matter to be reduced to a departmental inquiry alone, it is a criminal offence,” sources added.

Title: Plan to supply Harsul Lake’s water shelved
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Aurangabad: The Aurangabad Municipal Corporation’s (AMC) decision to supply water from Harsul Lake to around 16 wards near the Delhi Gate has hit a roadblock after several local corporators raised objections in Thursday’s general body meeting.

The corporators argued that the decision would exhaust water in the lake, causing water shortage to those residing in no-pipeline areas of the city.

According to AMC’s water works department, the capacity of existing water works scheme pumping water from Jayakwadi Dam has reduced to a dismal 135 million litres per day (MLD). The civic administration maintains that this water is not enough to meet the needs of the city. Subsequently, it supplies water to the residents once in six to seven days.

In the wake of limitations of water pumping infrastructure, the civic administration had decided to use Harsul Lake’s water instead of Jayakwadi water to quench the thirst of 15 to 16 wards near the Delhi Gate area. However, the move did not go well with corporators Bansilal Jadhav (Bhagatsingnagar), Rupchand Waghmare (Ekta Nagar), Jyoti Abhang (Chetna Nagar), Raj Wankhede (Wankhede Nagar) and Sitaram Sure (Surewadi), who objected to the decision.

Abhang said that the lake did not have enough water last year; however, this year, due to sufficient rainfall, the lake has water reserve. “Many areas around the lake have not been connected to the piped water supply network of the civic body. The residents in these areas depend on borewells to meet their water requirement. Water in the Harsul Lake ensures that the groundwater levels are recharged,” she said.

Rupchand Waghmare said that if lake from the water is distributed to the wards, the groundwater will get dried up.

When asked, executive engineer Kiran Dhande, who is heading the water works department, told the general body that lake can supply 95 MLD water until May. Sure said that the water supply will hardly last for 15 days to a month.

Considering the opposition of the members, the mayor issued a ruling that the plan to use Harsul Lake’s water for the said wards of the city be shelved.

Title: Man injured at rly stn dies in hosp
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Hyderabad: A man, who was shifted to Gandhi Hospital after he sustained injuries at Secunderabad Railway Station, died while undergoing treatment on Wednesday. The victim is suspected to be around 60-year-old and was shifted to the hospital a couple of days ago. A case of suspicious death was registered. TNN

Title: NMC plans redevelopment of gardens on different themes
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Nagpur: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) has planned redevelopment of gardens on different themes. It will develop gardens into tourism spots and give them different looks across the city.

Mayor Sandip Joshi has directed NMC officials to redevelop gardens on different themes. As a corporator, he had planted saplings in his ward with different themes. Considering the suggestions that he received during his public outreach programmes, Joshi has directed the officials to also provide a green gym, public toilets, drinking water, sitting arrangements, streetlights and yoga sheds at all gardens.

Accordingly, municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe has directed officials to implement theme-based gardens’ redevelopment immediately.

The Dayanand Park, approved by corporator Virendra Kukreja during his tenure as standing committee chairman at Jaripatka in North Nagpur, will be developed as an adventure park. It is a new garden. Sky walk, children’s play area, a lawn, badam and bakul trees are the salient features of the garden.

The Lata Mangeshkar garden in East Nagpur will be transformed into a butterfly garden. Over here, saplings which attract butterflies will be planted.

The Mahatma Gandhi garden at Hanuman Nagar in South Nagpur will be redeveloped as a fragnance garden with saplings of mogra, madhumalti, parijat, kunda, jai, ratrani and sonchafa.

The Trishatabdi garden in Nandanwan, Namdeo Nagar garden at Shanti Nagar in East Nagpur and the Jagruti Colony garden off Katol Road will be converted into flower gardens. Already, the Ambedkar-Bharat Mata garden is being developed as a rose garden.

Title: 19-yr-old housewife goes missing
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Hyderabad: A 19-year-old housewife went missing after she left her house without informing anyone and did not return. The woman has been identified as Lakkineni Kavitha, a resident of Bachupally. She left the house a week ago. After failing to trace the woman, her husband filed a missing case. TNN

Title: Justice S Muralidhar’s transfer routine: Central government
Content:
Justice S Muralidhar

NEW DELHI: The central government on Thursday strongly defended notification of Justice S Muralidhar’s transfer from Delhi high court to Punjab and Haryana high court, and criticised the opposition for “politicising” a routine transfer recommended by the Supreme Court collegium.“Transfer of Justice Muralidhar was done pursuant to the recommendation dated February 12 of the Supreme Court collegium headed by the Chief Justice of India. While transferring the judge, consent of the judge is taken. The well-settled process has been followed,” Union law minister Ravi Shankar Prasad said.“By politicising a routine transfer, Congress has yet again displayed its scant regard for the judiciary,” he added.The notification of Justice Muralidhar’s transfer to Punjab and Haryana high court came late on Wednesday evening, interestingly on a day when he had taken up the matter of communal riots in Delhi for adjudication and sharply pulled up Delhi Police for inaction and failure to register FIRs against politicians for hate speeches.Congress linked Justice Muralidhar’s transfer to his strictures against Delhi Police and alleged that it had exposed “intimidation and vendetta politics” of the BJP government. Congress’s Rahul Gandhi also invoked Mumbai judge B H Loya whose death while hearing the Sohrabuddin encounter case triggered a controversy.Congress general secretary Priyanka Gandhi tweeted, “The midnight transfer of Justice Muralidhar isn’t shocking given the current dispensation, but it is certainly sad and shameful.” Rahul tweeted, “Remembering the brave judge Loya, who wasn’t transferred.”Justice Muralidhar’s bench had pulled up Delhi Police over its failure to register FIRs for alleged hate speeches by BJP’s Anurag Thakur, Parvesh Verma and Kapil Mishra. It had expressed “anguish” and asked the police commissioner to take a “conscious decision” on it by Thursday observing “we do not want the city to witness another 1984 riots”.Justice Muralidhar, being the senior-most judge available on Tuesday night, had also conducted a late night hearing at his residence to ensure victims in a hospital in northeast Delhi got safe passage and treatment in better hospitals. He had asked the police to escort ambulances and ferry them to Delhi government hospitals.Along with Justice Muralidhar, the government also notified the transfer of two other high court judges recommended by the collegium — Justice Ranjit Vasantrao More from Bombay HC to Meghalaya HC and Justice Ravi Vijaykumar Malimath from Karnataka HC to Uttarakhand HC.The President also accepted the resignation of Justice Dharmadhikari of Bombay high court. He had resigned on February 15. Prasad also reacted on Rahul’s Loya jibe and said the Loya judgment had been settled by SC and those raising questions did not respect the judgment of the Supreme Court.

Title: Jolly lands in hospital after suicide bid
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Kozhikode: Jolly Joseph , the accused in Koodathayi multiple murder case , attempted suicide inside Kozhikode district prison on Thursday morning. The woman is undergoing treatment at Kozhikode Medical College Hospital.

According to police, the prison authorities noticed the incident around 5am when Jolly attempted suicide by making a wound on her wrist.

Other prison inmates reported the incident to the jail authorities. Probe is on regarding the object she used to attempt suicide. The use of a sharp metallic object or broken glass piece is suspected.

According to medical college hospital authorities, Jolly was taken to KMCH around 5.30am with a bleeding hand. She had made a cut on her left wrist with some sharp object. The injury was not serious and a minor surgery was performed for treatment.

According to sources, the wound was caused using some sharp weapon. However, prison authorities claimed that they could not recover any blade, knife or other sharp instruments from the prison cell. They also raised suspicion that Jolly might have caused the wound using her teeth.

Following the incident, police conducted a search inside the prison cell. Security has also been stepped up at the hospital.

Deputy inspector general of prisons M K Vinod Kumar visited the jail and conducted a preliminary investigation into the incident.

Jolly had shown suicidal tendencies during her police custody period too. The police team had recorded Jolly’s arrest a day before the proposed date as they suspected that she would attempt suicide.

Jolly is accused of murdering her ex-husband, parents-in laws and three others including a two-year-old child.

Title: Lack of railings on bridges in city a threat
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Jaipur: The Bundi bus tragedy that claimed 24 lives on Wednesday should be a warning for civic authorities in the city where many bridges over nullahs do not have safety railings .

The nullah on Dravyavati River towards Durgapura to Maharani Farm and from Gujjar ki Thadi to Mansarovar does not have railings or walls. Residents have complained that during monsoon, these nullahs overflow, which make it dangerous for commuters.

Krishna Maharishi, a resident of the area, said these are dangerous overbridges that were constructed by the Jaipur Development Authority (JDA) some time ago.

“There are no railings over these bridges. The nullah starts overflowing during monsoon and it gets slippery. Last year, a car fell off the bridge during monsoon. Authorities should take cognisance of this and build a railing before another tragedy occurs,” said Krishna.

There are no lights on the bridge as well making it dangerous to cross it at night. A mistake or a little lack of focus can cost the life of a commuter.

An official at JDA said the bridge near Shyam Nagar is not a part of Dravyawati river project. “There is a small railing and a pipeline going over the bridge that is giving commuters a bit of protection. However, if there is still a need, we will install a protective railing,” said an official.

In 2017, two people lost their lives at Kartarpura nullah in monsoon. After the incident, Jaipur Municipal Corporation (JMC) installed railings on both the sides. However, it still seems to be inadequate given to the low height of the bridge which makes it prone to waterlogging during rains. Instead of waiting for monsoon or any tragedy to occur, authorities must take some action right now.

Title: Citizens slam CMC move torecover hiked property tax
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Chandrapur: Claiming that Chandrapur Municipal Corporation ( CMC ) commissioner Sanjay Kakade’s “refusal” to roll back property tax hike, as directed by the high court , amounts to contempt of court, traders , industrialists and vigilant citizens from the city have demanded action against the officer.

Addressing a press conference here on Thursday, senior businessman Vinod Dattatray urged citizens to oppose the harsh recovery of property tax by the CMC.

“In 2016-17, the CMC had hiked property tax ranging between 500% and 1000% of around 68,000 properties and had disposed of more than 34,000 objections through manipulative hearings,” said Dattatray.

After the hike was challenged in the Nagpur bench of the Bombay high court, the division bench had quashed the hiked property tax levied on the citizens who had objected to it.

“The high court had quashed the CMC order demanding increased tax for 2016-2017 viz-a-viz the citizens of Chandrapur who had objected to the demand by filing complaints as per Rule 15 of the Taxation Rules (Chapter VIII of Schedule D of the Act),” said Dattatray while highlighting the court order. The HC had directed the CMC to issue fresh tax demand in consonance with the decision taken on the complaints of the citizens, he said.

Dattatray alleged that the municipal commissioner has deceived the citizens by publicly claiming that the court order was meant only for 47 petitioners. He claimed that on one hand the commissioner has warned property holders that none, other than the 47 petitioners, will be spared of the hiked property tax, on the other the CMC has informed the high court that it was promptly complying with its directives.

Many traders, industrialists, businessmen and hoteliers were present during the conference.

Title: Polytechnic Crossing’s new name after MiG
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Lucknow: Polytechnic Crossing on Faizabad Road will soon be renamed MiG Crossing after the MiG-27, a variable-geometry ground-attack aircraft once used and now retired by the Indian Air Force (IAF).

Buoyed by the success of Defence Expo 2020, the district administration along with Hindustan Aeronautics (HAL) has planned a makeover of the area under the Smart City project by creating a green belt and installing cut-outs of the fighter jet.

“With a budget of Rs 5 crore, HAL under its corporate social responsibility programme will take up development work in city. The makeover of Polytechnic Crossing is one of them,” said district magistrate Abhishekh Prakash.

To promote skill development among the youth, HAL will also create a defence hub on its premises where officials associated with different companies that participated in the expo will be given hands-on training.

Title: UoH student selected for FRT award in Oz
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Hyderabad: A fourth-year systems biology student in the integrated master’s course at the University of Hyderabad (UoH), Ananya Dash, has been selected for the Future Research Talent (FRT) Award 2020 by the Australian National University (ANU) in Canberra. TNN

Title: 2 Maha students back from Wuhan, 119 fly in from Japan
Content: Mumbai: Two PhD students from Maharashtra, who chose to stay back in Wuhan when the first batch of Indians was evacuated in January after the novel coronavirus outbreak, landed in Delhi on Thursday.Girish Patil (29) and Chandradip Jadhav (29), who were studying at the College of Materials and Metallurgy, Wuhan University of Science and Technology, had opted to stay back in Wuhan—the epicentre of the outbreak—due to financial constraints. From Delhi airport, the students, along with other Indians from Wuhan, were sent to the quarantine centre at Chawla camp, where they will be lodged for the next 14 days.Patil and Jadhav, both residents of Dhule, were among the bunch of six Indian students who stayed back in the university’s dormitory, when the first plane was sent to China to get Indians back. One of the six students said that now the university has officially extended the holidays for a few months. They also gave them a no objection certificate (NOC) for evacuation, he added. Students are now able to take advantage of online classes organized by the university.Meanwhile, the special Air-India flight that brought back 119 Indian and five foreign nationals from the coronavirus-hit Diamond Princess cruise liner from Japan early on Thursday morning includes two Mira Road residents. Mira Road’s Dinesh Thakkar was at the forefront of the effort to get back his daughter Sonali who worked as a security personnel in Diamond Princess. “My daughter spoke to us briefly on landing and after reaching the army quarantine spot in Haryana,” said Dinesh. He said another Mira Road resident employed on the ship is also among those evacuated.

Title: Jaipur: Lottery for reserved wards to be conducted on March 11
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Lottery for the newly constituted municipal wards in six corporations of the state will be held on March 1

JAIPUR: Lottery for the newly constituted municipal wards in six corporations of the state will be held on March 11.

After redrawing the boundaries of these municipal corporation twice last year in three major cities including Jaipur, Jodhpur and Kota, the district administrations will draw lottery of reserved wards next month for the upcoming municipal elections.

On February 14 , the state election commission wrote to the local self government (LSG) to provide information about reservation of wards by February 29 so that compliance of the orders of the high court by conducting elections in these bodies by April 18 can be achieved.

An official said, “In an order dated February 27, the directorate of local bodies (DLB) has issued a direction to these district election officers to draw lots in the six corporations comprising 560 municipal wards.”

The lottery will decide the category of a particular ward from where a candidate can contest. Of the newly formed 100 wards of Jaipur Heritage Municipal Corporation, 44 will be reserved for general candidates with 21 reserved for general category women.

Fourteen wards have been reserved for Other Backward Classes (OBCs) with 7 for OBC women; 7 for SC candidates (four for women) and two for STs (one for women).

Of the 150 wards of Greater Jaipur Municipal Corporation , 91 have been reserved for general candidates, with 30 for general category women. Thirty-two wards have been reserved for OBCs, with 11 reserved for OBC women; 13 wards have been reserved for SC candidates, with seven for women; five for STs, with two for women.

According to the Rajasthan Municipal Act 2009 and based on the 2011 census, the state government annulled all previous notifications regarding municipal corporations after constituting the new corporations.

Like Jaipur, two major cities of Jodhpur and Kota have been divided into north and south municipal corporations and will get two mayors. While 102 wards have been reserved for general category in Jodhpur, 82 have been reserved for the same in Kota.

Title: Living in an Lucknow Development Authority flat? Shell out Rs 12,000 per year for upkeep
Content:
Representative image

LUCKNOW: More than 18,000 residents of apartments and housing colonies constructed and maintained by Lucknow Development Authority (LDA) will have to face an additional annual burden of Rs 12,460 each in the name of maintenance.The amount will be levied from next month as user charge for water supply and maintenance of the localities.The charge will be levied on residential and commercial properties in areas like Jankipuram, Gomtinagar Extension, Sarojininagar, Aashiana, Priyadarshni Colony and Mansarovar Colony by the end of March. The allottees will have to pay for water supply, garbage collection, maintenance of roads, cleaning and interlocking of drains, road sweeping, installation of streetlights and maintenance of parks.According to LDA officials, so far, LDA had offered these services for free though they cost Rs 6 crore annually. However, a proposal to change the freebie policy was mooted in the board meeting of the development authority in October. The decision was immediately approved by the committee in wake of a financial crunch caused by LDA properties that have remained unsold for years.However, residents of these housing colonies complain about the dilapidated condition of roads in their localities and irregular garbage collection.“We are happy to pay the amount if LDA improves the pathetic condition of roads. There is not a stretch in our locality which is not dotted with potholes,” said Laxmi Jha of LDA colony in Aashiana.Vinod Kumar of Mansarovar Colony said, “Nothing will change even after we pay this user charge. Garbage collection in our locality is so irregular that we have to hire a private worker for collecting daily waste from our households.”LDA chief engineer Indu Shekhar Singh said, “The decision has been taken to improve civic amenities provided to our allottees. The user fee collected from households will be used for hiring more workers for garbage collection apart from repairing roads, streetlights and buildings among others.”

Title: HC seeks state govt plan on church takeover
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Kochi: The high court on Thursday asked the state government to inform its plan to implement the Supreme Court’s verdict at Kothamangalam church by Monday.

A division bench of Justice AM Shaffique and Justice Mary Joseph is considering an appeal by Ernakulam district collector challenging a single bench directive to take over the church and hand it over to the Orthodox faction. The directive was issued by the single bench on a petition by Orthodox priest Thomas Paul Ramban through advocate Roshen D Alexander.

During Thursday’s hearing, two members of the Jacobite faction informed the court that as parishioners, they are also filing appeals and that the appeal by the government should be heard along with their appeals. The court said it can only permit a priest appointed as per the 1934 constitution of the church to conduct religious services and that it cannot act against the apex court’s judgment.

The Orthodox faction alleged in court that the state government has a partisan attitude in the issue and is helping violators of the law and the Supreme Court’s judgment.

At this juncture, the court asked the Orthodox faction whether they intend to challenge the new ordinance brought in by the government. A counsel representing the Orthodox faction submitted that the full legislation has not yet become available and that a decision on a challenge could be taken only after that. The court said it may have to be considered whether the ordinance goes against the Supreme Court’s judgment, which limits the power to conduct religious services to a vicar in accordance with the 1934 church constitution.

State attorney KV Sohan submitted that the government has been formulating a scheme to implement the SC judgment at Kothamangalam church as was done in the case of Piravom church but it did not get the time to present it before the single bench. Following the submission, the court asked the government to produce the scheme before it on Monday.

Title: Two-day conclave at GITAM on Feb 28, 29
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Hyderabad: The department of electrical, electronics and communication engineering (EECE) at school of technology of GITAM, Hyderabad, is going to organise a two-day conclave on its campus on February 28 and 29. Experts from artificial intelligence industry will attend the conclave. TNN

Title: Wetland in Lucknow backyard wallows, chokes on pollution
Content:
Migratory bird comes to breed in wetlands of southeast Asia during winter

LUCKNOW: While cities across the world are investing in development of city forests and installing giant air purifiers, Lucknow is lucky to have a lesser known wetland barely a few kilometres from Hazratganj. Located just behind the Atal Bihari Vajpayee International (Ekana) stadium in Gomtinagar Extension, the place is inhabited by over 100 species of indigenous and migratory birds, including some listed in Schedule 1 of the Wildlife Protection Act, according to naturalists and bird enthusiasts.Spread across 3-4 sq km area, the place is slowly losing out to infrastructure projects in the area. Fearing that the wetland might die, a group of bird watchers has urged CM Yogi Adityanath to save it. “The place will lose out to rising construction unless the government intervenes,” said wildlife enthusiast Vivek Awasthi, reminding that India has recently supported the Convention on Migratory Birds (CMS), the only UN treaty that address issue of migratory birds and their habitats.Naturalist Rahul Mishra—who has been visiting the place regularly for three years—added: “With deer, flocks of birds, bounty of fish and butterflies, place is a heaven on outskirts. Efforts must be made to save it before land sharks eat it up.”Another regular visitor, Ratindra Pandey, said: “Here is a chance for the government to give Lucknow an eco-tourism spot without much investment,” he said. Talking about the uniqueness of the place, birdwatcher Prakash Vir Singh said: “Some extremely rare and shy migratory birds make this their home every winter. This is in addition to regular presence of ducks, bee-eaters, kingfishers, sparrows, parakeets and jacanas. Animals like deer, golden jackal, monitor lizards, water snakes and butterflies can be spotted on wetland in the migratory season. I am preparing a compendium of birds sighted here.”Specialists lend support to the cause, stating that Ekana is an opportunity that the government must not miss in larger public interest.“It is not a matter of wildlife and bird enthusiasts alone. Wetlands are a crucial part of the ecosystem having multiple roles that directly affect all forms of life, especially humans. One of the most important roles of a wetland is to maintain groundwater level and facilitate its recharge, besides saving the river. In other words, wetland’s presence is associated with river Gomti’s quality, Lucknow’s lifeline,” said Sushmita Sengupta, project manager at Centre for Science and Environment.Kashif Imdad, a specialist in wetland conservation with WWF, said that in modern cities, wetlands serve as air filters and purifiers.“Increasing levels of air pollution level is affecting public life in a big way. Wetlands are a natural solution to the problem. They are known to absorb pollutants and environmental heat without any investment,” she said.

Title: Tyre burst caused mishap which killed 24: Dhariwal
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

The fitness certificate of the bus was valid till September 30

JAIPUR: Parliamentary affairs minister Shanti Dhariwal on Thursday said in assembly that tyre burst seems to be the cause of bus accident in which 24 people were killed in Bundi district on Wednesday. However, the discussion on the issue ended with walk out by Opposition members.

Dhariwal said, according to the report from the district relief management control room, the prima facie cause of the accident was a tyre burst. However, the matter is being investigated. A case against bus driver Shyam Singh who also died in the accident has been registered. The veracity of the documents recovered from the vehicle is being examined, he added.

The vehicle had insurance and a temporary permit for a two-way trip from Kota to Sawai Madhopur where the marriage party was headed. Its fitness certificate was valid till September 20.

Dhariwal said the state's health and transport ministers went to Kota on Wednesday to offer their condolences to the families of the victims.

The state government has announced a compensation of Rs 2 lakh to the next of kin of those killed and Rs 40,000 for the injured. The government will also bear the expenditure on the education up to the college level of the victims’ children.

Deputy leader of Opposition Rajendra Rathore demanded the government to run a campaign against vehicles running without valid permit and fitness certificate.

He demanded that the compensation should be raised from Rs 2 lakh to Rs 10 lakh.

Leader of opposition Gulabchand Kataria said the government should take care of the future of the children whose family members were killed.

BJP MLA Chandrakanta Meghwal, while participating in the discussion said the bridge on the national highway where the accident took place was very narrow and dangerous.

After making a statement on the accident, Dhariwal targeted the opposition BJP by asking under whose tenure the highway was built.

As BJP members protested, speaker C P Joshi asked the minister to end his statement. The BJP MLAs then walked out of the House.

Title: Tamil Nadu looks at its beaches again to promote adventure tourism
Content:
A beach in Dhanushkodi

CHENNAI: Painfully aware that it has never promoted beach tourism or adventure sports on a large scale despite having the longest coastline in South India, Tamil Nadu tourism will soon display a theme video on the state’s beautiful sand stretches at 17 domestic and international airports across the country.The road linking Rameswaram and Dhanushkodi, which was rebuilt about two years ago, will be branded a ‘Calm to Storm destination and spruced up to kickstart the project that will also involve setting up an amphitheatre near Triveni Sangam at Kanyakumari. Dhanushkodi, about 20km from Rameswaram, was wiped out by a super-cyclone in 1964 and has been witnessing a tourism explosion since the road was rebuilt.In Chennai, state tourism department director V Amudhavalli said, a host of activities is planned including introducing a range of boats at Muttukadu and Mudaliarkuppam on ECR. “We are launching motor ski in the backwaters of the two facilities that have boathouses,” said Amudhavalli, who is also Tamil Nadu Tourism Development Corporation managing director.The state, with a coastline stretching more than 1,000 km from Pulicat in the north to Kanyakumari in the south and dotted with several beaches containing picturesque and heritage structures, could emerge as a hotspot for adventure tourism if the proper infrastructure is provided, said Tamil Nadu Tour Travel and Hospitality Association president V K T Balan. However, any adventure activities, including sailing, windsurfing, water skiing, scubadiving and river rafting, that are planned must be manned by licensed technicians trained by the Goa-based National Institute of Watersports, he cautioned, adding that about 75% of the state’s coastline has been underutilised.In the past, the government had with fanfare proposed a Sentosa theme park in Chennai, on the lines of the iconic facility with the same name in Singapore, a marina for yachts on the famous Marina, the second longest beach in the world, and a submarine museum off the Unesco-approved heritage town of Mamallapuram . All have remained non-starters. Approved Tour Guides Association president P Asoka said adventure tourism on the sea can be a big draw. “It would be well received.”

Title: Tamil Nadu: Girls outnumber boys for Class XII exams
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: More girls than boys will appear for the state board Class XII exams this year, while boys outnumber girls for the class X exams.

This is year 8,16,359 candidates will appear for Class XII exams at 7,276 schools across Tamil Nadu — of them 4,41,612 are girls and 3,74,747 are boys.

Class XI exams also reflect similar trend — 4,40,252 candidates are girls and 3,85,867 boys. In all, 8,26,119 students will appear for the Class XI board exams from 7,400 schools. In Class X, the majority are boys. They outnumber girls by 4,689. Asked why girl students outnumber boys in higher secondary, officials from the directorate of government examinations said that had been the trend for the last few years. "More boys pursue technical education like diploma or ITI while girls pursue higher secondary," an official said.

Meanwhile, more than 50,000 students in Class XII also sit for Class XI arrears exams this year. "If these students don’t clear the arrears in March exams, they would not get Class XII mark sheets even if they clear the exam," officials said.

Some 300 prisoners are also set to appear for Class X, XI and XII board exams.

Following the question papers leak in half-yearly exams, the school education department has strengthened the security measures. There would 4000 flying squads deployed for surprise visit during exams. And the strong rooms that sore the question papers and answer sheets will have CCTV surveillance and armed guards.

The directorate of government examinations has set up control rooms for students and parents to clarify their doubts and express grievances. Candidates or parents can contact the control rooms at 9385494105, 9385494115, 9385494120.

Title: CBSE playing with the future of students: Kerala HC
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

KOCHI: The high court on Thursday criticized CBSE for the way in which it handles the functioning of schools lacking affiliation . CBSE is playing with the future of students, the court said.

Justice SV Bhatti criticized CBSE when its regional director Sachin Thakur appeared before the court on Thursday as directed by the bench. The court is considering a petition by Arooja’s Educational and Charitable Trust through advocate B Sajeev Kumar.

During hearing, the court asked why CBSE is not taking any action against schools that are operating without affiliation. No enquiry or responsibility is being shown by CBSE after allowing schools to open across the state, the court criticized. If CBSE had even a bit of responsibility, the situation where these many students could not appear for the exams could have been avoided, the judge said. The court also said the issue of schools functioning without affiliation is a matter that affects the future of lakhs of students and even a small mistake on the part of CBSE cannot be entertained.

The court also asked the CBSE whether it was with its knowledge that the Arooja’s school had been allowing its students to appear for exams through another school. The court then asked CBSE to file a detailed affidavit explaining the issues highlighted by the court.

At the hearing, the court asked the state government to favourably consider whether the students of Arooja’s school can be permitted to appear for the board exams conducted by it. Though a counsel representing the state government had said that the students may not be interested in appearing for the state board exams, the court said let the parents and students decide on it at this stage. The state government should leave this option open for the students, the court said.

Scheduling further hearing on March 4, the court asked the CBSE regional officer to appear in court with all the documents and has also directed the investigating officer to be also present in court.

Title: 3-day Ramayana conclave in Ayodhya
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

A three-day conclave on Ramayana will be held in Ayodhya in the first week of March. The event will be inaugurated by head of Shri Ram Mandir Trust, Mahant Nritya Gopal Das. Sources in the government said the conclave will see discussions around the life of Ram and his impact on society. Experts on Ramayana from India and abroad, and research scholars are expected to attend the event. There will also be an exhibition on the presence of Ram in art and around 200 artists are expected to display their works. These, said an official, will revolve around Ram as King, Ram in exile and other important events in his life. The event is being organised by Sanskar Bharti, Ayodhya Dhodh Sansthan and Awadh University. Ram temple trust secretary Champatrai, former Goa governor Mridula Sinha and writer Narendra Kohli are some of the people expected to attend the event. tnn

Title: Transport dept forms team to probe Bundi bus mishap
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Jaipur: The transport department has initiated an investigation into the Bundi bus accident that claimed 24 lives on Wednesday. The department is checking various documents of the bus that plunged into the river after developing a technical snag. A team of officials was sent to Kota to find more details into the condition of the vehicle.

In the initial enquiry, the officials found that the bus was a 17-seater but was carrying passengers almost double than its capacity with 29 passengers.

Transport commissioner Ravi Jain said, “A team has been constituted to look into the accident and FSL will also check if the bus axle broke prior to the accident or later. Since the bus was badly damaged at this point it is difficult to ascertain this fact at present but FSL is working on it. We will also look at the reason for the tyre burst.”

The bus had a fitness certificate valid till September 2020 though officials will also look into it. “Although the bus had a fitness certificate, I will check the centre from where the certificate was issued. Also the documents found on the bus will be looked into.”

On Wednesday 24 people of a wedding party were killed and five critically injured after a private bus fell into Mej river near Papdi village on Kota-Dausa highway under Lakheri police station in Bundi. While 13 people died on the spot, others succumbed to injuries on the way to hospital in Lakheri town. The deceased included 11 women and three children. The wedding party was on its way to Sawai Madhopur city to offer ‘bhaat’ (gifts). Police received information at around 9.45am and a 13-member squad from the Lakheri police station rushed to the spot. Villagers nearby had started rescue operations after they heard the sound of the bus falling into the river.

Title: Two men open fire at MIM leader’s home in Malegaon
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Nashik: Two unidentified people opened fire at the residence of senior AIMIM functionary Rizwan Khan in Malegaon city at around 2am on Thursday. Khan told TOI this was the second time that such firing had taken place at his residence.

Khan, a two-time former corporator of Malegaon Municipal Corporation, has lodged a complaint at the local police station. He told TOI two men had knocked on his door in the wee hours of Thursday, just an hour after he returned home.

The AIMIM leader, who is a college professor and a businessman, said the two men rang the door bell thrice. “I had returned home at around 1am. Both, me and my wife, were awake when the door bell rang. We did not open the door but checked through the window to see who had arrived so late in the night,” he told TOI.

The couple saw two men, who had covered their faces with cloth and carrying guns, at their door. A bike was parked near the entrance.

Khan claimed that the two suspects seemed to be upset when no one answered the door. “They got infuriated and started firing at the house. The glass panes of some of the windows broke and some bullets even pierced the furniture,” Khan said.

He added the suspects fled on the bike after the firing. Some of Khan’s neighbours alerted the local police about the incident and a police team soon reached Khan’s residence.

Nashik rural superintendent of police Arti Singh said suspects had fired four rounds at Khan’s residence but no one was injured in the incident. “We have launched a manhunt to nab the suspects,” she said.

She said the police have collected the CCTV footage from Khan’s residence and some of his neighbourhood homes and are scanning them for clues. Khan’s bunglow is located in the heart of Malegaon city.

Khan said that a couple of months after AIMIM won the Malegaon central seat for the first time in the assembly elections last year, unknown people had similarly opened fire at his house. “I had informed the police at that time about it. I am apprehensive that I am being targeted due to political reasons,” he claimed.

Title: CBSE playing with the future of students: Kerala HC
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

KOCHI: The high court on Thursday criticized CBSE for the way in which it handles the functioning of schools lacking affiliation . CBSE is playing with the future of students, the court said.

Justice SV Bhatti criticized CBSE when its regional director Sachin Thakur appeared before the court on Thursday as directed by the bench. The court is considering a petition by Arooja’s Educational and Charitable Trust through advocate B Sajeev Kumar.

During hearing, the court asked why CBSE is not taking any action against schools that are operating without affiliation. No enquiry or responsibility is being shown by CBSE after allowing schools to open across the state, the court criticized. If CBSE had even a bit of responsibility, the situation where these many students could not appear for the exams could have been avoided, the judge said. The court also said the issue of schools functioning without affiliation is a matter that affects the future of lakhs of students and even a small mistake on the part of CBSE cannot be entertained.

The court also asked the CBSE whether it was with its knowledge that the Arooja’s school had been allowing its students to appear for exams through another school. The court then asked CBSE to file a detailed affidavit explaining the issues highlighted by the court.

At the hearing, the court asked the state government to favourably consider whether the students of Arooja’s school can be permitted to appear for the board exams conducted by it. Though a counsel representing the state government had said that the students may not be interested in appearing for the state board exams, the court said let the parents and students decide on it at this stage. The state government should leave this option open for the students, the court said.

Scheduling further hearing on March 4, the court asked the CBSE regional officer to appear in court with all the documents and has also directed the investigating officer to be also present in court.

Title: Congress team meets President Kovind, urges him to sack Amit Shah
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

A delegation led by Congress Party President Sonia Gandhi meets President Ram Nath Kovind at Rashtrapati Bhawa... Read More

NEW DELHI: A day after holding the home minister responsible for the outbreak of riots in Delhi, a Congress delegation Thursday met President Ram Nath Kovind and urged him to sack Amit Shah from the Union Cabinet. The party asked the President to remind the Modi government of its “raj dharma”.

Congress met Kovind as part of its plan following the meeting of the CWC on Wednesday where it reviewed the communal violence in the capital and targeted the Centre and ruling BJP for the tragedy. The party demanded Shah’s resignation for not acting on time to avert the violence and former PM Manmohan Singh called the riots a “national shame”.

The delegation led by Congress chief Sonia Gandhi submitted a memorandum to the President in which it accused the Centre and also the Delhi government of being “mute spectators” instead of initiating steps to control the situation.

“You should immediately call for the removal of the home minister given the gross ineptitude, abdication of duty and his inability to contain the situation … We hope you will take decisive action on this matter,” states the memorandum, parts of which were read out by Sonia Gandhi to reporters at Rashtrapati Bhavan.

“Rashtrapatiji, you are given the highest possible responsibility under the Constitution of India: to act as the conscience keeper of this government and to remind it of its constitutional duty and the pillars of raj dharma by which any just government must abide,” Sonia said, flanked by former Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, Ahmed Patel , A K Antony, Ghulam Nabi Azad, Mallikarjun Kharge , Priyanka Gandhi Vadra, Kumari Selja, Jitin Prasada among others.

She said the fact that the Delhi High Court had to step in and remind the Delhi Police of its duty to act against the rioters and the instigators, marked a “shameful indictment” of the central government, home ministry and the home minister.

“It is how the leaders and institutions of a country react in times of crisis that defines how we are remembered by history and the rest of the world. We cannot be found wanting in this hour,” the memorandum said.

Targeting Shah for the second day in succession, Sonia Gandhi asked, “What was he preoccupied with since last Sunday that he was unable, apparently, to give his attention to these grave events?”

Former PM Manmohan Singh told reporters, “We requested the President to use his power to call upon the central government to protect and preserve its ‘raj dharma’ so that the citizens of this country and this city are assured of peace, tranquility and justice.”

The opposition party also called it a failure of intelligence agencies and asked if they had provided any information which could have helped prevent the violence.

Sonia said the seeds of division were sown by the inflammatory remarks made by the BJP leaders during the recent Delhi elections.

Title: Belagavi DHO says no H1N1 cases reported in district
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Belagavi: Rumours of a Belagavi city resident having contracted the H1N1 virus and being afflicted with swine flu have proved to be just that, rumours. Officials in the Belagavi district health department confirmed that no samples had been dispatched to virology institutes either in Manipal, Udupi or in Pune. But, as a precautionary measure, the department has issued a notice to its personnel to remain vigilant against a possible breakout.

Following reports of a case of swine flu being confirmed in Belagavi, anxiety gripped a section of residents. However, as of Thursday evening, the Belagavi district health office has not received any confirmation. All private health institutions including the Karnataka Lingayat Education Society (KLE) hospital have been ordered to report positive cases of H1N1 to the competent government authorities.

A state-wide alert has been issued following detection of H1N1 cases being reported in parts of Karnataka. Most of these cases have been reported from the state capital, Bengaluru, and the officials in the district administration across Karnataka have been asked to leave no stone unturned in monitoring these cases.

Belagavi district health officer Shashikant Muniyal confirmed to TOI that no case of swine flu had been reported in the district this year. “These are just rumours. No case of H1N1 has been reported in the district,” said Muniyal.

He said that all primary health centres, taluk hospitals had been directed to monitor the health of those reporting with respiratory illnesses more closely. The key symptoms for swine flu have been classified into three categories: A, B and C. While minor breathing problems and regular cough are classified under ‘A’ and ‘B’ categories, and patients reporting to health centres with these symptoms will be sent home with medicines, personnel have been instructed to admit those patients complaining of more serious troubles.

Muniyal added that samples would be dispatched to virology centres if cases that arounsed genuine suspicion were reported in the district.

Title: Report flags pot cultivation, its impact on kids
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

NEW DELHI: The International Narcotics Control Board (INCB) in its 2019 annual report released on Thursday has said that India is a significant source of trafficked opioid Tramadol that are seized worldwide. It has also raised concern about large-scale illicit cultivation of cannabis in the country and its long-term impact on children.

Releasing the report, Jagjit Pavadia, member of the INCB and head of its finance committee, expressed concern about the extent of substance abuse by the young population. The report has highlighted the connection between the use of alcohol & tobacco and the use of psychoactive substances like cannabis, opiates and cocaine by children and adolescents. Quoting a survey of drug abusers, the report says the median age of onset of use for these substances is 16–19 years for alcohol and tobacco, 18–19 years for cannabis and 21–24 years for cocaine.

“Longitudinal studies that have followed children into adulthood indicate that the earlier the age of onset for alcohol, tobacco and cannabis use, the greater the likelihood of use of drugs such as opiates and cocaine,” it said. The research has explored this relationship and has shown that genetic, biological and societal factors are associated with this progression, it added.

“An analysis of data from 2010 to 2017 shows that India is among those countries worldwide with the greatest extent of illicit cannabis cultivation and production,” the report said. Though enforcement agencies in India eradicated 1,980 hectares of illicit cannabis in 2018, less than the 3,446 hectares destroyed in 2017, the actual illicit cultivation could be many times more.

Director general (DG) of the Narcotics Control Bureau Rakesh Asthana and DG of directorate of revenue intelligence Balesh Kumar were also present on the occasion and both expressed the desire for a higher coordination among Indian agencies to control trafficking of drugs and their abuse.

Title: Karnataka high court: Hubballi lawyer should appear for Kashmiri students
Content:
Karnataka high court (File photo)

BENGALURU: To uphold best traditions of the legal profession, a member of the Hubballi Bar Association (HBA) should appear on behalf of the three Kashmiri students charged with sedition for allegedly raising pro-Pakistan slogans in their engineering college hostel in Hubballi on February 14, the Karnataka high court observed on Thursday.The observation comes a day after the high court lampooned the local bar for allegedly heckling a group of Bengaluru lawyers, who appeared on behalf of the students, calling it "sheer militancy ".A division bench headed by Chief Justice Abhay Shreeniwas Oka made this observation after officer-bearers of HBA appeared before the court with a fresh resolution, modifying an earlier one passed on February 15 barring its members from appearing on behalf of the accused students.

Title: India’s Trump hug pushes Dems away
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

US President Trump’s massive rally in Ahmedabad could sway some Indian-American voters (AFP photo)

NEW DELHI: That India has a Democratic Party problem in the US became clear on Thursday when presidential hopeful Bernie Sanders weighed in on the Delhi riots, targeting the Modi government and US President Donald Trump in an equal opportunity tweet.

While the obvious jibe was against Trump, by emphasising that he thought the riots were only aimed against Muslims, Sanders was indirectly criticising the Modi government as well. He is not alone.

Democrat Congressman Joaquin Castro (Texas) added his own criticism. “These deaths in New Delhi are tragic, and the actions of those responsible must be condemned. Support for the US-India relationship has always been based on our shared values. I urge the Indian government to live up to those values and take decisive action to end further violence,” he tweeted.

Jamie Raskin, a Democrat Congressman from Maryland, tweeted, “Horrified by the deadly violence unfolding in India, all fuelled by religious hatred and fanaticism. Liberal democracies must protect religious freedom and pluralism, and avoid the path of discrimination and bigotry.” He was joined by Don Beyer, Democrat from Virginia, who said, “I condemn attacks against Muslims in India, and reject violence, bigotry and religious intolerance. The US state department should too.”

Even the chairman of the US House Foreign Affairs Committee , Eliot Engel, joined in, “Deeply troubled by the deaths from the communal violence in India over the past couple of days. The right to protest is a key aspect in democracy, but they must remain peaceful and police must ensure the safety of all.”

In the past six months, PM Narendra Modi has shared a political stage with Trump twice, once in the US and this week in Ahmedabad. The question has been asked whether India is making a mistake putting its eggs in the Republican basket, to the detriment of its traditional ties with the Democratic Party.

To say this will not have political implications in a fiercely polarised election year battle in the US will be myopic in the extreme, particularly since Indian-Americans form an influential voting bloc, as do Pakistani-Americans. Therefore, no Democrat politician looking for re-election can afford to ignore events in India, which might sway voters. Indian-Americans overwhelmingly vote Democrat, though in recent years, there has been some move towards the Republicans. US political watchers say Trump’s massive rally in Ahmedabad could sway some Indian-American voters, which would be a matter of concern to Democrats.

That said, there is increasingly a section within the so-called “progressive” Democrats who say they find nothing to commend and, therefore, are alienated by Modi’s India. Certainly, after the events of the past six months — from the negation of Article 370 to the citizenship laws — the liberal Democrat opinion has veered away from India, increasingly labelling it with words like “Hindu nationalist”, “fascist” et al. Increasingly too, there is a growing sympathy for global voices against “Islamophobia” and Modi’s India seems to be the perfect example of that.

In addition, the Indian system has made little effort to engage Democrats or the liberal opinion makers, like Ro Khanna, who is Sanders’s foreign policy head. On Capitol Hill too, there is a striking dearth of Indian voices attempting to engage US lawmakers on issues of contention. Meanwhile, a resolution in the House “urging the Republic of India to end the restrictions on communications and mass detentions in Jammu and Kashmir as swiftly as possible and preserve religious freedom for all residents” by India-sceptic Pramila Jayapal has got around 63 co-sponsors.

In a belated attempt to mend fences, last week saw the visit of a bipartisan congressional delegation to India comprising senior Democrat Ami Bera (California) and Republican George Holding (North Carolina). They emphasised the bipartisan nature of US Congressional support for India, but this consensus is clearly failing. Sources in the Indian government said a fresh outreach to the Democrat leadership was being planned, which would be helmed by the newly-appointed ambassador to the US, Taranjit Singh Sandhu.
