Title: Chennai: Man rescues sister from flesh trade, one held
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: A minor girl who was lured into prostitution and was being taken to a prospective client was rescued by her brother on Thursday, police said.

K Prakash, 30, told the girl that he would give her a huge sum of money if she accompanied him to meet a friend. She boarded a car with Prakash from Villivakkam.

When the vehicle neared the Arumbakkam metro station, the girl's brother, an autorickshaw driver, saw her. He confronted his sister who told him that Prakash was her friend. But the autorickshaw driver forcibly opened the car's door and picked a quarrel with Prakash. By then, another man, identified as Faizal, came there.

On information, a patrol team from the Choolaimedu police rushed to the spot. Seeing police, Faizal fled. Prakash, the girl and her brother were taken to a police station for interrogation. Prakash, who has burglary cases pending against him at the Avadi Tank Factory police station, told police he was on his way to Faizal's house in Chitlapakkam. He told police that he knew the girl for a year and had been going out with her.

Police arrested Prakash and seized his car and a machete.

Police have launched a hunt for Faizal and are probing to find out if Faizal was a customer or an accomplice of Prakash.

Title: Tamil Nadu replaces Madras on Saidapet bridge
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

The old emblem (left). The new one reading ‘Tamil Nadu Government’

CHENNAI: It was the last emblem of the state government featuring the word Madras, until the highways department began a renovation project about four months ago. Now, the seal over the pylon on Maraimalai Adigal bridge in Saidapet , built across the Adyar river, reads ' Tamil Nadu Government'.

The 'Government of Madras' seal painted on top of the pylon has remained untouched for more than 50 years as it did not attract the attention of the highways department that maintains the bridge.

Heritage enthusiasts say such words on a state government emblem cannot be found anywhere in the city. Writer R Venkatesh said Madras began to be replaced on emblems after the state was renamed Tamil Nadu in 1968.

The Maraimalai Adigal bridge has a historical value, with the original Marmalong bridge built in 1726 by Armenian merchant Coja Petrus Uscan to record the Madras Tercentenary Commemoration Volume. While the bridge is believed to have been named after the village of Marmalong or Marmalan identified with Mambalam, it still has a commemorative plaque in multiple languages including Arabic and Armenian regarding the construction of the original structure. Later, the bridge was rebuilt in 1966 when all government structures had Government of Madras tag. The bridge was also renamed after Tamil scholar Maraimalai Adigal.

Title: Opposition netas’ hate speeches led to Delhi riots, says BJP
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

BJP National President JP Nadda a during a welcome rally, in Solan in Himachal Pradesh (PTI photo)

NEW DELHI: BJP on Thursday attributed the communal violence in North-East Delhi to “hate and inciting” speeches by opposition leaders over the past couple of months with Union minister Prakash Javadekar referring to Congress chief Sonia Gandhi’s call for “aar par ki ladai” (fight to the finish) during a rally against the citizenship law in December.

Addressing a press conference, Javadekar also cited some comments of Congress members Rahul Gandhi and Priyanka Gandhi Vadra even as he pointed to the alleged recovery of stones, petrol bombs and acid from the rooftop of AAP councillor Tahir Hussain. He accused Congress and AAP of “politicising” the riots.

“Who started this? This did not happen in two days. People were being instigated for the past two months. After the Citizenship (Amendment) Act was passed on December 11, Congress held a rally at Ramlila Maidan on December 14 where Sonia Gandhi said now we have to decide: Is paar ya us paar'. Is this not instigation?” Javadekar asked, adding, “Our leaders like PM Narendra Modi , Amit Shah and Rajnath Singh talk about welfare of all.”

The minister alleged that there is "selective silence" among Congress and AAP leaders. “Mani Shankar Aiyar went to Pakistan and said we find hope in Shaheen Bagh. Salman Khurshid and Shashi Tharoor have supported protests like this. They are so vocal about Shaheen Bagh but they are selectively silent on reports by channels that an AAP corporator's house has become a factory of riots. All kinds of ammunition, petrol bombs, stones of various sizes have been found from his house. Why is Congress silent on this?" Javadekar said.

He said opposition leaders instigated people which resulted in violence. “Priyanka Gandhi said hundreds of people will be put behind bars. Is this not misinterpretation? Rahul Gandhi said: 'Don't worry. We are with you' ... they stoked fears," he said.

Asked about alleged provocative statements made by BJP members like Kapil Mishra, he said the matter is in court and added that AAP MLA Amanatullah Khan and AIMIM leader Waris Pathan made speeches that incited people.

"Amanatullah, who is now in AAP, said 'you won't be allowed to wear skull caps'. Can you tell me where this is written in CAA? All these are inflammatory statements, but Congress and AAP have not uttered a single word,” he said.

Javadekar said the situation in North-East Delhi is under control, probe has been fast-tracked and it will bring out the real culprits behind this violence. “However, Chief Minister (Kejriwal) is speaking in Assembly about the religion of those who were killed,” he said adding that identifying riot victims is also violation of norms.

Javadekar said the elected representatives from the violence-hit areas have been absent from the scene. “Why are the other political parties silent on attacks on policemen and journalists and death of IB officer Ankit Sharma ?”

Dismissing Congress’ demand for Amit Shah’s resignation, he credited the home minister with effective handling of the situation and the role of the Delhi Police for “return of peace” in the areas in the last two days.

Title: BMC spots tender clause mischief, saves Rs 20 crore
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Borivli railway station where the skywalk project is to be undertaken

MUMBAI: The cost of building a skywalk in Borivli dropped by Rs 20 crore after the BMC removed a tender clause that had allegedly been incorporated to favour some contractors.

A contractor had quoted Rs 85 crore to build the skywalk from Borivli railway station to the Western Express Highway near the Sanjay Gandhi National Park gate , via MG Road .

Last September, the BMC invited tenders for the project and the standard bid document stipulated that the bidders should be experienced in undertaking similar work elsewhere with the project cost having been at least 40% of the proposed Borivli project. Subsequently, in a hush-hush manner, the municipal administration increased to 60% from 40% the minimum work cost requirement. The result was that only four contractors qualified for the work.

The BMC short-listed M E Infraprojects, who quoted Rs 85 crore for the work. There were allegations of cartelisation where the contractors formed a group but bid separately to increase the cost and keep other players out.

Samajwadi Party corporator Rais Shaikh demanded the municipal commissioner should scrap the practice of putting specific conditions in tenders which led to cartelisation and favouritism. He alleged that it was causing the BMC losses. After Shaikh raised the issue with the municipal commissioner, the BMC scrapped the first process and invited fresh tenders without making any changes in the standard bid document.

The result was that another contractor who had earlier quoted Rs 93 crore for the work, reduced the quote to Rs 65 crore. He was the lowest bidder and the BMC finalised him for the work.

The proposal is now to be placed before the standing committee for approval. This time five bidders participated in the process and the lowest bidder among them was API Civilcon, who had quoted Rs 65 crore for the work.

When the same contractor had quoted Rs 93 crore for the same work earlier, he had been the second-lowest bidder after ME Infraprojects.

Five years ago, after the road and desilting scams surfaced, the BMC introduced a standard bid document asking all its department to follow it while inviting tenders, without adding any specific condition. Recently the BMC again started to alter the condition in the standard bid document, which the corporators allege is an attempt to favour some contractors.

"We insist on following the standard bid document while inviting tenders. It ensures that the officials do not use their discretionary power to add specific conditions to favour select contractors. It will keep cartelisation away and save taxpayer money," Shaikh said.

Title: Dharwad: Rising maternal and infant mortality rates distressing, says academic
Content:
This story is from February 28, 2020

Representative Image

DHARWAD: Calling for a revamp of the existing healthcare system in the country, retired professor at the Tata Institute of Social Sciences N Jayaram on Thursday said that the present infant and maternal mortality rates in India were deeply distressing.

The keynote speaker at the national symposium on ‘Health Policies and Programmes for Development: Achievements and Priorities’ organised by the department of sociology, Karnatak University, Jayaram said, “Malnutrition is the other area that is a cause for concern in India. Now increasing cases of mental depression also has a socio-cultural dimension to it as well. An increasing number of youngsters falling prey to diabetes is also disturbing.”

Jayaram sought to highlight the need for the people of a country to remain healthy if the nation was to develop at a steady pace. “Despite improvement in healthcare facilities, number of diseases in only rising,” he added.

Linguist and scholar GN Devy said that India, the economic policy of which hinged on both socialist and capitalist principles, ought to adopt a similar approach in the healthcare sector. “In the healthcare sector, partnerships between government bodies and corporate entities is absent,” he said.

TR Chandrashekhar, Jagan Karade, SC Natikar, SC Shettar, Dhruva Jyothi, Hanumagouda and Shoukat Azeem were among those who presented papers during the symposium.

A resolution seeking a healthcare policy friendly to the people, along with rolling out of specific programmes to treat diseases afflicting those in the vulnerable section such as Adivasis, women and construction works was passed at the end of the event.
